fields.headline: O'Neill takes the Celtic challenge
fields.standfirst:
Barnes's successor faces daunting task of catching Rangers
Graphic: O'Neill's career so far
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill was installed yesterday as manager of Celtic, ending tortured soul-searching both by the club and their new recruit. The Ulsterman arrived in Glasgow last night preparing to take by the hands one of the great managerial frying-pans of British football.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill was installed yesterday as manager of Celtic, ending tortured soul-searching both by the club and their new recruit. The Ulsterman arrived in Glasgow last night preparing to take by the hands one of the great managerial frying-pans of British football.

Days of characteristic analysis and prolonged weighing of options ended when O'Neill decided to contract the fever called Celtic. "It has been too great a lure to resist" said O'Neill. "It is a fantastic opportunity for me at a massive football club."

O'Neill was introduced to a teeming press conference at Parkhead while, in true Celtic fashion, 3,000 fans descended on the stadium for a glimpse of their latest saviour.

The new manager has signed a three-year contract reputedly worth £2.7m. After painfully protracted negotiations, Celtic confirmed they will meet Leicester's compensation demands, stipulated as being £1.25m in a clause recently inserted in O'Neill's Filbert Street contract.

"I've had four very happy, very fulfilling seasons at Leicester," said O'Neill. "But this was a call that came very close to my heart. With the size of this club, this size of this support, I just wanted this job."

The announcement also ended what has been the most trying 12 weeks of his life for Allan MacDonald, Celtic's chief executive. MacDonald once worked at British Aerospace, on occasions briefing bereaved families after aircraft disasters, but the quest, he confessed, to find John Barnes's successor and meet the demands of an impatient support had "taken a toll".

O'Neill appears to have every advantage of intelligence and ability on his side, but the task he faces at Celtic cannot be exaggerated. This big, proud club, with 50,000 season-ticket holders, has endured years of blighted potential and broken promises.

O'Neill is the club's sixth manager in six years. His first task will be to restore championship-winning mettle to Celtic next season. Rangers have just won the title by an embarrassing 21 points. Realistically, that honour had been beyond Celtic's grasp with six weeks of the season left. Worse still was that the death-knell sounded with a 4-0 drubbing by Rangers at Ibrox on March 26.

"This club has been huge since the days of Jock Stein," said O'Neill, who, as a boy growing up in Northern Ireland, was said to be a supporter. "I've been at games at this ground recently. Celtic have a fantastic stadium and a fantastic support. My job now is to give them a team to go with it."

One issue still to be resolved is any ongoing role at Celtic, if one still exists, for Kenny Dalglish. The director of football, after a season that upped his famed stress level, has been on a golfing week in Spain but is due back today. It has been heavily hinted within and beyond Celtic that Dalglish's tenure would be abruptly ended.

"It isn't right for me to say anything about that," said O'Neill . "I haven't even had a chance to have a chat with Kenny yet. But obviously, as manager, I'd want full control of the team. That means I can take the acclaim if things go well and the blame if things go badly."

At Leicester, the chairman John Elsom said: "I told Martin I thought he was making a wrong move, and that his career would be better served at Leicester. I am very disappointed.

"I spent one week trying to dissuade him from going and there were times when I thought he might change his mind. In the end, the pursuit of a personal dream related to his Roman Catholic heritage seems to have won the day."

Elsom would not be drawn on speculation linking Joe Kinnear and Peter Taylor with Leicester. Taylor, despite leading Gillingham into the First Division, is still working at Priestfield without a contract.

webTitle: Coffee countries find grounds for protest

fields.headline: Coffee countries find grounds for protest
fields.standfirst:
Latest attempt to boost commodity prices could cost caffeine addicts dear

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: For the coffee drinker, whether the connoisseur with authentic bean grinder or the Nescafé addict at the kitchen table, a golden era may be coming to an end. Fifteen years in which this black caffeinated liquid opiate of the masses has been cheap and plentiful could be replaced by a new age of costly coffee, with prices at levels unseen since the 1970s.
fields.body:
For the coffee drinker, whether the connoisseur with authentic bean grinder or the Nescafé addict at the kitchen table, a golden era may be coming to an end. Fifteen years in which this black caffeinated liquid opiate of the masses has been cheap and plentiful could be replaced by a new age of costly coffee, with prices at levels unseen since the 1970s.

Countries accounting for three-quarters of world production have signed a price support agreement and others have agreed not to take advantage of the resultant export cuts. Coming after the Lazarus-style return of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec), whose successful action last year effectively doubled oil prices, the coffee producers' deal may mean more than an extra few pence on a jar of Gold Blend.

It might herald a resurgence of commodity producer power that will ultimately upset all those tidy calculations in western finance ministries about "sustainable inflation-free growth".

Later this month , members of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries (ACPC) will submit plans to their secretariat in London for restricting output, and the cuts will come into force in October.

Despite murmurings in the market that the ACPC package is coming apart already, the pivotal producer - Brazil - is solid and its government is courting unpopularity among the domestic industry with a tough paperwork regime to police the cuts.

Brazil is to coffee what Saudi Arabia is to oil. Of the 105m 60-kilo bags produced globally each year, Brazil accounts for between 30m and 40m, depending on the harvest. The difference between a good and bad harvest in Brazil - about 12m bags - is equivalent to the entire annual production of the world's next largest producer, Colombia.

The ACPC last month agreed to withhold from the market up to 20% of production in order to support the price. The organisation's members are using a basket of prices to calculate a reference point of 95 cents per pound as the "floor" and 105 cents as the ceiling. Yesterday the price was hovering at about 95 cents.

ACPC members such as Brazil, Indonesia and Colombia have been joined by sympathetic non-members, the coffee equivalent of the "Nopec" oil producers. These include Mexico and Guatemala, and they, while not signing up for the export cuts, have agreed both to an orderly flow of exports and, critically, not to take advantage of the ACPC cuts by producing more coffee.

The smallest coffee producers, mostly sub-Saharan countries, are at the sharp end of fluctuations in price. Although their contribution to world exports is tiny - Uganda, Africa's biggest coffee exporter, produces just under 4% of global output - many are almost one-crop economies. Coffee accounts for more than two-thirds of Uganda's export earnings and over half of Rwanda's.

A fall in prices can have a devastating effect on these economies. When world prices plummeted in 1998, Uganda's foreign exchange earnings plummeted. This year, a bad harvest forced the country to revise down its growth forecast by 1.5 percentage points. Razia Khan, an expert on African economies at Standard Chartered Bank in London, says the Ugandan economy is extremely sensitive to conditions in the coffee market. "An agreement would make a big difference to the economy," she adds.

Only solution

The vulnerability of developing countries to swings in commodity prices has been a concern since John Maynard Keynes first suggested a stabilisation system at the Bretton Woods conference in 1944. It was foiled by commodity importers - mainly rich western economies. "Even though people have totally lost faith in the ability of commodity agreements to work, I can't see any other way that you can help the development of the world's poorest countries," said Andrew Simms, head of the global economy programme at the New Economics Foundation.

Caroline Eagles, coffee analyst with the internet service commodityexpert.com, said the deal - the third since the ACPC was founded - was understandable in the light of low coffee prices in the late 1990s. "The pact is not price fixing ... it's price support."

Should it prove successful, she said, the retail price of coffee is "bound to rise", but competition in the high street might limit any increases.

Coffee prices have crumbled since the early 1980s, from a peak of nearly 240 cents per pound to well below 100 cents. By 1992, the price touched a low of 50 cent, and consumers enjoyed the cheapest coffee in real terms for a generation.

In the winter of 1986/87, a quarter-pound jar of Nescafé Gold Blend cost £1.89. By 1994 it had dropped to £1.56. Today it costs about £2.15, approximating its mid-1980s level once inflation is discounted.

But, should the price of a jar of "instant" suddenly soar beyond reach, there are those who would point the finger of blame not at Brazil or Colombia but at the most coffee-addicted nation on Earth: the United States.

The ACPC grew out of the collapse at the end of the 1980s of the International Coffee Agreement, a price stability pact covering producer and consumer nations. Attempts to revive the pact in the early 1990s were frustrated by the US, which refused to sign, leaving the producers little choice but to form their own grouping.

webTitle: You'll never eat lunch in this town again

fields.headline: You'll never eat lunch in this town again
fields.standfirst: When your boss singles you out for unwanted attention, losing your office allies can be the hardest thing to cope with, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: When your boss singles you out for unwanted attention, losing your office allies can be the hardest thing to cope with, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.body:
At first I don't know quite what to make of Laura. She resigned from her secretarial job after a campaign by her boss of the sort of unimaginative smut that would make most people flee.

"Are you a natural blonde? Shall I take a look?" (fingering her skirt). "If you're really hot, why don't you take that blouse off? I won't tell anyone."

If thousands of men recognise themselves in these remarks, I'm not surprised. You don't need much experience of harassment cases to know that, bar the odd creative type, the lines are pretty standard. Sometimes I think there must be some special sexism conferences these blokes attend at the Moat Grange Manor House Inn Hotel off a motorway somewhere.

Day 1
9:45: Meet and greet, coffee served.
10:00: Lecture "Tits and bums": explores the secrets of making a young woman who works for you feel really uncomfortable about her appearance. 15 minutes are allowed at the end for questions.
11:00: Role play session on "bait and switch" - learn how to alternate saucy remarks and innuendoes with intervals of hostility / work criticism / silence to maximise employee discomfiture.
12:30: "Pub-style" lunch served in Queen Elizabeth Room.
1:30: Table dancing.

Laura, who is nineteen and shivery, didn't have any training. She tried a strategy a lot of people in power-deficit positions try. I call it humorous appeasement. The blokes usually call it "banter" or "she liked it really". So when Bossman Fingers delivered his line about natural blondes, Laura giggled and said: "Get off. I don't ask if you're bald all over"

Fingers chuckled off back to the water cooler. Laura sat at her WP wondering where this was leading. A few more of these interchanges and she wasn't sleeping much at night. Once Fingers started suggesting extracurricular weekend trips which Laura could attend as his "assistant", Laura's GP put her on antidepressants.

What I found hard to understand and what I ask Laura about in conference is what she said in her application to the tribunal about the "last straw" which caused her to hand in her notice.

She is in tears for the first time when she talks about it: "The other girls wouldn't have lunch with me."

"Why?"

"Because they thought I was sleeping with him, that I would repeat stuff to him that they said."

"But why was that worse than what went before?"

Laura covers her face with fingers which the tears slide through. "Because then, you know, it was just me on a bench, eating my sandwiches alone. I was so alone."

I suddenly feel I've been slow and insensitive. Even more so after my conference with Laura, when I go with some other barristers to lunch in one of the Inns of Court halls. Aged suits, new bug suits, suits of every shade between grey and black and every girth sit down in front of roast dinners and steamed puddings, a little fug of contentment rising.

On the table in front of me is a sheet of paper announcing the results of the Inn's recent survey of some modest alterations made to the lunch arrangements. Amongst the encomia of the food and the dinner ladies and the plaintive grumbles about "breaks with tradition" there is a comment about the disadvantages of the new table arrangement which stabs me to the heart: "Unable to sit with friends."

She resigned from her secretarial job after a campaign by her boss of the sort of unimaginative smut that would make most people flee. "Are you a natural blonde? Shall I take a look?" (fingering her skirt). "If you're really hot, why don't you take that blouse off? I won't tell anyone." If thousands of men recognise themselves in these remarks, I'm not surprised. You don't need much experience of harassment cases to know that, bar the odd creative type, the lines are pretty standard. Sometimes I think there must be some special sexism conferences these blokes attend at the Moat Grange Manor House Inn Hotel off a motorway somewhere. fields.headline: Sutherland in teasing hit
fields.standfirst: Enigmatic Variations Savoy Theatre, London **
fields.trailText: Enigmatic Variations Savoy Theatre, London **
fields.body:
Shaggy, craggy Donald Sutherland makes a welcome appearance on the West End stage. I wish, however, he had chosen a more robust vehicle than this 90-minute two-hander by Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt: a whimsically aphoristic, ceaselessly teasing Parisian hit that never quite comes out of the closet in which it so deviously lurks.

At first it all looks disarmingly simple. Sutherland plays Abel Znorko, who, with a name like that, obviously has to be a reclusive Nobel prize-winner living on a remote Norwegian island. John Rubinstein is Erik Larsen, a provincial hack to whom he has reluctantly granted an interview. At first Abel is gruffly abusive, denying that his latest novel, a heavy-breathing epistolary romance, has any basis in reality. "Love," he barks, "is nothing but a perversion of pure sexuality."

What irks me is that Schmitt never quite gets to grips with the subject that clearly fascinates him: the homo-erotic nature of triangular desire in which two men love the same woman. Schmitt's play is a dance of the six-and-a-half veils that balks at ultimate disclosure and denies the gay logic of its narrative.

What we get, in Roeg Sutherland's translation, is a good deal of vivacious chat about "the existential alienation of closeness" mixed with plot-spinning reversals suggesting an upmarket version of Sleuth.

Still, Sutherland, looking with his grizzled face and white hair like a mix of Hemingway and John Huston, is highly watchable as Abel: he may not quite convince you he's a Nobel laureate but he skilfully makes the transition from posturing recluse to dedicated romantic. And John Rubinstein astutely preserves a masked reticence as the unlikely interviewer. Anthony Page, as director, tactfully referees. But if we are to see Sutherland in plays set in remote Norwegian outposts, I wish it could have been something altogether jollier, such as Ibsen's When We Dead Awaken.

Until July 29. Box office: 020-7836 8888. This review appeared in some editions yesterday. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Nationwide adds interest to battle for cyberspace supremacy

fields.headline: Nationwide adds interest to battle for cyberspace supremacy
fields.standfirst:
New venture adds heat to debate between mutuals and listed lenders.
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The battle for financial services supremacy in cyberspace took a new twist yesterday when Nationwide announced a "market-beating" savings rate for online customers.
fields.body:
The battle for financial services supremacy in cyberspace took a new twist yesterday when Nationwide announced a "market-beating" savings rate for online customers.

Nationwide described its 7% e-Savings rate as its answer to Prudential's egg, Halifax's Intelligent Finance and the cahoot internet banking service from Abbey National which is launched next week.

In an interview with the Guardian, Brian Davis, chief executive of Nationwide, staked his claim to the e-banking crown. "We're in the market place. Our intention is to show IF and Egg the way to go."

"At least we're real," Mr Davis added, referring to IF and cahoot, which are yet to go live on the net.

The broadside by Nationwide, which has 200,000 customers for its three-year-old internet bank, comes as established financial services companies and new players vie for net customers.

Former building societies Halifax and Abbey National are using the internet to try to win current account customers - 80% of whom bank with the four retail clearers, NatWest, Lloyds TSB, HSBC and Barclays.

Mr Davis insisted the online rates he could offer were improved by the building society's ongoing mutual status.

"If I was a plc, the people that backed me would be shareholders," he argued, adding that his members' benefit came in the form of higher interest rates. "We can out-price plcs at the end of the day."

However, Jim Spowart, chief executive of Intelligent Finance, retorted that Nationwide was merely offering a "loss-leading product".

While the mutual versus plc argument is a long-running one - one rival sniped yesterday that Nationwide was frittering away capital which could be used for windfalls - this contest is for online customers, who are "cheaper" than those relying on branch networks.

Rivals pointed out that Nationwide's e-Savings product is attached to the society's FlexAccount, requiring customers to open two accounts if they want access to the high savings rate. The £50,000 cap on deposits also raised eyebrows but Mr Davis said this was designed to prevent it being swamped by deposits.

While the banks and building societies also face new entrants on the net, analysis by KPMG appears to suggest it is the established players which will win the e-banking race.

"Although new e-banks have the speed, agility and ability to adjust to new demands, free from legacy IT issues, the incumbent major European banks have three crucial competitive advantages that will help them win: traffic, trust and multi-channel access," the KMPG report, Awakening Giants, concludes.

The report also highlights the two-pronged strategy which has emerged among the financial services institutions: set up "baby banks" on the net, like Halifax, in apparent competition to own-branded online services, or put everything behind own-brand businesses in cyberspace, the path being followed by Barclays.

While Nordic countries have been faster to take to the internet than neighbours, accounting for a third of Europe's 6m online customers, KPMG predicts "m-banking" - on mobile devices - will grow faster.

While KPMG concludes that customers are unlikely to embrace new players in the long term, there appears to be little let-up in investors' appetite for new initiatives in this battle of the banks.

webTitle: This year's housing boom is benign, say lenders

fields.headline: This year's housing boom is benign, say lenders
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain should avoid repeating the disastrous boom and bust in the housing market of the late 1980s, mortgage lenders said yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain should avoid repeating the disastrous boom and bust in the housing market of the late 1980s, mortgage lenders said yesterday.

Ten years ago prices soared after new buyers surged into the market, attracted by the previous government's policy of council house sales and easier access to mortgages. The result, according to the Council for Mortgage Lenders, was that prices first skyrocketed and then collapsed.

"One of the main insights of the new research is that the increase in transactions during the late 1980s was a one-off event," said the CML's director general, Michael Coogan.

Today instead of rushing to get a foot on the property ladder, young people are putting off the decision to purchase a house, the CML says. Many now graduate with significant student debts and cannot afford to take on a mortgage.

Average home sales have fallen to around 1.5m a year, well below the late 1980s peak of 2.1m. "Recent levels of transactions and the forecasts we are making for the future are close to the long-term trend," said Mr Coogan. "Although prices in some areas have grown strongly, the housing market is not unsustainable in the way it was a decade ago."

The rate of price increases - running at around 17% a year according to the latest figures from the Land Registry - has yet to reach the peaks of the late 1980s. "Similarly the pattern of a glut of transactions followed by a sharp reduction in their numbers is unlikely to be repeated today," the CML said.

But while mortgage lenders may believe current prices are sustainable, almost half of homeowners think their property is overvalued, according to new research.

The survey, conducted by NOP on behalf of online estate agent Asserta, discovered that 45% think their homes have become overvalued because of the property boom.

The situation is even more pronounced in the capital, with the survey finding 63% of Londoners who believe their property is overvalued.

Asserta's prime interest, however, appears to be in the real top of the range properties. The research follows publication of the latest quarterly Land Registry figures earlier this week showing the number of million-pound house sales continuing to rise.

An Asserta spokesman said: "City earnings and fat bonuses are fuelling the million pound plus property market." He said that million pound house sales had been on the increase since the late 1980s with sales having trebled since 1997.

The result is that in London million pound house hotspots have developed in Knightsbridge, Belgravia, Mayfair and Holland Park.

David Lundholm, marketing director of Asserta, said: "In the past a million pounds would buy a huge property, but in London and the south-east what you get for your money today is considerably less."

NOP surveyed 1,000 home-owners.

webTitle: Pilkington plans to save £100m by going online

fields.headline: Pilkington plans to save £100m by going online
fields.standfirst:
E-commerce strategy aims to expand business

E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pilkington, the glass-maker, yesterday announced ambitious plans to go online with all its customers and suppliers by the end of this year in an effort to save up to £100m of its annual £1bn procurement bill.
fields.body:
Pilkington, the glass-maker, yesterday announced ambitious plans to go online with all its customers and suppliers by the end of this year in an effort to save up to £100m of its annual £1bn procurement bill.

The group, the latest manufacturer to seek growth and shaved costs by embracing e-commerce, has already set up websites for its building products division in Europe and Australia, while customers can buy car windscreen replacements via the internet in North America and Europe.

"E-commerce will enable us to step over levels in the supply chain and reach new customers and increase our market share. It's a very positive route for growth," said Andrew Robb, the firm's finance director.

But, he said, realistically Pilkington hoped to have half its customers online within the next three years, enabling it to make annual savings of between £50m and £100m. The group is a main stakeholder in Mercadium, a neutral building products site.

The expanded e-commerce business is one strand of a four-part strategy adopted by chief executive Paolo Scaroni to turn around the once ailing glass-maker which has been seen as a bid target for rivals such as France's Saint Gobain.

That strategy paid off yesterday when Pilkington announced annual pretax profits of £175m, up from £135m in 1998, and saw its stock rated a "buy".

However, exceptional charges of £123m, related to the company's painful restructuring, reduced pretax earnings to £52m compared with £118m a year earlier.

The "Step Change" programme, now complete in Europe, was extended in March to North America where Mr Scaroni expects to save £80m annually from 2003.

But Mr Scaroni laid fresh emphasis on the growth parts of his strategy.

One is to grow organically in the traditional markets of America and Europe and another is to expand in emerging markets such as Brazil, the Czech Republic and Romania where growth rates of 8% are twice those of western Europe.

Mr Scaroni also set out plans for "focused, profit-enhancing acquisitions" over the next three years, understood to be largely small, entrepreneurial companies.

Pilkington recently increased its stake in a Chinese joint venture, SYP, and bought out Japanese group Nippon Sheet Glass's minority interests in four of its units to gain access to car-makers such as Toyota and Nissan.

The annual dividend is held at 5p despite a 40% rise in earnings per share to 9.1p but the market endorsed the group's new strategy, marking the shares up 2.75p to close the trading session at 85p.

webTitle: Falling pound fuels hope of steady rate

fields.headline: Falling pound fuels hope of steady rate
fields.standfirst:
Industry waits to feel knock-on effects
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Industry has yet to feel the benefit of the pound's recent slump on the foreign exchanges, new data showed yesterday, adding to hopes that the Bank of England will keep interest rates on hold next week.
fields.body:
Industry has yet to feel the benefit of the pound's recent slump on the foreign exchanges, new data showed yesterday, adding to hopes that the Bank of England will keep interest rates on hold next week.

Manufacturing output grew fractionally last month, according to the latest snapshot of the sector from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.

"There's little sign of growth in UK manufacturing and the strong pound is still taking its toll on domestic and export orders," said Roy Ayliffe, director of professional practice at the institute.

"The effect of the weakening of the pound has not really fed in yet and manufacturing is looking for more of that in order to sustain any competitiveness abroad, especially against the euro."

The purchasing managers index stood at 50.7 in May, fractionally up from the 50.6 recorded the previous month. Readings above 50 indicate that the sector is growing.

Companies are still shedding workers, according to the institute but at a slower rate than in April.

The employment index stood at 47.6 in May, compared with 46.2 recorded the previous month.

Prices for fuels and raw materials are still rising, but at a slower rate than in April. "With export orders lagging movements in sterling, exporters seem set for many more months of gloom," said Dharshini David, UK economist at HSBC.

"This survey is one more reason to think that rates will remain unchanged next week."

The Bank's decision is finely balanced. The strength of the pound has kept inflationary pressures under control for several months and enabled the Bank's monetary policy committee to hold rates at 6% since February.

However, since the committee's last meeting, the pound has lost more than 5% of its value against the currencies of Britain's major trading partners.

"The MPC must be comforted by signs that the economy is slowing and will welcome the recent fall in the pound. The risk is that the economy may not slow as quickly as expected and that the pound may fall faster than expected," said Adam Chester, an economist at Halifax.

fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Yahoo!, the internet portal group, is in talks to acquire the Myplay music service in a $200m (£133m) deal.
fields.body:
Yahoo!, the internet portal group, is in talks to acquire the Myplay music service in a $200m (£133m) deal.

The talks could face opposition from America Online, the world's largest internet service provider, which signed its own deal with Myplay in March.

Myplay, which launched just eight months ago, offers a "virtual locker" service which aims to allow users to download, manage and play music on any device anywhere in the world.

Unlike other online music companies deluged with lawsuits, Myplay has so far won tacit support from the music industry by offering to pay royalties. It aims to make money by targeting advertising to users and emailing them about new releases from favourite artists.

A source close to the talks said yesterday that Yahoo! and Myplay were close to an agreement but neither would comment on the talks.

The March agreement with AOL presents the biggest challenge to the proposed deal. Under the terms of the deal, Myplay is linked to AOL's Winamp and Spinner websites.

AOL is understood to have been keen to expand its partnership with the upstart company.

However, as one of Yahoo's! largest rivals, it is unlikely to want to continue a relationship with Myplay if a takeover is agreed.

Yahoo!, based in California, has previously had talks with Sony and Seagram, two large media and technology groups, about developing an online music service.

Both Napster, a popular song-swapping service, and MP3.com, an online rival, have been accused of piracy by the Recording Industry Association of America.

fields.headline: Arrogance justified
fields.standfirst: Contempo Monarch, London ****
fields.trailText: Contempo Monarch, London ****
fields.body:
"You've had to put up for a few years with bands with no tunes and no style. We've got shitloads of both," states Richard Archer, frontman and agent provocateur of Contempo. Forget for a moment that he's right - with his indie boy good looks and frontman arrogance, you want to hate him and his cohorts. But from the moment they hit the stage, defiance is not just impossible, it's stupid.

Hailing from Staines, Contempo are suburban boys with chips on their shoulders and Paul Weller posters on their walls. As they crash into On the Floor, the desperation of wanting something more spills over the crashing keyboards and defiance fills the air. A natural star in a Soul Boy T-shirt, Richard Archer clutches at his microphone for dear life, ripping into each song, by turns flirtatious and combative, his voice rising and falling as he lives his pop dream and tells tales of the life he's trying to escape.

The enthusiasm of the band is catching, their songs full of choruses that bounce their way into your brain. It's cheeky without being cloying. Contempo love their record collections but, like the cool kid rather than the sad case in school, they're not about to restrict themselves to it. New single It's Kickin Off is as much punk rock as it is Spencer Davis. The Motown harmonies are there, but so is the early 80s synth sound and the odd little bleeps that came after Phil Spector and Stax. Richard Archer turns his back to the audience, one arm aloft holding his mic. He doesn't have to see the nodding heads and dancing feet before him - he knows Contempo are good.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Boots gets into the fitness centre swim

fields.headline: Boots gets into the fitness centre swim
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Boots will continue its diversification away from its chemist origins by opening fitness centres next year and offering advice on health in two flagship stores.
fields.body:
Boots will continue its diversification away from its chemist origins by opening fitness centres next year and offering advice on health in two flagship stores.

But its attempts to expand the Boots brand away from high street chemists, which the City fears are being targeted aggressively by supermarkets offering cheaper products, failed to impress the stock market yesterday. Its shares fell 8% on concern about competitive pressures.

As part of its aim to earn half of its profits from non-chemist items in the coming years, Boots has already opened opticians and six dental practices which will be expanded to 50 during the year.

David Thompson, finance director, said yesterday that the Body360 standalone health, beauty and fitness centres, two of which will open next year, would not target men who wanted to lift weights or women obsessed by their image in Lycra.

"It's for Mr and Mrs Average who care about their health." If the centres, which will offer swimming pools as well as advice on meditation and giving up smoking, prove successful Boots might consider acquisition of an existing fitness chain or form partnerships in the £1m-a-year industry.

Boots is to spend £14.5m on such "well being services" this year. It also intends to remodel the layout of some its stores this autumn to introduce new displays of perfumes,cosmetics as well as making room for nail bars and dentists, chiropodists and the recently announced laser hair removal. The first branches to be refitted will be Chelmsford and Crawley, and it will open more edge-of-town stores, which are more profitable.

From July, customers who have their films processed in Boots stores will be able to have their snaps loaded on to their own secure website. "Bootsphoto.com means every photographer can have their personal photo album on the internet," the company said.

The group, which reported a 5% rise in pre-tax, pre-exceptionals profit to £587.4m for the year to the end of March, tried to play down concerns that its margins were being squeezed by supermarkets.

The group still has over 25% of the health and beauty market but admitted that like-for-like sales at Boots The Chemist were up just 1.8%.

fields.headline: Railtrack wants extra £1bn
fields.standfirst:
Train network chief warns of investment cuts unless decline in subsidies is reversed

More about transport
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Railtrack, the owner of the nation's rail network, said yesterday that it needs up to £1bn a year in additional revenues - much of it from the taxpayer - if it is to finance investment to meet forecast increases in demand.
fields.body:
Railtrack, the owner of the nation's rail network, said yesterday that it needs up to £1bn a year in additional revenues - much of it from the taxpayer - if it is to finance investment to meet forecast increases in demand.

Chief executive Gerald Corbett made it clear that such a programme would require substantial extra funding from the Treasury - reversing the decline in public subsidy to the railways over recent years.

If the extra money was not forthcoming Railtrack would be forced to review its investment plans, he said. "You can either have a railway in which [public] subsidy continues to decline, where there is no growth ... or you can have a bigger, better railway. That way means increased subsidies."

Mr Corbett's comments come as both the government and the rail regulator Tom Winsor are drawing up proposals which will have a crucial impact on the funding of the industry. Mr Winsor is in the final stages of a review of the regulatory regime - which covers the amount Railtrack can charge train operating companies for access to the network - while the government is at work on an integrated transport plan.

In a year overshadowed by the Ladbroke Grove crash in October in which 31 people died, Railtrack saw pre-profits fall from £428m to £421m before an exceptional charge of £61m which reduced the total to £360m - about £1m a day. This year's profits will be "materially below" the £421m, the group warned. Analysts are already pencilling in profits of around £350m. The final dividend is being held at 17.6p a share. The shares ended 32p higher at 872p.

Mr Corbett argued yesterday that when Railtrack was set up in 1995 its financing reflected the fact that the rail industry was not growing. The amount it could charge the operators was largely fixed. As a result Railtrack was not able to compensate for the 20% growth in the number of trains on the network. Railtrack's views about the growth in the market was underlined by figures from the Department of Transport figures published yesterday. They showed that the number of passenger miles last year was the highest since 1946 while the number of journeys was the highest since the early 1960s.

The financial regime under which the company was set up had also assumed that Railtrack would invest some £3.5bn in the first five years while the group had actually spent some £2bn more than that. As a result its debt level is rising.

At present the rail industry's income is around £4bn a year - including subsidies of some £1.3bn - with the operating companies paying Railtrack £2.4bn for access to the network. But with the regulator about to decide on access charges for the period 2001 and 2006 Railtrack is stepping up the pressure for more to fund its renewal and enhancement programme.

Mr Corbett said he expected that the regulator would draw up a regime which ensured that Railtrack was "appropriately funded going forward." Asked how much he wanted Mr Corbett replied: "About £1bn more than we are getting at the moment."

Railtrack refused to be drawn on which investment plans might be affected if it did not get the money it wanted saying decisions could only be taken in the light of the outcome of the review.

The group said it was continuing to invest heavily in safety, speeding up plans to introduce the train protection warning system. It was also introducing measures to reduce the risk of signals being passed at danger, to cut the number of broken rails and to fight vandalism and trespass.

fields.headline: A meditation on glazing
fields.standfirst: Shelf Life St Pancras Church, London ***
fields.trailText: Shelf Life St Pancras Church, London ***
fields.body:
St Pancras Church in London's Euston Road is like an early 19th-century experiment in postmodernism, an odd, enduring mix of pagan and Christian, British and Greek. So the temporary addition of a live art installation to the church doesn't come as much of a surprise. A glass shelf is currently suspended three metres above the ground via an elegant construction of chrome stilts, and for three-and-a-half hours each evening, dancer and choreographer Carol Brown is performing her solo Shelf Life.

The installation was created with visual artist Esther Rolinson and began as a dialogue between movement and architecture - the raised shelf defining the area within which Brown can move and the perspective from which she's viewed. But the concept evolved a further cluster of metaphors - of things being left on shelves, of the slow, inexorable processes of age and decay - and these are now a central part of the performance.

Brown is an assertive, even glamorous, performer, confidently angling her strong body through different planes and levels as she works within the limits of her stage. But she also operates from an unusually calm focus, so even as we register the ambitious structures of her choreography we're also caught by the sense of a slow, steady heartbeat grounding all her moves. As traffic noise snarled up with the serene washes of Russell Skoons's sound score, it was as if we could hear the sound of two conflicting human rhythms - the ragged palpitations of city life and the internal pulse dramatised by Brown's body. As ordinary people were briefly snagged into watching the show - passing by on buses or looking down from flats and offices - Brown's meditative dance, isolated on her shelf, seemed an icon of contemplation, a little memento mori. It was the neatest possible justification of live art - life, simply, being turned into art.

Until June 2. 020-7387 0031. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: State of the production
fields.standfirst: Moments of Madness BAC, London *
fields.trailText: Moments of Madness BAC, London *
fields.body:
The past few months have seen an unusually large number of theatrical dispatches from Wales. The message they have sent has largely been bleak, depicting a country and a people suffering from confusion, depression and indifference.

The agony continues with this latest production from Volcano, a long-established physical theatre company with many admirers and imitators. Volcano has been a treasure because of its ability to physicalise not just feelings but also thought, and use text - from Shakespeare and Ibsen and Tony Harrison to Marx and Baudrillard - with rare intelligence. Its work has never just been about bodies slamming against walls.

But something has gone badly wrong with this state-of-the-nation piece that instead of opening out debates about regionalism, nationalism, self-determination and national identity and culture actually shuts them down. Set during a conference on arts, culture and the state, it feels suspiciously like the company's argument with itself. It is exclusive rather than inclusive, incestuous rather than accessible. After a while it makes you yawn and long to go for a walk on Clapham Common.

Ron Davies is just one reference point: Julie Christie, Rudolf Hess, Edward II and Eisenstein's Battleship Potemkin (the piece apparently takes place in the hull of a ship) are others in an evening that feels increasingly pretentious, and for all its talk of revolution is astoundingly decadent. The target here is not capitalism, or exploitation, but Arts Council bureaucrats, smug academics and agenda-wavers.

A lack of theatricality is a major problem and if the 90 minutes finally achieves some momentum in its murderous If-style fantasy sequences, by then the production has become so obscure that you wonder whether it might be intentionally parodying itself. And if it were, would it know?

Until June 11. Box office: 020-7223 2223. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Wilkinson sells Slovaks formation dummies
fields.trailText: For someone who claims that winning the European Under-21 championship is not the be all and end all, the England coach Howard Wilkinson decided to indulge in an odd spot of kidology yesterday.
fields.body:
For someone who claims that winning the European Under-21 championship is not the be all and end all, the England coach Howard Wilkinson decided to indulge in an odd spot of kidology yesterday.

England need to beat the hosts, Slovakia, at the Inter Bratislava stadium in front of what is likely to be a capacity crowd of 8,500 to stand a chance of topping Group B and reaching Sunday's final. They also need the leaders, Italy, to fail to beat Turkey. Otherwise it will be a place in the third-fourth play-off.

Slovakia are in a slightly stronger position, as a draw will do if Italy lose. To that end Wilkinson claimed, after training at a rain-soaked ground on the outskirts of the capital, that the formation he had used during the kick-about bore no relation to his actual line-up for tonight but was for the benefit of a Slovakian television cameraman.

"We came here not knowing much about Slovakia," he added, "certainly not as much as if [the England coach] Kevin Keegan was preparing for a game against them." However the Under-21 coach did admit that he had seen videos of Slovakia's two games and says that he was very impressed.

"They've deserved their results [a 2-1 win against Turkey and a 1-1 draw with Italy]. They are a very experienced squad and they'll be playing in front of a full house. They have played together for a long time, they move the ball about and are nice and tidy.

"But our lack of a crowd, particularly against Turkey, did not have a massive negative effect and I hope it does not have a massive positive effect [for the Slovaks]. They have deserved the results they have got. They're an experienced squad, it will be a full house, so it's game on."

Wilkinson also singled out the left-sided midfielder Vratislav Gresko as a danger man. He was a member of the Bayer Leverkusen team who missed out on the Bundesliga title on the final day of last season and also played in their Champions League campaign. And in terms of reputation he is seen as something of a David Beckham, if only for his ability to cross the ball at set-pieces.

His delivery could be crucial tonight given that Wilkinson singled out England's failure to deal with set-pieces as a contributing factor to their 2-0 defeat by Italy.

However, Nicky Weaver is confident that England can extend their stay here and is hopeful the Turks can help by getting the better of Italy.

"There's no extra pressure on us," the Manchester City goalkeeper said. "It wasn't a great result against Italy but we bounced back well against Turkey [6-0] and now we know we've got to win and hope Turkey get a result against Italy. I certainly don't think we're just playing to get in the play-off. Stranger things have happened."

Wilkinson will have to reshuffle his left flank tonight as Derby County's Seth Johnson is suspended. And the coach was intent to continue his mind games and leave the Slovakia coach Dusan Radolsky guessing as he cited Jon Harley, Ledley King and Anthony Gardner as possible replacements.

While one of those, probably Chelsea's Harley, will get the nod, with King remaining in central defence, spare a thought for Lee Hendrie. The midfielder has had a terrible 12 days, only a late substitute in Aston Villa's unsuccessful FA Cup final side and then losing his place here. He started against Italy last Saturday but, despite being one of the few to do himself justice, he was taken off at half-time and did not feature in Monday's rout of Turkey.

Wilkinson confirmed Hendrie is not injured but refused to elaborate. "I have spoken to him. I have changed the team and David Dunn, once he got over the first 20 minutes back in at this level, did very well. Competitions like this are about 20 players and that's not a throw-away line to keep everybody happy.

"If the five or six who are not involved are not looked after properly and do not contribute properly, then jobs like this go awfully wrong. There's got to be the right social atmosphere and you have to work harder with those [who are omitted] than with the others, but that's not to say you keep them sweet."

England (probable 3-5-2): Weaver; King, Carragher, Young; Mills, Lampard, Dunn, Murphy, Harley; Cort, Jeffers.

There's got to be the right social atmosphere and you have to work harder with those [who are omitted] than with the others, but that's not to say you keep them sweet." England (probable 3-5-2): Weaver; King, Carragher, Young; Mills, Lampard, Dunn, Murphy, Harley; Cort, Jeffers.

fields.headline: Chelsea close on Hasselbaink
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink looks certain to join Chelsea for a club record £14m after Atletico Madrid announced a deal was in place to take the striker to Stamford Bridge.
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink looks certain to join Chelsea for a club record £14m after Atletico Madrid announced a deal was in place to take the striker to Stamford Bridge.

"Hasselbaink will move to Chelsea," Atletico's general manager Miguel Angel Gil said yesterday. "An agreement between the clubs has been reached and all that remains is for the clubs to exchange faxes and for the signing to be ratified by the Premier League."

Personal terms are understood to have been settled on a four-year contract, with the former Leeds United player earning about £40,000 a week after tax.

The 29-year-old, who is preparing for Euro 2000 with Holland, could find the deal delayed because Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchison is on holiday until the end of next week, although Hutchison has previously conducted business from abroad.

Hasselbaink's arrival, and reports linking Chelsea with Real Betis' Finidi George, raise further questions about the future of Gianfranco Zola and Chris Sutton. Zola is considering a move to Napoli, where he spent four seasons from 1989.

"I know Napoli want me," he said, "and they are a very in teresting proposition. I hope Chelsea will give me the opportunity to leave. Gianluca needs different types of strikers to me for his style of play."

Newcastle have signed the Argentina midfielder Christian Bassedas, 26, from Velez Sarsfield for £3.5m.

Barry Fry said last night he was staying as Peterborough manager, 24 hours after claiming he was "booted out" following an argument over his support for the youth academy at a board meeting. The club denied sacking him.

 The Scottish Football Association has voted to increase the number of substitutes in the Scottish Cup from three to five.

webTitle: Bosnich out in the cold as United capture Barthez

fields.headline: Bosnich out in the cold as United capture Barthez
fields.trailText: After 16 hours of tortuous negotiations Fabien Barthez returned to France last night with a Manchester United contract packed among his belongings.
fields.body:
After 16 hours of tortuous negotiations Fabien Barthez returned to France last night with a Manchester United contract packed among his belongings.

To the relief of everyone at United, with the likely exception of Mark Bosnich, Barthez emerged from another exhaustive session of talks to confirm he had joined the Old Trafford payroll with a six-year deal worth £9.6m.

Although Monaco had been seeking a transfer fee of 100 million francs (£9.5m) United put the end figure at £7.8m. The move makes Barthez the most expensive goalkeeper in British football.

"I cannot describe how happy I feel. In my dreams I would love to become a legend here like Eric Cantona and Peter Schmeichel," said the 28-year-old.

"I spoke to Thierry Henry, Emmanuel Petit and Patrick Vieira and they have all said there is no better place to play football than England. The long-ball game is a thing of the past and everyone plays great football. United are at the top and any footballer in my position would love to play for them."

Barthez's arrival is likely to mean Bosnich's departure and Roma and Deportivo La Coruna will lead the bidding. Although Ferguson would prefer to keep Bosnich, it was apparent from the manager's assessment of his goalkeeping candidates that Barthez will depose him next season.

"I am delighted he has joined us," said Ferguson. "Apart from his obvious goalkeeping skills he has the personality to play on the biggest stage. That is an area in which Schmeichel excelled. Fabien is a World Cup winner and has the personality and vast experience that is required."

For a delicate few hours late on Tuesday evening the talks seemed to have reached an impasse but Barthez dispelled any suggestion that they had been on the brink of collapse. " Mais, non ," he said, before tentatively testing his English. "We just could not find a pen."

webTitle: Bulldozers to dust, Villa to red-brick rubble

fields.headline: Bulldozers to dust, Villa to red-brick rubble
fields.trailText: Stadiums are coming down and going up all over England. The bulldozing ghouls of progress tread on old friends as well as dreams.
fields.body:
That soaring red-bricked neo-Victorian glory which identified Birmingham's Villa Park the world over lay in an exhausted heap yesterday morning, nothing more than an anonymous pile of builders' rubble.

At Southampton the endearing Dell braces itself for similar oblivion. So, after all the ifs and buts and hints of reprieve, do Wembley's twin towers - and after last night's penultimate show, they will stand sentinel to only one two more football matches (the Charity Shield, then England v Germany in October) before being wiped off the face of the earth. Which comes next? Highbury? Goodison Park? Craven Cottage? The bulldozing ghouls of progress tread on old friends as well as dreams.

Stadiums are coming down and going up all over England. New stadiums - swish, sleek, characterless and crazily exorbitant cathedrals to steel and concrete and corporate hospitality - are coming out of our ears. I suppose they are necessary. I am certain they are not allowing much time for goodbyes.

Not that "gleaming" new means plain sailing. Already since the autumn 17 international matches have been played below that steepling cliff face which is Cardiff's new stadium - but interest repayments apparently remain cripplingly scary.

I could have wept when I saw the television pictures showing the demolition of Villa Park's Trinity Road stand. To all intents that proud red-brick fortress was the architectural signature not only of Aston Villa but, somehow, of urban English football itself and its rise and rise from the roots of the Industrial Revolution.

In fact, it was only 76 years old. But Trinity Road and I go back a long time. I daresay I would not have been crouching in this corner on top of this column if it had not been for Trinity Road. A half-century ago on a January Saturday, my father took me up on the train from Gloucester. A tram from the Bull Ring deposited us, agape, in the excited toing-and-froing pre-match mayhem below the overwhelmingly mountainous and roseate edifice.

No other football ground in the whole world boasted such a grand facade, nor a more theatrically welcoming one - with its breathtaking and classical central stairway, its pavilion turrets and Dutch gables and mosaic embellishments. Pastoral county cricket at Cheltenham did not count. It was the first immense and concentrated sporting throng I had been swept up, up and away in - and I was hook-line-and-sinkered for life.

Villa beat Fulham 3-0. It was a good Villa team and from deep recesses I recall such names as Harry Parkes, Johnny Dixon, Con Martin, Amos Moss and Larry Canning (who became a BBC sports reporter). I should by rights, after such a ravishing introduction, have become a Villa supporter for life.

But my Dad said he had known in London before the war the stalwart Fulham full-back Joe Bacuzzi - and that we would wait for me to get his autograph after the game. And so we did - and so, just because of that big man's smiling handshake and flamboyant signature, was my lifelong allegiance to Fulham FC there and then pronounced and sealed. (How we have been unequivocally lumbered with our team would make a good book sometime).

Anyway, no more Villa Park's Trinity Road defining edifice. This week's pile of rubble surprised even those closest. One fan, Ian Robathan, had launched a belated preservation campaign. He remains resentful at the club keeping plans in the dark - "and angry that we didn't do more to save this final link with Villa's great Victorian heritage".

Another sorrowful Villa fan is the football grounds' history addict, the author Simon Inglis. The latest classic from Inglis is Sightlines (Yellow Jersey, £18), a glorious stadium odyssey in which he tramps his obsession round the world - and where, by chance, he finds the senior supervisor building the swish new national stadium in the Lebanon to be none other than Tony Dorsett - son of Dickie Dorsett ("the Brownhills Bomber"), who was Villa's inside-left when they played that auspicious game against Fulham 50 Januaries ago... Exits and entrances, what comes down goes up and what goes around comes around.

fields.headline: Classy Atherton in his element
fields.standfirst: England 203-3 v Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Eleven years and 96 matches ago, Mike Atherton played his debut Test innings here and made a duck, leg before wicket as so many were that summer to Terry Alderman. The debt has been cancelled many times over since, however, and of Test-match grounds around the world this is the one above all others that belongs to him.
fields.body:
Eleven years and 96 matches ago, Mike Atherton played his debut Test innings here and made a duck, leg before wicket as so many were that summer to Terry Alderman. The debt has been cancelled many times over since, however, and of Test-match grounds around the world this is the one above all others that belongs to him.

Four times - against New Zealand twice, West Indies and India - he has made centuries and he would have made another in his last innings here as well had he not batted himself to a standstill as Alec Stewart applied the coup de grace to South Africa. The duel with Alan Donald that day has moved into the realms of cricket legend.

Yesterday, against less testing opposition, he played his way with calm assurance to the verge of what will be, should he carry on this morning, his fifth century on this ground and his 14th in all. Perhaps it is something in the water.

With a start delayed until 1.40pm as a result of overnight rain, England, unchanged from Lord's and unsurprisingly put in to bat by Andy Flower, made 203 for three, 96 of them to Atherton. On the way, when he hit the boundary that took him to 95, he overtook Denis Compton's ground record of 955 Test runs.

With him, on eight, will be Stewart who made a century in the last Test at Lord's and yesterday found himself at the crease towards the day's end after two quick wickets. They were those of the England captain Nasser Hussain, who took 35 minutes to open his account, passed 3,000 Test runs and then hit an extravagant catch to mid-off, and Graeme Hick, who was quite stunningly caught by Brian Murphy, full stretch, one-handed, Jonty Rhodes-style at backward point. Both wickets fell to the teenage debutant seam bowler Mluleki Nkala.

This was due reward for some honest endeavour from the young man who, after replacing Bryan Strang as one of two changes from the first Test - Stuart Carlisle replaced Trevor Gripper - was given the new ball, bowled a nervous first spell in which he was too wide but came back enthusiastically.

The foundations of England's total had been laid by an opening partnership of 121 between Atherton and Mark Ramprakash, only the fourth century opening stand against Zimbabwe in their 43 Tests.

Such partnerships have been a rare commodity for England in recent years. When Atherton and Mark Butcher put on 115 in Cape Town over the new year it was the first hundred stand since the same pair added 145 on this ground in that tumultuous match against South Africa two years ago.

For Atherton, though, this was the 19th time he has shared a hundred stand for the first wicket, one more than Graham Gooch, and for England fewer only than Geoff Boycott (20), Herbert Sutcliffe (21) and Jack Hobbs (24).

This alliance was a good one, between batsmen who do not so much complement one another as augment. Ramprakash, whose career as an opener is in its infancy, later was to acknowledge the help that he drew from his partner's vast experience.

The concentration from both was intense and, on a pitch that certainly had moisture in it but against bowlers unable to exploit it, they played and missed only occasionally. Heath Streak in particular was off the pace after his efforts at Lord's.

Ramprakash, comfortable within the England environment now, played what must be his most fluent innings for his country since his century in Bridgetown two years ago. He made 56 with nine boundaries, none better than the brace of full-flourish cover drives off Streak and Neil Johnson either side of the tea interval. But eventually a combination of extra bounce from Johnson and a studiously low forward defensive stroke resulted in the ball looping to gully.

This was a situation made for Atherton, however, and he was really troubled only twice. When 15 he might have been caught as he drove at Pommie Mbangwa and got an inside edge.

Simultaneously, though, Andy Flower grassed the chance and Merv Kitchen called no-ball.

Then, on 89, he flicked Nkala off his legs and Carlisle, at deepish short square-leg, dived to his right and just failed to hold a reflex catch.

That aside there was some vintage stuff during his stay of more than five hours, with some perfectly timed driving and cutting bringing the bulk of his 13 boundaries and a six coming when he hooked Streak's bouncer over square leg.

Zimbabwe GW Flower, GJ Whittall, MW Goodwin, NC Johnson, A Flower (captain, wkt), SV Carlisle, ADR Campbell, M Nkala, HH Streak, BA Murphy, M Mbangwa.
Umpires MJ Kitchen (England) and DL Orchard (South Africa).

webTitle: Atherton gives England a great start

fields.headline: Atherton gives England a great start
fields.standfirst: England were 203 for 3 at the close of play: Atherton 96*, Stewart 8*
fields.trailText: Michael Atherton was left on 96 not out as England made a great start batting first in the second Test against Zimbabwe at Trent Bridge on Thursday. They finished on 203 for three and, providing the Nottingham weather holds out until Monday, England can expect to record a series whitewash against their hapless opponents over the next few days.
fields.body:
Michael Atherton was left on 96 not out as England made a great start batting first in the second Test against Zimbabwe at Trent Bridge on Thursday. They finished on 203 for three and, providing the Nottingham weather holds out until Monday, England can expect to record a series whitewash against their hapless opponents over the next few days.

Trent Bridge is Atherton's most prolific Test venue: he has already hit four tons here, including his first, the 151 he took off New Zealand ten summers ago. But he will have approached today's task with some trepidation - after rain washed out the morning session, the damp, overcast conditions, and a wafting cross-ground breeze from the river Trent looked as though they could combine with the Zimbabwean bowling to some effect.

But the new-ball bowlers - an off-form Heath Streak and debutant Mluleki Nkala - could do nothing with the favourable conditions while they lasted, and the England opening pair of Mike Atherton and Mark Ramprakash negotiated the opening gambit with some assurance. After Atherton confidently hit Heath Streak's ball for two through square leg, fears that ball would dominate bat dissipated immediately. Next over, Nkala's first delivery in Test cricket was called a no-ball, and the pattern of the afternoon was set.

At times it was hard to tell which opener was the dogged anchor and which the stylish strokemaker, but Ramprakash looked more than comfortable in the opening role. When he bowled, Neil Johnson was zippy, but had no luck. By the time Streak returned, this time from the Radcliffe Road End, he had the dubious honour of being belted through the covers by Atherton to bring up England's 50 in the 22nd over. Landmark reached, Mike and Mark increased the scoring rate by attacking the bad balls, and brought a dismally small Nottingham crowd to life with some delightful strokes for four.

Flower tossed the ball to his legspinner, Brian Murphy, as early as the 29th over and Athers and Ramps knew they were well on top. Atherton, playing in his 97th Test, passed 6,500 runs in Test cricket with a punched four through the off-side. After tea he riled Streak by taking 14 off one over, including one six lofted over square leg. The fast bowler replied with a bouncer, before trudging from the field for some treatment from the physio. Just when the England openers looked like they would emulate Geoff Marsh and Mark Taylor - who batted throughout the first day of an Ashes Test on this ground 11 years ago - Johnson produced a quicker ball which Ramprakash could only deflect to gully from the shoulder of his bat: 121 for one. The in-coming Hussain, who missed out on the run-feast at Lord's, then started cautiously, before getting off the mark with a four from the 23rd ball he faced.

For a while England resembled Australia, easily racking up 182 runs for just the loss of Ramprakash, before they suddenly reminded us who they really were. Nkala grabbed two quick wickets to make his a debut to remember: Hussain prodded one into Streak's hands at mid off before Hick, one of the Lord's centurions, fell for just five in Nkala's next over thanks to a superb sprawling catch by Murphy at cover. But England trundled past 200 in the 74th over of the day and the platform has been set for a big total, one which should push any hopes of victory from the Zimbabweans' grasp.

Zimbabwe GW Flower, GJ Whittall, MW Goodwin, NC Johnson, A Flower (captain, wkt), SV Carlisle, ADR Campbell, M Nkala, HH Streak, BA Murphy, M Mbangwa.

The in-coming Hussain, who missed out on the run-feast at Lord's, then started cautiously, before getting off the mark with a four from the 23rd ball he faced. For a while England resembled Australia, easily racking up 182 runs for just the loss of Ramprakash, before they suddenly reminded us who they really were. Nkala grabbed two quick wickets to make his a debut to remember: Hussain prodded one into Streak's hands at mid off before Hick, one of the Lord's centurions, fell for just five in Nkala's next over thanks to a superb sprawling catch by Murphy at cover. But England trundled past 200 in the 74th over of the day and the platform has been set for a big total, one which should push any hopes of victory from the Zimbabweans' grasp. webTitle: Athers and Ramps do a Boycott and Luckhurst

fields.headline: Athers and Ramps do a Boycott and Luckhurst
fields.trailText: It was a classically English display, of the kind you might have seen 30 years ago. Ramps produced two cover drives that were a cut above anything he has done recently for England and Atherton was Atherton. But Zimbabwe shouldn't be too embarrassed.
fields.body:
Last time England were put in to bat in a Test match, they instantly collapsed to 2 for 4 (at Johannesburg last November). The time before that, they were 4 for 2 (Melbourne, December 1998). On both occasions, Mike Atherton made a pair. However, neither of those matches was against Zimbabwe.

You have to feel for the Zims. They won the toss and bowled in conditions that could not have been more helpful - or more tailored to them, because the surface was so slow, it could have been Harare in the rainy season. The crowd, too, was of a size that they are used to. But they are a demoralised, downtrodden bunch at the moment, and the violent death of a friend of the team, which could have galvanised them, just acted as another weight on their shoulders.

They didn't bowl badly, but luck deserted them as it does when times are hard, and their lack of firepower was all too obvious. The one proper bowler, Heath Streak, was off colour; his 19-year-old new-ball partner, Mluleki Nkala, was as predictably green as the pitch. Pommie Mbangwa may have ripped through Yorkshire's Second XI this week but his swingers came at such a gentle pace that Atherton and Mark Ramprakash could simply wait and see which way the ball was going before selecting their shot. Maybe that's why they call him Pommie: because he's a pie-thrower.

Atherton and Ramprakash started tentatively, with only 20 off the first 11 overs. The two gung-ho openers in the England team, Alec Stewart and Nick Knight, may have been muttering in the dressing-room. But Athers and Ramps know how to ease up through the gears and they did so as if playing at Southport or Southgate.

It was a classically English display, of the kind you might have seen from Boycott and Luckhurst 30 years ago. Ramps produced two cover drives that were a cut above anything he has done recently (when allowed to play) for England: as correct as ever, but dismissive rather than studious. He celebrated passing 50 with a cover drive so handsome that David Gower reached for the words "ease and grace", which is like being called regal by the Queen.

Atherton was Atherton: the odd pendulum swing of the bat, a few half-controlled edges, and one inside-edge on to the pad just like the one he was given out to at Lord's, but also endless sang-froid, many a late adjustment, and, as time went on, some resounding shots either side of the man at cover point. After two consecutive fifties, the old boy has already done enough this summer to be sure of making it to 100 caps, bad back permitting, on his home ground in the third Test against West Indies on August 3.

Don't blame Ramps for not turning 50 into 100: Neil Johnson got the ball to pop up, and this is such a front-foot pitch that it wasn't wrong to go forward. It is partnerships that win matches, not individual scores, and a hundred for none was the perfect foundation for England.

Zimbabwe shouldn't be too embarrassed: the last time England were put in in a home Test, they made an even better start - 179 for 0 against the might of Donald and Pollock at Edgbaston two years ago. Andy Flower's only real mistake was to keep on keeping on. His recent results, like Alec Stewart's in 1998-99, offer conclusive proof that you cannot combine the roles of captain, wicketkeeper and senior batsman. It was said that Tatenda Taibu kept badly against Yorkshire, but that would just mean swapping one indifferent keeper for another. And Zimbabwe might just have got their best batsman back.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly. The Wisden Verdict appears here, a few minutes after the close, every day that England are in action.

fields.headline: Luxembourg nursery hostages released
fields.trailText: Police today shot the lone gunman holding 28 hostages in a Luxembourg nursery and released the children and teachers he was holding captive.
fields.body:
Police today shot the lone gunman holding 28 hostages in a Luxembourg nursery and released the children and teachers he was holding captive.

The assault started with two shots before police stormed the building. Witnesses heard shooting and saw some children leaving the centre.

The 39-year-old man had a history of mental illness. Police feared that he might do something irrational as the siege entered its second day and he became tired.

Four young children were released earlier today but the gunman continued to hold 25 children and three adults. He entered the Wasserbillig nursery in eastern Luxembourg yesterday afternoon and released eight children last night before making demands for passage to Libya.

A teacher managed to smuggle six or seven children out of the nursery just after the hostage-taker entered the building. A further two children were released at 9am this morning, and two more early this afternoon. The children he released were in good health, police said.

The hostage-taker has spoken with his own psychiatrist via a mobile phone. He has been seen at one of the school's windows waving his gun and a hand grenade beside a picture of a teddy bear.

"We are still in regular contact with the hostage-taker by phone," Mr Schmit told a news conference this morning. "As far as we can tell the situation is calm, but there is a certain fatigue... The climate is becoming more tense."

The hostage-taker originally called for $1.38m as well as a plane, but he is understood to have dropped the demand for money. It remains unclear why the Luxembourg citizen, who is of Tunisian origin, would want to fly to Libya.

Authorities told reporters that the hostage-taker, who came from a neighbouring village, was married and had two children of his own and that his children had at one time attended the nursery

Local residents said that the man blamed the nursery and held a grudge against the daycare director for the fact that he lost custody of his children when he separated from his wife. RTL Luxembourg radio reported that a man identifying himself as the hostage taker called the station twice, insisting the children inside the school were fine and had been playing late into the night. The man said he was driven to this act of desperation "because of custody problems" surrounding his two children.

fields.headline: O'Neill finally accepts Celtic job
fields.standfirst: Graphic: O'Neill's career so far
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill has been confirmed as the new manager of Celtic.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill has been confirmed as the new manager of Celtic.

After days of procrastination, the former Leicester boss finally decided to move to Parkhead earlier today. And in a 6pm press conference O'Neill admitted he was delighted at the chance to manage such a famous club. "It seems like it has taken a long time but in reality it hasn't," he said. "It gives me the opportunity to explore a dream."

"I have been very impressed with the place. I am amazed at the stadium. It has a fantastic supporter base. It needs a team to go with it and that is my responsibility.

"I have thoroughly enjoyed my four-and-a-half years at Leicester and to leave that was not an overnight thought," he added. "But deciding to come to Celtic took two and a half seconds. The lure of Celtic is what attracted me here."

Celtic chief executive Allan MacDonald said: "Martin has a high standing in the game and we are confident he can bring success to Celtic. As player and manager he has competed at the highest level and has great experience of European competition.

"It was this combination that convinced the board he was the man to lead Celtic. It is important we can now build on the playing side. We are confident we have a man of outstanding quality," he added.

Attention will now turn to the identity of O'Neill's successor at Filbert Street with Gillingham manager Peter Taylor and Joe Kinnear the current favourites.

fields.headline: Real McManaman fails to show
fields.standfirst:
Minute-by-minute match report
Adams steals the Macca show
Richard Williams' analysis
David Lacey on the final 22
fields.trailText: Last night England looked like a team about to go places. Precisely where was not always clear but the spirit of this victory in their last serious test before the European Championship was encouraging even if the performance was patchy.
fields.body:
Last night England looked like a team about to go places. Precisely where was not always clear but the spirit of this victory in their last serious test before the European Championship was encouraging even if the performance was patchy.

A match designed to give Steve McManaman a platform to roam as freely and effectively as he did in helping Real Madrid to win the European Cup did not turn out quite like that.

McManaman set about his task willingly enough but Paul Scholes took the eye more when his limited role in midfield allowed him to get forward, and the goals came from England's most reliable source.

Both followed corners from David Beckham, the first scored by Robbie Fowler shortly before half-time, the second by Tony Adams midway through the second half, his first England goal for 11 years. Both also owed much to the presence of Alan Shearer in the penalty area.

Playing his last England game at Wembley before he retires from international football, Shearer showed the aggression, perception and speed of reaction which will be so crucial for Kevin Keegan in Euro 2000.

Overall the performance was an improvement on last Saturday's tepid 1-1 draw with Brazil. Certainly it was as positive as the coach had promised, with Sol Campbell driving forward at every opportunity. But for a long time, hard though Scholes and the freshly capped Steven Gerrard worked in midfield, the passing was prosaic and predictable and not until the second half did England start to break their chronic habit of giving the ball away when not under pressure.

There were times when England's football shrieked aloud for Dennis Wise's passes to pull it together. For all that, Gerrard did well enough to give Keegan a satisfactory option should anything happen to Paul Ince.

Individually there were other successes. Fowler, even before he scored, allayed any doubts Keegan might have had about the striker's sharpness following his injury problems. In goal, moreover, Nigel Martyn made a series of saves from Andrei Shevchenko to suggest that, while he might be No2 to David Seaman, he is really England's No1.

To accommodate McManaman's roaming activities Keegan, as expected, played with three at the back and used Beckham and Phil Neville to give England's movements consistent width. It quickly became apparent, however, that this was never going to recreate the circumstances McManaman enjoys when Michel Salgado and Roberto Carlos are his wing-backs.

In addition Neville's need to switch the ball to his right foot when he did advance on the left meant that McManaman's hopes of creating something by drifting inside from that flank were limited.

At the start England looked more effective when Fowler was driftng to the right and providing low crosses to coincide with Scholes's late runs through the middle. From the second of these the Manchester United man hit a post.

Defensively England looked suspect against the pace of Sergei Kandaurov. Adams never looks comfortable in the middle of a back three but his interception to deny Shevchenko a chance proved crucial as England struggled to get their act together.

Towards half-time, in fact, their movements became sufficiently co-ordinated to pose more problems for Ukraine's defenders. From the right-hand byline Beckham set up a chance for Fowler, who was thwarted by the awkward cross, but in the 44th minute Shearer met a corner with a downward header which Kernozenko blocked only for Fowler to score from the rebound.

Emile Heskey replaced Fowler for the second half without fulfilling the promise his partnership with Shearer had shown against Argentina. Nick Barmby, another substitute, later set up opportunities for both Heskey and McManaman but neither could beat Kernozenko.

England's second goal, in the 67th minute, arrived after Kernozenko had punched another corner from Beckham on to the chest of the diving Shearer, the ball bouncing off the captain at a convenient angle for Adams to drive it into the net.

By then England had cause to be grateful for the agility of Martyn, who had blocked a shot from Shevchenko by the near post, dived full length to turn wide a header from the same player and then turned a deflected free-kick from the striker over the bar.

In the end England could be reasonably satisfied with the evening except that its main object had hardly been fulfilled. A wandering McManaman may yet be the answer but last night the question was never really put.
