fields.headline: What now for Leicester?
fields.trailText: Four successive top-ten finishes in the Premiership, two Worthington Cup triumphs and a proven record of transforming reserves and rejects into top-quality players.
fields.body:
Four successive top-ten finishes in the Premiership, two Worthington Cup triumphs and a proven record of transforming reserves and rejects into top-quality players.

Whatever way you look at it, Martin O'Neill's record at Leicester is extraordinary.

And it becomes more extraordinary still when you remember that during his four-and-a-half years at Filbert Street he won the same number of trophies as Arsène Wenger (in roughly the same time period) - and more than Roy Evans, Ron Atkinson and George Graham put together.

So it's understandable that now the symbiotic relationship between the manic Ulsterman and the east Midlands club has been broken, pundits are predicting an uncertain future for both of them.

Don't believe a word of it. O'Neill will love the challenge of managing Celtic, and he's got enough ability and personality to succeed where John Barnes and countless others have failed. And his skilful handling of the boardroom bust-ups at Leicester will equip him for the Vatican-like skulduggery that occurs behind the scenes at Parkhead.

I also predict that Leicester, despite their fans' understandable fears that they will 'do a Wimbledon' after losing their talismanic manager, will comfortably avoid relegation from next season's Premiership - providing they choose the right man.

That's easier said than done. Because a lot of big names have already been banded about for the vacant position at Filbert Street, including Danny Wilson, Roy Evans, Trevor Francis, Peter Taylor and Joe Kinnear.

But if the club has any sense they will strike the first three off their list immediately. Danny Wilson and Roy Evans are two of the nicest men in the game, but their managerial reputations lie in tatters.

And the record of Trevor Francis isn't much better. During his time at QPR, Sheffield Wednesday and Birmingham, he's always promised more than he's delivered, while his notoriously prickly man-management skills (remember his treatment of Martin Allen at QPR?) won't go down well in the close-knit Filbert Street dressing room.

That means the choice comes down to two people: Peter Taylor or Joe Kinnear.

In many ways Taylor is in a similar position that O'Neill was five years ago. After a rocky spell at Southend, he's shown, both as England U-21 coach - where he got the team to the 2000 Euro finals with a 100% record - and as Gillingham manager, that he's one of the brightest young managers in the game.

And there's no doubt within football that he will get his chance with a Premiership club. It's just a question of when - and whether Leicester at this moment in time are the right club for him.

Because if the rumours about the uncertain futures of Matt Elliot, Muzzy Izzet and Neil Lennon are all true, the new manager is going to need an experienced head to steady an rocky ship.

That's why Leicester will play it safe and choose former Wimbledon manager Joe Kinnear. Before he was shabbily released by the South London club he worked miracles - somehow managing to get the best out of average players year after year, somehow managing to produce cup run after cup run, and always defying the critics who predicted that Wimbledon were doomed to relegation.

Remind you of anyone you know?
fields.bodyText: Four successive top-ten finishes in the Premiership, two Worthington Cup triumphs and a proven record of transforming reserves and rejects into top-quality players. Whatever way you look at it, Martin O'Neill's record at Leicester is extraordinary. And it becomes more extraordinary still when you remember that during his four-and-a-half years at Filbert Street he won the same number of trophies as Arsène Wenger (in roughly the same time period) - and more than Roy Evans, Ron Atkinson and George Graham put together. So it's understandable that now the symbiotic relationship between the manic Ulsterman and the east Midlands club has been broken, pundits are predicting an uncertain future for both of them. Don't believe a word of it. O'Neill will love the challenge of managing Celtic, and he's got enough ability and personality to succeed where John Barnes and countless others have failed. And his skilful handling of the boardroom bust-ups at Leicester will equip him for the Vatican-like skulduggery that occurs behind the scenes at Parkhead. I also predict that Leicester, despite their fans' understandable fears that they will 'do a Wimbledon' after losing their talismanic manager, will comfortably avoid relegation from next season's Premiership - providing they choose the right man. That's easier said than done. Because a lot of big names have already been banded about for the vacant position at Filbert Street, including Danny Wilson, Roy Evans, Trevor Francis, Peter Taylor and Joe Kinnear. But if the club has any sense they will strike the first three off their list immediately. Danny Wilson and Roy Evans are two of the nicest men in the game, but their managerial reputations lie in tatters. And the record of Trevor Francis isn't much better. During his time at QPR, Sheffield Wednesday and Birmingham, he's always promised more than he's delivered, while his notoriously prickly man-management skills (remember his treatment of Martin Allen at QPR?) won't go down well in the close-knit Filbert Street dressing room. That means the choice comes down to two people: Peter Taylor or Joe Kinnear. In many ways Taylor is in a similar position that O'Neill was five years ago. After a rocky spell at Southend, he's shown, both as England U-21 coach - where he got the team to the 2000 Euro finals with a 100% record - and as Gillingham manager, that he's one of the brightest young managers in the game. And there's no doubt within football that he will get his chance with a Premiership club. It's just a question of when - and whether Leicester at this moment in time are the right club for him. Because if the rumours about the uncertain futures of Matt Elliot, Muzzy Izzet and Neil Lennon are all true, the new manager is going to need an experienced head to steady an rocky ship. That's why Leicester will play it safe and choose former Wimbledon manager Joe Kinnear. Before he was shabbily released by the South London club he worked miracles - somehow managing to get the best out of average players year after year, somehow managing to produce cup run after cup run, and always defying the critics who predicted that Wimbledon were doomed to relegation. Remind you of anyone you know?

webTitle: Mandelson rounds on DUP over disruption plan

fields.headline: Mandelson rounds on DUP over disruption plan
fields.trailText: The hardline Democratic Unionist party, led by the Reverend Ian Paisley, was yesterday criticised for its attempts to bring down the Good Friday agreement from within the Stormont executive.
fields.body:
The hardline Democratic Unionist party, led by the Reverend Ian Paisley, was yesterday criticised for its attempts to bring down the Good Friday agreement from within the Stormont executive.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, said the DUP's plan to disrupt the province's newly-restored power-sharing executive was futile.

"Opposition for opposition's sake gets absolutely nowhere," he said. "People who voted for the DUP should be properly represented by the DUP."

The DUP yesterday unveiled its plan to frustrate the work of the reformed executive.

Peter Robinson and Nigel Dodds will return as ministers for regional development and social development, but will refuse to sit in the executive and will resign when the DUP fails in an attempt to have Sinn Fein thrown out.

But instead of allowing the posts to be filled by the pro-agreement Ulster Unionists and Alliance party, the DUP will rotate them through its assembly members.

The plans were attacked by various members of the executive, including first minister, David Trimble, and his deputy Seamus Mallon. Mr Trimble accused the DUP of "playing games".

Mr Mallon said: "I can assure you we will not allow this political party to play Russian roulette with their departments and with the political process."

webTitle: Ill health makes Plaid leader quit

fields.headline: Ill health makes Plaid leader quit
fields.trailText: June 1 2000: Colleagues and political opponents yesterday paid tribute to the Plaid Cymru leader Dafydd Wigley after he decided to stand down as president of the party he steered to stunning success in last year's national assembly elections in Wales.
fields.body:
Colleagues and political opponents yesterday paid tribute to the Plaid Cymru leader Dafydd Wigley after he decided to stand down as president of the party he steered to stunning success in last year's national assembly elections in Wales.

The long serving Caernarfon MP, who received treatment for a heart condition last Christmas, is giving up the post on medical advice.

He has also decided to step down as leader of the 17-strong group in the assembly where Plaid Cymru forms the main opposition to the minority Labour administration. He will remain in the post until the new party president has been elected in July.

Party members, who had hoped to persuade Mr Wigley to consider alternative ways of easing the burden on his health, accepted his decision reluctantly following an emotional meeting in Llandudno yesterday.

Mr Wigley, 57, was elected MP for Caernarfon in February 1974 and has been president of the party since 1991.

During his presidency the party's support at the polls has soared from 8% to 30% last May when Plaid Cymru snatched several traditional Labour heartland constituencies in the assembly elections.

Plaid Cymru chairman Marc Phillips said the party's debt to Mr Wigley was incalculable. He said there could scarcely be another party that had benefited as much from the vision and energy of one man.

Describing the Plaid Cymru leader as a politician for whom he had the utmost respect the first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, said Mr Wigley had made a major contribution to Welsh politics.

"I am sure he will continue to play a constructive part in the devolution story."

The former Welsh secretary, Ron Davies, who worked closely with Mr Wigley during the referendum campaign that led to devolution, said the Plaid Cymru leader had done much to bring status and credibility to the assembly.

"He brought a degree of authority to his group and led his party to a historic high water mark.

His contribution has been very significant. He is highly regarded in Wales and very well respected across the party politcal divide."

Nominations to replace Mr Wigley as president have to be submitted by June 30 and voting will take place on the basis of one member one vote at branch meetings between July 20 and 30.

Among the front runners to replace him will be Ieuan Wyn Jones the Ynys Mon MP who led Plaid Cymru in the assembly while Mr Wigley was convalescing after Christmas.

fields.headline: O'Neill confirmed as Celtic manager
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill was tonight named Celtic's new manager after the news was confirmed by the Stock Exchange.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill was tonight named Celtic's new manager after the news was confirmed by the Stock Exchange.

O'Neill's decision ends day of speculation and is a blow for Leicester chairman John Elsom, who was hoping to persuade O'Neill to stay at Filbert Street.

More to follow.

fields.headline: Weblife: cyber greetings
fields.standfirst: Why send an email alone? asks  Suzi Pritchard, when you can send so much more
fields.trailText: Why send an email alone? asks Suzi Pritchard, when you can send so much more
fields.body:
My learning-disabled sister, Marcy, is a keen surfer and fan of electronic or virtual greeting cards. She's a sociable person who sends a constant stream of birthday, holiday and "hi there" cards from her home in Florida to friends and family across the world, and I am one of the lucky recipients.

Cybergreetings are big business in the United States. An Infoseek search showed more than 2 million cards sites, catering for every conceivable sentiment and holiday. Hallmark's Online Card shop is currently offering cards for father's day, graduation day and memorial day, while egreetings.com reminds us that in the US national tea month and national fishing week are coming up.

In the past year, I have seen cybercards progress from illustrations or simple, silent animations to 120 second extravaganzas with specially recorded soundtracks needing Media Player and Flash downloads to enjoy them properly. Many of these are free and you can also send postcards, interactive games, I Ching readings, horoscopes and virtual gifts.

Blue Mountain.com, the largest and most visited card site on the web became the target of a virus hoax last year. The hoaxer claimed that customers could be infected by sending or opening a Blue Mountain card, which is a complete impossibility. Online success can breed envy and ugly business tactics.

The site was started four years ago to publicise Blue Mountain's paper cards; it now sells gifts, flowers, chocolates, gourmet foods and virtual gifts, as do many others. The free ecards are a potent draw for visitors.

Once on site, you can choose your category - and there are dozens of them - pick a card and personalise it, adding names, messages, stamps, colours and fonts which the software integrates into the format. The cards are emailed to the recipient as a hot link which he or she can click on to see the card.

Another free site, E-cards.com specialises in animal and artist designed cards; it makes a donation to the World Wild Life Fund for every card sent and also functions as a virtual gallery for the artists. Cards are free since advertising and sponsorship pays online and site costs.

Greeting Cards.com will send "free" cards if you fill out a membership form and suffer the resulting advertisements. For $1.45 (approximately £1) paid by credit card, you can take a card "home" with you and send it as many times as you wish, although it can be customised only once.

Its sister site, Zing, specialises in photo cards and has software facilities for users to upload and customise their own photos, integrating them into card formats.

The variety of sites and cards ranges from the excruciatingly sweet Hugs Place http://members.aol.com/penny2849/hugs.html which sends "virtual hugs and kisses" to your recipients, to the raunchiest of adult sites.

All~4~Free is an excellent directory that lists more than 6,000 card sites connected by hot links and divided into useful categories.

But if you want to make your own e-cards to send as attachments, there are publishing kits like Sierra Print Artists Plus (£14.99 www.sierrahome.co.uk). The more sophisticated Microsoft Home Publishing 2000 package which has a section for making and sending e-cards and other web projects. (£29.99-£69.99 www.Home-Publishing.com).

These kits are an electronic version of the childhood collage technique, cutting bits out of magazines and pasting them on paper. Of course, they are complex and sophisticated, offering hundreds of fonts and colours plus thousands of graphics. But they are great fun and easy to use, once you've mastered the basics.

For those who really get into card design, All~4~free helps potential e-retailers by providing a free online course, Greeting Cards 101 which gives all the information and links needed to set up your own online card business. They also host a graphics vault and other design services.

This is an area crying out to be developed by UK companies and designers. The Americans dominate the market but their products are too sentimental and too saccharine for British tastes and are oriented to American holidays.

With a few honourable exceptions, such as Giftstore and Wicked Moon, there are almost no well run, innovative UK sites.

At Hallmark or Blue Mountain, fierce competition has forced designers to create something approaching a new artform - fine art animations and mini films that can be saved and savoured. This is a developmental forum that has no parallel in this country despite the UK's reputation for producing world class designers and animators.

No central body or design council, no art school seems to have noticed and filled this gap in the global market. Perhaps I should send our prime minister a "Let's do something about this" card. I can probably get one at BlueMountain.com.

webTitle: The way for Hague to play it

fields.headline: The way for Hague to play it
fields.standfirst: We don't want every monocle-wearer harrumphing out of the woodwork, to show how ghastly we Tories can be
fields.trailText: We don't want every monocle-wearer harrumphing out of the woodwork, to show how ghastly we Tories can be.
fields.body:
The tantrums being thrown by all sides over Oxford University's alleged elitism should be viewed with wry amusement by the Tories. After all, this is the same university that denied Mrs Thatcher her honorary degree in the mid-80s. The reason was nothing more than good old-fashioned snobbery. The grocer's daughter was not one of them - a chemist and a woman to boot. And of course, the chorus of support wafting from the dreaming spires for Tory policies over the past 20 years was, well, non-existent.

Nevertheless, it behoves all good Tories to view the current spat with a cool temperament, and to avoid following the chancellor of the exchequer in with the boot. After all, Oxford is the victim of a sustained campaign of lies and distortion, half-truth and embellishment. It is our duty as an opposition to stand up for the truth and to point the finger at the guilty men. It is pretty clear where this campaign is going, and it is time we nipped it in the bud.

Huge efforts are made by Oxford to encourage state school pupils to apply, from the abolition of entrance exams to the target schools programmes. If more did apply, more would get places. Further, to class all independent school pupils as little Lord Fauntleroys is simply wrong. Many of the pupils at independent schools who are applying to university at the moment were on assisted places until this government abolished them. Many are at schools where the fees are relatively modest and where parents save every spare penny they can to send their children there. Many are on scholarships or bursaries provided by the schools themselves.

Any examination of the facts, then, would reveal that there is relatively little discrimination against state school pupils in our top universities, and enormous efforts being made to encourage them to apply. It is also worth noting that under 20 years of Conservative government, the proportion going on to higher education rose from just one in eight to almost one in three, and polytechnics became full universities. In a row about the democratisation of higher education, the Tories need no lessons from Labour.

But this is not what the row is about, in any event. Gordon Brown is not interested in getting Laura Spence or anyone else a place at Oxford. He wants two things. First, a reprise of the old "forces of conservatism" row last autumn, when every monocle-sporting, jodhpur-wearing, sherry-drinking Tory came harrumphing out of the woodwork to remind people how ghastly we can be. So far, thankfully, we have resisted this temptation, though there are worrying signs we could become more vocal.

It is Brown's and Labour's long-cherished desire to abolish independent schools. The wholesale destruction of our education system has long been Labour's project, based on a mixture of motives including cod educational trends and infantile class envy. The argument is that the brightest and the best of our pupils are siphoned off into bastions of privilege and learning and given a first-class education denied to the people. The answer is simply to abolish independent schools, so that everyone mixes together, all class divisions are abolished and education standards rocket up for everyone.

Of course this is cloud cuckoo land, but one can see how a party that is used to appropriating private property and implementing plans for most aspects of our daily lives comes back to this solution again and again. But what Labour discovered when Harold Wilson set up the public schools commission is that many independent schools are very, very good. Not because of wealth and privilege, but because of ethos and standards.

A good school succeeds for many reasons. It is a combination of a good head, a motivated teaching staff, engaged parents, and numerous other factors. But what sets independent schools apart, and what has seen some state schools succeed against the odds, is a feeling that the school is in charge of its own destiny. If you had visited some of the early grant-maintained schools in some of the most deprived inner-cities, you would have seen a school transformed, no, not by money, but by the head and teachers knowing that their decisions affected their destiny.

Labour has run state education for the past 30 years, in councils up and down the land. The current row over access to university stands as a shaming indictment of everything the left in this country stands for. William Hague would do well to avoid being sucked too closely into further defences of Oxford University or elitism. Rather, he would do well to read out a charge sheet against the Labour party for what they have done to our schools. He should propose a new Tory manifesto. The abolition of local education authorities. The return of schools to their heads and teachers. Somehow, a way of emasculating the NUT, which has utterly destroyed teachers' public image. And the return of assisted places to resume the democratisation of our independent schools. That would be a classy response to a low-class campaign.

Ed Vaizey was a Conservative candidate at the last general election.

The answer is simply to abolish independent schools, so that everyone mixes together, all class divisions are abolished and education standards rocket up for everyone. Of course this is cloud cuckoo land, but one can see how a party that is used to appropriating private property and implementing plans for most aspects of our daily lives comes back to this solution again and again. But what Labour discovered when Harold Wilson set up the public schools commission is that many independent schools are very, very good. Not because of wealth and privilege, but because of ethos and standards. A good school succeeds for many reasons. It is a combination of a good head, a motivated teaching staff, engaged parents, and numerous other factors. But what sets independent schools apart, and what has seen some state schools succeed against the odds, is a feeling that the school is in charge of its own destiny. If you had visited some of the early grant-maintained schools in some of the most deprived inner-cities, you would have seen a school transformed, no, not by money, but by the head and teachers knowing that their decisions affected their destiny. Labour has run state education for the past 30 years, in councils up and down the land. The current row over access to university stands as a shaming indictment of everything the left in this country stands for. William Hague would do well to avoid being sucked too closely into further defences of Oxford University or elitism. Rather, he would do well to read out a charge sheet against the Labour party for what they have done to our schools. He should propose a new Tory manifesto. The abolition of local education authorities. The return of schools to their heads and teachers. Somehow, a way of emasculating the NUT, which has utterly destroyed teachers' public image. And the return of assisted places to resume the democratisation of our independent schools. That would be a classy response to a low-class campaign. fields.headline: Michelangelo Antonioni: Passenger
fields.trailText: Antonioni is known for his capacity to express alienation visually. The Passenger does that... The comparison has to be with painting, but also with a novelist's ability to describe both a scene and a state of mind. If Antonioni is not particularly fashionable now, that's our loss, not his
fields.body:
It was once said that one admires Michelangelo Antonioni's films without feeling fond of them; or one resists them, turning a blind eye to their beauty. It has also been said that his films teach us to see as we've never seen before. There's an element of truth in these statements, particularly as far as his great trilogy of L'Avventura, La Notte and L'Eclisse are concerned.

These remarkable works, made in the early 60s, are deeply pessimistic love stories. They are disorientating because conventional narrative is always avoided and it often seems that nothing whatever is happening except within the minds, or possibly the confused souls, of the participants.

Jeanne Moreau, who starred with Marcello Mastroianni as the loveless couple in La Notte, once said to me: "God, I was bored. But you can't argue with Antonioni. He never replies." Even so, the three films are revolutionary in form, eloquent in content and can affect you deeply. Is he the Henry James of film-making?

It's unorthodox to prefer the far later Passenger and the fact I do probably says more about me than about the film (its alternative title is Profession: Reporter). But it too is a remarkable work and a major return to form after the incoherent, shallow Zabriskie Point. It is a bit like a heavily intellectualised Graham Greene story, partly because of its screenplay, by Mark Peploe and structuralist critic Peter Wollen (who was once a political correspondent in foreign parts) and partly because Antonioni was concerned with spiritual values. Jack Nicholson plays a burnt-out reporter who exchanges his identity with that of a man he finds dead in a North African hotel room. He does this to get away from the mess of his old life but discovers he is being haunted not only by a wife and friends who go in search of him but by strangers who are not going to do him any good. He starts a relationship with a younger woman (played by Maria Schneider) but the further he goes to escape his previous life, the worse the situation becomes. He ends up sharing the same fate as the man whose mask he has taken.

The film is beautifully shot by Luciano Tovoli in France, Spain and North Africa and intimates as much about the contemporary political situation as it does about the state of its protagonist's mind. It also contains several amazing sequences, including a seven-minute take that has seldom been equalled - a shot that passes through the narrow bars of a window to frame Nicholson, moves into a courtyard then moves back to look through the bars again. The first time we see Nicholson, he is alive. The second time he is dead. Curiously, at one point in the film, Schneider finds a gun in Nicholson's luggage and he takes it from her with a gruff "No." It fits the film, but it also fits the fact that Schneider shot Marlon Brando in Last Tango, the film that made her famous. One dead star is perhaps enough for one so young.

Antonioni is known for his capacity to express alienation visually. The Passenger does that, as does Blow-Up and the aforementioned trilogy. The comparison has to be with painting, but also with a novelist's ability to describe both a scene and a state of mind. If Antonioni is not particularly fashionable now, that's our loss, not his.

fields.headline: Critics have no power - Honest
fields.standfirst:
As Dave Stewart's Brit-flick Honest bombs at the box-office, the director has been blaming the media for its failure. Film critic Xan Brooks defends his profession.

Honest, this All Saints movie is a total flop
fields.trailText: As Dave Stewart's Brit-flick Honest bombs at the box-office, the director has been blaming the media for its failure. Film-critic Xan Brooks defends his profession.
fields.body:
Spare a thought for poor Dave Stewart, the multi-millionaire musician, showbiz impressario and sometime film-maker. Here's Stewart's problem in a nutshell: he's just directed a flat-out dreadful movie, and the punters don't want to see it. In its opening weekend, Honest (starring three members of All Saints) averaged a paltry £500 per cinema. Last Saturday, no more than five people showed up for a screening at a vast venue in Leicester Square.

Some might regard the development as a heartening display of good taste on the part of the great British public. Others might reflect that the film itself is fatally misconceived (its 18-certificate excludes the core All Saints market). Stewart, though, has a different conclusion. Throughout the whole farrago, he has been scathing in his attack on the British press. In Stewart's mind it was the critics what done it, the cynical media what killed his baby.

All of which is quite exciting. Speaking as one of that number, I rather like the perception of myself as some all-powerful bully. I get off on the idea of a gang of hulking critics, bunking off class, strutting through the media playground and aggressively bundling any stray millionaire film-maker we take a dislike to. "Sorry sir, we didn't mean to nick Dave's packed lunch and chuck it on the roof - we were just having a larf. Honest."

Unfortunately, this is just a pipe-dream: beguiling but bogus. In my brief apprenticeship writing about movies I have never been entirely convinced that film critics have any impact whatsoever on subsequent box-office performance. If Honest had been greeted with rave reviews, maybe there would have been 10 people in that Leicester Square cinema instead of five. But the critics' influence would still have been negligible, stuck someplace behind the lure of big stars, hefty marketing campaigns and word of mouth. In the end, nobody is quite sure what makes a film a hit. Some movies strike a chord with audiences, and some (as Dave could tell you) don't.

Just look at the biggest hit of last year. The Phantom Menace was released to an almost uniform raspberry of bad notices but still racked up receipts that have run into the hundreds of millions of dollars. Mission: Impossible 2 has just leapt to the top of the American box-office while the ink was still wet on the (generally duff) reviews. At the time of Star Wars 1977 release, the critic John Powers remarked that it was "as exciting as last year's weather reports", while Time Out said that ET was "as vulgar as a Brooke Bond TV chimps commercial". Both films are now safely ensconced in the all-time box-office top ten. True, reviewers may have some sway over the more limited releases (boosting Almodovar's All About My Mother, perhaps, or hampering the recent Rancid Aluminium), but put them up against the big-hitters and they're like a mosquito worrying an elephant. Honest, significantly, was touted as a mainstream movie. It had a big release, a slew of cash behind it (witness the Cannes promotional bash) and it is now dying a desultory death. But it wasn't the critics that killed it.

So why do they do it, these powerless critics who routinely find their lofty verdicts ignored by their readership? Well, perhaps it has something to do with the simple pleasure of writing about film. Or perhaps it's about getting up the noses of men like Dave Stewart. Both impulses, certainly, have a lot to be said for them.

webTitle: Dissident republicans suspected in Hammersmith bombing

fields.headline: Dissident republicans suspected in Hammersmith bombing
fields.trailText: Republicans opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process have emerged as the chief suspects behind the early morning explosion at Hammersmith Bridge in London.
fields.body:
Republicans opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process have emerged as the chief suspects behind the early morning explosion at Hammersmith Bridge in London.

No group claimed responsibility for the attack, which caused only slight damage and no injuries. But suspicion immediately fell on dissident IRA members, who have a history of setting off small blasts at key stages in the peace process to embarrass Sinn Fein republicans whom they regard as traitors for joining the new devolved government.

Police say a high-explosive device attached to a girder under the south side of Hammersmith Bridge detonated at around 4.30 this morning.

After the explosion, the area near the busy junction of the A4 at Chiswick was sealed off, severely disrupting traffic.

"It must always be remembered that there are minority republican terrorist movements who are still on the ground, still potentially active," John Taylor, deputy leader of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP) said. The blast came hours before Northern Ireland's power-sharing government held its first cabinet meeting since devolved government resumed on Tuesday.

Westminster restored home rule after the IRA agreed to open its arms dumps for international inspection. On Saturday, UUP leader David Trimble won the backing of his party's ruling council to return to the power-sharing arrangement set up by the Good Friday accord.

Sinn Fein assembly member Gerard Kelly said he had no idea whether the Hammersmith bomb was linked to events in Ulster.

"I don't wish to add to the speculation. I don't know who planted the bomb or if it was connected to Ireland. If it was connected to what is happening in Ireland, then it is detrimental to the peace process," he said.

Terrorism experts suspect the attack was most probably the work of the Real/Continuity IRA, which broke from the Provisionals three years ago.

"Although they use two names in terms of personnel, they are essentially the same group," said David George, who lectures on terrorism at Newcastle University. "This is the first time they have managed to carry out an attack on the mainland. I am sure this is a big boost to them internally, particularly as they suffered several major reversals at the end of last year."

The group was founded in 1997 by the Provisional IRA's quartermaster who walked out over their peace process strategy.

"He not only had control over of the IRA arms dumps, but took with him several local quartermasters," Mr George said. "They had very good control over the dumps and although taking stuff out is a capital offence for the IRA, it is thought they did remove weapons and explosives."

fields.headline: Bomb explodes on Hammersmith bridge
fields.trailText: Anti-terrorist police are examining Hammersmith bridge after a small bomb exploded on the south side of the bridge at 4.30am this morning.
fields.body:
Anti-terrorist police are examining Hammersmith bridge after a small bomb exploded on the south side of the bridge at 4.30am this morning.

No one was hurt in the explosion and no group has yet claimed responsibility, police said. Motorists faced lengthy delays as the bridge and the nearby A4 flyover remained closed.

Alan Fry, head of Scotland Yard's Anti-Terrorist Branch, said it was "too early to speculate" on who planted the bomb.

Today's explosion follows a series of attacks in Northern Ireland this year believed to be the work of the Real IRA, the group which bombed Omagh in August 1998 killing 29 people, and the Continuity IRA.

But if dissident Republicans were involved, it would be the first time they would have launched an attack in mainland Britain.

The IRA made a bombing attempt on the bridge during its London bombing campaign four years ago. Two Semtex bombs were discovered at a substation, under a walkway on the south side of the river, in April 1996.

Adrian Larkman, who lives in nearby Angel Walk, heard today's blast.

"I work nights and I was cooking when there was a loud bang. The windows of my house shook. I dialled 999 and I was apparently the first person to call," he said.

"I put my boots on and went outside five minutes later and there were already policemen there. I asked what was going on and they said there had been an explosion on the south side of the bridge and they were checking whether there could be a second device," said Mr Larkman.

Belinda Coates, a barmaid living at the Blue Anchor pub next to the bridge, said eight people staying there had been woken by the blast.

"It was pretty loud," said Ms Coates. "It does worry me because I am away from home and it was very close and pretty loud.

"It is all shut off around here, police are preparing to abseil down the side of the bridge and the bomb squad are outside the front door."

Hammersmith bridge reopened last December after being shut for almost three years for repairs. Emergency work to strengthen the bridge's hangers and overhaul steel supports began in February 1997.

But the £3.5m repair project on the bridge, which is more than 110 years old, was delayed last year when it was discovered that the wrong type of steel plates had been ordered.

 Police have asked witnesses to phone 0800 789 321.

fields.headline: Meet the real Sergei Rebrov
fields.standfirst: Click here to hear Rebrov's first interview in England.
fields.trailText: Spurs' record £11m signing Sergei Rebrov is a lover of whodunnit novels, a fanatical radio ham and - according to the Ukrainian public - a better goal scorer than Andrei Shevchenko, Football Unlimited can exclusively reveal today.
fields.body:
Spurs' record £11m signing Sergei Rebrov is a lover of whodunnit novels, a fanatical radio ham and - according to the Ukrainian public - a better goal scorer than Andrei Shevchenko, Football Unlimited can exclusively reveal today.

During a press conference at White Hart Lane this afternoon, Rebrov showed his English is improving rapidly and repeated his desire to play for Tottenham in the Premiership - but he gave very little else away.

So Football Unlimited spoke to top Ukrainian journalist Fidel Pavlenko, who works for the BBC's World Service and knows Rebrov well, to find out more about Spurs' new signing.

"In Ukraine most people think Rebrov is a better goalscorer than Shevchenko," Pavlenko told us. "He's scored more goals for Kiev, more goals for the Ukrainian national side and more goals in the Champions League than Shevchenko.

"He is also not just a striker. He can play anywhere from midfielder to straight centre-forward, and although he is only a small man, he is great in the air. In fact half his goals are from headers - and in Ukraine he is considered the best header of the ball in the League. He has two good feet too," he added.

According to Pavlenko, Rebrov is a serious, level-headed family man. "He was married last year and he has a son," he says. "He's not a drinker, he's not a nightclubber and he isn't a dancer. But he is very serious about football.

"He is also very serious about amateur radio. He's got state-of-the-art radio transmission equipment and he spends all his time using Morse code to communicate with random people across the world," Pavlenko claims. "While he was at Kiev he managed to persuade the president to install equipment worth thousands of pounds in the club hotel. And he's already applied for his radio licence in the UK - because he doesn't want to interfere with police radios."

When he's not being a radio ham, Rebrov also likes Ukrainian pop-music and reading novels - especially old Russian classics like Dostoevsky and modern whodunnit thrillers like Agatha Christie.

But Pavlenko does have doubts about how quickly Rebrov will settle in London. "I'm not sure whether he'll be able to produce the goods straight away - it might take him a few months to settle. Take Luzhny at Arsenal, for example, who found moving to England a huge cultural shock and failed to establish himself in the first team."

And Pavlenko isn't convinced that Spurs is the right club for Rebrov either. "Frankly it's a step down," he says. "Back in Ukraine people think he deserved something bigger. He's been involved in European football for the past seven or eight years and now he's ended up at Spurs.

"However Tottenham were persistent. Pleat travelled to Ukraine, brought him to the club and persuaded him they have ambition and it obviously did the trick. But the reputed £2m signing-on fee and £24,000-a-week wages probably helped."

webTitle: Mowlam targets race bias in public services

fields.headline: Mowlam targets race bias in public services
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: One person in six among the ethnic minority population feels discriminated against by the public services, the Cabinet Office minister Mo Mowlam will reveal today as part of the government's "opportunities for all" campaign.
fields.body:
One person in six among the ethnic minority population feels discriminated against by the public services, the Cabinet Office minister Mo Mowlam will reveal today as part of the government's "opportunities for all" campaign.

"Sometimes it's down to rudeness, to being ignored or badly served. In a quarter of cases, it involves verbal racial abuse. Whatever the reason, there is no excuse and there can be no place for it if we are to build a genuinely fair and enterprising society," she will tell a Westminster conference to promote equality of opportunity.

Ms Mowlam's statistics have emerged from a sub-group of the government's 3,000 strong people's panel, a cross section of citizens picked by the Mori polling organisation and the University of Birmingham to test opinions.

The sub-panel, 500 people representing diverse ethnic minority groups and opinions, was asked to report on how its members felt treated by the state. Ministers are falling over themselves to admit they have still not done enough to get minority groups properly represented in officialdom, especially at the top end. The survey covers schools, the NHS, employment, benefits and other points of contact between officialdom and voters.

fields.trailText: ANDY FOR SOME
fields.body:
ANDY FOR SOME

It was like listening to a pack of hyenas who'd found the back door into McDonalds. The assembled ranks of the press had just been informed by England coach Kelvin Koogan that Andy Cole would not be going to Euro 2000. It was an injury to the top of the Manchester United striker's foot that stopped him from travelling, Koogan said. He was too much of a risk. That's what you say, responded the horde while sharpening their teeth with nail files. No, I tell the truth, Koogan said. The room erupted in vicious laughter.

It seemed that nobody believed poor Koogan when he said he and Cole hadn't fallen out. And, going by Cole's track record, it wasn't going be long before he laid into his former club boss in a soaraway tabloid. But, to the surprise of everyone, Cole spoke out this afternoon instead. "I had a meeting with [Kelvin Koogan] yesterday afternoon to discuss the situation regarding my foot," he said, sounding like an ailing pensioner. "We both agreed the risk of not being able to perform fully in such an important tournament was too great a risk to take."

But surely there must have been some sort of row somewhere? A little bit of jostling in the Bisham Abbey laundry room? Or at least a spot of spitting in the isotonic porridge? Apparently not. "A lot has been made of my position within the England camp," Cole said. "Some have also intimated that an argument took place and I consequently walked out on the England camp. Nothing could be further from the truth." The Fiver refuses to believe that for a second - it's more than our job's worth.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MAKE YOUR &£!*ING MIND UP TIME

Alright Martin O'Neill, your time is up. You were supposed to have left Leicester for Leeds in 1998. But you didn't (although a dodgy pair of bifocals convinced the Fiver for six months that you had). Then, last summer, you were supposed to take the Nottingham Forest job, then the Northern Ireland job. But you didn't. Now you're supposed to be definitely off to Celtic. But you might not. And to be quite frank, we've had enough.

Another uneventful day has passed in the O'Neill transfer saga (perhaps Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink is acting as his agent). Many people expected an announcement by Celtic before the markets opened this morning. But the Fiver spoke to Barry at the fishmonger's stall and he said he didn't see anything. The local Leicester press then reckoned that Celtic would announce the move this afternoon, but Celtic themselves told the Fiver they had nothing planned (we almost asked them out for a drink as a result).

For what it's worth, the Fiver still expects that, by this time tomorrow, O'Neill will be strapped down to the second-hottest seat in Scottish football. But there's nothing more embarrassing than constantly having to change your mind. So, just in case, the Fiver can exclusively reveal that Martin O'Neill/Peter Taylor/Tommy Burns has decided to leave/join/stay on at Leicester/Celtic/AC Milan and told the press this morning that he is "delighted/gutted/hung over". There, that should do it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTES OF THE DAY

"I'd throw Phillips of Sunderland in with Shearer. He's a natural and he'll dip his bread at any level" - Brian Clough, living legend.

"I met him recently up at Sunderland. He smiled, called me 'Mr Clough', so he's got some brains. Unlike Beckham" - Brian Clough, one of a kind.

"Mind you, being thick isn't an affliction if you're a footballer. And Beckham works hard, he's brave and he crosses a ball superbly. Beckham treats a football like he does a wife - lovingly, with caresses" - Brian Clough. Hey, BBC Sport, need a new pundit?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DOWN WITH PAUL DURKIN, YOU'RE GOING DOWN WITH PAUL DURKIN

Now the Premiership is officially competition-free and boring, we'll be needing something else to while away the dull months between August and May. So thank God that the Premiership powers-that-be have decided to introduce a system in which referees can be relegated if they're useless. Tee hee!

The idea behind this excellent idea is simple. Lower-league nit-pickers who are proving themselves to be particularly irritating and tiresome (or "doing well" as it says here) will now have a chance to move up the divisions. At the same time Premiership referees will only be guaranteed three months of top-flight action per season. Come November, if a Premref hasn't had at least 5,600 column inches devoted to his being chased by an unhappy Irishman with a pulsating head, he'll be turning out in the Ryman league quicker than you can say Terry Burton.

Of course, the Fiver would rather concentrate on the positive side of this new measure which, according to FA head of refereeing John Baker, will "help everyone concerned to maintain the highest standards of refereering across the whole of the professional game." The Fiver wishes everyone well, but sees one potential flaw in the plan: does anybody really want to witness David Elleray sinking to his knees and breaking down in tears at the final whistle?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Juventus plan to tempt Arsenal into selling Patrick Vieira by making a £14m offer within the next week. Carlo Ancelotti wants to pair Vieira, tipped as the next Arsenal captain, with Edgar Davids in the Juve midfield.

Lorenzo Amoruso could leave Rangers for Sunderland. "I've known about Sunderland's interest for about a month now," the Italian said today. Rangers are expected to tie up the £4m signing of his replacement, Dutch defender Bert Konterman, by the end of the week.

Both Chelsea and Arsenal have sent representatives to watch Dutch striker Anthony Lurling in the current U-21 tournament in Slovakia. Lurling, 23, plays his club football for Heerenveen.

Manchester United are thought to be ready to offer a two-year contract to Laurent Blanc. The Lord Imperial Ferg wants the 34-year-old to partner Jaap Stam while the champions wait for Sol Campbell's contract to expire at Tottenham.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has been left out of Holland's Euro 2000 squad. Frank Rijkaard has chosen Feyenoord's former Rangers striker Peter van Vossen instead.

Blackburn have signed Manchester United defender John Curtis for £1.5m. The 22-year-old full-back has just completed a successful loan spell at Barnsley. "He is a boy we feel can only get better," said Graeme Souness.

Mark Bosnich says he will only leave Manchester United if the club grant him a free transfer, despite the arrival of Fabien Barthez. "When Manchester United inform me that I am free to leave under those same terms, I will do so," he said today. "Until such time, I have three years remaining on my contract and I intend to see them out."

Joe Kinnear has admitted he was "minutes away" from becoming Sheffield Wednesday's manager. "The contract was perfect, it was just the programme on the future of the club," Kinnear told the SWFC website. "I appreciate the programme that the club were taking, and I have nothing but the utmost respect, but I just thought that the ideas the club had were not mine and that's where we disagreed. It had to do with finances but any further statement should come from the chairman."

Watford full-back Des Lyttle has joined West Brom on a free transfer.

Fulham midfielder Steve Finnan has withdrawn from the Republic of Ireland squad for the three-match Nike Cup tournament in America.

Oliver Dacourt has formally sealed his £7.2m move to Leeds.

Sergei Rebrov and Neil Sullivan have similarly completed their moves to Tottenham.

Fulham are to play India's national team in a friendly at Craven Cottage on July 22.

Former Atletico Madrid manager Radomir Antic is the new coach of Real Oviedo.

Ayr have bought Dundee strikers Eddie Annand and James Grady.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.30am)
The world likes it, and so do you.

Channel 5: Dutch Football (4.30am)
Roda JC v Kavanagh QC.

Sky Sports 1: International Football - Live (7pm)
England U-21 v Slovakia U-21 in the European U-21 championships, not to be confused with the concurrently-running Toulon U-21 championships.

Fifa TV (11.45pm)
Sepp Blatter and Lennart Johansson reprise the roles of Professor Heinz Wolff and Lesley Judd in The Great Egg Race, a remake of The Great Egg Race.

Sky Sports 3: Six-a-side football - Live (7.30pm, 1am SS1)
Northern Masters. Which is either a cheap pint of low-quality bitter or a load of old Everton and Sunderland players hauling their wobbly bellies around a hard court.

World Cup Classics (10.30pm)
Brazil v Peru in 1970. Doesn't Pele look beautiful?

British Eurosport: Football - Live (7pm)
The Toulon U-21 championships, not the European U-21 championships. Or is it the other way round?

Football (9pm)
The U-21 European Toulon championships. Er...

webTitle: Gate slams on last of the boat people

fields.headline: Gate slams on last of the boat people
fields.standfirst: Camp shuts 25 years after first Vietnamese refugees arrived in Hong Kong
fields.trailText: Hong Kong was yesterday preparing to close its only remaining camp for the last of 200,000 Vietnamese boat people, whose plight once made headline news across the world.
fields.body:
Hong Kong was yesterday preparing to close its only remaining camp for the last of 200,000 Vietnamese boat people, whose plight once made headline news across the world.

Most occupants of the Pillar Point refugee centre have already left, but 200 were fighting to stay put. Some will be allowed to stay past the official closing time to organise their departure, but government officials said they would evict those without satisfactory reasons for remaining behind.

A banner proclaiming "We need a place for living" was draped over the gate, as government officers took over from the Caritas charity which has run the camp.

"We shall have to live on the streets and steal in order to survive," said one angry Vietnamese. Police and fire engines stood by in case of trouble as families trundled past with trolleyloads of possessions in striped cotton bags.

Earlier, the occupants had been warned that they would be regarded as trespassers from midnight and that water and electricity would be cut off.

Most of the camp occupants have been given residency status in Hong Kong. But some, known as ex-China Vietnamese after settling on the mainland before arriving in Hong Kong, will be deported unless they win an ongoing court case.

Some of those who refuse to move claim that Hong Kong's resettlement allowance is not enough and that they have no jobs to go to.

"Most of those left are ineligible for fuller assistance because they have earning power," insisted the Assistant Secretary for Security, Alan Chu. He refused to say whether force would be used to evict the last residents.

Hong Kong has always shown less patience with the boat people than the outside world, partly because of its high number of refugees.

More than 210,000 Vietnamese have reached Hong Kong since the first leaky boat arrived in 1975.

This number was only exceeded by the 250,000 who fled to Malaysia. Thailand received 160,000, and Indonesia slightly less, out of an Asia-wide total of nearly 850,000.

Many of the boat people died on the perilous journey to Hong Kong, while others were raped or thrown overboard by Thai pirates.

In the first years after North Vietnam's 1975 victory against the South, most boat people claimed they were "escaping from communism". But thousands of ethnic Chinese Vietnamese fled the country as Beijing-Hanoi discord led to the 1979 Chinese invasion of Vietnam.

In later years, many were economic migrants tempted by the unusual willingness of many western countries, led by the US, to accept large numbers of so-called refugees.

Nearly half a million were resettled in the west from 1989 to 1996. Many more were allowed to emigrate legally from Vietnam. Hanoi also accepted back more than 100,000 refugees, who are said to have suffered virtually no discrimination on their return.

The 1,200 Vietnamese who were the last inhabitants of Pillar Point are the remnants whom the major resettlement countries in the west have refused to accept. Some have even been denied re-entry by Vietnam because their nationality is unclear.

The UN High Commissioner for Refugees has admitted that "the blanket resettlement of the boat people went on for too long, and was sustained more by political than humanitarian imperatives".

The image of the refugees' plight has been used to help justify American efforts to isolate Vietnam internationally after its victory in the war.

The Hong Kong camps, on islands and in other remote areas, were overcrowded. Inmates were kept behind wire and occupied thinly partitioned living spaces.

There were outbreaks of gang warfare, as well as riots against the "forced repatriation" of those failing to qualify for refugee status. More than 20 died in a camp fire in 1992, and 50 police were injured in a mass breakout in 1996.

Hong Kong's handling of the boat people caused friction between Britain and China before the handover of the territory in 1997. Beijing accused Britain of deliberately leaving behind a problem for the future. Pro-Beijing politicians in Hong Kong were also accused of seeking popularity by stirring up anti-Vietnamese sentiment.

fields.headline: Jesse James
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the Wild West's most famous son on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the Wild West's most famous son on the net.
fields.body:
1. Jesse James may have been alive and kicking in Texas 69 years after the history books say he died.

2. To find out if this is true, researcher Bud Hardcastle and the Wild West outlaw's grandsons will exhume the body of Frank J Dalton, who died in 1951.

3. Dalton claimed to be the famous gunslinger shortly before he died. When local residents carried out a visual post-mortem on the body, they found several bullet holes and rope marks on his neck.

4. According to legend, James was shot by one of his own gang, Robert Ford, in 1882 in St Joseph, Missouri, who wanted to collect a $10,000 reward.

5. Another theory is not that "the town wasn't big enough for the both of them", but that James used Ford to fake his own death so he could get the lawmen off his back.

6. James learned his fighting skills as a guerrilla raider for the Confederates in the American civil war.

7. After the Union won in 1865, James banded together with his brother Frank to form the James gang. They robbed banks until the day Jesse was supposedly killed.

8. The official grave is two miles away from the spot where he died. There are also photographs of him dead.

9. After that, his fame developed through the movies. Films such as Jesse James Under the Black Flag (1921) and The Long Riders (1980) portray him either as a vicious outlaw or a western Robin Hood.

10. Ed Kelly, the man who killed the man who may or may not have killed Jesse James, was himself shot in Oklahoma in 1904 - back in the times when men were real mean.

webTitle: Finally, a Star role for cyber-Murdoch

fields.headline: Finally, a Star role for cyber-Murdoch
fields.standfirst: Harvard drop-out's internet enthusiasm brings surprise reward
fields.trailText: There are few people who could drop out of Harvard while managing a band and still find themselves running a business worth an estimated $15bn by the age of 27. But then there are few in the privileged position of being a member of the Murdoch clan.
fields.byline: David Teather  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
There are few people who could drop out of Harvard while managing a band and still find themselves running a business worth an estimated $15bn by the age of 27. But then there are few in the privileged position of being a member of the Murdoch clan.

James Murdoch, the youngest of Rupert Murdoch's children was yesterday named chief executive and chairman of pan-Asian business Star TV. The appointment is a powerful endorsement of the young executive who once vowed he would never work in his father's shadow and moves him closer to the centre of power in Murdoch senior's sprawling media empire, News Corporation.

Star TV will play a crucial role in Mr Murdoch's attempt to grapple with the internet age. The network reaches 300m people across 53 Asian countries, operates 40 channels and will be a crucial part of Platco, the combination of News Corp's satellite interests which has been given the task of building a global platform for internet access.

James was sent to the region earlier this year to help ready Star TV for its inclusion in Platco and the planned flotation of the combined satellite group. The appointment was initially only temporary but he will now move to Hong Kong from his Manhattan base after the abrupt departure of Star TV's former chief executive, Gareth Chang.

Mr Chang's exit after falling out with Mr Murdoch may prove felicitous for the media mogul, who was stung by the departure of his daughter Elisabeth from the family firm last month. Ms Murdoch had been a senior executive with News Corp's British pay-TV business, BSkyB, and the promotion of her brother will help cement the remainder of the dynasty in place.

For watchers of the Murdoch soap opera the appointment will also be seized upon as evidence that James now presents a serious challenge to elder brother Lachlan in the succession race.

Mr Murdoch recently gave a clear hint that Lachlan, 29, had been chosen as his favoured candidate for an eventual successor although he named his number two, Peter Chernin, as caretaker until his children were ready.

People close to News Corp have noted, however, that James with his easy relationship to the internet has become an increasingly valued adviser to his father. James' appointment could lead to a seat on the board of Platco and ultimately the News Corp inner sanctum, a group of directors whose circle only Lachlan has managed to enter so far.

While Lachlan preferred to work in newspapers, his father's first love, and Elisabeth chose television, James raised eyebrows when he decided to work with the internet. Far from causing him to be marginalised within the News Corp group, however, the choice now looks prescient.

James has always dismissed speculation about any sibling rivalry and has refused to comment on the future for either himself or Lachlan. He usually stresses that he reports to Mr Chernin. He often adds that he feels "lucky" to be where he is.

The two brothers are close. After James opened a four-hour presentation on the company's internet business earlier this month, Lachlan leant over to squeeze his shoulder in a gesture of support.

Analysts credit James' role in founding News Corp's digital media arm - he became president in November 1997 - for yesterday's promotion. The division, housed in a fashionable downtown area of New York, is a relatively small part of the News Corp empire but James was in the right place at the right time when his father expressed a newfound faith in the value of the internet a year ago. His promotion came as little surprise to company observers who noted his involvement in some high-profile deals in recent months such as News Corp's $1bn investment in Healtheon, an online healthcare business.

James' handling of some sensitive issues in recent months in Asia appears to have encouraged company executives to put him in charge permanently.

Star TV faces several important strategic issues. It has lost about $30m a year since News Corp bought it for $850m from Hong Kong-based businessman Richard Li Tzar-kai in 1993.

James has said that the future of Star TV will partly depend on the successful adoption of new interactive services and one of the most difficult parts of his new job will be salvaging Star's links with Cable & Wireless HongKong Telecom. Their joint venture has stuttered since Mr Murdoch lost out in a takeover battle for HKT with Pacific Century CyberWorks.

James' rise at News Corp has been swift and fairly surprising given his early career.

After quitting Harvard where he was studying history and film, the chain-smoking youngest son set up his own music label. Rawkus Entertainment was making a small profit on revenues of US$2.5m when it was bought by News Corp in 1998.

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ...a toast rack
fields.trailText: ...a toast rack
fields.body:
It's the most important meal of the day. As you shuffle around in your dressing gown, sniffing the milk to see if it's off, you suddenly smell burning. Then the smoke alarm screeches. Mmm: cremated bread for breakfast again.

If only you'd had the foresight to buy Mappin & Webb's £400 sterling silver toast rack, your golden brown bread would be sitting snugly, eagerly awaiting its smattering of marmalade instead of smoking gently in your £219.95 2+2 combi stainless steel Dualit toaster (available in mint green, canary yellow, lavender blue and gunmetal). That's if you can bear to sully it by putting toast in it. After all, something this elegant deserves a quality product, such as bagels, crumpets or muffins, not just a thin slice of white economy loaf.

With such a glorious shine, it makes an ideal mirror, too. Perfect if you're one of those types who insist on putting on your mascara at the breakfast table. For more details call 020-7409 3555.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Travel
fields.trailText: Travel
fields.body:
If you're the sort who likes to plan holidays with military precision rather than do everything at the last minute, some of the newer travel sites might be for you.

www.travelleronline.com is the sister site of the travellers' club WEXAS International and the only one to offer members free access to the Official Airline Guide - which allows you to build up an itinerary online, by searching the world's scheduled airlines and more than 60,000 hotels (it usually costs £400 a year to subscribe).

Other facilities include www.passepartout.co.uk, a secure site which stores passport numbers, insurance policy details and so on, in case baggage is lost or stolen en route.

For family holidays, try www.thefirstresort.com which claims to offer no less than eight million different package holidays. It allows price comparisons across the leading British tour operators, including Airtours, JMC and First Choice.

For weekend breaks, there is an interesting new site, www.webweekends.co.uk being launched last week. An online directory of themed and packaged breaks ranges from gardening to romantic jaunts and covers short breaks that will appeal to every taste and age group. However, booking online won't be possible until September.

 Helen.Brooks@theguardian.com. The Guardian's online shopping directory is at www.shoppingunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Label of love
fields.standfirst: Forget the big names - more and more of us are opting for supermarket own brands. After all, as  Helen Jones  discovers, the only difference may be the price
fields.trailText: Forget the big names - more and more of us are opting for supermarket own brands. After all, as Helen Jones discovers, the only difference may be the price
fields.body:
Supermarket own-label products used to be seen as cheap, badly packaged, inferior imitations of leading brands, which you only bought if you couldn't afford the real thing. These days, however, a stack of own-label goods in your trolley is the sign of a clever consumer.

We buy more supermarket brands than anyone else in Europe. According to a Mori poll, 20% of British shoppers say that half or more of their buys are own-label.

They account for 80% of the dry pasta we buy, 66% of ice cream and 54% of biscuits, says market research firm AC Nielsen.

The shabby, downmarket image of supermarket products is rapidly disappearing as Tesco, Sainsbury's and the rest introduce premium products as good as those supplied by the big brand owners.

"The own-label market has changed dramatically in the last decade," says Brian Sharoff, president of the Private Label Manufacturers Association. "Now six out of every 10 consumers believe that own-label products are the same as big brands when it comes to quality, taste, availability and freshness."

And no wonder, for many of the products bearing Sainsbury, Tesco, Asda or Safeway labels roll off the very same production lines as more expensive brand names. It's the stuff of urban myths - expensive branded goods made by the same people as their cheaper, own label counterparts.

Manufacturers are notoriously secretive about the practice, worried that consumers will switch to the cheaper supermarket versions if they know they come from the same source as branded goods.

Marcus Mitchell, marketing director of branding experts CLK, says that although manufacturers don't want to talk about it, producing own-label goods is a fact of life in an increasingly competitive market. "Only global manufacturers such as Coca-Cola can afford to ignore the rise of own-label," he says.

The manufacturers have to tread a fine line between satisfying the demands of the increasingly powerful supermarkets and protecting the brands in which they have invested millions of pounds. But for hard- pressed manufacturers there is often little choice.

"For an increasing number of companies producing own-label goods is not a sideline, it's a strategy for growth. Food manufacturing is highly competitive and companies are always looking for new ways to expand," says David Goudge, managing director of branding company, the Brand Development Business.

Take cereal company Kellogg. For years it has said that the only place you will find its cereals is inside a Kellogg's pack. It even used the advertising slogan "If you don't see Kellogg's on the box, it isn't Kellogg's in the box." But as the market gets more competitive and consumers ditch breakfast cereals in favour of a latte and bagel to go, or a quick slice of toast before running for the bus, the ailing cereal giant has started quietly supplying own-label cereals to German discount supermarket Aldi.

"This decision has been taken as part of Kellogg's pragmatic strategy of cutting costs and utilising production capacity across Europe," says Kellogg. However, industry insiders suggest the company may begin supplying UK supermarkets if the Aldi experiment is a success.

Weetabix also makes cereals for supermarkets and is one of the few companies to be upfront about it. "We are happy to confirm that we do indeed manufacture for several major retailers but the details are confidential for contractual reasons," says spokesman Peter Davidson.

Even Heinz are in on the act, admitting they "very occasionally" produce own-label products - although they stress "it is absolutely not a core part" of their business.

Supermarkets usually insist that their products taste as close to the original as possible, but, according to Paul Edwards of the Henley Centre consumer consultancy, if shoppers are particularly attached to a branded product they will stick with it, irrespective of the fact that there are similar products available.

Heinz baked beans are a good example and inspire a great deal of loyalty. In a recent survey 60% of consumers said they wouldn't swap for the cheaper own-label product.

However, adds Edwards, "if the price difference between a branded and supermarket product is big but the difference in the quality is small, then people aren't stupid - they will go for the supermarket brand. More consumers are choosing to buy own- label because they think it's a smart thing to do."

Own-labels no longer represent a choice between high quality and low price but a choice between high quality at one price and high quality at a lesser price.

webTitle: Dispersal system is not the answer

fields.headline: Dispersal system is not the answer
fields.standfirst:
Executive summary
Full report

Refugees in Britain: special reort
fields.trailText: June 1, 2.45pm: Britain's official approach to asylum seekers is limping from one crisis to another, writes home affairs editor Alan Travis.
fields.body:
Home Office ministers reacted with stunning complacency this morning to the alarming warning from the government's own spending watchdog that the forced dispersal of asylum seekers is in danger of failing.

Their response was all too typical of an official approach which has led to Britain's asylum system limping from one crisis to another.

The Audit Commission had warned in its report, Another Country, that without urgent action, including a possible injection of national lottery cash, the 4,000 asylum seekers who have been bussed out of London and the south-east face becoming trapped in poverty or may drift back to London. Thousands more are set to join them when the scheme is fully implemented later this year.

The official watchdog said outside London much more needs to be done to prepare local communities in the new dispersal areas, where legal, health, education and social services are all in short supply. In some areas doctors and schools are refusing to accept asylum seekers and their children and hostile local media coverage is increasing racial tension and the possibility of violence.

Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, reacted to these alarming findings by claiming that they reflected the situation when the local authorities ran a voluntary scheme for the dispersal of asylum seekers from London over the past year. A new national compulsory scheme came into effect on April 3.

"They did their field work before our new system came into place. What we have done is learned the lessons that we needed to learn and consulted with health and education authorities. What we had back then was an ad hoc, back-door dispersal rather than a formal process. Under our national scheme, we do consult with health authorities to make sure that there is adequate provision."

But there were plenty of people this morning prepared to testify that little has changed since the Home Office's own scheme came into force last month.

Dave Garrett, the Northern Director of Refugee Action, said the new plans were heading for failure on every level. "It will not work for asylum seekers. They will be put in areas not used to multiculturalism, so that will lead to antagonism. They will not have health, legal or education services. And it will not work for the government because it will not stop people coming to Britain."

webTitle: Mental health tsar's pledge to patients

fields.headline: Mental health tsar's pledge to patients
fields.trailText: People with mental health problems should have 24-hour access to services by next April, the government's mental health tsar will announce today.
fields.body:
People with mental health problems should have 24-hour access to services by next April, the government's mental health tsar will announce today.

In his first public pronouncement since becoming national director of mental health in April, Louis Appleby will guarantee radical reform of psychiatric services.

He will also promise the phasing out of mixed-sex psychiatric wards within two years; an end to patients being sent to hospitals in other areas as soon as possible; and special training for psychiatrists in "cultural awareness".

His commitments were welcomed by mental health groups, which have grown increasingly alarmed at ministers' focus on the public safety implications of mental health policy rather than the need for reform.

Judi Clements, chief executive of the charity Mind, said the director's approach looked extremely encouraging.

"They are all fundamental things that we would like to see changed. Power to his elbow."

Professor Appleby said he wanted to bring together the interests of users of mental health services, their families and carers and health and social care workers - interests that were frequently wrongly seen to be in conflict.

"Too often, services are fractured and people fall between the cracks.

"I am keen to hear directly from patients, families and professionals about their experiences and the changes they would like to see."

Sending patients to hospitals in other areas was not just distressing to them and their families, it was also highly dangerous as suicide rates among such patients were highest in the first week after discharge.

"If you are being discharged from one area to another completely different area, it is in the nature of the services that they may struggle to pick up your care straight away. It's inhuman, but it's also risky," he said.

Guaranteeing local care would not necessarily mean opening more hospital beds, Professor Appleby said, as new forms of treatment enabled many people to be treated elsewhere and remain at home.

His call for cultural awareness training for psychiatrists reflects the relatively high number of black psychiatric patients and mounting concern that services are failing to relate to Asian communities.

Professor Appleby said psychiatrists ought to improve their communication with non-English patients.

"I do think it would be reasonable for doctors working in multi-cultural services to be aware of key words so some of the dialogue would not be entirely through an interpreter."

Ms Clements said Mind welcomed in particular Professor Appleby's assurance that mixed-sex wards would be phased out within two years.

"We would want to have a precise definition of ward, as we have sometimes had people thinking that as long as the beds are separate you can mix everything else.

"But as long as that's clear, we'll be delighted."

A spokesman for the National Schizophrenia Fellowship highlighted the commitment to 24 hour access to services within 10 months.

"That's the one that gets the real thumbs-up from us. The problem we find is that people looking for help out of hours can't find it and often turn to the police.

"The police are telling us they are pretty fed up with this and there have been a few high profile tragedies with things going wrong.

"People should be able to turn to health and social care staff 24 hours a day, every day."

webTitle: Old-timers to the fore as Bowie and Bacharach top the bill at Glastonbury

fields.headline: Old-timers to the fore as Bowie and Bacharach top the bill at Glastonbury
fields.trailText: Following the ancient saw that the old ones are the best ones, this year's Glastonbury festival may well be dominated by artists who could have headlined the first mudlark back in 1970.
fields.body:
Following the ancient saw that the old ones are the best ones, this year's Glastonbury festival may well be dominated by artists who could have headlined the first mudlark back in 1970.

David Bowie, US country star Willie Nelson and lounge legend Burt Bacharach were among the acts announced yesterday for the 22nd festival, to be staged next month at its traditional home, Worthy Farm in Pilton, Somerset.

The three artists, who have a combined age of 191, will all appear on the main stage on the final day, bringing the curtain down on three days of music, dance and performing arts that organisers are promising will be the biggest yet.

The best selling pop act of last year, Travis, will headline on Saturday evening, a slot that traditionally brings out the extremes in the band of the moment. Oasis played a famously lacklustre set in 1996, while Pulp and Radiohead were generally thought to have triumphed in succeeding years.

Travis had a hit last year with Why Does It Always Rain on Me?, so the band at least has the material to cope with adverse weather of the sort that has blighted two of the last three festivals.

Among other highlights on the main stages are the Chemical Brothers, making their third appearance at the festival in as many years, best-selling dance act Basement Jaxx, and Moby, who will get the chance to prove his ambient sound works as well in a field as on the car adverts that feature his work.

Elsewhere on the seven stages around the 800 acre site, the mix is more ecclectic. The jazz stage will feature reggae great Horace Andy, Gil Scott Heron, and Roni Size's Reprazent. Kate Rusby, Hank Williams III, and jazz guitarist Ronnie Jordan will play on the accoustic stage. The Avalon field will feature veteran psychedelicists Gong, as well as Rolf Harris.

New this year is the Glade, an area reserved for mellower dance music than that found elsewhere on the site. "It's going to be magical," said a spokesman.

As well as music the festival features a full programme of cabaret, comedy and circus acts, and a giant screen. Since the festival coincides with the Euro 2000 quarter-finals, the screen will show all the matches.

Some 100,000 people are expected to attend, paying £89 each (including camping). Festival organisers say: "The long-term weather forecast is good and there are more toilets than ever."

The Guardian is sponsoring this year's event, and free mini-guides, the official, hang-round-your-neck guide containing listings, essential information and a map, will be available on site.

The line-up

Friday

Chemical Brothers, Moby, Eagle Eye Cherry, Cypress Hill, Moloko, Nitin Sawnhey, The The, Reprazent, The Bluetones

Saturday

Travis, Pet Shop Boys, Ocean Colour Scene, Leftfield, Asian Dub Foundation, John Martyn, Elastica, Ladysmith Black Mambazo

Sunday

David Bowie, Basement Jaxx, Burt Bacharach, Willie Nelson, Happy Mondays, Embrace, Horace Andy, Gil Scott Heron, St Etienne
