webTitle: Italian minister's wife faces bribery allegation

fields.headline: Italian minister's wife faces bribery allegation
fields.trailText: Magistrates in Lucca have begun investigating allegations of corruption and tax fraud by the the wife of Italy's foreign minister, an embarrassing development that could further weaken Giuliano Amato's fragile centre-left coalition.
fields.body:
The following legal notice was added on Tuesday June 27 2006
Lawyers acting for Ms Cerri inform us that after the arrest reported in the article below, Ms Cerri was acquitted of all charges in May 2004. The Court of Appeal in Florence upheld the decision on May 19 2006 and Ms Cerri's acquittal is now final. Magistrates in Lucca have begun investigating allegations of corruption and tax fraud by the the wife of Italy's foreign minister, an embarrassing development that could further weaken Giuliano Amato's fragile centre-left coalition.

Donatella Dini, a well known society hostess and head of a business empire with interests in central America, is accused of bribing a public official to obtain a 30bn lira (£10m) loan for a Florentine company. Her husband, Lamberto Dini, is a former prime minister and a key member of the Amato cabinet.

On Monday officers of the revenue guard arrested a Milan estate agent and friend of Mrs Dini. The two are accused of giving a £17,000 bribe to the chairman of the Industrial Promotion Institute, an offshoot of the industry ministry, to secure his help in obtaining a loan for the company, which makes batteries for mobile phones.

The warrant for Ms Cerri's arrest is reported to refer to handwritten notes confiscated from Mrs Dini's office in Rome which allegedly indicate that £60,000 was to be shared by the mediators in the affair.

The official, Maurizio Menegon, a former MP for Mr Dini's Italian Renewal party, denied receiving the bribe in an interview with the Milan daily Il Giornale yesterday and insisted that his institute had no power to influence the granting of loans.

Mrs Dini, who inherited a property empire from her first husband, is also under investigation for suspected tax evasion in connection with her offshore holdings.

An effervescent socialite who was once reported as describing herself as a cross between Hillary Clinton and Cruella de Vil, she has hitherto proved a considerable asset to her husband's political career.

webTitle: Honest, this All Saints movie is a total flop

fields.headline: Honest, this All Saints movie is a total flop
fields.standfirst: Comment: Critics have no power - Honest
fields.trailText: Honest, the hugely hyped gangster flick with which the girl band All Saints hoped to launch their film careers, has bombed at the box office
fields.body:
Honest, the hugely hyped gangster flick with which the girl band All Saints hoped to launch their film careers, has bombed at the box office.

The £4.2m film, directed by pop singer Dave Stewart of Eurythmics fame, flopped spectacularly when it opened over the weekend, averaging barely £500 at each of the 220 cinemas where it was screened.

Despite a glitzy premiere at the Cannes festival and a publicity blitz which made great play of its drug and orgy scenes, only five people turned up at one Saturday evening screening in Leicester Square.

Honest's abysmal showing is all the worse considering it opened over a bank holiday, when audiences are usually at their peak. Even Rancid Aluminium, widely regarded as the worst of a whole flock of recent British movie turkeys, took £50,000 more on its first weekend from 80 fewer screens. The equally risible Guest House Paradiso, starring Rik Mayall and Adrian Edmondson, made six times as much.

Last night as Honest was being pulled from cinemas across the country, its distributors, Pathe, refused to blame its failure on the 18 certificate imposed by censors. "Obviously we are very disappointed," a spokesman said.

However, industry analysts said Stewart's refusal to cut the "infrequent strong sex and drug use, and occasional strong violence" detailed by the British Board of Film Classification meant it was inevitable the bulk of its target teenage audience would be barred from going.

Mary Scott, of the industry magazine Screen International, said the film's performance was "pretty shocking. The 18 certificate obviously hasn't helped when you think of all their schoolgirl fans, but even so it should have done much better. They have shot themselves in the foot. The first weekend is crucial for every film: if you don't perform well then, that's usually that."

Stewart, who in his film-making manifestation likes to be known as Dave A Stewart, blamed the press for bumping the censor into imposing the 18 certificate. "The censors were so paranoid because of the sex and drugs. They write anything they want. [The press say] I'm a mental patient, who has a nudist colony in the south of France, and that I teach hairless dogs to speak."

He also complained at Cannes that he had never been taken seriously in Britain. "There is an assumption that you shouldn't make a film if you are a pop musician. It's nice to be in this country [France] where they are interested in writing about the film rather than my hairless dog farm or [his star] Natalie Appleton's breasts."

Although the caper - which features three members of the band playing East End girl robbers against a backdrop of London's swinging sixties - was dismissed by the Observer as "witless, soulless and inert", though most critics agreed it was not as awful as the Spice Girls vehicle Spiceworld.

Spiceworld took in £11.5m. Honest will be lucky to recoup £1m.

Ironically, Melanie Blatt, one of the three band members in Honest, complained at the premiere that modern youngsters were too apathetic.

"I would love to be part of a rebellion about something. Kids today are too spoiled. They have everything they want and nothing to rebel about. They are happy to play video games," she said.

While the £111,309 Honest took in its first weekend was enough to give it 12th spot in the box office charts this week, takings are likely to drop like a stone next week when it will be shown on many fewer screens. Its takings were a drop in the ocean compared to the £3m which the chart-topping Gladiator made over the same period.

fields.headline: Cheque clearing
fields.standfirst: The Consumers' Association today published a report accusing banks of swindling customers by making them wait for up to 11 days to clear cheques. Mark Tran explains why British consumers face such long delays
fields.trailText: The Consumers' Association today published a report accusing banks of swindling customers by making them wait for up to 11 days to clear cheques. We explain why British consumers face such long delays.
fields.body:
How long does it take for a cheque to clear?
It takes three days for a cheque to pass through the clearing system on average, but can take up to eleven days before customers have access to the money.

Why does it take so long?
The recent government banking review led by Don Cruickshank attributed the delays to the large amount of paper flowing around the system in the form of cheques. Although Britain does not depend on cheques as much as the US, for example, it lags behind such countries as Norway and Finland in the use of fast and reliable electronic payment systems. Moreover, the timescale of electronic systems still resembles that of the paper-based systems they are replacing. The Cruickshank review concluded that systems for cheque clearing and electronic transfers were stuck in the 19th century.

How does the Consumers' Association explain this slowness?
Its report in Which? magazine echoes the Cruickshank review. Which? says the delay is due to the fact that 8m cheques written each day are posted around the country, while bounced cheques are also returned by mail - so the bank has to wait for the post to arrive before it can be sure that it can pay a cheque.

Is it simply inconvenient, or is there an economic cost?
There is an economic cost. Clearing delays make it hard for retail and business customers to manage their affairs effectively. This results in higher bank charges from unauthorised overdrafts and foregone interest.

How does the British clearing system compare to others?
Cheque recipients in Canada start to earn interest within 24 hours and are often able to withdraw funds against cheque payments in the same time. Retail customers in Finland can make same-day payments.

What happens to the money while it is being cleared?
Banks and building societies earn interest on the money while it's waiting to be cleared, although this is often overstated. For most cheque transactions, the recipient starts receiving interest for the transaction value on the same day as the payer stops receiving it.

Who controls the clearing system?
The major banks are in charge of the payments' system so there is little incentive for them to introduce schemes to benefit users. The Cruickshank report says that the bankers who control the system lack fresh ideas and expertise to improve it. This is particularly problematic as e-commerce takes hold.

What can be done?
The Cruickshank review noted that the Bank of England and the Financial Services Authority have not pushed hard enough for more competition, while the competition authorities lack sufficient powers to promote competition and innovation. The review advocates a new framework in which an entity gives out licences for participating in payments systems. Those firms awarded licences would have to abide by principles safeguarding effective competition.

fields.headline: Injured Cole denies Keegan rift
fields.trailText: Andy Cole has denied walking out on England after being omitted from the Euro 2000 squad.
fields.body:
Andy Cole has denied walking out on England after being omitted from the Euro 2000 squad.

The Manchester United striker said there had been no argument with manager Kevin Keegan, and that he has been suffering from a foot injury which has prevented him travelling to the Low Countries.

Cole said: "I had a meeting with Kevin Keegan yesterday afternoon to discuss the situation regarding my foot.

"I have been carrying the injury for some time now and it has become more and more troublesome and not settled down as I had hoped.

"Obviously a decision had to be made and following the conversation with Kevin we both agreed the risk of not being able to perform fully in such an important tournament was too great a risk to take.

"A lot has been made of my position within the England camp. I can only once again repeat that I am desperate to play for my country and compete at the highest level.

"I also felt that had the injury not occurred I had a great chance of being involved in Euro 2000.

"Some have also intimated that an argument took place and I consequently walked out on the England camp. Nothing could be further from the truth."

Cole is now hoping to get the foot injury sorted out once and for all during the close season.

"Obviously on a personal note I am deeply disappointed not to be taking part but the most important thing now is to get the injury sorted.

"I wish Kevin and the boys the best of luck and like the rest of the nation, hope and believe we can be successful in this year's Euro finals."

webTitle: June 1: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 1: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Jody Foster denies baby rumours, Spike Lee bounces back, George Clooney set for cuckold role, Gene Hackman in line for Fox thriller, Greg Kinnear up for Ashley Judd project, and Josh Hartnett proves to be hot-property
fields.body:
 Jodie Foster has moved swiftly to deny mushrooming speculation (triggered by a report in the Daily Mirror) that she is pregnant with her second child. Representatives of the 37-year-old actress insisted yesterday that the story is a complete fiction, and explain that Foster may simply have been overheard remarking that she would like a playmate for her 18-month-old son Charlie. The Mirror's original report did not go so far as to name the father of the alleged child, but Foster has always kept a tight lock on her personal life. The identity of baby number-one's dad remains one of Hollywood's most closely guarded secrets.

 Bouncing back after recent disappointments, Spike Lee has announced that he is to executive-produce an original movie for the Showtime cable channel in the US. Written and directed by Lee Davis, 3am is a New York-set drama revolving around the experiences of three taxi-drivers and the cast includes Danny Glover and Pam Grier. For Lee it's a tentative return to film-making after wary studio bosses rejected him from the job that he really wanted - the director's role on the forthcoming Muhammad Ali biopic.

 George Clooney is reported to be in negotiations to play a cuckolded husband in Unfaithful, the next film from glossy British director Adrian (Lolita) Lyne. The problem is that the film, an Americanised overhaul of Claude Chabrol's 1969 French psycho-drama La Femme Infidele, may struggle to fit into Clooney's busy schedule. With The Perfect Storm set for summer release, the ER graduate is currently shaping up to star in Ocean's Eleven for old collaborator Steven (Out of Sight) Soderbergh.

 Gene Hackman is in line to star in the Fox thriller Behind Enemy Lines, about two marines who find themselves dropped (you guessed it) behind enemy lines. One of these marines is a wet-behind-the-ears rookie, the other a grizzled old pro. No surprise to learn, then, that Hackman is tipped to play the latter part.

 Greg Kinnear is reported to be in talks to sign up to the new Ashley Judd picture, Animal Husbandry, about an anthropologically minded minx who applies the rules of the animal kingdom to her own troubled love life. Kinnear would play Judd's feckless boyfriend. Tony Goldwyn directs and the film is due to start shooting at the end of the summer.

 Consolidating his success in the likes of The Faculty and The Virgin Suicides, hot-property Josh Hartnett is in negotiations to play the lead role in 40 Days, 40 Nights, a hip comedy-drama to be co-produced by Universal and Miramax. Hartnett would play the once-burnt-twice-shy hero who gives up sex for Lent only to find his abstinence tested when he meets a young cutey to whom he just can't say no. The film is written by Rob Perez and will be directed by loose-cannon director Michael Lehmann, whose wayward career has carried him from the sublime (Heathers) to the ridiculous (Hudson Hawk). Alluring Kate Holmes (Joey out of Dawson's Creek) was initially lined up to play Hartnett's love-interest, but TV commitments are now thought to have prevented her involvement.

webTitle: We pick England's best XI - now pick yours

fields.headline: We pick England's best XI - now pick yours
fields.standfirst: Kevin Keegan has chosen the 22 men he will take to Euro 2000. Below Football Unlimited writers pick their best XI from the names available. See what you think and then have your say
fields.trailText: Team 1
fields.byline: Paul MacInnes, Scott Murray and Sean Ingle
fields.body:
Team 1

Goalkeeper: Martyn
Defenders: Campbell, Adams, Keown
Wing-backs: Beckham, Barry
Midfield: Wise, McManaman, Scholes
Forwards: Shearer, Owen

Apparently all of the England players prefer to play 4-4-2. So what better time to change formation than in a major international tournament? Seriously though, I do believe that playing wing-backs offers England far more options when going forward and that attacking poise, or lack of it, has been England's biggest failing since France '98. There may be less width (although when was the last time you saw an England full-back overlap successfully?) but there's more variety and it also allows England to play their best ball-players in the middle of the park - Beckham included.

Nigel Martyn has been in good form for roughly three years and deserves the number one spot. Adams and Keown have a supernatural understanding and must play together. Gareth Barry may be a risk, but I'd rather have the possibility of some real wing-back play than Phil Neville's consistent mediocrity. Wise gets in above Ince because he does more than simply break up play, and the same reasoning in reverse applies for Steve McManaman. I'm still not convinced that Owen can play with Shearer, but both get in on their individual merits alone. PM

Team 2

Goalkeeper: Seaman
Defenders: Barry, Adams, Keown, Gerrard
Midfielders: McManaman, Wise, Scholes, Beckham
Forwards: Shearer, Owen

It's a waste of time pretending England are going to win this summer, so bung Barry and Gerrard in the full-back positions and let them learn about the international game. Having said that, there's no point dicing with 1988-style embarrassment either, so fill the rest of the defence with Arsenal's pensioners - they won't have to worry about cultivating an understanding with each other, and they can concentrate on baby-walking the nippers through the tournament.

Wise has been the best combative midfielder all season, and he can play a bit on the left, so starting him alongside McManaman gives the shaggy winger a bit of licence to roam from the flank he'll be expected to patrol when he doesn't have the ball. Scholes is England's true world-class playmaker, so give him creative carte blanche in the middle and keep Becks out on the right where he belongs - he can work on his promising relationship with Gerrard, and may even be able to pop in a cross or two.

As for Shearer and Owen... oh, come on. SM

Team 3

Goalkeeper: Martyn
Defenders: G.Neville, Adams, Campbell, Barry
Midfielders: Beckham, McManaman, Scholes, Wise
Forwards: Shearer, Owen

Despite the performance against Ukraine, Kevin Keegan will almost certainly play 4-4-2 against Portugal. It's what the senior players prefer, and (when it works) it gives the side more attacking width than 3-5-2. To make it work though, Keegan needs to be bold. That means choosing an attacking, fluid midfield. The way I would play it, if Beckham wants to come inside, McManaman can go right. Or if the side comes under pressure, Wise can drop into the middle. Basically the formation is a lot more flexible (and harder to defend against) than having a holding player like Ince sitting in front of the back four making tackles (and not a whole lot else).

I also believe Nigel Martyn, who has played impeccably for England deserves his chance. And rather than play the right-footed Phil Neville at left back he should play Barry to give more natural attacking width. Up front Shearer and Owen pick themselves, considering that Heskey is still raw, Fowler still unfit, and Phillips hasn't been given much of an opportunity to shine. SI

webTitle: Fiji military claim breakthrough in hostage impasse

fields.headline: Fiji military claim breakthrough in hostage impasse
fields.standfirst: Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Fiji's army claimed the release of 30 hostages, including the prime minister, could be imminent after the country's temporary ruler met coup leader George Speight face to face for the first time.
fields.body:
Fiji's army claimed the release of 30 hostages, including the prime minister, could be imminent after the country's temporary ruler met coup leader George Speight face to face for the first time.

"We have had a very major breakthrough," said military spokesman Captain Eroni Volavola. "I think we can say that within the next 24 to 36 hours, you'll start seeing a lot of very positive things coming out from parliament."

Asked if the talks between Fiji's military leader Commodore Frank Bainimarama and Mr Speight included a schedule for the release of the hostages, he said: "That could be one of them."

Mr Speight has been holding Mahendra Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, and members of his government hostage at the country's parliament since May 19.

An announcement will be issued tomorrow about a deal that would lead to a release of the hostages over the weekend. It is believed that Mr Speight's rebels will be bought off with promises of roles in a new civilian government for Fiji, although Mr Volavola says Mr Speight is unlikely to become prime minister.

Mr Volavola spoke to reporters after military negotiators met Mr Speight for more than three hours inside the barracks from which Commodore Bainimarama has been running the country since martial law was imposed on Monday. Mr Speight went into the meeting with allies that he had named to his own "cabinet".

After the negotiations had finished, Mr Speight remained for more than an hour inside the barracks drinking kava, a traditional mild sedative, with Commodore Bainimarama "as if nothing had happened," Mr Volavola said.

Mr Speight went across town to Commodore Bainimarama's military barracks late in the day, unarmed and in the company of 40 Fijian troops who had earlier gone into the parliamentary compound to seek the release of the hostages. A military spokesman said that, with his gunmen in the parliament still holding the hostages, Mr Speight's security had been guaranteed.

It was Mr Speight's longest trip away from the scene of the hostage crisis since it began, although he had made other brief appearances outside parliament accompanied by armed guards.

Since taking power, the army has accepted Mr Speight's major demands: scrapping the 1997 constitution which guarantees equal rights for the ethnic Indian minority, deposing President Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara and offering Mr Speight and his gang an amnesty.

Having initially said that it would install a civil administration to restore democracy to Fiji, the military said yesterday it may stay in power for up to three years until a new constitution is drawn up and fresh elections planned.

Mr Speight has called on the military instead to install his self-styled Fijian nationalist government.

The United States, Australia and New Zealand have threatened sanctions if democracy is not returned to democratic rule.

 A hostage who was freed yesterday to go to a funeral - on condition that she return to captivity - has not come back. "If she comes back, she comes back," Mr Speight's spokesman Joe Nata said. "If she doesn't, she doesn't."

webTitle: How Viv missed out on a triple century

fields.headline: How Viv missed out on a triple century
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your question.
fields.trailText: Can you please tell me how Viv Richards was out when he made his highest Test score of 291 at The Oval in 1976? asks P Clarke
fields.body:
Can you please tell me how Viv Richards was out when he made his highest Test score of 291 at The Oval in 1976? asks P Clarke

I can tell you, because I was there! Tony Greig was bowling from the Vauxhall end, in his offbreak mode. Richards took a step or two down the pitch, got a little inside-edge to a well-pitched-up ball and it sneaked through onto his stumps. I remember being frustrated that I'd missed out on seeing a triple-century (probably not quite as frustrated as Viv though). It was 14 years before I did see one in the flesh - Graham Gooch's 333 at Lord's in 1990. That Oval match was the famous one when Michael Holding bowled like the wind and took 14 wickets. And Dennis Amiss, using a new exaggerated back-and-across technique, made 203 in his comeback game after being left out because he'd struggled against pace bowling. Despite Amiss's efforts West Indies won by 231 runs, to take the series 3-0.

When was the last time David Gower played for England? asks David Tyrrell

Gower made his last Test appearance against Pakistan at The Oval in August 1992. He made 27 and 1. He finished with 8231 runs from 117 Tests - both England records at the time (but both later overtaken by Graham Gooch), at an average of 44.25, with 18 hundreds. Gower also played in 114 one-day internationals, the last in February 1991, scoring 3170 runs at 30.77, with seven centuries.

Did the father of the novelist HG Wells play cricket for England? asks Peter Gardner

Wells's father Joseph didn't play for England - but he did turn out for Kent, for whom he took four wickets with successive balls against Sussex at Brighton in 1862. He's actually the first person credited with that feat in first-class cricket.

Is it out if the wicketkeeper holds the ball in his hands and knocks the bails off with his legs while the batsman is out of his crease? asks Anirban Majumdar

He shouldn't be given out, because Law 28 says that the fielder has to break the stumps "with his hand or arm, provided that the ball is held in the hand or hands so used, or in the hand of the arm so used". You can be out stumped (Law 39) if the ball rebounds off the wicketkeeper's pads and hits the stumps with the striker out of his ground. For all the Laws, go to the Lord's website.

Ross Gregory did well for Australia in the 1936-37 Ashes series. Why didn't he tour England in 1938? asks John Thurbin

Gregory was a quick-footed right-hand batsman who made his debut for Victoria while he was still at school. He was only 20 when he was called up for the last two Tests of the 1936-37 Ashes series - which, uniquely, Australia came from 2-0 down to win 3-2 - and made 23 and 50 at Adelaide and 80 at Melbourne. There weren't any Tests in 1937-38, and Gregory didn't make a century in domestic cricket that season, although he was fairly consistent. When the team to tour England was chosen Gregory was left out. It's difficult to find out why, at this distance - but two of the untried batsmen who did come were Lindsay Hassett and Sidney Barnes, who both became fine players. One book suggests that the man who got Gregory's place was Arthur Chipperfield, who had made 99 on Test debut himself in England in 1934. England never did see Ross Gregory play: he was killed in action in the war in 1942.

Which former Yorkshire and England wicketkeeper committed suicide in 1998? asks Mark Seymour

It was David Bairstow, the barrel-chested ginger-haired keeper who made his first-class debut as a schoolboy in 1970. In all he played 429 matches for Yorkshire, and captained them from 1984 to 1986. Only 14 wicketkeepers have bettered his career tally of 1099 first-class dismissals - and he scored 13,961 runs as well. "Bluey" Bairstow played four Tests for England, including the 1980 Centenary Test against Australia at Lord's, and also appeared in 21 one-day internationals. After retirement he had some business and personal problems, and sadly hanged himself at home on January 5, 1998. He was only 46. An excellent obituary, by David Hopps, appeared in the March 1998 edition of Wisden Cricket Monthly.

Has Taunton in Somerset ever hosted a Test match? asks Sahil Malik

The County Ground at Taunton has never staged a Test match (only seven grounds in England have), but it has staged three one-day internationals. The first was in the 1983 World Cup: England made 333 for 9 from their 60 overs (David Gower 130), then restricted Sri Lanka to 286, Vic Marks, the offspinner playing on his home ground, took 5-32. The other two were in last year's World Cup: first Zimbabwe beat Kenya by five wickets, then India hammered Sri Lanka in a record-breaking match. India's 373 for 6 (only 50 overs this time) included a record one-day stand of 318 for the second wicket between Sourav Ganguly (183) and Rahul Dravid (145). Sri Lanka made only 216 (Robin Singh 5-31) to lose by 157 runs. This defeat confirmed that the 1996 champions would not be able to reach the next phase of the 1999 tournament.

Can you tell me when England will next tour the West Indies, and whether an itinerary is yet available? asks Peter Barnett

England's next tour of the Caribbean is planned for the winter of 2003-04. The itinerary probably won't be released until early in 2003. The next Test series in the Caribbean will start in February or March 2001, when South Africa go there for their first full five-Test series. West Indies will be itching to avenge the 5-0 drubbing they suffered in South Africa in 1998-99, so that should be well worth watching.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read last week's column, click here

webTitle: Fifth white farmer killed in Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Fifth white farmer killed in Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Intruders shot dead a white farmer at his home in Zimbabwe during a gunbattle in which one of the assailants also died, farm leaders said today.
fields.body:
Intruders shot dead a white farmer at his home in Zimbabwe during a gunbattle in which one of the assailants also died, farm leaders said today.

Tony Oates is the fifth white farmer to have been killed since mobs of squatters and ruling party militants illegally occupied hundreds of white-owned properties.

He was shot dead late Wednesday on his farm about 40 miles north-west of Harare, the Commercial Farmers Union said.

The intruders cut the burglar bars in the bedroom where Oates was sleeping. His wife, who was watching television in the house, escaped.

"He shot at the intruders and killed one of them, but he was also shot and died," a union spokeswoman said.

The union said the killing was criminally rather than politically inspired. Oates' farm in the fertile district of Trelawney tobacco and grain district was not occupied by the illegal squatters who are demanding land they say was stolen during the British colonial area. But several properties neighbouring Oates' farm have been occupied by mobs since February.

Three white farmers killed during violent occupations of their land were openly supporting the biggest opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC). A fourth was robbed before being killed in an exchange of gunfire.

More than 80 whites have fled their farms after receiving death threats from militants led by veterans of the war that ended white rule in Rhodesia, as Zimbabwe was called, in 1980.

President Robert Mugabe has described the occupations as a justified protest against unfair land ownership mainly by the descendants of colonial-era British settlers.

The MDC, the biggest threat to the ruling party in parliament elections slated for June 24-25, accuses Mugabe of allowing the occupations and promising land to rural poor to boost his flagging popularity and punish white farmers for openly supporting the opposition.

At least 26 people, most of them opposition supporters, have been killed in political violence since February.

fields.headline: Barthez, bien sûr
fields.standfirst: Jon Henley in Paris on Manchester United's new goalkeeper, perhaps the most popular man in France
fields.trailText: Jon Henley in Paris on Manchester United's new goalkeeper, perhaps the most popular man in France
fields.body:
His was the gleaming pate Les Bleus liked to kiss for luck during their victorious 1998 World Cup campaign; his the grinning cover picture that sold 1.1 million copies of Paris Match -- the third most successful issue in the celebrated magazine's history.

Fabien Barthez, the world's most expensive goalkeeper following his transfer yesterday to Manchester United, inspired a generation of French females who had never so much as seen a football before to declare their undying devotion to the game, and prompted thousands of carefully coiffed French males to take a razor to their locks.

It was that cheeky, self-effacing little smile, said the girls - plus, um, that bit when, you know, he tore his shorts and had to change them right there, on the pitch. He was no mean shot-stopper either, pointed out the boys, conceding only two goals (one of them a penalty) in France's seven World Cup games.

Either way, the French took the former Marseille and Monaco keeper to their hearts as they have no other footballer since Michel Platini, voting him sports personality of the year in 1998 and 1999. A half-way successful Euro 2000 should see him hit the hat-trick.

A bit of a rebel in his time, he was suspended for two months back in 1995 for smoking pot. But that was no doubt to alleviate the pain of spending a season in the second division, whence Marseille had been relegated following their European Cup win over AC Milan and the match-fixing scandal that emerged in its wake.

The son and grandson of rugby players from Toulouse, Barthez is now pretty much the Beckham of la belle France: filthy rich, outrageously talented, occasionally wayward, the star of countless commercials (most noticeably McDonald's), and graced with a gorgeous companion in the form of supermodel Linda Evangelista.

In all, he almost certainly has the necessary crowd-pleasing assets to become as popular in Manchester as Eric Cantona, despite the fact that at present he is probably best remembered by Mancunians for captaining Monaco in the two draws (0-0 at home; 1-1 away) that knocked Sir Alex Ferguson's men out of the 1998 Champions League at the quarter-final stage.

Barthez left Monaco partly because of a row with coach Claude Puel over his performance in a nasty match against Marseille, and partly because he was fed up playing to a half-empty stadium - as is often the case in the wealthy but decidedly unfanatical Principality. Old Trafford could provide this Gallic showman with the stage he has been missing, just as it did for Cantona.

But that was no doubt to alleviate the pain of spending a season in the second division, whence Marseille had been relegated following their European Cup win over AC Milan and the match-fixing scandal that emerged in its wake. The son and grandson of rugby players from Toulouse, Barthez is now pretty much the Beckham of la belle France: filthy rich, outrageously talented, occasionally wayward, the star of countless commercials (most noticeably McDonald's), and graced with a gorgeous companion in the form of supermodel Linda Evangelista. In all, he almost certainly has the necessary crowd-pleasing assets to become as popular in Manchester as Eric Cantona, despite the fact that at present he is probably best remembered by Mancunians for captaining Monaco in the two draws (0-0 at home; 1-1 away) that knocked Sir Alex Ferguson's men out of the 1998 Champions League at the quarter-final stage. Barthez left Monaco partly because of a row with coach Claude Puel over his performance in a nasty match against Marseille, and partly because he was fed up playing to a half-empty stadium - as is often the case in the wealthy but decidedly unfanatical Principality. Old Trafford could provide this Gallic showman with the stage he has been missing, just as it did for Cantona.

fields.headline: Andrew Faulds
fields.standfirst: Passionate Labour MP of the pre-pager era
fields.trailText: Passionate Labour MP of the pre-pager era.
fields.body:
Andrew Faulds, the unmistakably loud and thespian Labour backbencher, who has died aged 77, was a House of Commons character who never managed to live up to the role he envisaged for himself. Most actors and entertainers who enter politics suffer the same fate.

Tall, handsome and imposing, Faulds was a man of deeply-held passions, vocally pro-Arab and pro-European throughout his career. But he lacked either the patience or the subtlety to do effective justice to those concerns at Westminster. Instead he became the sort of MP easily written off for explosive rows, spectacular rudeness to colleagues of whom he disapproved and a weakness for having himself thrown out.

There is scope for this kind of parliamentary theatre in a political career. MPs as different as Michael Heseltine, Tam Dalyell, Ian Paisley and George Galloway have all indulged in the kind of histrionics which oblige the Speaker of the day to ask them to leave the premises for a cooling-off period.

But, in their different ways, they all seemed to have a discipline and focus lacking in the Labour member for Warley East from 1974 until his retirement on the eve of the Blair landslide in 1997. For both Faulds and his young leader this was probably a lucky escape: though on the right of the Labour party on many ideological issues, Faulds was his own man and did not take kindly to pagers, spin doctors or other means of modern thought control.

Andrew Faulds was born in what was then Tanganyika, now Tanzania, the son of Matthew Faulds, a Presbyterian missionary. Like many a child of the manse he reacted against the puritanism of his childhood without abandoning its high-mindedness or sense of moral certainty. Educated in Scotland, including Glasgow University, he became an actor, joining Equity as early as 1944, and later a member of the union's council. Among his 37 films was Carver Doone, a clutch of voice-overs and - to small boys listening to BBC radio in the 50s - he was immortalised as Jet Morgan, hero of the spine-chilling adventure series, Journey into Space.

At the behest of the great Paul Robeson, it was said, he also joined the Labour party. Not quite in the Robeson league, the Faulds voice was wonderful then, and remained so to the end. When Andrew Faulds called a Tory opponent "an honourable shit" (1988) or declared that Norman St John Stevas "lacked the capacity to put a bun in anyone's oven" (when the House was discussing abortion) there was not much doubt as to whom said exactly what.

First elected for Smethwick, scene of a famous conflict with racism, in 1966, Faulds was fiercely anti-racist, among whom he sometimes numbered Zionists. When Harold Wilson's government grappled with Ian Smith's unilateral declaration of independence (UDI) in then-Rhodesia, Faulds's solution was "hang Smith".

When Enoch Powell made his shameful "rivers of blood" speech in nearby Wolverhampton in 1968, Faulds called him "unChristian... unprincipled, undemocratic and racialist". The Labour government's restrictions on Kenyan Asians with UK passports entering Britain in the same year was also racialist. He was right about that too.

Yet Faulds, who switched to safer Warley in 1974, was not a man with whom to enter the political jungle. He resigned as a ministerial PPS in 1969 and was fired as a junior arts spokesman in opposition (he was passionate about culture too) a few years later. Wilson, it was said, tired of his silliness.

He was reappointed arts spokesman after Labour's defeat in 1979. But by 1982 Michael Foot, a kind and patient man, had had enough and dropped him again.

But he was an active MP, championing causes like the Palestinians and Turkey, even Colonel Gadafy of Libya. In 1982 he was one of a small contingent of mainly Labour leftwing MPs who vocally opposed Britain's military re-conquest of the Falkland Islands. Despite Speaker Thomas's relative generosity to his group, he got himself thrown out for protesting too much.

Uncritical in his affections, fond of good company and foreign trips, Faulds was also capable of being offensive to Margaret Thatcher as few Labour men felt able to be, not least Neil Kinnock. On at least one occasion he laced his attack with sexual innuendo.

That was odd. Married to Bunty Whitfield in 1945 (they had one daughter), Faulds was famous around Westminster as a ladies man, happy to flaunt a young conquest in front of MPs whose private lives were quieter. Many of them admired his cheek.

Bearded and full of Old Testament outrage, he was vain but often very likeable, the "Donald Sinden of the Commons", one sketchwriter called him. Often involved in personal attacks on MPs, even Jewish Labour colleagues, his political opinions were generally more orthodox in a Blimpish way than he might have cared to admit.

In 1983 he backed his fellow-Brummie MP, Roy Hattersley, against Neil Kinnock for the Labour leadership. He called the Channel Tunnel "a silly idea" and opposed the televising of parliament - a medium which an actor should have embraced. Given his fatal flamboyance he may have been wise not to do so. Like so much else it was a lost cause.

Andrew Matthew William Faulds, politician and actor, born March 1 1923; died May 31 2000

webTitle: Anthony Hopkins tipped for Stephen King adaptation

fields.headline: Anthony Hopkins tipped for Stephen King adaptation
fields.trailText: Castle Rock are rumoured to be lining up director Scott Hicks and actor Anthony Hopkins for a big-budget treatment of a Stephen King story, Hearts in Atlantis
fields.body:
Castle Rock are rumoured to be lining up director Scott Hicks and actor Anthony Hopkins for a big-budget treatment of a Stephen King story, Hearts in Atlantis.

A collection of interlinked coming-of-age stories that was first published last year, Hearts in Atlantis looks to be King's most purely autobiographical work - tracing the upbringing of an impoverished, fatherless kid growing up in rural Maine in the 50s and 60s.

Castle Rock will concentrate on the title story in the collection, which revolves around the experiences of a group of students at the University of Maine, who find their wild life of self-discovery overshadowed by the Vietnam War and the threat of the draft. The leading character takes refuge in the homespun wisdom of a reclusive older man who becomes his mentor. If negotiations are successful, Hopkins will play the mentor, with the younger role still up for grabs. Hicks (director of the Oscar-winning Shine and the recent Snow Falling on Cedars) will direct and shooting is scheduled to begin later this year.

As a writer, King remains best known for his gory horror tales (which he himself describes as the literary equivalent of a Big Mac and fries) but Castle Rock have been credited with turning out the most mainstream and successful King adaptations. Hearts in Atlantis appears closest in spirit to their 1986 adaptation of Stand by Me (which followed four boys' hunt for a dead body), but their previous efforts also include Misery, The Shawshank Redemption and The Green Mile - all of which received at least one Oscar nomination. Castle Rock's association with the author goes back a long way - even the studio's name is that of a fictional Maine township that crops up in various King novels.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer stories microwaved on full power for three minutes
fields.trailText: Chelsea and Arsenal have sent representatives to watch Holland's 23-year-old striker Anthony Lurling. Lurling, currently turning out for the Dutch in the under-21 tournament in Slovakia, plays his club football for Heerenveen. He told the Daily Express, "I know English clubs are interested in me and if they really want me, then I will probably go there."
fields.body:
Chelsea and Arsenal have sent representatives to watch Holland's 23-year-old striker Anthony Lurling. Lurling, currently turning out for the Dutch in the under-21 tournament in Slovakia, plays his club football for Heerenveen. He told the Daily Express, "I know English clubs are interested in me and if they really want me, then I will probably go there."

Manchester United are planning to supplement their French quota by moving for Laurent Blanc. The Daily Express reports that Sir Alex Ferguson will offer the 34-year-old international captain, and close friend of new signing Fabien Barthez, a two-year deal at Old Trafford.

Gianfranco Zola has admitted that his time at Chelsea is up. "I hope that Chelsea will give me the opportunity to leave," he told the Daily Mail. "I hope that Napoli will sign me, all I want to do is keep playing."

Christian Bassedas has completed his £3.5m move to Newcastle from financially-troubled Velez Sarsfield. The Argentine international midfielder put pen to paper last night. "It is a good move for me because I have always wanted to play in the Premiership," he said. "It is a good move all round because now my team mates can be paid the wages that are owed to them."

Eidur Gudjohnsen is ready to spurn the advances of Chelsea and sign for Manchester City, the Daily Mail reports. Bolton had hoped to cash in on their young Icelandic striker by selling him to the West London club, but Gudjohnsen prefers a move to City and Wanderers may be forced to let him go for as little as £1.5m.

Arsenal and Newcastle are both chasing Atletico Madrid keeper Francisco Molina. Planet Football suggests that the Spanish international is another player on his way out of the relegated club, for a fee of only £2.25m.

Sunderland are ready to make another move for Everton's Don Hutchison. Peter Reid failed with a £1m bid for the Scot earlier in the year.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Cybershop shock

The sad news last week was that e-tailing - shopping on the internet - is not the burgeoning business some of us had thought. Rather than cruise down virtual high streets, nine out of 10 of us prefer to plod round M&S and keep an eye on our credit card transactions. Brian Hunt is one of the adventurous few who shop online, but he has thought twice about it since buying goods from Addons, part of Microland UK. The advertisement promised "24-hour secure shopping". However, in February, Hunt received an email from a stranger informing him that he had found a way to view all the names, addresses and telephone numbers of every customer. Worse, the stranger had discovered the bank card details for all orders placed between February 1-16. The correspondent claimed he had tried to report this to Addons and that the company never answered the phone and ignored his emails.

Hunt's details were, he promised, safe with him, but he couldn't answer for anyone else who might have discovered the information.

 It's certainly impossible to reach Microland UK by phone, but an email prompts a quick response. The culprit, says a spokesman, was a teenager who "hacked into our website and stole some of the information which at that time was not secure because of problems at the internet service provider."

Stockport trading standards says it is aware of the problem and has referred the matter to the data protection registrar, which publishes security guidelines for cybershoppers on its web site at www.dataprotection.gov.uk. The credit card research group says that although cybershopping accounts for only 2% of credit card transactions, it generates 50% of complaints. As a general tip, only entrust card details to a secure page that scrambles them while in transit. You should see a closed padlock on the status bar of your screen and the address in a secure area should start https:// rather than http://. Should your security be breached you are entitled to claim compensation for damage or distress caused through the data protection registrar.

If anyone else would like to share cybershopping experiences with us, please feel free

Threatened with arrest

That quaint old fashion of shopping in the high street is not necessarily any less stressful than cyber transactions, however. G Darcy of Liverpool relates how his wife took some of her tops to Bhs in Manchester's Trafford Centre to match them up with likely dresses. On leaving the store she was detained, the police were called, her car keys confiscated and her vehicle searched in her absence. When nothing was found, her bag of clothes was taken off her and she was threatened with arrest unless she could prove that they were not stolen. The following day the Darcys had to travel back to Manchester to present the relevant receipts. Darcy complained to the store but says he received no apology from the manager. "My wife has a privilege discount card," he says. "If this is how they treat privileged customers one can only imagine what happens to shoplifters."

 "The whole thing was very unfortunate," says a Bhs spokeswoman. "Mrs Darcy will now be receiving compensation."

Tom goes on record

While cold callers make a living out of you, you could be making money out of them, according to an article in the St Petersburg Times helpfully sent in by Sylvia Trench. So infuriated was Tom Mabe of Louisville by intrusive marketing calls that he posed somewhat tastelessly as a homicidal maniac when a carpet cleaning firm called, a potential suicide for the benefit of a pre-arranged funeral firm and a range of burping red necks, deranged yuppies and flamboyant gays to disconcert whomsoever else might bother him. He recorded his best exchanges on to a CD which sold 53,000 copies and he has now been signed up by Virgin Records in Nashville.

A ticket's no proof

The formidable Cherie Blair met her match in London Underground and so has H Lane of London, who declares herself a compulsive complainer. The trouble began when Lane failed to find her tube ticket when it was requested by an inspector and was in too much of a hurry to empty out her bag in search of it. Instead she paid the £10 penalty fare on the assurance that it would be refunded when she found her ticket. She did find it, sent it off along with her penalty fare receipt - and was rebuffed.

Eventually, after pressure from the London regional passengers committee, London Underground grudgingly stumped up most of the fine, but held back £1.80 to cover the cost of Lane's original journey, which meant she'd paid twice. "They don't consider a ticket proof of purchase since I don't have a receipt and apparently work on the assumption that I've used someone else's ticket," she says.

 Unsurprisingly the passengers committee says that penalty fares are the single most complained-about issue on the tube. "We have succeeded in persuading the Underground to be more reasonable in the way they handle appeals from passengers, but ultimately the law does allow penalty fares to be charged," says a spokesman. "We hope that when the system is fully gated then the Underground will agree to abandon a system which so obviously causes grief to a minority of passengers."

However, Lane's penalty was justified, he insists. "Anyone could claim to have a ticket but be totally lying," says our spokesman. "Ms Lane is not in this category but since she was unable to show a valid ticket she's been charged as though she didn't have one."

Paying for 'free' calls

Mobile phone calls are infamously pricey, but at least you usually get a few minutes talk time for your money. Not so poor Keith Richards from London who rashly bought a Pay-as-you-go package from BT Cellnet.

A special offer gave him £10 worth of free credit and he bought a voucher worth a further £15 to get himself started. He was also given a free number with which to contact BT Cellnet. When he rang it, however, he found himself charged for the call and his frustration increased when repeated attempts to reach customer services on the line failed.

Since then, he says, he has made two brief calls which registered at around 8p, yet his phone tells him he's spent £5.30. After tireless and expensive attempts to get through to customer services on a landline he was advised to leave his phone on overnight while an engineer worked on the problem and by morning he found his credit had shrunk still further although he'd made no further calls. He's now given up trying to get through to the helpline.

 BT Cellnet says that it was equally tireless in its endeavours to send the phone a message to activate the free credit. "We didn't ignore the problem," says a spokeswoman. "It's just that our attempts failed for technical reasons." Miraculously, though, the elusive customer services did get round to contacting Richards a few days after Consumer paid them a call and he was offered £15 compensation. Too late! Richards has given up his new toy in despair.

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Disney dinosaurs upset Puttnam
fields.trailText: Teachers must counteract dazzling but inaccurate depictions of the past, like the new Disney blockbuster Dinosaurs, with equally exciting learning material, Lord Puttnam, the Oscar winner turned educationist, warned yesterday
fields.body:
Teachers must counteract dazzling but inaccurate depictions of the past, like the new Disney blockbuster Dinosaurs, with equally exciting learning material, Lord Puttnam, the Oscar winner turned educationist, warned yesterday.

The peer, now chairman of the General Teaching Council, criticised the "sanitised" Disney depiction in Dinosaurs, a computer based animation film which is breaking box office records in the US.

"It's very attractive but absolutely and specifically untrue," he said. "The dinosaurs are kind of cute - they are nice to each other, they are a benign community ... I don't think the film ever explains why they are not still around.

"It's so compelling in terms of its imagery. And, while it is remarkable, the challenge to all of us in education is to come up with something which can compete with it."

In a speech to the National Association of Head Teachers in Jersey, Lord Puttnam said teachers had to be able to "offer alternatives to the Walt Disney view of history".

By 2003, he said, Britain would have a shortfall of 330,000 people trained in information technology - "a very serious blight on our economic future".

"We cannot afford to turn our backs on the learning potential offered by digital technology and hope it will somehow go away," he said.

Outside the conference, Lord Puttnam said he was saddened by the atmosphere in schools today.

His son had taught in one school for a few weeks and had been told to walk down the corridor with his arms by his side in case female pupils barged into him and accused him of assault. Teachers were also told to keep doors open when alone with a pupil.

"It's crazy that a professional human being starts their day with a kind of assumption that they are either a serial rapist or a paedophile. That's a non-society," he said.

webTitle: June 1: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 1: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Jody Foster denies baby rumours, Spike Lee bounces back, George Clooney set for cuckold role, Gene Hackman in line for Fox thriller, Greg Kinnear up for Ashley Judd project, and Josh Hartnett proves to be hot-property
fields.body:
 Jodie Foster has moved swiftly to deny mushrooming speculation (triggered by a report in the Daily Mirror) that she is pregnant with her second child. Representatives of the 37-year-old actress insisted yesterday that the story is a complete fiction, and explain that Foster may simply have been overheard remarking that she would like a playmate for her 18-month-old son Charlie. The Mirror's original report did not go so far as to name the father of the alleged child, but Foster has always kept a tight lock on her personal life. The identity of baby number-one's dad remains one of Hollywood's most closely guarded secrets.

 Bouncing back after recent disappointments, Spike Lee has announced that he is to executive-produce an original movie for the Showtime cable channel in the US. Written and directed by Lee Davis, 3am is a New York-set drama revolving around the experiences of three taxi-drivers and the cast includes Danny Glover and Pam Grier. For Lee it's a tentative return to film-making after wary studio bosses rejected him from the job that he really wanted - the director's role on the forthcoming Muhammad Ali biopic.

 George Clooney is reported to be in negotiations to play a cuckolded husband in Unfaithful, the next film from glossy British director Adrian (Lolita) Lyne. The problem is that the film, an Americanised overhaul of Claude Chabrol's 1969 French psycho-drama La Femme Infidele, may struggle to fit into Clooney's busy schedule. With The Perfect Storm set for summer release, the ER graduate is currently shaping up to star in Ocean's Eleven for old collaborator Steven (Out of Sight) Soderbergh.

 Gene Hackman is in line to star in the Fox thriller Behind Enemy Lines, about two marines who find themselves dropped (you guessed it) behind enemy lines. One of these marines is a wet-behind-the-ears rookie, the other a grizzled old pro. No surprise to learn, then, that Hackman is tipped to play the latter part.

 Greg Kinnear is reported to be in talks to sign up to the new Ashley Judd picture, Animal Husbandry, about an anthropologically minded minx who applies the rules of the animal kingdom to her own troubled love life. Kinnear would play Judd's feckless boyfriend. Tony Goldwyn directs and the film is due to start shooting at the end of the summer.

 Consolidating his success in the likes of The Faculty and The Virgin Suicides, hot-property Josh Hartnett is in negotiations to play the lead role in 40 Days, 40 Nights, a hip comedy-drama to be co-produced by Universal and Miramax. Hartnett would play the once-burnt-twice-shy hero who gives up sex for Lent only to find his abstinence tested when he meets a young cutey to whom he just can't say no. The film is written by Rob Perez and will be directed by loose-cannon director Michael Lehmann, whose wayward career has carried him from the sublime (Heathers) to the ridiculous (Hudson Hawk). Alluring Kate Holmes (Joey out of Dawson's Creek) was initially lined up to play Hartnett's love-interest, but TV commitments are now thought to have prevented her involvement.

webTitle: Book at bedtime turns into a dream

fields.headline: Book at bedtime turns into a dream
fields.standfirst: Steven Spielberg paid $2m for a first novel by an unknown French architect.  Lanie Goodman meets the latest international publishing sensation
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg paid $2m for a first novel by an unknown French architect. Lanie Goodman meets the latest international publishing sensation
fields.body:
When the French architect Marc Levy recounted elaborate bedtime stories to his young son every night, he couldn't have dreamed that they would one day turn him into a multi-millionaire. The novel Levy based on those stories, If Only It Were True, has sold 230,000 copies and will soon be translated into 28 languages. On its release in France in January, the book went straight to the top of the bestseller list and remained there for eight consecutive weeks. It is still hovering near the top of the charts.

But the real puzzle behind the book is how an untranslated French manuscript written by a virtually unknown first-time author triggered nearly every major Hollywood studio into a bidding frenzy for screen rights. The result is that Levy's book has been bought up by Steven Spielberg's Dreamworks studios for $2m.

"The funny thing is that I've never really had any literary ambitions," says Levy, the 38-year-old director of a large architectural firm in Paris. "It always amused me to scribble down ideas and invent all kinds of characters for my son. Sometimes I pretended to take notes during professional meetings, when in fact," he smiles, "I was somewhere else."

Levy's success story began two years ago when his sister Lorraine, a television scriptwriter, discovered a half-finished manuscript and persuaded her brother to develop it for an adult audience. The novel was immediately accepted by the respected Paris publisher Robert Laffont Editions, and programmed into its bestseller collection for the coming season.

Set in San Francisco, where Levy lived as a student, If Only It Were True tells the story of Arthur, an architect who moves into an apartment and discovers in his closet the spirit of a young woman, Lauren, who has been in hospital in a coma for six months. They fall in love, but Arthur is the only one who can see her and his friends and colleagues believe he's gone mad. When doctors threaten to unplug the life-support machines, he kid naps his beloved's body in a stolen ambulance and takes her to a remote hideaway. Lauren miraculously recovers, but has no memory of her passionate affair with the stranger at her bedside, and Arthur has to court her all over again.

"Basically, it's about a guy who falls in love with the letter and not the envelope," says Levy. "It's something like Saint-Exupéry's idea in The Little Prince that you can only see clearly with the heart."

Susanna Lea, who handles international rights at Laffont, says that when she first read the manuscript, the story immediately struck her as movie material. She prepared a brief English summary of it for last October's Frankfurt book fair. "We could never have predicted it," she says, "but hours later, the phones were ringing off the hook - all the studios were calling in the middle of the night to make an offer."

No one was more surprised than Levy himself, at home in Paris, stuck in bed with Epstein-Barr virus. In the auction for the film rights, the bidding narrowed down to two studios: Fox 2000 and Dreamworks. "It wasn't a just question of money because the others were offering the same amount. I've always a had tremendous respect for Spielberg's work," he says.

Shortly afterwards, Levy was flown to New York for a five-hour meeting with Spielberg to discuss the fine points of the novel, which the director hadn't read. Once the movie option had been finalised, Susanna Lea yielded to the storm of foreign publishers clamouring to buy the book rights. "We paid seven figures for it," says Judith Curr, president and publisher of Pocketbooks, a division of Simon & Schuster.

So doesn't anyone object to the fact that literature can now be bought and sold at a colossal price solely on the basis of a minimal plot summary? "The fact that the scouts got excited after reading two paragraphs doesn't diminish Levy's novel," says Curr. "People get the essence straight away. I call it the 'tingle effect'."

So far, Levy seems undaunted by his sudden launch into literary stardom and considerable fortune. But he has decided to put architecture on hold and settle in London to work on his next book. And although Spielberg has appointed him "creative producer" of the film, Levy prefers not to say who he would cast. "It's like taking my child to see Santa Claus," he smiles. "I'm not about to ask how they're going to wrap the gifts."

 If Only it Were True is published by Fourth Estate at £10. To order a copy for £7 plus 99p UK p&p freephone 0800 3166 102 or send your order with a cheque payable to The Guardian Culture Shop, to 250 Western Avenue, London W3 6EE.

fields.headline: He does it with magic
fields.standfirst: Hollywood is filming Jack the Ripper - again. But this time the script comes from a comic. Writer Alan Moore tells  Nick Hasted  about his latest coup
fields.trailText: Hollywood is filming Jack the Ripper - again. But this time the script comes from a comic. Writer Alan Moore tells Nick Hasted about his latest coup
fields.body:
Well over six feet tall, hair and beard tangled and long, Alan Moore strides through his home town of Northampton like its secret king. His one and only novel, Voice of the Fire, explores the history of this settlement at England's geographic heart. It finishes with Moore himself stumbling into the night, wild-eyed and sickened after magically conjuring a gruesome ending for the book. "I was finding my territory, identifying myself with it, trying to become it in some mad way," he says.

Moore, 47, is better known as modern comics' writing king, transfiguring the medium with Watchmen (1987), set in a densely re-imagined America in which superheroes are atom bomb-like political pawns. It was an instant bestseller, optioned by Terry Gilliam until he acknowledged its unfilmable depths. During the brief vogue for "adult" comics that followed, Moore worked in Hollywood with Malcolm McLaren, and, at a comics convention, was hysterically mobbed.

The attention repulsed him, and despite being on the cusp of fame, he withdrew in order to begin several massively ambitious new comics outside the mainstream. Among them were a fractal maths-based examination of everyday life called Big Numbers, and From Hell, about Jack the Ripper. All these projects mysteriously stumbled. There were rumours that the FBI was chasing Big Numbers' artist, that he'd fled into the night on seeing the script's terrifying difficulty. Moore's strange success on literature's margin had crumbled.

Recently, though, a resurgence has begun. From Hell took 10 years to complete in serialised form but is now about to be published as a book. The story has drawn in new fans, among them Iain Sinclair, who admired it at length in Lights out for the Territory, his investigation into London arcana, and Oliver Stone, who bought the film rights.

Moore's take on the Ripper (here, Queen Victoria's physician, Sir William Gull) and his interest in the veins of history, myth and male destruction that spread from the murders, may not survive the transfer to Hollywood. Filming has just started in Prague, with Johnny Depp as middle-aged cockney Ripper-hunter Inspector Abberline, and Nigel Hawthorne as Gull.

Moore is too busy with a sudden stream of new comics to worry - five a month, a pace that would break most writers. Between issues, the Tate has asked him to contribute to its Blake retrospective next year. It's only right. For as he affably chats over lunch in Northampton, he reveals the secret of his renewed success. Like Blake (and other authors, including William Burroughs and Clive Barker), Moore says that, when he writes now, it's magic.

"I can remember the exact panel during the writing of From Hell when I became interested in magic," he says. "Gull says that one place that gods inarguably exist is in the human mind. I wrote that sentence, and noticed the word 'inarguable', which is quite a big word, and that was the beginning of the end. I thought, 'I can't see why that isn't true. And if it is true, then I'm probably going to have to change the whole of my life to fit around it.' "

It was on Moore's 40th birthday that he made that switch - using drugs and ritual and imaginative concentration to, he believes, conjure gods and ask them for ideas. "I told friends they ought to be keeping an eye on me. I had to really think - how will people know if I've gone mad? The only criteria I could set was, am I as creative? Am I as productive? And my creativity has gone into hack hyperdrive, where you can write five books a month, and they're all good, and you don't even get that tired.

"Writing is like a conscious trance now. I see imagination as a landscape, and if I'm imagining something that somebody else has imagined before, I go further. I might focus on a flavour, or a scent, then the conceptual detail sharpens from the fog, and I write. I can move at blinding speed from concept to concept, often without drugs and ritual.

"Any idea I derive from magic that doesn't have an application in the material world, I discard. If the ideas are good, it doesn't matter if the gods are there, does it? If I act like they are, I get a response."

Moore sees magic as a system to understand the "cold mechanics" of an area beyond scientific reach. But he knows he is open to ridicule. "I don't think many Booker writers would want to risk talking like this. It's like Brian Eno said about artists - they're superstitiously terrified of their own talent. If you really start thinking about 'inspiration', it's uncomfortably close to being spooky. It can make you sound silly."

Moore, by contrast, thinks of his attempt to map the imagination as a sensible survival tool in a world where we now spend so much time in "unreal" TV and virtual space, and information density is reaching "boiling point", prefiguring a post-industrial, post-rational age to come. "I'm trying to work out the rules. I'm lucky to be a writer now."

Moore might not have thought so 10 years back, when his most cherished projects, Big Numbers especially, crashed and burned in an extremely real collision of collapsing publishers, absconding artists, and an emotional and financial battering. From Hell is the 572-page, profound monster he pulled from the wreckage. "I wanted to extend the normal way we investigate murder in fiction," he remembers of its 1988 beginnings. "I'd read the title of Douglas Adams's book The Dirk Gently Holistic Detective Agency, and I thought that sounded like a good approach. You wouldn't just solve the crime - you'd solve the entire universe the crime existed in. I wanted to follow the threads of murder to their end."

From Hell accordingly operates as a horror story, a conspiracy theory, a thesis on how the 1880s and the Ripper crimes bled into the next 100 years of history and myth, and a re-creation of the daily lives of his prostitute victims. Its centrepiece, though, is the chapter-long chopping-up in her room of the last of them, Marie Kelly. "I dreaded writing that," Moore recalls. "I knew I'd have to spend so long in that awful little room. You've got to be aware of all the details. You're aware it's incredibly hot, because the fire melted the kettle in the hearth. You're aware it took him two hours. You're aware of the autopsy photographs, and the child-like absorption they show. And you start to think: what would be going through someone's mind for two hours, while they're cutting people's insides and arranging them round a room? I don't know if that is what it would be like. But it felt real to me."

From Hell's sympathy stays with the victims, though. On its last page, Moore watches a stripper at the Whitechapel pub where the prostitutes drank. "That's what From Hell's about in the end - a pallid little Goth dancing for men down from the City, with pictures of the victims on the walls. It's about how vulnerable we make women, and why."

Another recent Moore comic, The Birth Caul, also criticises society, but ends more optimistically. Rewinding the life of a man not unlike Moore, tearing away the compromises he's accrued, it's about our potential. "One of the prettiest things Aleister Crowley ever said is, 'Every man and woman is a star.' I believe that," Moore says with passion.

"In the human mind, the number of possible connections that can be made between neurons greatly exceeds the number of atoms in the universe. And most people watch EastEnders. I didn't start with any obvious genetic or financial benefits. I was not promising. I believe anybody could do this if they believed they could. We could be so much more potent than we are."

webTitle: The best morgue scene: Final destination

fields.headline: The best morgue scene: Final destination
fields.trailText: Following a series of prophetic visions, including the apparent suicide of his best friend Chad, Alex Browning (Devon Sawa) and his schoolmate Clear Rivers (Ali Larter) have snuck into the local morgue to see if Chad's body will yield any clues as to what's going on. At which point they're interrupted by the looming figure of the morgue attendant (Tony Todd). "Look," exclaims Alex, "I'm his friend." The morgue attendant stares at him dolefully. "I know who you are." Clear peers down at the slab. "What are all those tiny marks?" The attendant smiles. "Article lacerations from pulling at the wire." "Pulling at the wire?" "Uh-huh." "If he was pulling at the wire," Alex reasons, "then he wasn't trying to kill himself. It was an accident!" "In death, there are no accidents. No coincidences. And no escapes. What you have to realise is that we're all just a mouse that a cat has by the tail. Every move we make, from the mundane to the monumental - the red light that we stop at or run, the people that we have sex with or don't, the airplanes that we ride or walk out of - it's all part of death's sadistic design, leading to... the grave ." Alex and Clear stare at the attendant in complete silence.

webTitle: United put Barthez in goal for £7.8m

fields.headline: United put Barthez in goal for £7.8m
fields.trailText: Manchester United yesterday signed one of the most charismatic players in world football when they paid Monaco £7.8m for goalkeeper Fabien Barthez.
fields.body:
Manchester United yesterday signed one of the most charismatic players in world football when they paid Monaco £7.8m for goalkeeper Fabien Barthez.

The 28-year-old French international agreed a six-year deal worth £45,000 a week.

Barthez is best known for his shaven head and on-off relationship with the supermodel Linda Evangelista, a celebrity coupling that turned them into the continental equivalent of David Beckham, his new team-mate at United, and Posh Spice.

He is so popular in France that only the issues of Paris Match magazine dedicated to the deaths of former president François Mitterrand and Diana, Princess of Wales sold more than the 1.1m copies when he was on the cover.

Yesterday he was unfazed by his new move. "I have played in a World Cup final and Champions League final before and nothing troubles me," he said. "Everybody knows that Manchester United are the big club, the big team."

Sir Alex Ferguson, the United manager, said: "I'm delighted that Fabien has joined us. Apart from his goalkeeping skills, he has the personality to play on the biggest stage."

Barthez's stay promises to be eventful. In 1995 he was suspended for two months for using cannabis, and earlier this year his coach at Monaco accused him of throwing a game against Marseille, his former club. Barthez denied the claim.

fields.headline: Walk this way
fields.standfirst:
John Prescott's transport strategy will try to encourage us on to our feet. But will a decrease in car journeys reduce child pedestrian deaths?
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott may or may not have won a huge sum for transport, but what he does now have is a national strategy for the transport we use most - our legs. Except walking is not actually a strategy and it is not national. Somewhere between his transport white paper (full of promises) and delivery, the strategy was downgraded to "advice" to councils to encourage walking.
fields.body:
John Prescott may or may not have won a huge sum for transport, but what he does now have is a national strategy for the transport we use most - our legs. Except walking is not actually a strategy and it is not national. Somewhere between his transport white paper (full of promises) and delivery, the strategy was downgraded to "advice" to councils to encourage walking.

Page one of the document (www.detr.gov.uk) concedes defeat. "None of this will make much difference to car mileage, air pollution or global warming". A bit of a damp squib for a statement four years in the making, initiated by Tory transport minister Steve Norris.

The government still has the opportunity to redeem itself. Its 10-year transport plan is due out in July. It will focus on the investment needed - Mr Prescott's putative £140bn. But amid the billions needed for roads and railways there is a danger that local transport, and pedestrians in particular, will hardly get a look in.

Walking may not have the glamour of high-speed rail services or the middle England appeal of the motor car but it matters. More than one quarter of all journeys is made on foot, including about 80% of journeys less than a mile in length. Walking is the most egalitarian, the most environmentally friendly and arguably the most sociable mode of travel. As Ben Plowden of the Pedestrians' Association puts it, walking is the glue that binds the transport system together. Most journeys by public transport and many by car involve one or more stages of walking.

Perhaps the problem is that walking matters to the poor more than the rich. Some 60% of households in the lowest income quintile do not have a car. People from these households make about 60% of their journeys on foot. If you add to that the walk to and from the bus stop, then eight out of ten journeys made by people from low-income non-car owning households involve walking. By contrast, people from high-income car owning households make about 75% of their journeys by car and less than 20% on foot. The chart illustrates this.

Added to this is the scandal of the UK's record on the safety of children. Child pedestrians from the lowest socio-economic group are five times as likely to be killed in road accidents as their wealthy counterparts. One study of Edinburgh and the surrounding Lothian region showed that children from poor districts were eight times as likely to be knocked down in traffic accidents as those from the leafy suburbs. The children who are the least likely to enjoy the benefits of cars are the most likely to be run over by them.

The UK has a good road safety record overall but on child pedestrian casualties it has one of the worst records in Europe. The UK rate for child pedestrian fatalities is double that of Germany and a third higher than France. More than 130 children were killed and more than 4,500 seriously injured while walking or cycling in 1998, the most recent year for which figures are available.

The journey to school provides one of the best illustrations of the potential contribution of walking to sustainable transport policies. On weekday mornings during term time, at the peak hour of 8.50am, nearly one in five cars on urban roads is ferrying children to school. This is the result of a near doubling in the proportion of journeys to school by car over the last decade, from 16% to 29%. The increase in car use corresponds mainly to a reduction in walking. Children's health and independence have been the losers along with the environment. Only one in eleven primary pupils now goes to school unaccompanied, while 10 years ago one in five did.

The school travel advisory group, established by government to advise on how to reduce the number of car journeys to school, recommends a return by 2010 to the level of walking, cycling and bus journeys to school in the mid-80s. This would mean 80% walking, cycling and bus use for primary pupils compared with 63% now and 90% for secondary pupils compared with 79% now. Needless to say the government has not endorsed these targets.

There is no difficulty in resolving the paradox of Britain's very bad record of child pedestrian injuries and its declining walk rate to school. One of the most effective ways of reducing road accidents and encouraging walking is by reducing speeds; 20mph zones, which combine the lower speed limit with traffic calming measures, reduce the overall accident rate by 60% and the child pedestrian accident rate in particular by 70%.

A 10-year programme of 20mph zones targeted at the 3,000 most deprived neighbourhoods in England identi fied by the Social Exclusion Unit, for example, would cost about £500m: small beer. There are nine "home zone" pilots that go a step further with a complete makeover in street design to create a safe environment for pedestrians and children.

If the government is going to meet its own target of reducing the number of child pedestrian deaths and serious injuries by 50% by 2010 it will have to get serious about walking. In addition to reducing speeds, feasible measures include better pavements, lighting and safer road crossings. Most are small and local. Individually they will not grab the national headlines. But taken together they would slowly and surely challenge our car culture. And that would be better for everyone.

 Tony Grayling is a transport specialist at the Institute for Public Policy Research.

Tony Grayling
