fields.headline: A message to the people of Freetown
fields.standfirst: The following is the full text of a message distributed by British troops to the people of Freetown
fields.trailText: 'The UK military has acheived its mission of stabilising the security situation in Sierra Leone while Unamsil reinforcements arrive.
fields.body:
'The UK military has acheived its mission of stabilising the security situation in Sierra Leone while Unamsil reinforcements arrive.

As Unamsil reinforces and assumes the role of defending Lungi airport there will be a withdrawal of British troops.

However, a strong British military team will assist the Government Defence Forces and Unamsil. The essential technical and other advice given to both will remain firmly in place.'

fields.headline: Hooked on secrecy
fields.standfirst: Knowledge is therapeutic. Let it flow
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor's towering trilogy about Northern Ireland came to a close on BBC2 last night. Only a journalist of his standing could have persuaded people from all sides of this conflict to cooperate in such a manner
fields.body:
Peter Taylor's towering trilogy about Northern Ireland came to a close on BBC2 last night. It has been an extraordinary series in which terrorists, soldiers, politicians and spies have spoken frankly about the last 30 years in a troubled corner of the United Kingdom. Only a journalist of his standing could have persuaded people from all sides of this conflict to cooperate in such a manner. The result was a first rate piece of journalism. It was also first rate history. Much that has hitherto been obscure or hidden was revealed or clarified for the first time. More satisfying still, the programmes also felt as though they were some part of a process of truth and reconciliation. There was a feeling of closure in the way that former enemies were willing to speak about their spent hatreds and grim deeds.

Apart from what the series told us about Northern Ireland there are two wider points to be made. One is about the BBC. The entire series took five years to make. It was never going to reach a mass audience (though many serious newspapers and magazines would be pleased to reach its audience of 1.5m). It involved thousands of hours of research, a hundred hours of filming and, in Peter Taylor's case, a lifetime of contacts and reading. It is no coincidence that the other outstanding documentary series of the past five years, Norma Percy's The Death of Yugoslavia, was also commissioned and shown by the BBC. Every time a Murdoch tabloid sneers at the BBC, remember these two series. There is still such a thing as serious television journalism in this country and it appears to be increasingly pointless to expect it any more from ITV. There was some small irony that the last episode of Mr Taylor's series coincided with the Independent Television Commission asking whether public service broadcasting can be sustained - or is even "needed" - any longer on commercial channels.

The second point concerns the role of journalists in informing citizens about what the security services do in their name. Peter Taylor had no cooperation from the Ministry of Defence in tracking down and speaking to former members of the intelligence community in Northern Ireland. Some of those he did trace were warned against speaking to him, with the threat of ostracism or financial penalty. We can confidently predict that those who defied these threats will not be prosecuted. Mr Taylor's reputation for responsible film-making is so well established that it would be madness to pick on those who cooperated with him.

Colonel Nigel Wylde, a holder of the Queen's Gallantry Medal for his work in Northern Ireland, is less fortunate. He is currently being prosecuted under the Official Secrets Act for allegedly helping the author Tony Geraghty with research. The MoD has nine injunctions in place against former soldiers preventing them from publishing books or speaking out. The government also has an injunction preventing the Sunday Times and its Irish correspondent Liam Clarke from writing about collusion between army intelligence officers and Loyalists. The Guardian and its sister paper, the Observer, are both being pursued by the police to hand over material which might incriminate the former MI5 officer, David Shayler. The former head of MI5, Stella Rimington, is being demonised for writing an account of her time in the security services. A secret offshoot of the cabinet office's joint intelligence committee, chaired by a diplomat, Michael Pakenham, is reported to be behind these Draconian attempts to pursue individuals, with Mr Blair's blessing.

At the same time the government is passing still further laws jeopardising journalists working in this area. The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill extends existing bugging and tapping powers to all forms of communication, including mobile phones, emails and pictures sent electronically. The police would find it much easier to acquire data, including addresses of emails sent and received as well as websites hit and browsed by journalists, who could then no longer guarantee the security and identity of their sources. The Terrorism Bill, also going through the Lords, makes it an offence for anyone - including journalists - not to disclose to the police any information obtained about the activities or intentions of "terrorists", or those they suspect of being "terrorists" - a term capable of very broad definition. fields.headline: Gunman takes children hostage
fields.standfirst: 'We are in contact with the hostage taker. We hope to have a solution without any physical problems on any side'
fields.trailText: A heavily armed man was holding more than 20 children and three teachers hostage in a nursery in Luxembourg early today, demanding to be flown to Libya and threatening to become violent if his demands were not met.
fields.body:
A heavily armed man was holding more than 20 children and three teachers hostage in a nursery in Luxembourg early today, demanding to be flown to Libya and threatening to become violent if his demands were not met.

The man walked into the daycare centre in Wasserbillig, a village on the Luxembourg-German border, during the afternoon with a pistol, hand grenade and knife.

The gunman had earlier let 16 other children walk to safety after he was allowed to speak to his psychiatrist, a police spokesman, Victor Schlentz, said. The authorities were talking to the man by telephone.

He had talked to a lawyer, demanding free passage if he let the children go. The youngsters are aged from a few months to seven years.

Late last night the building was completely surrounded by around 100 special armed gendarmes. Rows of ambulances and fire engines were standing nearby.

"The situation is calm and stable," Joseph Schmit, the regional police director, told reporters. "We are in contact with the hostage taker. We hope to have a solution without any physical problems on any side," he said.

The police were still trying to verify exactly how many children were left in the classroom, as they were unable to see from the outside.

"We believe we are talking about 25 to 30 children, we are still trying to verify that," said Victor Schlentz of the Luxembourg police.

The interior minister, Michel Wolter, told a news conference that the man was of Algerian origin but had held Luxembourg nationality since 1982. He has a history of mental problems.

"I have given orders that the situation be ended without vi olence. Negotiations are still going on," Mr Wolter said.

"The situation is relatively stable, the children have had something to eat and drink and have been put to bed," he said, adding that medicine would also be taken to the building.

"We think we know the motive," he said. "The reasons for what he is doing are in his former family life."

The man's children, who were taken from him by social services, had attended the nursery.

Mr Schmit said no more details would be given as the man was listening to news bulletins on a radio and had been angered by reports about his mental health.

Negotiations with the man, who has asked for a car as well as a plane, were progressing slowly. The police appeared to be unwilling to force the pace.

The parents of the children being held were given counselling at the local community centre.

According to local officials, 14 of the children still in the nursery were Portuguese.

webTitle: Mandelson rounds on DUP over disruption plan

fields.headline: Mandelson rounds on DUP over disruption plan
fields.trailText: The hardline Democratic Unionist party, led by the Reverend Ian Paisley, was yesterday criticised for its attempts to bring down the Good Friday agreement from within the Stormont executive.
fields.body:
The hardline Democratic Unionist party, led by the Reverend Ian Paisley, was yesterday criticised for its attempts to bring down the Good Friday agreement from within the Stormont executive.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, said the DUP's plan to disrupt the province's newly-restored power-sharing executive was futile.

"Opposition for opposition's sake gets absolutely nowhere," he said. "People who voted for the DUP should be properly represented by the DUP."

The DUP yesterday unveiled its plan to frustrate the work of the reformed executive.

Peter Robinson and Nigel Dodds will return as ministers for regional development and social development, but will refuse to sit in the executive and will resign when the DUP fails in an attempt to have Sinn Fein thrown out.

But instead of allowing the posts to be filled by the pro-agreement Ulster Unionists and Alliance party, the DUP will rotate them through its assembly members.

The plans were attacked by various members of the executive, including first minister, David Trimble, and his deputy Seamus Mallon. Mr Trimble accused the DUP of "playing games".

Mr Mallon said: "I can assure you we will not allow this political party to play Russian roulette with their departments and with the political process."

webTitle: Death of former MP who courted trouble

fields.headline: Death of former MP who courted trouble
fields.trailText: Andrew Faulds, the former actor and Labour MP, died yesterday aged 77.
fields.body:
Andrew Faulds, the former actor and Labour MP, died yesterday aged 77.

Mr Faulds represented Warley East in the West Midlands from 1966 to 1997. Last night veteran Labour MP Tony Benn described him as "very direct and blunt in his manner, passionately in favour of the European Union and a strong supporter of the Arab cause.

"He spoke his mind and didn't much care what people thought about it. He had very definite opinions and was inclined to explode with anger. As a result he was a memorable figure and quite a character in the House of Commons."

The assistant general secretary of the Labour Party, Phil Murphy, described him as "one of the great personalities in the House of Commons". "He was never a predictable character and that added to his attraction. He was also a loyal servant of the Labour party."

Mr Faulds appeared in several TV productions and one of his best known roles was as Jet Morgan in the 50s radio series Journey into Space. He also played Carver Doone in the TV series Lorna Doone and starred in the film Jason and the Argonauts as well as numerous Ken Russell films.

He entered parliament in 1966, representing the now defunct Smethwick constituency before Warley East. He kept his Equity card and was in demand for TV voice-overs.

In April 1967, he attacked Norman St John-Stevas for discussing abortion "when he has not the capacity to put a bun in anybody's oven". In 1982, Mr Faulds was suspended from the Commons for five days for insisting on speaking out against the Falklands war.

Fervently pro-Arab and anti-Zionist in the Middle East, he was sacked as arts spokesman by Harold Wilson for a quip about a Labour MP as better off representing the Knesset. Although reappointed as arts spokesman in 1979, he was again sacked by Michael Foot in May 1982 for voting against the Falklands war.

Mr Faulds leaves a wife, Bunty, a daughter and two grandchildren.

fields.headline: Ethiopia ends war with Eritrea
fields.trailText: The Ethiopian prime minister yesterday declared his country's two-year border war with Eritrea over, saying that Ethiopia had recaptured all the disputed land which Eritrea occupied by force in May 1998.
fields.body:
The Ethiopian prime minister yesterday declared his country's two-year border war with Eritrea over, saying that Ethiopia had recaptured all the disputed land which Eritrea occupied by force in May 1998.

Meles Zenawi was quoted on Ethiopian state television as saying, "The war against Eritrea has been accomplished in victory."

His announcement came after two days of peace talks between the two sides in Algeria, during which an accord for implementing a peace deal agreed more than a year ago was finally struck.

But an Eritrean government spokesman, Yermane Gebremeskel, said: "They [Ethiopia] cannot say the war is over when they still occupy Eritrean territory," referring to the thousands of square miles of southern Eritrea that Ethiopia has occupied since launching a massive offensive on May 12.

Eritrea says that Ethiopia must withdraw all its forces to their pre-May 1998 positions before Eritrea will consider the war over.

But despite Eritrean reluctance to confirm an end to the war, Ethiopia is in the military ascendancy and if it is prepared to withdraw its forces from undisputed Eritrean territory then Eritrea is unlikely to reignite the conflict.

Ethiopia and its former ally, Eritrea, came to blows in May 1998 when Eritrea invaded parts of northern Ethiopia.

Two years of offensive and counter-offensive followed in which first world war-style trench battles were fought and in which hundreds died for every metre of territory gained.

But last month's offensive changed that as Ethiopian troops broke through the lines and advanced rapidly into western and southern Eritrea. Hundreds of thousands of civilians fled.

The peace deal calls for both sides to withdraw to pre-war positions and for an independent commission to delineate their common border.

A United Nations World Food Programme spokesperson said that if farmers did not get home and plant their crops as soon as possible the harvest would fail, leaving millions in need of food aid.

Ethiopia's declaration last night is a clear sign that Eritrea is offering little resistance to Ethiopia's demands at the negotiating table.

According to western diplomats in the Eritrean capital Asmara, Eritrea had little will to fight once Ethiopian troops broke through its lines and into Eritrean territory.

After Ethiopian diplomats in Algeria had assuaged Eritrean fears that Ethiopia wished to conquer the entire country, Eritrea would have seen little sense in continuing a war of attrition, they said.

The popular Eritrean government will sell the deal to their people as a victory, they predicted.

webTitle: Back to his roots - with a five year plan

fields.headline: Back to his roots - with a five year plan
fields.standfirst: Labour's 27-year-old candidate for Tottenham relishes the chance to succeed Bernie Grant
fields.trailText: Labour's 27-year-old candidate for Tottenham relishes the chance to succeed Bernie Grant.
fields.body:
As hot seats go David Lammy's looks a comfortable one. He sits in a deep armchair at the Greater London assembly's temporary offices in Westminster, sporting an intimidating CV for a 27-year-old and a sharp mohair suit to match. Unusually for a barrister, he wears it with a white T-shirt.

Lammy is talking about his brief career as a GLA member. Ken Livingstone, the mayor, had offered him the chairmanship of the fire authority which he turned down, preferring backbench scrutiny to policy making at this stage.

In any case, his GLA career is all but certain to end on June 22 after just seven weeks. He has just been selected as the Labour candidate for the byelection in Tottenham, north London.

It will take a serious, and unlikely, upset to defeat him. The late much-mourned Bernie Grant had a majority of 20,200 after the Blair landslide. But he is dead at 56 and Tottenham Labour party has just had to choose between the late MP's white wife, Sharon Grant, and one of his black protegees, David Lammy.

A commercial litigator with the firm of DJ Freeman, with a string of "first" and "youngest" achievements behind him (he even sits on the Church of England's archbishops' council), Lammy won by 52% on the first ballot, 172 votes out of the 300-plus party members who took part.

Why? "A combination of many things," he explains. "They liked the fact that I was local, very local. My life and my family's life was very similar to many Tottenham families, many party members knew me.

"You can't stand in Tottenham and win with 172 votes unless people believe you can speak with an authentic voice about their needs and the issues. They know damn well that I can do that because I'm from the area and I'm not some kind of Millbank stooge or lobby fodder."

At the selection meeting he insisted that his life had been tough too, despite the golden CV. "Tough that my father left, tough that my mother raised four of us on income support, tough that I experienced stop and search, tough that I found myself being confused with the criminals at the bar." He was briefly - two months - on the dole in Tottenham.

But all this is explained with the fluent self-assurance of one of life's lottery winners and Lammy is still in the hot seat. He has been denounced as a middle class Blairite who does not understand the needs of working class Tottenham as Bernie and Sharon did.

He may be black and, like Grant, of Guyanese stock, but how could a boy who went away to choir school and on, after Harvard, to became a barrister understand? The London Socialist Alliance has already promised to run against him.

In his first interview since last Thursday's selection, Lammy is keen to get across his commitment to Tottenham and to proclaim his roots. Many of his family live there, although he does not. He still goes home a lot, still worships at St Phillip's.

Tottenham, he says, is in London's fourth most deprived borough, ninth in the country. "I would not have left the GLA for any other seat. I can put my hand on my heart and say that. The GLA is very exciting, there's lots to do."

Lammy grew up in Totten ham, the son of immigrant parents, "aspiring people from the Commonwealth".

His father ran a small business which foundered. "He became a broken man under Thatcher, he scarpered." Lammy's mother raised four kids alone, never on more than £12,000 a year.

He attended the local Downhills primary school where he showed he had a good voice. The school head and a priest suggested he went to King's, the state boarding school which provides choristers for Peterborough cathedral.

"We didn't have much sense of what it was about as a family. Initially I wasn't keen."

In 1983 Peterborough was an expanding overspill town full of ex-Tottenham families. But Lammy was the only black pupil and found it hard. Only at GCSE time did things start to click. "I was a late developer," he says.

But develop he did. "I would have gone to Cambridge, had they not rejected me," he says, endorsing the chancellor Gordon Brown's recent critique. "These interviews are daunting, they are gruelling, not easily accessible to kids who do not come, palpably, from an upper middle class background - and I didn't."

So he read law at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London and then started at the bar. Soon after, he applied to do an MA at Harvard and, when accepted, took a sabbatical.

"It was incredibly exciting, and not what I thought it might be - a seriously elitist institution - mixing with the sons and daughters of the great and good.

"The law school was very diverse ... the programme for scholarships was amazing for kids from deprived areas. Bizarrely enough there were more kids from my background - not Tottenham, but Harlem or Detroit - than in any English academic institution I'd been involved in."

He came to politics via a different route. His uncle had been a Labour councillor in Newham and SOAS was a left-leaning college. Time spent in the US after his studies at Harvard fired him up about the mayoral model for urban politics. The wily Willie Brown, now mayor of San Francisco, impressed him hugely when he worked there.

Then there was Bernie. The MP had helped the family with its education - his brother and sisters (all in state schools) did well too. Bernie had "been a hero to many of us ... He was fantastic in encouraging people to get into politics. Oona King [the MP for Bethnal Green and Bow] would say so too, a very approachable MP to the younger generation."

Turning to the future of Tottenham, he thumps the armchair and tells how young families who should be to staying are currently having kids and moving on to Enfield, Barnet or, the posh end of the borough, Muswell Hill. "They're the people we need to stay to get Tottenham moving."

"I don't represent the status quo for Tottenham. What I am interested in is transforming Tottenham, in changing it. If in five years time we're not jumping out of those [deprivation] statistics, if in 10 years time we are not well out of it I will have failed," he says.

A bold claim, but others are bolder. One London Labour MP says "Britain's first black prime minister?" - only half in jest. It is a heavy burden of expectation for a the standard-bearer for new generation to carry.

The MP had helped the family with its education - his brother and sisters (all in state schools) did well too. Bernie had "been a hero to many of us ... He was fantastic in encouraging people to get into politics. Oona King [the MP for Bethnal Green and Bow] would say so too, a very approachable MP to the younger generation." Turning to the future of Tottenham, he thumps the armchair and tells how young families who should be to staying are currently having kids and moving on to Enfield, Barnet or, the posh end of the borough, Muswell Hill. "They're the people we need to stay to get Tottenham moving." "I don't represent the status quo for Tottenham. What I am interested in is transforming Tottenham, in changing it. If in five years time we're not jumping out of those [deprivation] statistics, if in 10 years time we are not well out of it I will have failed," he says. A bold claim, but others are bolder. One London Labour MP says "Britain's first black prime minister?" - only half in jest. It is a heavy burden of expectation for a the standard-bearer for new generation to carry.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: A watched pot boils faster | Baby island born | Cosmic wind
fields.body:
A watched pot boils faster
The old adage that a watched pot never boils could be wrong in the weird world of quantum physics. The Quantum Zeno Effect states that the act of observation can change that which is observed - just by looking, the observer slows down quantum processes. Drs Gershon Kurizki and Abraham Kofman from the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Israel, argue that the reverse is likely to occur: watching a process speeds it up. Apparently, the Quantum Zeno Effect applies only to a few processes. Normal kinds of decay such as the emission of particles of light increase as an observer measures the rate of decay. In other words, molecules change from one state to another more quickly when they are watched. The experimenters haven't yet tested the theory by keeping an eye on their kettle. Source: Nature

Baby island born
Scientists have just witnessed the birth of a new island in the Pacific. The team from CSIRO Exploration and Mining were exploring volcanic activity in the Bismarck Sea and the Pacific and found a volcano in the Solomon Islands, which had been dormant for nine years, spouting molten lava 70m above sea level, and releasing 500m high plumes of sulphur gas. The scientists took samples from the island as it was forming, and measured the effect of the Kavachi volcano on the ocean's chemistry.

Cosmic wind
Winds traveling at 1 million miles per hour are released just before matter is sucked into black holes. Nasa's Chandra X-ray Observatory examined black holes in the galaxy NGC 3783 and discovered the biggest produces more radiation than a billion suns as gas is sucked into the hole at almost the speed of light. Some of this gas is absorbed by the hole, the rest is heated to more than 100,000 degrees Celsius and driven into the galaxy at a million miles an hour. "This is the most detailed X-ray spectrum ever taken of a galaxy with an active black hole," says Dr Shai Kaspi, of Penn State. "It reveals that the wind contains oxygen, neon, magnesium, silicon, sulfur, argon and iron."

fields.headline: Divided we stand tall
fields.standfirst: Teaching plant cells to split faster has a huge effect on growth, writes  Claire Cockcroft
fields.trailText: Teaching plant cells to split faster has a huge effect on growth, writes Claire Cockcroft
fields.body:
Breeding better crops that grow faster is high on the agricultural agenda. Now scientists have discovered a novel way of speeding up plant growth rate using a naturally occurring plant protein that regulates cell division, according to today's edition of Nature magazine. The final size of the plants and other characteristics, however, are not altered - fields of colossal crops will not be on the horizon; the plants will just reach maturity earlier.

Plants need to respond rapidly to variations in their external and internal environment because when a location becomes unpleasant they cannot up and move to more satisfying surroundings. Instead they alter their architecture by growing more roots or leaves to make the most of available nutrients. But the exact way in which this floral foraging occurs is something of an enigma.

Researchers at the Institute of Biotechnology in Cambridge and Aventis CropScience in Belgium are investigating the growth and adaptability of plants and have found that cell division is a critical factor in determining how plants react to environmental changes. Cell division occurs mainly at the growing tip of the shoot and roots in special zones called meristems. It's the activity of these regions that determines the architecture and growth rate of all plants.

During the cell division cycle, a complex process unfolds: specific protein complexes orchestrate a cascade of chemical activity within the cell and interact with the cell's structural machinery. Regulatory proteins called cyclins are central to this intricate process in animals, plants and yeasts. They get together with their catalytic protein partner, called a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) which becomes activated at particular points in the cycle if specific signals indicate that the time is right to divide. These complexes are the guardians of the gate, patrolling proliferation.

The Cambridge team, led by Dr Jim Murray, discovered the CycD family of genes from a tiny plant known as Arabidopsis. Plant D-type cyclins respond to extra-cellular signals such as sugar availability and control the point during the cell cycle at which cells become committed to division.

They discovered that engineering tobacco, another favourite experimental plant, with the Arabidopsis CycD2 gene leads to faster growth, measured as biomass accumulation, height and root development, and improved vigour in the field.' Four weeks after germination the altered plants were up to twice the size of the control plants. The plants produce new leaf organs more rapidly and, because they reach maturity more quickly, they flower up to two weeks earlier.

The Arabidopsis CycD2 protein associates with a tobacco CDK partner, forming a biochemically active complex that can drive the cell cycle. Elevated levels of CycD2-CDK complexes enhance plant growth rate by accelerating the rate at which new cells are produced in the meristems.

P ainstaking studies, taken over a 20-hour period, show that the cell cycle is shorter and that there are larger numbers of faster cycling cells in the meristem than in the control plants. These faster rates of cell division in the meristems do not affect cell size or meristem structure, but result in more rapid production of new leaves.

"The way plants react to environmental influences by altering their growth rate has always been rather obscure," says Dr Murray. "This research points to cell division as playing a key role."

Plants were previously thought to grow at a maximum rate under given circumstances. Discovering that a naturally occurring plant regulatory protein can accelerate growth shows that growth is not intrinsically optimised and that cell division influences the activity of meristems and overall plant growth rate. This challenges the widely held view that cell division is not the major driving force for growth and only occurs to subdivide space.

Conventional breeding tries to improve crop performance by crossing closely related species but this random shuffling of genes can sometimes cause unwanted side effects. The fine-tuning of one gene appears to be a precise way of increasing growth rate without introducing detrimental side-effects from the gene pool.

Arabidopsis belongs to the Brassica family, an extensive plant group which includes all the vegetables children love to hate: cabbage, cauliflower and brussel sprouts. As many of its genes closely resemble those from oilseed rape and cereals, these findings have good implications for crop design, potentially shortening the time to harvest, giving greater flexibility of sowing time and faster crop rotation during a single growing season.

There are also environmental benefits. Since the plants show improved competition against weeds and grow more vigorously in the early stages of growth, this reduces the need for widespread crop spraying with herbicides. If this technology is transferable to trees, it could be beneficial for the forestry industry: to grow trees more quickly for timber production or for environmentally friendly energy production initiatives such as the Arable Biomass Renewable Energy (ARBOR) project in Yorkshire.

fields.headline: The scent of the maggot
fields.standfirst: Sanjida O'Connell on the worm's turn and the lessons of the smell of grub
fields.trailText: Sanjida O'Connell on the worm's turn and the lessons of the smell of grub
fields.body:
The subject may seem redolent of an old music hall joke: "I say, I say, I say, my dog has no nose!" "How does he smell?" "Terrible!"

So begins Dr Matthew Cobb's explanation of how maggots smell. (Terrible? He would defend them, it's only the rotting flesh they inhabit that stinks.) The olfactory habits of maggots may sound arcane, but working out how maggots sniff out food could have profound implications for agriculture, as well as furthering our understanding of how our ability to smell actually works.

Cobb, who is at the Laboratoire d'Ecologie in Paris, normally studies adult maggots in the form of fruit flies. "I was always very snotty about maggots because they don't do much. They're nothing but a moving bag of genes that has to eat. You can get flies to mate and learn." Cobb then realised that the maggot's very simplicity means it is an easier system to understand.

"They have a mindless existence: you starve them and put them in front of a smell and they move towards it." What better, if smell in maggots is what excites you?

Now that the genome of fruit flies has been unraveled, it's been discovered that they have 50 different genes which code for 1,200 nerves used to detect smell. But the maggot has only 21 nerves for smell and no one knows which genes are involved. What scientists do know is that none of the genes that allow a fly to develop a sense of smell are used by the maggot. This suggests that all maggots may have the same olfactory system whether they are a blow fly larva or stag beetle grub which developed several million years ago.

How we all smell is a subject that has intrigued the best and brightest minds throughout history. The Greek philosopher Democritus, who conceived the idea of atoms, thought sweet smells were produced by round atoms and sharp scents by pointy ones and, according to Cobb, our understanding hasn't advanced much.

In the 1660s a Dutch scientist, Jan Swammerdam, tried to figure out how the maggot, this sack of jelly with a mini nervous system and no discernible nose, could smell. His perception is still thought to be astounding more than 400 years later. Maggots have a dorsal organ on their head which is covered in a mucous layer that traps smells. They have proteins that bind to smells. "They protect and carry them like a molecular chaperone," says Cobb, transporting them to receptor cells. But it is not known how these alleged receptor cells do the business of smelling, or even what they might look like.

Apparently fruit fly larvae can detect 45 out of 52 smells they were given, and onion fly maggots can smell 27 odours found in onions. The test is to put a bunch of larvae in a dish with a smell at one end and count how many gravitate towards the smell: a scientific version of the Guinness ad's Cuban snail race where the protagonists slide speedily towards an overturned pint.

It is hardly surprising that research on the olfactory ability of the cabbage root fly shows that they can smell cabbages. The trouble is, it has proved impossible to tell if the maggots are reacting to all the smells, or if they can distinguish between them.

But why should maggots be able to smell anyway? Mother flies lay their eggs on prime food, be it a rotten apple or a decomposing animal, and all the maggot has to do is eat. Cobb doesn't believe the maggots' ability is an evolutionary hang-up; they have been around for 40 million years and if they haven't got rid of their sense of smell by now, there must be a reason. One explanation could be that if a maggot falls off its food, it could use its sense of smell to negotiate its way back.

Another is that smell would allow maggot to discriminate between shades of decomposition. Fruit and flesh don't decompose at the same rate, so smell could help them avoid toxic substances that build up in some areas and not others.

Forensic science relies on being able to pinpoint death by the number, type and age of maggots in the corpse: different species of maggot are attracted by specific rates of decay which they might be able to determine through their sense of smell.

S mell may also help maggots to help us inadvertently. Henry VIII used them to heal his ulcers, and the Seaman's Mission in Greenwich also employed them for a time. The ability of maggots to facilitate wound healing was first noticed on the battlefield when maggots accidentally infected wounds. During the American Civil War, a confederate officer remarked: "I have frequently seen neglected wounds filled with maggots... as far as my experience extends, these worms only destroy dead tissues, and do not injure specifically the well parts." The maggots might use smell to discriminate between healthy and rotting tissue.

An alternative idea is that the food the larva feeds on could influence where and on what the adult lays eggs. Once the larvae have reached a certain size, they form pupae. Inside the cocoon they dissolve completely; this molecular soup reforms as an adult fly. And yet some memories of smells learnt by the larvae are retained as adults. This seems remarkable, but the brain of the maggot is the only organ which does not dissolve and it may be that neuronal patterns laid down in the brain are preserved in the adult. But as Cobb says, these explanations are "all rather sad. It's junior school nature study rather than science. No one knows why maggots smell."

The research might help farmers: it might be possible to find a substance that smells so attractive to maggots, they would migrate out of their preferred food, cabbage roots, in the case of the cabbage root fly which can devastate whole fields, and could be trapped.

As for Cobb, he is following in Swammerdam's footsteps: the Dutch scientist studied the cheese skipper fly which infests cheese.

"These mites, when they are about to become nymphs, generally desert the cheese in which they had hitherto lived, by leaping up and down, till they find, if possible, a more favourable situation."

The maggots hold their tail in their mouth and bounce. By letting go of their tails they can jump about two feet. In Corsica and Sardinia, cheese riddled with maggots is considered a great delicacy, though not recommended by the medical establishment.

Recently Cobb attempted to cultivate these maggots by feeding them Camembert. But apparently they were not interested in French cheese.

fields.headline: Living for the future
fields.standfirst: The automated home that science fiction writers have only dreamed of could                                                                     be with us sooner than you think, writes Jack Schofield
fields.trailText: The automated home that science fiction writers have only dreamed of could be with us sooner than you think, writes Jack Schofield
fields.body:
The UK is to get a Home of the Future, thanks to two Belgians. Peter Bongers and Frank Beliën have been working on a project called Living Tomorrow for a decade, and last week they opened their second futuristic home on the outskirts of Brussels. Now they're planning a series across the globe, starting in Amsterdam in 2002. "We think that if a project like this can work in Brussels then it can work anywhere," says Bongers with a grin.

"We're also working on a Living Tomorrow in Berlin and, in the near future, we aim to develop projects in the United States and China as well. Our ambition is to become world number one in a market that doesn't really exist at present." Bongers hopes the development of the London version will parallel the one in the Netherlands. "We are very very close to a deal in London, near the Millennium Dome," he says. Whether the Dome will still be there is another matter, but Living Tomorrow isn't aimed at passing tourists so much as groups of professionals who are given customised tours.

The future homes can't handle more than about 200,000-300,000 visitors a year, and there isn't room for all the people who want to see them. Bongers and Beliën started their project in 1991, and Microsoft boss Bill Gates - well known for his own futuristic home near Seattle, Washington - opened their first house of the future in 1995. Living Tomorrow 2 (see www.livtom.com) is also scheduled to last five years: even though the installation is continuously upgraded, the pace of development is so rapid that the future soon goes out of date.

The house - which is a house, a laboratory and a showroom - covers 3,700 square metres, including a lecture theatre and meeting rooms. It cost Euro 14.5m (£9m) to put together, and there's another  8m (£5m) in the "media budget". Even if it attracts the expected 200,000 visitors a year for five years, that's £14 a head: not cheap. About half of the products in the house are already on sale, the other half are prototypes and research products. The project's 96 commercial partners (four places are still available) use the house to find out how their products can work together, as well as for marketing purposes. For example, MXK (Moulinex-Krups) had to develop ways to network its microwave oven so that it could be controlled from the house's kitchen computer.

Of course, not all the partners are developing electronics products. A lot of them are working with paints, tiles and other building materials. Heating, plumbing, and waste disposal problems need more than microchips. Nonetheless, it is possible to apply electronics in interesting ways. Sleepy's Ergosleep bed, for example, is computer controlled: it raises and lowers a series of slats to match the bed to the sleeper's profile.

Obviously the whole house is wired to the internet, and Joachim De Vos, the project's information and communications technology manager, says everything is done using IP, the internet protocol. The television sets, telephones and computers don't have separate connections as they would today: everything is delivered via the net.

De Vos says the problem with using IP is that it has no "quality of service" provision that would enable different traffic to be given priority: you might be unable to phone the police because the TV set is using all the bandwidth to download a movie. However, he says this will start to change with the next version of the protocol, IPv6. The house is currently controlled from a series of small wall-mounted touch-sensitive panels with LCD screens, but De Vos says he expects more use to be made of hand-held personal digital assistants (PDAs) such as the Palm range.

The result is not very futuristic from some points of view - it's almost within reach of the rich, and beyond the wildest dreams, or needs, of the majority of the earth's inhabitants. But as the novelist, William Gibson, once observed: " The future is already here: it's just unevenly distributed."

De Vos says the problem with using IP is that it has no "quality of service" provision that would enable different traffic to be given priority: you might be unable to phone the police because the TV set is using all the bandwidth to download a movie. However, he says this will start to change with the next version of the protocol, IPv6. The house is currently controlled from a series of small wall-mounted touch-sensitive panels with LCD screens, but De Vos says he expects more use to be made of hand-held personal digital assistants (PDAs) such as the Palm range. The result is not very futuristic from some points of view - it's almost within reach of the rich, and beyond the wildest dreams, or needs, of the majority of the earth's inhabitants. But as the novelist, William Gibson, once observed: " The future is already here: it's just unevenly distributed."

fields.headline: When sips sink ships
fields.standfirst: Michael Brooks  on the danger of drinking and sailing
fields.trailText: Michael Brooks on the danger of drinking and sailing
fields.body:
What we should do with the drunken sailor is not the problem. It's the sailor who's only very slightly tipsy that poses the most risk. When Joseph Hazelwood returned to the Exxon Valdez late in the evening of March 24, 1989, he had supped only a couple of drinks.

The ship's pilot smelled alcohol on Hazelwood's breath, but there were no signs of actual drunkenness, so he said nothing. A few hours later, Hazelwood's condition led to a "failure to provide proper navigation", according to the National Transportation Safety Board. The tanker grounded off the Alaskan coast, and devastated the area with 11.2 million gallons of spilled oil.

Hazelwood insists he was not drunk, and the jury at his trial agreed. But it might have been better for the Alaskan wildlife if he had been. Then someone might have removed him from his post, says Jonathan Howland, a professor of behavioural science at Boston University's School of Public Health.

Howland has conducted trials on marine engineers that show the remarkable effect of just a small amount of alcohol. His results, published in the journal Addiction, demonstrate that a couple of drinks - which leave people well below the legal alcohol limit for steering a ship, driving a car or operating machinery - can double the time it takes to perform crucial tasks. And performance can still be significantly impaired the day after heavy drinking.

Howland's research began because of a general interest in the causes of accidents and injury. "I thought there might be unexplored sources of injury and system error due to low doses of various agents," he says. That could mean simple tiredness, cold medicines, antihistamines and painkillers as well as mild use of alcohol or drugs. "There are many people exposed to these low levels, so even if the individual risk is low, it can add up to as much as the risk from a few people receiving high levels."

He searched the scientific literature, but failed to find any reason why the US department of transportation had set the blood alcohol concentration limit at 0.04% for people operating commercial ships. "We couldn't see that much research had been done to detect whether 0.04 was a safe level. We're hoping our results will cause people to re-visit that figure: there should be a scientific basis for the limits."

So he gathered a group of engineering students from the Massachussetts Marine Academy, and made them perform an emergency routine on the academy's engine room simulator. The next day he separated them into two groups, and gave each group something to drink. No one knew what they had drunk, but one group had received an alcohol dose equivalent to a couple of beers, while the others got placebos. Then he asked them to perform another emergency simulation. "The effect was enormous," Howland says. The students with a couple of beers inside them took twice as long to perform the task as they had done the day before.

But, Howland adds, the most frightening result was not that the students' perfor mance was so poor after such a low dose of alcohol, but that they didn't even realise it.

"They're not sensing the fact that they are dosed, and they don't notice that their performance isn't as good as it was before. That's the critical thing: people can't voluntarily remove themselves from operating a system if they don't know they're impaired. And if they don't know, and they're not acting impaired, no one else is going to remove them."

He has repeated the experiment on a simulator for deck officers - the kind of job that Hazelwood failed to do. The results were exactly the same. "This is not a freak finding," he says.

Several shipping companies have already asked Howland to discuss his results with them, and the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism recently presented the research to Congress.

But Howland is not confident that legal levels will be altered. "Similar studies were done on military pilots 20 years ago, and the regulations stayed where they were," he says. And his "hangover studies" seem to show that even a 0.00 per cent blood alcohol concentration is no indication of fitness to operate a ship.

This research is still going on, so Howland believes it is too early to draw firm conclu sions. But getting the Marine Academy engineers drunk, letting them sleep it off, shower and breakfast before trying out the emergency drill does seem to show a residual slowness. "This is even more relevant to the industry," Howland says. "Sailors get shore leave, they go and get drunk, and they are still impaired eight or nine hours later, even if their blood alcohol concentration is zero."

Putting him in the longboat till he's sober, hosing him down in the scuppers, or anything else the sea-shanty suggests you do with a drunken sailor just isn't enough. Drinks and ships simply don't mix.

webTitle: Shorts staff search bridges sectarian divide

fields.headline: Shorts staff search bridges sectarian divide
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Shorts, the Belfast-based aerospace company, is to give the Northern Ireland peace process a significant boost by taking on substantial numbers of Catholics to fill the 1,200 new jobs it announced yesterday at its regional jet manufacturing business.
fields.body:
Shorts, the Belfast-based aerospace company, is to give the Northern Ireland peace process a significant boost by taking on substantial numbers of Catholics to fill the 1,200 new jobs it announced yesterday at its regional jet manufacturing business.

The company, owned by Canadian firm Bombardier and once regarded as a bastion of Protestant east Belfast, expects to overcome the "chill factor" which traditionally prevented Catholics crossing the city when it begins recruiting new staff.

The recruitment drive will increase the workforce by 20% to an all-time high of 7,000 within two years.

The Catholic proportion of the 5,763-strong workforce has grown from 12.5% to 15% in recent years, according to company officials.

A recent recruitment fair brought 9,000 applications, many of them from Catholics, and the first several hundred new staff should begin work before the end of July.

Insiders denied that the announcement had been geared to the reintroduction of the devolved government to Stormont just 24 hours earlier but both David Trimble, the Northern Ireland assembly's first minister, and his deputy, Seamus Mallon, hailed it as a move that underpinned the peace process.

Mr Trimble said: "This is an extremely important endorsement of Northern Ireland as a hi-tech manufacturing location by a leading global corporation as we seek to build a more stable and prosperous future for everyone."

Mr Mallon added: "This sends a clear signal that Northern ireland is capable of competing for and winning global business."

Shorts, acquired by Bombardier on privatisation 10 years ago, when it lost £47m pretax on sales of around £200m, now trades in the black on a turnover that has doubled to £417m last year.

Its recent growth has come with the expansion of Bombardier's regional and business jet operation, including the 50-seater CRJ100-200, the Challenger 604 and Global Express long-distance aircraft for company executives.

Shorts supplies the fuselage, engine housings and wing components for the jets.

Michael Graff, Bombardier's president, said: "We will be very proud if, through the success of our operations here, Bombardier has delivered a measure of economic benefit that will help secure a better and more stable future for everyone in this community."

webTitle: Scottish and Southern powers up for net launch

fields.headline: Scottish and Southern powers up for net launch
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Scottish and Southern Energy is branching out from its core utility operations in order to sell personal finance policies over the internet.
fields.body:
Scottish and Southern Energy is branching out from its core utility operations in order to sell personal finance policies over the internet.

Jim Forbes, the group's chief executive, said yesterday that the service - to be known as Simple2 - would start selling stakeholder pensions from October. "Within months it will offer mortgages, credit cards, Isas, and car and home insurance," he said.

Simple2, which will be available for the utility firm's 3.7m customers, is aiming to offer at least five competing products for each category.

Mr Forbes said it had been negotiating with larger financial institutions including Standard Life, Scottish Widows, Aberdeen Asset Management, Clerical Medical and Intelligent Finance.

He hoped that the institutions would offer the group's electricity and gas services to their customers - a target audience of at least 10m people.

SSE has set up an online version of its Scottish shops which sell domestic appliances. It is also planning to offer customers a special internet tariff which it claims will be "one of the most competitive in the UK".

The group, formed through the 1998 merger of Scottish Hydro-Electric and Southern Electric, yesterday reported that pre-tax profits rose 13.5% to £525.8m during the year to March 31 2000.

Mr Forbes said the group had already achieved savings of £53m from the merger and more were to come.

The number of gas customers had risen 50% to almost 600,000, well on the way to its 1m target, although the group had ended the year with fewer electricity customers.

The SSE boss said the group now had the ability to raise £3bn for acquisitions or investment. He said he was interested in building new gas-fired power stations and buying coal-fired stations if the price was right.

But the group was more interested in expanding its supply business in the UK. Executives indicated that it was on the shortlist to buy the Norweb supply business put up for sale by United Utilities.

Mr Forbes said the group's telecom business was near to signing deals with Vodafone and One2One, which would let the mobile operators use SSE sites for new aerials.

During the last financial year the group spent £96.2m buying back its shares at an average cost of £4.88 a share. The board intends to seek shareholder approval for further buy-backs. A final dividend of 19.2p a share will raise the total dividend to 27.5p, a 7% increase on last year.

fields.headline: Judge puts mobiles in dock
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A leading anti-terrorist magistrate has written to France's three mobile telephone operators to complain that their inability to provide police with prompt information on suspects' calls is hindering criminal investigations.
fields.body:
A leading anti-terrorist magistrate has written to France's three mobile telephone operators to complain that their inability to provide police with prompt information on suspects' calls is hindering criminal investigations.

"The slowness of your services either reduces our chances of success or delays the arrest of people who are suspected of serious crimes, with consequent risks to the population in general," wrote judge Gilbert Thiel, who is investigating a series of Breton separatist attacks.

The judge's irate letter to operators SFR, Bouygues and the partly state-owned France Telecom, complains that the three firms routinely take between one and five months to come up with potentially crucial data on where exactly a mobile phone call was made.

Mobile records, which can allow police to place suspects near a crime scene or link them to other individuals, are becoming valuable sources of evidence in France, where a new mobile phone is being bought every seven seconds.

Investigators traced Sid Ahmed Rezala, the suspected murderer of British student Isabel Peake, by monitoring the mobile phone he was using at a hide-out in Lisbon, Portugal.

fields.headline: Australia fends off net gambler
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A crackdown on gambling in Australia has scuppered plans by the British online betting firm Gaming Internet to take over Australian firm Consolidated Gaming Corp.
fields.body:
A crackdown on gambling in Australia has scuppered plans by the British online betting firm Gaming Internet to take over Australian firm Consolidated Gaming Corp.

Gaming Internet's managing director, Ian Ryden, said: "We will not be proceeding with the proposed offer as we no longer believe that it would be in the best interests of our shareholders."

The company announced on April 27 that it planned to bid around £16.7m for CGC.

CGC said the decision had been made in light of the Australian government's announcement last week that it plans to impose a 12-month moratorium on new interactive gaming licences to stem the industry.

Australia has one of the world's highest rates of gambling and the government fears easy access to betting sites on home computers might add to the estimated 200,000 problem gamblers in the country.

"Gaming Inc is of the view that there has been a change in circumstances since the announcement of their proposed takeover bid," CGC said in a statement to the Australian stock exchange.

Australia's federal government is considering banning internet gambling altogether but some of the state governments are resisting such a move.

Under the Australian constitution, licensing of gambling activities is a state, not a federal responsibility and states earn considerable revenues from taxing the activity.

The Tasmanian and Australian Capital Territory governments have issued seven new licences in recent weeks, pre-empting legislation in the national parliament to impose the moratorium.

Gaming Internet said it was pursuing a number of other "exciting" possibilities.

fields.headline: 365 directors add weight to stock
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Senior directors at 365 Corporation yesterday attempted to lift some of the gloom surrounding the company's declining share price by stepping in to buy shares in the company.
fields.body:
Senior directors at 365 Corporation yesterday attempted to lift some of the gloom surrounding the company's declining share price by stepping in to buy shares in the company.

Shortly after the market closed chief executive Dan Thompson and four fellow directors announced that they had bought 16,129 shares each at 93p earlier in the day.

Their move followed the announcement of the online sports and music content provider's maiden full-year results as a public company and a series of presentations to analysts and journalists during which Mr Thompson attempted to add some clarity to the City's view of 365's business model.

Management hopes the briefings will inject renewed urgency into a share price which has traded as high as 350p but has fallen as low as 80p since the shake-up in internet stock valuations.

In the year to March 31 2000 turnover was £22.4m but marketing and acquisition costs led to a pretax loss £14.75m. The only comparable figures are for the eight months to March 31 1999, when group turnover was £2.6m and pretax losses were £1.15m.

But Mr Thompson was at pains to emphasise the underlying strength of 365's business model, which distributes proprietory content across platforms including the internet, television and mobile phones.

"If you strip out the investment in pure future growth we are already profitable," Mr Thompson said. "It is a decision as to when you switch from long-term profitability to short-term profitability. We are in a nice position of being flexible and able to switch when we want."

However, he refused to give a forecast on when 365 is likely make money for shareholders. "We consumed £7.5m cash last year and had £52m cash in the bank at the year end. That is more than enough funds to take us through our growth plans," he said.

Mr Thompson said the correction in valuations provided some golden acquisition opportunities.

"Three months ago we were being quoted ridiculous prices by private companies that said they were going to list with a value of more than £100m and now they are struggling to raise cash," he said. "It presents some fantastic opportunities."

fields.headline: Holding back the fears
fields.standfirst: It's time musicians exploited the net to call their own tune, says Simply Red's Mick Hucknall
fields.trailText: It's time musicians exploited the net to call their own tune, says Simply Red's Mick Hucknall
fields.body:
The music business has been overrun recently by get-rich-quick dot.com businesses looking to profit from the high perceived value and easy digital transferability of music. For some, music is a limitless source of cheap content, just waiting to be exploited. Many of these companies are run by people with little or no experience of the music business, and still less understanding of why people buy music.

With so much emphasis on the digital recording and distribution of music, it's easy to forget that the essence of music is in giving and listening to a performance. When we treat music as an industrial commodity, and young people as merely consumers, we overlook the joy of participating in music... of learning to play an instrument, of joining a band or an orchestra, and playing gigs.

Whatever the means of delivery, whatever the technological and corporate structures, music will always be about groups of talented individual performers communicating emotionally with individual fans. As a musician, I'm less concerned with how music can sustain the growth of online commerce than with what the internet can do to solve musicians' everyday problems. The new technology has thrown up new ways of creating and consuming music.

As the basic unit of musical creation shifts back from the album to the single, relationships between musicians are becoming more fluid, especially in the dance arena. Musicians increasingly work on short projects of one or two tracks, rather than planning multi-album careers based on a fixed band of players. In this fast-moving environment, many artists will have to resume control over the legal and business aspects of their work... the smaller scale of projects will no longer justify the detailed and expensive input of lawyers and accountants.

The huge potential of the internet will be realised only as musicians and musical entrepreneurs gain control of the new technology for their own benefit, rather than a few city investors chasing a quick flotation. Of course, it's already happening, but at a grassroots level, so it generates fewer headlines than high-profile corporate activity.

The do-it-yourself spirit reminds me of the explosion of punk and new wave in the late 70s... it's a very exciting world to be in. My chief concern is to foster this spirit among young people. In January 1999, I proposed an initiative to the Music Industry Forum which I called Communities In Tune. Its aim was to bring community centres to the internet generation.

To provide a national network of local centres, which young people could participate in running, where they could have internet access and learn, rehearse and perform music in the heart of their local community. The emphasis was on small-scale self-help projects in which all sectors and age-groups of the community would have a stake. Its first phase would be the creation of an online information service for those interested in running centres. This would offer advice on all aspects of management, including sources of local, national and European funding.

This is not a plea for more government money. The issue is not so much about funding as access to funding. Public funds must be spent more wisely. Naive councils, encouraged by greedy consultants, have wasted millions constructing lavish venues for which there is no local demand. Obviously, you can't claim funds if you don't know they're available. Recent research commissioned by Youth Music confirms that more information and more local facilities are the two biggest requirements for attracting young people to participate in making music.

The Youth Music research also confirms that young people find websites and CD-roms the most useful music resources. The internet is the most natural way for young people to learn about music and the music business. I strongly support Paul Brindley's ArtistRight initiative (see page 2), which has the potential to transform the lives of amateur and professional musicians alike. As part of the Youth Music's Instrument Amnesty, a network of 20 centres around the country has been established to collect and distribute the instruments.

I am hoping that this might form the nucleus for my Communities In Tune scheme. Incidentally, if you haven't donated an instrument to the Amnesty and you have one available, please do so; there is still time. I have also been told about the work of website designer Arksoft, which is working on software that will provide online do-it-yourself contract drafting with automated legal advice, for those who can't afford to see a lawyer.

An organisation called Jazz Services is trying to establish a national network of venues with good quality facilities for performers, and fair business attitudes to musicians. A few tens or hundreds of thousands of seed funding to initiatives like these and ArtistRight would do far more good than millions invested in another unwanted white elephant venue. Paul Brindley's report is the first I have seen which recognises that modern musicians are entrepreneurs... running micro-businesses, creating copyrights, generating economic activity and employment throughout the leisure and hi-tech sectors.

They take huge financial and personal risks for the distant chance of wealth and stardom. But that is not their real motivation. Their real motivation is hinted at in an ode by Arthur William Edgar O'Shaughnessy, which is the origin of the overused expression 'movers and shakers':

We are the music makers
We are the dreamers of dreams...
We are the movers and shakers
Of the world forever, it seems.
fields.bodyText: The music business has been overrun recently by get-rich-quick dot.com businesses looking to profit from the high perceived value and easy digital transferability of music. For some, music is a limitless source of cheap content, just waiting to be exploited. Many of these companies are run by people with little or no experience of the music business, and still less understanding of why people buy music. With so much emphasis on the digital recording and distribution of music, it's easy to forget that the essence of music is in giving and listening to a performance. When we treat music as an industrial commodity, and young people as merely consumers, we overlook the joy of participating in music... of learning to play an instrument, of joining a band or an orchestra, and playing gigs. Whatever the means of delivery, whatever the technological and corporate structures, music will always be about groups of talented individual performers communicating emotionally with individual fans. As a musician, I'm less concerned with how music can sustain the growth of online commerce than with what the internet can do to solve musicians' everyday problems. The new technology has thrown up new ways of creating and consuming music. As the basic unit of musical creation shifts back from the album to the single, relationships between musicians are becoming more fluid, especially in the dance arena. Musicians increasingly work on short projects of one or two tracks, rather than planning multi-album careers based on a fixed band of players. In this fast-moving environment, many artists will have to resume control over the legal and business aspects of their work... the smaller scale of projects will no longer justify the detailed and expensive input of lawyers and accountants. An organisation called Jazz Services is trying to establish a national network of venues with good quality facilities for performers, and fair business attitudes to musicians. fields.headline: What about the workers?
fields.standfirst:
More money, more staff, more time - 'everyone will tell you the same'
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: More money, more staff, more time - 'everyone will tell you the same'
fields.body:
The government yesterday distributed 12m leaflets in hospitals, doctors' surgeries and supermarkets, asking people to list their three priorities for the NHS. The public has a week to return the tear-off reply slips with their views on what NHS money should be spent on. The Guardian asked NHS staff for their three wishes for the NHS:

David Polson, 43, consultant obstetrician and gynaecologist

I have two wishes: more money and more staff. We can't improve the service by penny pinching and we have known that for a long time. Medical and support staff are leaving in large numbers: money could stop them. I don't have a third wish. Everyone who works here will tell you the same. Money and recruitment is all we need to solve the mess.

Andrea Duxbury, 35, staff nurse

Patients should be allowed to choose where they are treated. If someone is sent to a hospital in London, for example, they should be able to say, "no, I've heard it's rubbish" and opt for Leeds. Second, we need more staff. Staffing levels are bad everywhere you go. Then we need better working conditions. Nurses' hours are not being adapted to suit working mothers. A lot of people are tired on the job.

Joe Murphy, 38, senior operating practitioner

We need a national register for operating department practitioners so that assistants to surgeons and anaesthetists are made accountable. The government is planning to do this in September 2001. I want to see an end to the shortage of critical care beds. If an emergency patient comes in and there isn't a bed, we are forced to postpone surgery. Communication between staff at different levels must be improved for better continuity of care.

Jean Jellicoe, 45, pharmaceutical technician

Staffing needs to be improved. Pharmaceutical technicians are leaving the NHS in droves and we aren't attracting recruits. There aren't enough student technicians to fill the places. We need bigger pharmaceutical departments with more space for preparing prescriptions. We need time. Staff are going to private care homes because here they don't have the time to interact with patients properly.

Sarah Haley, 23, junior doctor

My main wish would be to cut waiting lists for residential care and nursing homes. Patients who are fit to be discharged from hospital face an eight week wait for secondary care. Doctors need better access to test results. Patients who fall just short of emergency status are having very long waits for scan results. Hospitals need to be better designed. A lot of wards have beds so close together there is not enough room to manoeuvre round them with the curtains drawn.

Daz George, 27, porter

First, morale needs a boost. Among porters, morale is subzero. There are now three hospitals on this site and our workload has doubled but we are short of men. We need more equipment: accident and emergency trolleys and specialised wheelchairs. Third, porters need better pay.

Angelique Chrisafis interviewed staff at Hope hospital, Salford, Greater Manchester

webTitle: The conflict between public and private care

fields.headline: The conflict between public and private care
fields.standfirst:
Accusations of waiting lists being juggled to enhance earnings
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Accusations of waiting lists being juggled to enhance earnings
fields.body:
Every junior doctor working the graveyard shift dreams of being one. But in the latest round of debate about how to cure the ills of the National Health Service it is the consultants who have found themselves the target for much of the criticism emanating from the Department of Health and even No 10.

The main thrust of the allegations has been that the way consultants are contracted to work means many spend more time working in private practice while still picking up almost a full NHS salary.

This has led to the charge that some of the more unscrupulous are keeping waiting lists long in order to attract more business to their private practices. It is not difficult to see where the conflict of interest lies when telling someone they can wait 12 months for their knee operation on the NHS, or they can write a cheque at the private hospital down the road where they can have the operation next week.

Treatment in the UK's hospitals is almost exclusively a consultant-delivered service. The aim of the NHS is that every patient admitted for care, whether it be for open heart surgery or a psychiatric evaluation, should be under the supervision of a named consultant.

But getting to the top of the tree is no easy task. It takes 15 years in total: five years in medical school, followed by three as a house officer and a further seven of specialist training, slowly taking on more responsibility until the day doctors are finally given the piece of paper that says they are a consultant.

The root of the conflict can be traced back to the birth of the NHS more than 50 years ago. The contract which Nye Bevan agreed - that consultants could continue to work in the private sector at the same time as working for the NHS - was the only way he could bring them on board and get the fledgling health service off the ground.

Bevan said later: "I stuffed their mouths with gold", but the agreement basically remains today. All consultants can earn the equivalent of 10% of their NHS salaries from private practice. Those who choose to forgo 1/11th of their salary, which works out at about £4,500 for a newly appointed consultant, are entitled to carry out as much private work as they like, provided they continue to devote "substantially the whole" of their time to NHS duties.

But the system has thrown up massive inequalities even between consultants. While a consultant geriatrician is likely to earn next to nothing from private practice a consultant orthopaedic surgeon probably takes home two-thirds of his or her pay from the private sector.

A survey by John Yates, professor at the health services management centre at Birmingham University, found that full time orthopaedic consultants conducted on average only 6.4 operations a week, taking just over seven hours. They controlled their waiting lists, making knee, hip and other bone operations the most sought after private operations.

Many, both inside and outside the health service, believe it is time the rules were changed. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, upped the ante last month when he asked a rhetorical question during an address to the Royal College of Surgeons. Could the fact that consultants on maximum part-time contracts with the NHS earned nearly as much from the private sector as they did from the NHS create a "perverse incentive" to keep waiting lists long?

A re-negotiation of the contract has been on the table since 1997, but the government and the BMA have failed to reach agreement. The department of health knows that any radical changes will meet with fierce resistance, especially from the surgeons.

If the government, as has been mooted, offers a 20-30% increase in consultants' salaries for them to forgo private practice, there is a good chance that surgeons who are earning a large part of their salary privately will walk away from the NHS.

The BMA says the idea that consultants are spending all their time in private practice is a myth anyway. According to Fiona Simpson, spokeswoman for the organisation, figures show that the 25,000 consultants in the UK work on average 50 hours a week in the NHS, with at least one in three working 60 hours.

"They are there putting in the hours but people say they are not operating. But what they don't realise is that a consultant is probably going to spend a day a week seeing patients in outpatients, another day doing ward rounds, then there is emergency surgery, sometimes carried out in the middle of the night, as well as their teaching commitments combined with their management and audit responsibilities. If you look at all these different elements it is hardly surprising that surgeons do not spend all of their week in the operating theatre."

fields.headline: Tories attack New Deal 'flop'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The main impact of the government's £220m New Deal for lone parents has not been to find them jobs but to flush out couples who have been cohabiting while illegally claiming benefits, the Conservatives said last night.
fields.body:
The main impact of the government's £220m New Deal for lone parents has not been to find them jobs but to flush out couples who have been cohabiting while illegally claiming benefits, the Conservatives said last night.

In a savage attack on the cost and alleged ineffectuality of Gordon Brown's flagship programme, the Tories' welfare spokesman, David Willetts, also accused ministers of "fiddling their own figures" to cover up the fact that the true cost of finding a job for a lone parent may be as high as £22,500, not £1,388, as officially claimed.

Using an analysis of New Deal pilot schemes produced for the Department of Social Security, Mr Willetts, the brains behind the new Tory pension plans, yesterday made two further damning claims:

 that 34% of lone parents involved found jobs through friends and relatives, compared with 1% who credited the government's "personal adviser" system;

 that lone parents on income support were slightly more likely to find jobs in areas without a New Deal for lone parents (NDLP) scheme than inside such a programme.

Ministers, led by Mr Brown, Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, and his predecessor, the champion of lone parent working, Harriet Harman, have defended the New Deal, though Mr Willetts, an ex-Treasury official, accuses them of withholding key figures to bolster their case.

Mr Darling told MPs in March that "the number of lone parents on income support was 3.3% lower than it would have been without the NDLP", implying that they had found jobs.

Mr Willetts claims that in 18% of cases the reason for this was the admission of undeclared cohabitation or informal "re-partnering" - a traditional bone of contention because of "social security snoopers" checking up on claimants.

That makes it the most effective part of the scheme, an accidental throwback to old-style "snooper" tactics as officialdom focuses on individual cases, Mr Willetts believes.

"When Alistair Darling takes credit for an additional 3.3% movement off income support, he is referring to a higher rate of detected re-partnering. The main effect of the scheme appears to have been the discovery of partners previously unknown to the benefits agency," his pamphlet, A Raw Deal for Lone Parents, says.

Last night independent academic analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies and the Policy Studies Institute conceded that the beneficial effects on the 410,000 lone parents in the DSS target group had been small, but said it was still "early days".

Both thinktanks are doing their own research and warned against rushing to judgment simply on pilot schemes launched before the NDLP went nationwide.

Mr Willetts was unapologetic. Faced with the flood of extra public spending that Mr Brown is poised to unleash on key public services - including his "opportunity for all" welfare reforms - the Tories know their best hope is to persuade voters that their taxes are being wasted.

In a pamphlet to be published by the Thatcherite Centre for Policy Studies, which he used to run, the Tory MP for Havant rubbishes successsive claims by ministers that the results from the scheme, launched for lone parents as early as July 1997, have been "very good".

Detailed examination of the DSS's own analysis in March suggests that lone parents claiming income support fell by 120,000 - as the economy boomed - in the two years before 1997, then stopped falling, then resumed at a lower level. In effect, he says the growth of flexible part-time working, not the New Deal, was decisive.

The Policy Studies Institute's provisional conclusion accepts part of that argument, but says that Labour's wider package of incentives to get poor families with children into worthwhile work must be "looked at in the round".
