webTitle: QXL.com results prove better than expected

fields.headline: QXL.com results prove better than expected
fields.standfirst:
Auctioneer hopes for an earlier profit

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Online auctioneer QXL.com is expected to move into profit a year earlier than expected after narrowing losses, and that process could be accelerated when the recent acquisitions are bedded into the group during the summer.
fields.body:
Online auctioneer QXL.com is expected to move into profit a year earlier than expected after narrowing losses, and that process could be accelerated when the recent acquisitions are bedded into the group during the summer.

Chief executive Jim Rose admitted yesterday that analyst predictions that QXL.com will reach profitability by 2004 could be brought forward by one year.

"It seems reasonable to me," he said, after revealing better than expected full-year results. "A lot of things have changed here over the past year. The execution of the business is really coming together, and we're building critical mass.

"The recent acquisitions we've made present a variety of cost-saving synergies through centralised sales and marketing, and will significantly increase revenues."

Mr Rose said the effect of QXL's most recent acquisitions - the takeovers of German rival Ricardo.de and Sweden's Bidlet - are unlikely to be felt until after the businesses are finally integrated with QXL in July or August.

Despite pre-tax losses for the year to March 31 widening from £2m to £75.8m, Mr Rose said the narrower operating loss for the fourth quarter was evidence that costs were under control and losses were fading.

Pre-tax losses before exceptional items for the period improved marginally from £11.4m to £11.1m.

Gross margins climbed from 10.4% to 14.2% during the same period, and turnover for the year rose 176% from £2.5m to £6.9m.

The news cheered QXL shares, which have suffered since the Ricardo purchase, and they closed up 15p at 127p. Mr Rose said he believed the previous share price weakness was due to selling by seed investors following the recent lapsing of post-flotation lock-in periods, and that buying among the big institutions would soon stabilise it.

Analysts remain divided as to whether QXL can build a market leading position across Europe before EBay, the American group which has pioneered online auctions.

QXL has moved aggressively to consolidate its position in Scandinavia and Germany and analysts believe it will now look to make a further purchase in France - possibly by buying local firm E-bazar.

Although Mr Rose refused to rule out a bid for any of QXL's French rivals, he suggested organic growth could be enough to build a market-leading position in the area.

"There was a compelling reason for us to buy in Germany but less so in France, where we're not far behind the competition," he said.

"As for EBay, you just have to look at the outside metrics to see that we're number one by far in Europe."

QXL is now likely to examine the possibility of expanding into Latin America - probably with local partners, and into South-east Asia.

fields.trailText: • Bidders: 11 companies including Deutsche Telekom, Mannesman, Vivendi, Viag and WorldCom will join Germany's third-generation mobile phone licence auction, starting on July 31.
fields.body:
 Bidders: 11 companies including Deutsche Telekom, Mannesman, Vivendi, Viag and WorldCom will join Germany's third-generation mobile phone licence auction, starting on July 31.

fields.headline: An NHS for the people
fields.standfirst:
A historic commitment is looming

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's new health plan is bidding to become the second most important event in the history of health administration. A prototype of the radical 1948 NHS reform - merging a voluntary hospital system steeped in debt with a parallel system of municipal infirmaries, many of them once workhouses, dispensing stigma - had already been tried in the emergency health system during the second world war
fields.body:
Labour's new health plan is bidding to become the second most important event in the history of health administration. A prototype of the radical 1948 NHS reform - merging a voluntary hospital system steeped in debt with a parallel system of municipal infirmaries, many of them once workhouses, dispensing stigma - had already been tried in the emergency health system during the second world war. But hospital waiting lists have been a part of the NHS throughout its life. Now Labour policymakers, as we disclosed yesterday, are exploring ways of effectively abolishing waiting lists in the national plan they are due to publish in July. Good for them. There are a dozen reasons for ducking the risk. They are right to ignore them. Ending long waiting times is almost as big a reform as launching the NHS.

Even close friends will have been warning Labour of the risks they are taking: the infinite demand for health care; the difficulties of controlling GP hospital referrals; the sad saga of 1995, when hospitals waits of over 12 months were all but eliminated, only for outpatient numbers to soar the following year; the anger which elimination of waiting lists will generate among consultants, whose private practices are driven by the length of NHS queues; and the difficulties and squirming embarrassment which Labour suffered in trying to meet its much more modest election pledge to reduce waiting lists by 100,000.

All true. And the new pledge, if made, would have an even higher profile. All eyes are focussed on what Labour's plan will include. They will not be able to fudge it, as they did with their last waiting list promise, by turning an "early reform" into a pledge that was made early. Yet for all this, there is one overriding reason why Labour is right: it is totally unacceptable in the 21st century for the health service to continue with its present miserable guarantee - the feeble commitment to provide treatment, after possible months waiting for an outpatient appointment, within another 18 months. If the NHS is to be "saved", it must meet modern consumer standards. This will mean many radical changes - breaking down professional demarcation barriers, more flexible medical teams, more work from under-used specialists. A recent study suggested orthopaedic surgeons are spending only seven hours a week in operating theatres - just over six operations in a working week of 50 hours - yet one quarter of the million people on the current waiting list are there for orthopaedic surgery.

Every debate involving the reform of the NHS in the last 50 years has come back to the need for more resources. But this issue has now been removed by Labour's pledge to lift health spending by one third in the next four years. Ministers are right to insist the extra resources must be properly used. Clearly before any more orthopaedic surgeons are appointed, their productivity must be improved. Labour's primary care reforms, which involve local budgets, could provide the necessary brake on too many hospital referrals. The health secretary was right yesterday to be unapologetic about the government's tough national standards - and its new independent inspectorate to assess hospitals and primary care. No public service can avoid accountability in a modern society. He is right to point to the oldest and most serious defect in the NHS: the huge variations in services at local level. This is unfair to both patients and taxpayers. But he has also promised "earned autonomy" - where local health teams are working well, fewer central controls. That is in the interests of medics, managers and ministers. He must be held to it.

fields.headline: Premiership battle at final stage
fields.trailText: The next fortnight will be crucial in the battle between BSkyB and rival cable company NTL as the Premier League prepares to decide on a lucrative deal for televising football over the next three years.
fields.body:
The next fortnight will be crucial in the battle between BSkyB and rival cable company NTL as the Premier League prepares to decide on a lucrative deal for televising football over the next three years.

Both media companies are said to be attempting to secure the right to broadcast 66 live games per season as well as 40 pay-per-view games, which are the basis of the deal.

Recent newspaper reports that NTL has bid £1.25 bn in total have met with scepticism from sources within football. "There is still a long way to go and nobody is quite sure what the figures are. Both sides are playing games but nobody would be surprised if figures of over £1 bn are mentioned," one said.

The entire package for televising football, which includes highlights and internet rights, could generate as much as £2 bn.

The current television deal expires at the end of next season.

Premier League officals have spent the past three weeks sifting through more than 70 bids and the final contenders have been divided into groups.

The most important is believed to include those companies bidding for the live and pay-per-view games. A second group includes those interested in highlights packages, which will be broadcast on Saturday and Sunday nights.

A third group includes those attempting to secure internet rights and those that plan to work closely with clubs which want to televise games on in-house channels.

A final decision is expected in July.

According to one report, NTL has out-bid BSkyB, which owes much of its success to the televising of live football. One newspaper even suggested that Premier League officials met NTL executives to ensure that their bid was a "serious one".

Examination of the bids has been so secret that even chairmen of Premier League clubs do not know the identity of bidders or the sums involved.

fields.headline: Elimination of the waiting lists
fields.standfirst:
There is no lack of ideas as to how referrals and treatment could be more efficient
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: There is no lack of ideas as to how referrals and treatment could be more efficient
fields.body:
The government's ambitious strategy to abolish NHS waiting lists will require an injection of billions of pounds, overhaul of the health service structure and an influx of thousands of staff.

Here are eight ideas being floated as ways to cut waiting lists to a maximum of three months:

Dedicated elective surgery centres

Among the key proposals is the establishment of a small number of high volume elective surgery centres for the specialities with the biggest waiting lists.

The centres would deal solely with those procedures with a high enough volume to justify 24 hour medical staff and an on-site emergency intensive care unit.

The NHS Confederation, which represents NHS trusts, boards and health authorities, has argued that the failure to tackle the mismatch between the demand for and the supply of elective surgery is not simply a matter of under-funding, but also of poor management. In theory, these dedicated centres would be less affected by the increase in demand in winter, when flu patients take over many beds

Bed and theatre capacity could be ringfenced either within hospitals or without, with patients at the centres offered hotel accommodation rather than in-patient beds. The full cost of these treatments would be borne by the primary care group with the waiting list.

Consultants and other staff would be seconded or recruited to the centres on a six month rotation, with a big pay rise as an incentive. Surgeons performing the same operation day in, day out are more likely to become bored and make mistakes.

Nigel Edwards, head of policy at the NHS Confederation, said: "This might mean that patients with minor conditions would often wait less time than those with more serious needs, but that frees up capacity for people who really need to see a specialist."

The "elective factory" has the support of Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians, although he expressed reservations about staffing costs and implications for the rest of the NHS.

Breakdown of demarcation between NHS staff

Hospital managers are keen to see an end to the traditional occupational groups with their own hierarchies, instead arranging staff around patients or around particular diseases or injuries.

There is strong support for employing staff without full medical training to do jobs which presently require it, such as using nurse anaesthetists in minor operations, with a fully qualified anaesthetist on standby. This would work well in the dedicated surgery centres where staff would perform the same operation every day and gain expertise. A new grade of sub-consultants could be trained to do simpler operations.

Sir George Alberti supports the "more imaginative use of non-medical health care specialists" - who need two or three years of training, compared with the six years for a doctor - for preparing patients before treatment, leaving doctors free to see more patients.

The RCN also favours greater responsibilities for senior nurses, including protocols for discharging patients with minor injuries and fast-track referral to consultants.

However, Professor Peter Hutton, president-elect of the Royal College of Anaesthetists, said his members "do not embrace the concept of the nurse-anaesthetist". He said: "In Europe, where they have them, they are trying to get rid of them because the morbidity rate is higher."

Specialist teams

Specialist "Swat" medical teams could be "airlifted" into areas with waiting list problems. They could advise on reviewing systems and capacity in those areas.

New consultants' contracts

A renegotiating of hospital consultants' contracts would enable health trusts to demand more hours from consultants, many of whom give time to private practice.

This might require a big pay increase for NHS work, but it is unlikely that many would leave the NHS, as falling waiting lists would reduce demand for private care.

Managing demand

Some urge the development of a properly structured and graded system for GPs to refer patients to specialists and to hospitals. It is estimated that 40% of patients referred to consultants do not need to see a specialist.

An agreement between GPs of a threshold of referral, with scoring systems for various complaints, would be crucial in ensuring consistency and equity between different GPs' practices and would drastically cut waiting lists for an initial appointment with a consultant.

An end to long waiting lists would cause fewer patients to be put on lists in the first place. Mr Edwards said: "If you have long waiting lists, it's quite common that people are put on them not because they need the treatment now, but because they might need it later."

The shorter the average wait for treatment, the less complicated and sophisticated the scoring system would need to be.

Mike Pringle, chairman of the Royal College of General Practitioners, said proper guidelines to prevent inappropriate referral could also mean more referrals from some GPs who had been under-referring their patients.

There is great scope for expanding the way in which GPs refer within primary care, Professor Pringle said, pointing to a GP in Burnley with specialist knowledge of dermatology who sees all the patients within his local primary care group with dermatological complaints and then refers on only those who will benefit from seeing a consultant.

Internal efficiency measures

Although many hospital managers operate on the basis of "the motorway rule" of supply-induced demand - "a bed built is a bed filled" - there are plenty of simple measures to improve efficiency within hospital trusts.

The Royal College of Nursing recently called for bed managers on 24-hour call with the authority to manage all bed allocation across hospital trusts.

Many doctors favour cutting out some of the long referral stages between a patient going to a GP and getting an appointment with a surgeon, by offering one-stop shops where patients can see all the specialists in a single visit.

"A significant number of patients that consultants see could be managed by nurses or therapists or specialist GPs," Mr Edwards said.

Limiting appointments with consultants to patients when there is diagnostic uncertainty or uncertainty about the treatment regime could cut waiting times, as could the expansion of accident and emergency teams to include physiotherapists and other specialists.

Better management of chronic conditions

Most emergency admissions are of people with a chronic disease and many of these admissions could be prevented with more systematic management of such problems as heart conditions, asthma and diabetes.

In January, nearly all elective beds were used by emergency patients, many of whom had flu. There are a lot of patients for whom a hospital bed is as appropriate a treatment as sending them home would be, so the lack of access to elective beds for "emergency" cases would force doctors to look at alternative methods of assessment or treatment.

Educating the public

A national campaign is needed to help patients understand what can and cannot be achieved by hospital care and by consultants, according to Prof Pringle. Good medical practice requires that GPs refer any patient who requests a further consultation, but patients must understand when it is and is not appropriate to seek a second opinion, and how to use the alternative services available to them, such as NHS Direct and pharmacists.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Any Square Miler worth his/her annual bonus tries to predict the movements of the herd. But yesterday would have tested even the most enthusiastic market monitor for any sign of group strategy among the dealing hordes.
fields.body:
Any Square Miler worth his/her annual bonus tries to predict the movements of the herd. But yesterday would have tested even the most enthusiastic market monitor for any sign of group strategy among the dealing hordes.

Nasdaq's dizzying rise pepped up the markets early in the day, with the FTSE quickly climbing 60 points in early trading.

By the end of the day, only tech stocks appeared to have sparkled - the Techmark 100 index ended 112.9 up at 3,256.25. The FTSE could only manage 0.3 more than yesterday's close at 6,359.3.

Cyberspace seemed to be where the action was. Affinity Internet saw its shares move 87p at £14.87 after announcing it would offer BT's internet package to its clients. Baltimore added 37p at 455, lifted by news of an upgrade in rating from Lehman Brothers to "buy" from "outperform" - with a 750p target.

It appears Bill Gates' name still impresses investors, if not judges. A deal with Microsoft to supply software saw tech specialist Staffware shoot up 275p to £17.75.

Anglo-Dutch software group CMG topped the FTSE 100 gainers, ahead 104p at 933p, while Thus firmed 30p at 310.5p, with Logica up 147p at 1,789p and Misys up 30p at 577p.

IT expert InterX , whose shares have bombed recently, made up much lost ground with a 250p rise to 1,150p. The reason for the fillip? A date for its results.

However, the triumph of technology was far from complete. Market players thought Invensys's proposed acquisition of Dutch software concern Baan stank, and shares sank 35.5p to 230p. Cable & Wireless lost 28p to £11.12. Profit-taking saw Psion shed 10p at 548p and Energis drop 60p to £25.40.

So what about the bricks and mortar? Shell gained 2.5% to 553.25p, with the market impressed by the company's crude price estimates. A poor showing in utility stocks saw United Utilities shed 19p to 631p. Capita Group 's stock was in demand, rallying after a recent dull performance, up 121p to £14.95.

Heavy trade in Blue Circle reflected its £400m share repurchase plan for which it said more than 200m shares had been tendered, forcing a scale-back to 64.75 shares for every 100. Shares in Britain's biggest cement producer ended the day up 2% at 426.25p.

Not much good news, then, for the old economy. With US employment data later this week and the grand wizards of the OECD warning that rates must rise to avoid a hard landing for the US economy, it could get worse.

fields.headline: Focus
fields.standfirst: Anglian Water
fields.trailText: Companies which change name usually claim that a corporate makeover is needed because the original title no longer reflects its activities.
fields.body:
Companies which change name usually claim that a corporate makeover is needed because the original title no longer reflects its activities.

There is a little of that behind Anglian Water's decision, announced yesterday, to become AWG later this year.

Chris Mellor, Anglian's managing director, believes the industry is on the brink of massive change which will see companies extending their operations into new areas at home and abroad.

But Anglian's name change also reflects its determination to claw back £160m of advance corporation tax payments.

Most of the big water companies have paid huge amounts of ACT because of their generous dividends since privatisation in 1989. ACT was usually recovered against later profit, but the rules have changed and further ACT payments, known as shadow ACT, will not be recoverable.

To avoid adding to its £160m of outstanding ACT, Anglian has decided to issue shareholders with redeemable shares rather than dividends.

But under its current corporate structure it may not issue sufficient redeemable shares because its reserves are too small. So it has decided to create a new holding company - to be named AWG - as the process will create a big merger reserve based upon the market value of Anglian.

So, for about £3m in fees, Anglian will soon be able to issue redeemable shares instead of dividends for the five years needed to recover all of the outstanding ACT.

Anglian, which froze its water prices last year, yesterday reported pre-tax profits of £204m for the year to March 31, against £227m the previous year. Shareholders are to get a final payment of 30.2p a share through the issue of redeemable shares, making a total of 43p for the year.

Mr Mellor described the introduction of competition as "a bit of a mess". The government needed to set a proper timetable for competition in water as it had in gas and electricity.

fields.body:
It's that drug again. Relenza, the influenza treatment, is back in the news and, once again, the reason is about as welcome to investors as a dose of la grippe.

Glaxo Wellcome, Relenza's perplexed parent, has pulled its application to Europe's medicines watchdog to have the drug approved not only for treating existing flu but also for use in a preventive role by those who merely fear going down with the illness.

Exclusion from the European Union's preventive medicines market might wipe 10% from the annual sales of Relenza, estimated by analysts to be anything between £150m and £300m.

Brussels regulators wanted more data from Glaxo on the effects of Relenza on high-risk groups such as the elderly. Given that Europe - in common with US regulators - has approved Relenza for treatment, as opposed to prevention, presumably the prospect of old 'uns taking the drug worries the EU not a bit, provided they already have flu.

Back in Blighty, Relenza is about to trundle once more around the approval process of the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice), the agency that decides whether or not the taxpayer - in the form of the national health service - will pick up the bill for certain costly drugs.

Last October, Nice gave Relenza the red flag on what was the supervisory body's first piece of live decision-making. Glaxo hit the roof, with chairman Sir Richard Sykes firing off a stiff letter to then health secretary Frank Dobson, warning that the company might move abroad.

Glaxo accused Nice of having nothing to do with clinical excellence and everything to do with holding down the NHS bill. Presumably, tempers will have cooled by the time Relenza is resubmitted in the summer.

Later this year, Glaxo will ask the US authorities to approve Relenza as a preventive drug, but in this age of instant communications the Americans might find it odd if, as seems probable, Glaxo has still not resubmitted its application to Brussels.

After all, part of the reasoning behind Glaxo's unhappiness with Nice last year was that home state (or, in this case, home trading bloc) approval for a medicine is of critical importance when seeking approvals elsewhere in the world.

Relenza had seemed the latest in a long and noble line of Glaxo products that changed fundamentally the treatment of common ailments and the quality of life of the sufferers: betamethasone (eczma), salbutomol (asthma), Zantac (ulcers). Perhaps that is how, ultimately, it will be seen. But just now the word "jinx" seems hard to avoid.

webTitle: Food for thought in an untypical ABS fudge

fields.headline: Food for thought in an untypical ABS fudge
fields.standfirst: Fund managers miss their mark | Rentokil £5m glitch |  Hitting a wall
fields.trailText: Fund managers miss their mark | Rentokil £5m glitch | Hitting a wall
fields.body:
Garry Weston always ran Associated British Foods the way he wanted to. He was never one to chase corporate fashion or cave in to the City's calls for quick fixes when occasionally, during his half-century, things got a bit rocky.

Instead the chairman sat in a frugal office in a drab Knightsbridge block (Bowater House) and made long-term decisions which produced a company that, all things going smoothly, will reclaim its position in the FTSE 100 next week.

With the Weston family still owning more than 60% of the business, there was no real surprise yesterday that the dynasty is to continue in the shape of Garry's 36-year-old son, George, who is becoming deputy chairman as well as continuing his current job running AB Foods' bakeries division. At the same time, Harry Bailey, Garry's right-hand man for the past 20 years or so, becomes non-executive chairman.

Yet sadly these appointments looks something of a fudge and very un-Westonesque. Peter Jackson, the chief executive brought in to run the group early last year, will be in the odd position of Weston junior's boss during regular business days and tugging his forelock to the deputy chairman whenever a board meeting is in progress.

If Weston junior has been brought up properly and knows the business, Weston senior should do the decent thing and let his son get on with the job.

£5m glitch

On Tuesday Rentokil, the rat catcher combine, completed its takeover of Ratin, its Danish associate whose only assets were shares in Rentokil. The move clarifies the firm's ownership structure but for technical reasons this has involved the issue of 919m new Rentokil shares which will be cancelled when the lawyers on the deal have finished fiddling about.

So some dimwit at FTSE, the joint venture between the stock exchange and the Financial Times which oversees the main market indices, decided on the same day that Rentokil should be reweighted within the various Footsie indicators to take account of all these new shares which, albeit temporarily, increased the company's market capitalisation by almost 40%.

By lunchtime yesterday, someone had drawn the Ratin takeover documentation to FTSE's attention and explained the synthetic nature of the transaction. The penny dropped and a fresh statement was rushed out - reducing Rentokil's market capitalisation by 919m shares and cancelling the reweighting.

This could be treated as a piece of harmless stock market farce except for the fact a number of gormless fund managers took the original reweighting statement at face value and rushed to buy shares in Rentokil, only to have to turn around yesterday and sell them again. The shares jumped 12.5p on Tuesday in response and then slumped 10p to 150p yesterday.

The alleged professional investors getting it all so wrong were so-called passive funds, the index trackers which simply buy shares in proportion to a company's weighting within a particular market index and then sit on these so that their investment performance mirrors the performance of the relevant index.

They bought Rentokil automatically because it said on a computer screen that it had become a bigger company.

When it all turned out to be a clerical error, the same index-tracking rules forced these institutions to sell - crystallising a loss of up to 7% overnight. The level of dealings yesterday suggested a good £5m has been lost by fund managers who were clearly just following what their computers said they should do rather than bothering to use the brains they were born with.

Hitting a wall

The investment banks which pulled the plug on the latest attempt to set up a league table of the City's biggest mergers and acquisitions whizz-kids claim they do not want to encourage a "star culture" within their firms.

However, the real reason why Thomson Financial Securities failed to get any cooperation from the banks probably has less to do with touchy-feely management styles and rather more to do with the embarrassment such a list would cause.

The potential for conflict of interest within modern, global investment banks is very real - as is the chance that comprehensive listings of individuals working on particular transactions will highlight these conflicts.

For all the promises of Chinese walls, restricting the flow of information round an investment bank, a shrinking number of big advisers means that star corporate financiers build up insider knowledge. As one finance director put it: "I respect the use of Chinese walls. But you cannot erect one between the left and the right side of the brain."

fields.headline: Invensys makes offer for Baan
fields.standfirst: 1,000 jobs expected to be lost
fields.trailText: 1,000 jobs expected to be lost
fields.body:
Shares in Invensys fell sharply yesterday after the automation and controls business announced a widely expected €762m (£476m) bid for the ailing Dutch business software company, Baan.

The bid has the backing of the Baan board as well as three key shareholders groups - including the Dutch firm's founders, Jan and Paul Baan who control just under 6% of the shares.

Invensys - formed last year by the merger of BTR and Siebe - is planning sharp cutbacks at Baan in a drive to get the software company back into the black. The Dutch group, once a darling of the Amsterdam market and a strong contender to SAP's title as Europe's biggest software company, has suffered losses in the past seven quarters. Yesterday, however, Invensys chief executive Allen Yurko said the aim was to bring Baan back to the break even level within 12 months and to be earning a 10% return on sales within two years. But the plan will mean the loss of 1,000 jobs and restructuring costs are expected to hit $400m (£267m) over the 18 months following the acquisition.

According to Invensys the acquisition of Baan is part of its strategy of being able to provide support from the factory floor to the boardroom. The acquisition "is a significant step towards our stated goal of becoming an integrated software and systems provider offering technical solutions across the entire automation and controls value chain", said Mr Yurko.

Invensys is offering €2.85 a share - almost 9% above Baan's closing price last night. But the shares nudged above €3 in dealings yesterday prompted by some speculation that a higher offer could materialise. Invensys shares were down 35p at 230p.

fields.headline: Allders raises £100m war chest
fields.trailText: The Allders department store group said yesterday it was looking for acquisitions and could raise more than £100m to fund them.
fields.body:
The Allders department store group said yesterday it was looking for acquisitions and could raise more than £100m to fund them.

Announcing first-half profits of £13.3m on sales of £281.9m, the chief executive, Harvey Lipsith would not name his targets, but said "some are pretty obvious."

Last month the company - Britain's fourth largest department store group - made an approach for Bentalls, according to industry sources. But talks apparently ended after it offered less than the net asset value of about 190p. Bentalls has eight stores and annual sales of £53m.

Much of the funds needed for acquisitions could be secured on the group's property portfolio, Lipsith said.

The group gave an upbeat outlook for the rest of the year, saying that like-for-like sales for the eight weeks to May 27 rose by 5.9%.

But according to one analyst, the figures for current trading were flattered by the late date of Easter.

Allders said pre-tax profits fell to £13.3m from £14.3m for the first 27 weeks last year, but that on a comparable 26 week basis it had recorded a £1m increase.

The interim dividend was held at 3.4p and the company said its performance in a difficult retail climate had been "resilient."

Lipsith said trading had benefitted from improved advertising while the success of its young fashion department Act3 had expanded the customer base.

On the Internet, Allders has launched a bridal register and said it plans to launch two more sites in the next year, but would not give any details.

 Northern Foods yesterday reported a 6% rise in pre-tax profits for the year ending March 31 2000. Profits rose to £100.2m from £94.5m in 1999. The group supplies Britain's leading retailers such as Tesco and Marks & Spencer.

Total dividend for the year rose by 6.6% to 7.25 pence. Earnings per share rose by 7% to 13.43p.

fields.headline: Bribery crackdown sought
fields.standfirst: OECD members say corrupt firms are shielded
fields.trailText: Foreign governments are planning to press Britain to get tough in prosecuting companies which use bribes to win international business contracts, according to a confidential report.
fields.body:
Foreign governments are planning to press Britain to get tough in prosecuting companies which use bribes to win international business contracts, according to a confidential report.

While welcoming the Home Office's commitment in principle to enact legislation making it a specific offence to offer sweeteners to foreign public officials, members of the Organisation for Cooperation and Development are determined that the new laws will have teeth.

The government's intention to update domestic legislation to comply with the OECD's convention on bribery was revealed in the Guardian last week.

The decision, taken against the advice of officials, followed pressure from other governments which have accused Britain of shielding corrupt firms from prosecution by repeatedly failing to acknowledge that existing laws based on the 1906 Prevention of Corruption Act are inadequate.

Britain is the only one of the 20 countries which ratified the convention not to have adapted its laws, although two other G7 members, France and Italy, have not even got that far.

By admitting that legislation needs updating, the government has taken the sting out of a critical report due to be published at next month's annual OECD ministerial meeting in Paris.

However, a copy of the report makes clear that OECD member governments believe the enforcement mechanisms will have to be much stronger if they are to be effective.

Any prosecution under the 1906 legislation has to be authorised by the attorney general or the solicitor general, who have to be convinced that prosecution is in the public interest and likely to lead to a conviction.

OECD members of a working group believe this burden of proof is excessive and want the government to take this message on board when drafting the new legislation.

fields.headline: Shipyard wins £234m deal
fields.trailText: Northern Irish shipyard Harland and Wolff said yesterday it had won a provisional order worth more than $350m (£234m) to build two luxury cruise liners.
fields.body:
Northern Irish shipyard Harland and Wolff said yesterday it had won a provisional order worth more than $350m (£234m) to build two luxury cruise liners.

The shipyard - famed for building the ill-fated Titanic - earlier this month secured its future with a $450m order for four passenger ferries, said it had been awarded a letter of intent by cruise line Luxus Holdings.

"Coupled with the recent order from Seamasters International for four advanced Ropax vessels, we are beginning to compile an order book which illustrates the diversity of projects which we are in a position to undertake," chief executive Brynjulv Mugaas said.

The contract has yet to be finalised, however. The order follows news that Northern Ireland's largest manufacturing employer, Bombardier Aerospace, plans to create 1,200 jobs over the next two years at its Belfast firm, Short Brothers.

The announcements are likely to be seen as a major vote of confidence in Northern Ireland which this week saw a return to home rule.

Reuters

fields.headline: Family feud risks $3bn Hyundai rescue
fields.trailText: Hyundai Group's founding family agreed yesterday to sell $3bn in assets and bowed to pressure from its creditor banks and the government to hand over day-to-day running of South Korea's largest conglomerate.
fields.body:
Hyundai Group's founding family agreed yesterday to sell $3bn in assets and bowed to pressure from its creditor banks and the government to hand over day-to-day running of South Korea's largest conglomerate.

The restructuring aims to allay concerns about a cash crunch at Hyundai, but the news was overshadowed by outbursts from Chung Mong-koo, the eldest son of the company's founder, who refuses to relinquish control of the car division, Hyundai Motor.

Hyundai's 84-year-old founder and honorary chairman, Chung Ju-yung - who built up the business from a car repair shop he opened in 1940 - finally threw in the towel yesterday, telling his two sons this was the only option for the group.

Kim Jae-soo, the executive in charge of the corporate restructuring programme said that the sons "will exercise rights and responsibilities as majority shareholders but they will no longer involve themselves in day-to-day management of the group".

But Chung Mong-koo insisted that he was the right man to run the car business.

The restructuring was welcomed by Hyundai's bankers, but analysts said the row would not help to solve the company's problems - or those of other troubled corporations in Korea.

"I think the main question this raises is who is making all these decisions for Hyundai and why all the confusion?" said Brian Hunsaker, head of research at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

Hyundai and Korea's other family-run conglomerates, or chaebols, were ravaged by the financial crisis that swept Asia in 1997-98. They have been resisting pressure to reform as demanded by the government and the International Monetary Fund.

Reuters

webTitle: Asylum seekers suffer as dispersal system fails

fields.headline: Asylum seekers suffer as dispersal system fails
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The compulsory dispersal of asylum seekers is in danger of breaking down, with refugees drifting back to London amid rising racial tension around Britain, an audit commission report warns today.
fields.body:
The compulsory dispersal of asylum seekers is in danger of breaking down, with refugees drifting back to London amid rising racial tension around Britain, an audit commission report warns today.

The commission says that outside London some schools and doctors are refusing to accept asylum seekers; specialist legal, translation and social services and community support are in short supply; and negative local press coverage is inflaming public opinion.

The report, Another Country, says that dispersal offers an opportunity to develop a coherent response to the needs of asylum seekers and failure will prove costly.

"Without effective support, asylum seekers could be trapped in a cycle of social exclusion and dependency in their new communities or they may drift back to London," it says.

It recommends urgent action, including a possible injection of lottery funds.

Many local authorities are still largely unprepared for the dispersal into their area of asylum seekers. Some communities outside London have taken asylum seekers voluntarily, but since April they have been obliged to accept them.

"Inadequate support services outside London present a barrier to dispersal. For example, legal advice is a priority for asylum seekers, yet less than half of the immigration law firms are outside London. Mental health services, English language support and refugee community organisations which offer practical and social help are also concentrated in London.

"Hostile media coverage and local concerns about the political impact of dispersal may further jeopardise the success of the new arrangements. In many areas, supporting asylum seekers is an unpopular policy - if the cost of support is borne by local taxpayers, community relations may suffer."

The report also recognises the complaints of local government that it spent £30m more supporting asylum seekers last year than it managed to reclaim from central government. Ministers have promised a further £10m but recognise concerns that future funding might not cover costs.

The report finds evidence that some doctors are refusing to register asylum seekers because consultations with them typically take three or four times longer than those with other patients.

Schools are also resisting accepting the children of asylum seekers if they cannot provide language support or are concerned that the new arrivals might affect test results. Research suggests that 2,000 children of asylum seekers are without school places. The report found that fewer than 12% of local authorities with a social services department had a refugee strategy.

The commission advocates that local government should develop a media strategy to promote positive press coverage, highlighting the human issues involved.

In an analysis of 161 local press articles in October and November last year it found that only 6% cited a positive contribution made by asylum seekers and refugees.

It warns councils not to feed hostility by providing services for asylum seekers that are not available to other residents. It cites cases when asylum seekers were given money for furniture which was not available to homeless people.

In another case asylum seekers were provided with taxis to take them to new accommodation while locals had to use public transport.

The report suggests using national lottery funding and even private sponsorship to ensure there are sufficient resources in dispersal areas.

Impact of dispersal

 About 4,000 asylum seekers and their families have been sent to live outside London. About half have been dispersed under the compulsory scheme which came into effect on April 3.

 Most have gone to Yorkshire and Humberside and the north-west although some have gone to Scotland.

 About one in three asked to move while the scheme was still voluntary refused to leave London.

 There are 94,000 asylum seekers waiting for a decision on their case - most are in London and the south-east.

 There are 65,000 refugee children in schools in England and Wales but a further 2,000 are without places.

 The north-east consortium of local authorities yesterday announced it had signed a Home Office contract to take asylum seekers. By the autumn all new asylum seekers will face dispersal as the scheme is phased in.

It recommends urgent action, including a possible injection of lottery funds. Many local authorities are still largely unprepared for the dispersal into their area of asylum seekers. Some communities outside London have taken asylum seekers voluntarily, but since April they have been obliged to accept them. "Inadequate support services outside London present a barrier to dispersal. For example, legal advice is a priority for asylum seekers, yet less than half of the immigration law firms are outside London. Mental health services, English language support and refugee community organisations which offer practical and social help are also concentrated in London. "Hostile media coverage and local concerns about the political impact of dispersal may further jeopardise the success of the new arrangements. In many areas, supporting asylum seekers is an unpopular policy - if the cost of support is borne by local taxpayers, community relations may suffer." The report also recognises the complaints of local government that it spent £30m more supporting asylum seekers last year than it managed to reclaim from central government. Ministers have promised a further £10m but recognise concerns that future funding might not cover costs. The report finds evidence that some doctors are refusing to register asylum seekers because consultations with them typically take three or four times longer than those with other patients. Schools are also resisting accepting the children of asylum seekers if they cannot provide language support or are concerned that the new arrivals might affect test results. Research suggests that 2,000 children of asylum seekers are without school places. The report found that fewer than 12% of local authorities with a social services department had a refugee strategy. The commission advocates that local government should develop a media strategy to promote positive press coverage, highlighting the human issues involved. In an analysis of 161 local press articles in October and November last year it found that only 6% cited a positive contribution made by asylum seekers and refugees. It warns councils not to feed hostility by providing services for asylum seekers that are not available to other residents. It cites cases when asylum seekers were given money for furniture which was not available to homeless people. In another case asylum seekers were provided with taxis to take them to new accommodation while locals had to use public transport. The report suggests using national lottery funding and even private sponsorship to ensure there are sufficient resources in dispersal areas. Impact of dispersal  About 4,000 asylum seekers and their families have been sent to live outside London. About half have been dispersed under the compulsory scheme which came into effect on April 3.  Most have gone to Yorkshire and Humberside and the north-west although some have gone to Scotland.  About one in three asked to move while the scheme was still voluntary refused to leave London.  There are 94,000 asylum seekers waiting for a decision on their case - most are in London and the south-east.  There are 65,000 refugee children in schools in England and Wales but a further 2,000 are without places.  The north-east consortium of local authorities yesterday announced it had signed a Home Office contract to take asylum seekers. By the autumn all new asylum seekers will face dispersal as the scheme is phased in.

webTitle: Bid battle for Hyder takes on a political dimension

fields.headline: Bid battle for Hyder takes on a political dimension
fields.standfirst: US power group sparks controversy as it offers £464m, topping an agreed bid from Nomura
fields.trailText: The battle for control of Wales's biggest company began in earnest yesterday. The US group, Western Power Distribution, trumped an agreed £403m offer for Hyder from Nomura with a £464m bid - and the Japanese bank said it could raise its offer.
fields.body:
The battle for control of Wales's biggest company began in earnest yesterday. The US group, Western Power Distribution, trumped an agreed £403m offer for Hyder from Nomura with a £464m bid - and the Japanese bank said it could raise its offer.

The prospect of a bidding war for the debt-ridden utility company was at risk of being overtaken by the political conflict, with Welsh Assembly leaders anxious to preserve thousands of jobs in Wales.

A row is also emerging over regulation. Western Power insists that the European commission is the competent authority for the issue, while Nomura looks to the assembly to prompt intervention by British authorities.

Western Power, which already owns South West Electricity, said it would offer 300p for each Hyder share compared with Nomura's 260p offer. Nomura will consult politicians, the Hyder board and unions before deciding whether to raise the stakes.

Robert Symons, Western Power's chief executive, said he was "frankly disappointed" that the Hyder board had failed to recommend his bid.

Mr Symons said the bid was worth 15.4% more than Nomura's offer - and 58.5% above the share price on March 27, the day before Hyder said it was in bid talks. Hyder shares closed last night at 304.25p, suggesting that the market expects higher offers.

Mr Symons raised Welsh hackles with his complex plans for the business. He wants to switch the running of Dwr Cymru, Hyder's water business, to United Utilities, based in Warrington, and sell its services business to UU for an undisclosed sum.

Hyder Infrastructures, the profitable green energy and project management arm, could be broken up, sold off, or given new investment - prompting union fears that up to 4,000 jobs are at risk.

The operational headquarters of the electricity business, Swalec, would stay in Cardiff but management control would move to South West Electricity in Bristol. He would not say how many jobs would be lost as a result.

Rhodri Morgan, the first secretary of Wales, said the assembly wanted guarantees about jobs, environmental projects and Hyder's head office. Pointing out that Nomura had given such undertakings, Mr Morgan said: "We don't want to get involved in a battle between bidders but without such guarantees we might have to take sides and make our views known to the three regulators".

Mike Kinski, the former chief executive of Stagecoach whom Nomura has designated as chief executive for Hyder, said Nomura's strategy was "to acquire all the business and develop it from a base in Wales" while the rival offer was really a break-up.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Microsoft keeps up fight
fields.body:
Microsoft keeps up fight

Microsoft was last night expected to file its last legal brief before an American judge rules on whether it should be broken up.

Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson is expected to announce his verdict on a suitable remedy in the landmark anti-monopoly case as early as tomorrow.

His comments in court and decision to curtail the hearings on possible remedies have led most observers to predict that he will agree with the US government that Microsoft should be broken up.

Yougest chief for Coutts

Coutts, the private bank, has appointed its youngest ever chief executive, 38-year-old Andrew Fisher. This follows the retirement of Herschel Post in January and the decision of Mr Post's successor, Glyn Jones, to pursue other interests.

Mr Fisher joined Coutts - which is own by the Royal Bank of Scotland - in 1998 as commercial director. Before that he held senior international roles with Standard Chartered Bank, consumer group Unilever and the consulting arm of accountants Coopers & Lybrand.

iTouch flotation timing touted

Independent News & Media said yesterday a flotation of its iTouch mobile phone information service remained likely this year.

Independent has a stake of about 70% in iTouch, which was set up in South Africa and is rolling out its operations in Britain, Ireland, Israel, New Zealand and Australia.

RJB signs deal to save jobs

A £700m coal supply deal which will safeguard thousands of mining jobs was signed yesterday.

The five-year deal has been agreed between RJB Mining and the owners of Europe's biggest power generation station, Drax, in Selby, North Yorkshire.

The deal, which comes into force next April, means up to 25.5m tonnes of coal mined at RJB's Selby complex and other Yorkshire collieries will be supplied to AES Drax Power.

Ritz opens near VW park

Volkswagen is banking on that fierce brand loyalty with its latest venture - a self-styled car theme park called Autostadt, a cross between Disney World and the Smithsonian Institute that boldly extols the virtues of the company.

Expectations are so upbeat that the combined entertainment park, showroom and automotive museum will attract 1m tourists a year that the Ritz Carlton hotel chain picked this distinctly unglamorous factory town as the location of its second German hotel after Berlin.

fields.headline: Doctors snub Blair 'big idea'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Hospital consultants will today slam the brakes on Tony Blair's "big idea" for the NHS by throwing out proposals for flexible working that would be central to the goal of abolishing waiting lists.
fields.body:
Hospital consultants will today slam the brakes on Tony Blair's "big idea" for the NHS by throwing out proposals for flexible working that would be central to the goal of abolishing waiting lists.

The British Medical Association's annual consultants' conference looks certain to reject the idea of a new grade of specialist doctor who would work alongside consultants and take on much of their clinical work.

Delegates are also expected to attack suggestions that consultants could be required to work at nights and weekends, and even stay overnight at hospitals, in order to meet demand for round-the-clock surgery.

But consultants' leaders, wary of again being cast as the "forces of conservatism", last night mounted a damage limitation exercise. They stressed that they stood ready to negotiate reform in the context of a "consultant delivered" service.

Peter Hawker, who chairs the BMA's consultants' committee, said: "I doubt very much that change will pose us too many problems."

As disclosed yesterday in the Guardian, flexible working by doctors and nurses lies at the heart of the ambitious strategy being discussed in government to cut waiting time for all hospital treatments to less than three months.

The prime minister is enthusiastic about the strategy, said by government health advisers to be achievable within the five years of a second Labour term, but the Treasury is anxious at cost implications over and above the 35% increase in NHS funding already promised for the next four years.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, yesterday acknowledged that the strategy was on the table in discussions about the NHS national plan, due to be unveiled by Mr Blair next month.

The government could afford to be "very radical indeed" in the plan, Mr Milburn said on BBC radio. "It's simply not on in this day and age, the 21st century, that the best we can guarantee for patients is that they will have to wait no longer than 18 months for treatment."

Yesterday was designated NHS "census day" and the Department of Health completed distribution of 12m leaflets to hospitals, doctors' surgeries, pharmacies and supermarkets asking people to list their top three priorities for modernising health care.

Responses, required to be posted within five days, will be collated by two market research companies. But ministers already know that waiting times will be the number one concern.

Mr Milburn later acknowledged concerns that people had not been given time to get their responses in before the official deadline and agreed that the wording was unclear.

"I am sorry that there has been confusion about the wording on the consultation leaflet," he said. "But this is a genuine consultation. I value the views of patients about the NHS and I want to hear from them."

All replies would be seriously considered and a summary would be published as part of the reform plan, Mr Milburn added.

Under the waiting list abolition strategy, outlined by the NHS Confederation representing health authorities and trusts but also, critically, backed by key advisers, non-urgent or elective surgery could be carried out in special centres working seven days a week.

Dr Hawker warned that such centres would cut off elective surgery and limit essential access to x-ray staff, physicians, and specialists in elderly care. He said: "We need to have elective capacity, but we have structures for that already - they are called hospitals."

Even enthusiasts for the concept of surgery centres, specialising in a fixed type or types of operation, cautioned that there were limits to the approach.

Roy Lilley, a former NHS trust chairman and now a leading author and pundit on health management, said: "You could even do things like cataracts and hernias in mobile surgery units - after all, they do cataracts standing in the street in Africa - but for hips you have obviously got to have proper recovery beds and something like a hospital environment."

Today's consultants' conference will debate flexibility proposals mooted in a health department consultation paper on workforce planning, published in April, which suggested creation of a specialist grade to work "alongside but not under" consultants.

This comes against a back ground of drawn-out and so far inconclusive talks, initiated in 1997 by the BMA itself, on reforming the consultant contract. The contract is seen by many critics as standing in the way of any real progress on modernising hospital care.

A resolution put forward by West Midlands consultants says the proposed grade would "spread demoralisation among the profession" and "avoid the consultant expansion necessary to deliver a service of consistently high quality".

The resolution will meet little opposition. But Dr Hawker will use the opportunity to say that consultants already lead change in the hospital sector - and are prepared to be radical.

"Day case surgery, angioplasty, one-stop clinics, new drugs, new treatments, new techniques have all been led and introduced by doctors," he said last night.

webTitle: New battle as British begin pullout from Sierra Leone

fields.headline: New battle as British begin pullout from Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst:
Fierce fighting for strategic town as news of withdrawal is greeted with dismay on streets of Freetown

Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: British forces yesterday signalled the start of withdrawal from Sierra Leone on the day rebels launched an attack on the strategic town of Lunsar.
fields.body:
British forces yesterday signalled the start of withdrawal from Sierra Leone on the day rebels launched an attack on the strategic town of Lunsar.

Both sides were reported to have suffered heavy casualties after government troops reportedly ran out of ammunition and were forced to give ground. It was unclear last night who remained in control of Lunsar, 65 miles (105 km) northeast of Freetown, which had been captured by pro-government forces on Monday.

Earlier, government soldiers handed out leaflets in Freetown reassuring civilians that a "British military team" would remain behind to support and advise government and UN troops.

News that the deployment was being scaled down, as anticipated, was greeted with dismay on Freetown's Beach Road. "We want the British to stay for two years," shouted one boy. From another came "For five !" - capped in turn by a cry of "For ever!" The next slogan was: "A British vice-president!" followed triumphantly by the final sally: "A British president for Sierra Leone!" Roars of laughter accompanied this auction of high office.

The young men on Beach Road, where shady trees shelter a line of little food and cigarette stalls as well as a series of impromptu seminars for the unemployed, are as personable a bunch as you would find anywhere. Their passionate desire that their country should be set to rights is expressed in this pro-British hyperbole, a version of which can be found on every street corner in Freetown.

Philip Konti, 22, said to general approval: "We don't want to let the British go. They are our brothers, they are the ones who colonised us. They shouldn't leave us now when we still have no security."

It is hard to convey the intensity of those who see in the British presence not only a solution to the war but a signal that Sierra Leone is to be included again in the world of prosperity, jobs, good clothes, and good living.

"Here we are," said Sa Rynaka, "we are nice boys, we are strong boys, we are educated, and there is no peace and no jobs. We want to be re-colonised. You should stay because we don't trust ourselves."

Early yesterday morning soldiers at checkpoints in the city began handing out leaflets from the Sierra Leone army announcing that the British, having helped stabilise the security situation, would soon begin to withdraw, leaving behind a strong training and advisery team. The leaflets, no doubt composed with British help, congratulate the Sierra Leone army on its successes against the Revolutionary United Front and stress that reinforcements for the UN forces will soon be arriving.

Up at the president's house, Professor Septimus KaiKai, spokesman and adviser, one of whose tasks is to field ques tions from the public in phone-in radio programmes, sighed when he heard that the British were pulling out.

"This means I'll have to go back to the studios," he said. But he argues that the boost the British gave to morale would not dissipate.

The British are dismantling the joint task force headquarters at Lungi international airport, and shipping equipment and personnel home over the coming days. That would leave a forward headquarters in Freetown intact and would not change the number of British riflemen on the ground for another fortnight or so.

The British government will examine proposals for what to do after that. These are thought to include an interim military training team, which will function until a more permanent training mission, with staff from several countries, can be set up. There will also be a protection force of some kind, of a size yet to be determined.

Freetown's citizens, while glad that more Nigerian troops, in particular, are coming in, are still disturbed at the news of the reduction of the British presence. Some, like the boys of Beach Road, seem to think they can stop it by sheer assertion. Others, such as Aminasa Kanala, a hairdresser, offer a resigned thank you. She lost a brother and sister to the rebels, but takes comfort in the thought that if they were to threaten Freetown again, the British would return.

webTitle: 'I feel a complete failure if I haven't made someone cry'

fields.headline: 'I feel a complete failure if I haven't made someone cry'
fields.standfirst: Kathryn Williams, the new queen of bedsit angst, talks to Dave Simpson
fields.trailText: Kathryn Williams, the new queen of bedsit angst, talks to Dave Simpson
fields.body:
Kathryn Williams's bedroom wall boasts a picture she has painted of a dog and a crow. It is rather memorable because the dog is shown emptying the contents of his bladder over the crow's head. Standing by the mischievous masterwork, the artist looks every bit as delighted as the mutt with his leg cocked in triumph.

"It's called Summer Golden Showers," Williams explains. Dogs are her big obsession. Her last, acclaimed, album was called Dog Leap Stairs and contained a song called Dog Without Wings. The new (and infinitely superior) follow-up, Little Black Numbers, has photographs of a dog all over the cover. She has painted hundreds of them and even spends part of our interview thumbing through a 1969 copy of the Observer Book of Dogs. None of this should have anything at all to do with the music. Except it does. "Dogs," says Williams, pointedly, "take the black out of the day."

This blackness is why we are here: the great swathes of melancholy that cut through Williams's brilliantly evocative music. This mood, helped along by the songs' trademark haunting cello sound (provided by her pal Laura Reid), has led to Williams being tagged "the new Beth Orton" or, increasingly, "the new Nick Drake". Being so labelled understandably sends Williams, well, absolutely barking mad.

"I love Nick Drake but I certainly don't try to sound like him," she insists. "He was a brilliant guitarist, complex and meticulous. I'm really ramshackle and crumbly." In fairness, there is something of Nick Drake (you could throw in early Suzanne Vega) in the raindrop way Williams sings - but a truer, more existential comparison lies in the sense of tragedy under the skin of the songs. What is most affecting about Williams's music is the way that melodically uplifting songs are somehow stalked by the Black: it is never actually spelled out but hovers, eerily, like a darkness on the edge of town.

"As you get older the days are shorter and that worries you," says the next great queen of bedsit angst, "and then you spend time worrying about the days being shorter. You realise that there never is a day of pure happiness, or pure sorrow."

These thoughts - like the lines from her song Flicker about a man's life being "just a flicker, then a breeze" could have come from an old woman of the hills, looking back on her life, rather than a disarmingly (and unexpectedly) bubbly young woman.

Williams is 26 and was born in Liverpool. Her folk-musician father played the same clubs as the fledgling Beatles and Paul Simon. Her mother listened to Janis Joplin. Although she is reluctant to discuss details, Williams's life has not been without tragedy. It transpires that she was bullied at school ("I worked at trying to be funny"); more recently a close friend, Mike Tunner (to whom Little Black Numbers is dedicated), died after being accidentally electrocuted while working in the US. The haunting Fell Down Fast concerns him.

"We were mortal enemies from childhood who would wind each other up," she sighs. "At parties, everyone else would leave the room and we would argue, as a game, for hours. It was this weird thing of having someone who secretly you really loved." Since taking up the guitar at art school in Newcastle, where she still lives, Williams's rise has not been easy. Behind her cheery if thoughtful persona lies a sobering tale of debt (self-financing those records: the first cost £80 and the new one £3,000), struggle and sleeping on fans' floors. But she has been rewarded with several breaks. An appearance at the 1999 Barbican Nick Drake tribute catapulted her to national attention; and demo time with London Records led to a sympathetic producer, PJ Harvey's engi neer Head. More recently there was the rare honour of being asked to sing on the new John Martyn album, Glasgow Walker. "He arrived looking like he had just been dragged through a field, with his flies undone, and he hugged me like a bear - I really like him!" she says.

There probably are not that many excitable 26-year-old John Martyn fans nowadays, nor are the pop charts (the fairly successful Orton aside) exactly brimming with the heritage of Nick Drake, Carole King and Joni Mitchell. But Williams could change that. She points out that in Aberdeen recently her audience ranged in age from 15 to over 60, insisting that while current marketing targets pop at one generation or another, there can be a common ground across the generations.

"I'm playing with new bands and supporting veteran folk people too," she says. "I quite like the way that's not 'cool'. No one is making decent music for audiences of every age group. You've either got 15-year-old boys who buy Garbage because they fancy singer Shirley Manson, or Daniel O'Donnell for the grannies."

She pauses, slightly reconsidering. "Well, I suppose there are the Corrs who seem to cross over, but that's_ insidious and sick."

Her own appeal is universal, she says, because "everybody needs that quiet time. Everybody needs to cry." And they do, apparently rather frequently. "I feel a complete failure if I haven't made at least one person blubber," she says, grinning again but entirely serious.

With record company vampires loitering ("They have even phoned me up at 10.30 at night. This, it seems, is a real problem, especially given the mountain of debt, an unpaid electricity bill and the noble pooch's infamous capacity for hunger. "It's not just that, either," she says, exasperated. "Increasingly, I'm living in a household full of cats."

Dogs are her big obsession. Her last, acclaimed, album was called Dog Leap Stairs and contained a song called Dog Without Wings. webTitle: Garry Weston steps down after more than half a century

fields.headline: Garry Weston steps down after more than half a century
fields.trailText: Eight months after suffering a stroke and 51 years after joining the board of the family company, Garry Weston is stepping down as chairman of Associated British Foods - the food group whose products include Twinings Tea, Wagon Wheels, Kingsmill bread and Silver Spoon sugar.
fields.body:
Eight months after suffering a stroke and 51 years after joining the board of the family company, Garry Weston is stepping down as chairman of Associated British Foods - the food group whose products include Twinings Tea, Wagon Wheels, Kingsmill bread and Silver Spoon sugar.

But the Weston family, which owns just over 60% of AB Foods, is keeping a strong grip on the business, with Garry Weston's 36-year-old son George, who runs the bakeries division, moving on to the board as deputy chairman.

Garry Weston's long-term business partner, Harry Bailey, is becoming non-executive chairman, with chief executive Peter Jackson and finance director John Bason - the management team put in place last year - continuing to run the group on a day to day basis.

At the same time Mr Weston is handing over chairmanship of Fortnum & Mason, the Piccadilly store which is also controlled by the Weston family, to his daughter Jana Khayat.

It was announced in September that Mr Weston, 73, had suffered a mild stroke, but it was expected at the time that he would return to work within a few weeks. However, associates say that he has continued to suffer poor health.

AB Foods, originally known as Allied Bakeries, was founded by Garry Weston's Canadian-born father in 1935, and is credited with introducing sliced bread to Britain.

Trading at the group has suffered over recent months as customers, such as the big supermarket chains, have exerted fresh downward pressure on AB Foods' margins. Headline interim profits last month showing an 8% drop to £175m were also affected by last year's decision to distribute a slice of the group's cash mountain to shareholders - including the Weston family.

It also warned that over-capacity in milling and baking was squeezing profitability.

The group, which employs 34,000 and turns over £4.3bn, has stamped on any suggestion that a wholesale restructuring might be in the offing, denying rumours that its Primark discount clothing chain might be demerged or that the whole group might be taken private.

fields.headline: Bad show, Blighty
fields.standfirst: The Brits have traditionally cleaned up at New York's annual Tony awards. But that's all changed, says  Matt Wolf
fields.trailText: The Brits have traditionally cleaned up at New York's annual Tony awards. But that's all changed, says Matt Wolf
fields.body:
It's Tony Award time again on Broadway, and all New York seems to be a stage. That's not merely because 33 of Broadway's 37 theatres are currently booked, with fresh arrivals waiting in the wings. There's a new confidence on and off Broadway, born of a sense that American theatre can again hold its own very nicely, thank you, without the help of the British.

Only a year ago eight British-spawned productions opened on Broadway in almost as many weeks. The influx this year has been markedly smaller, not to mention less successful. In 1981 Peter Shaffer's Amadeus, with Ian McKellen and Tim Curry won a clutch of Tonys and ran for several years. By contrast, Peter Hall's revival, with David Suchet and Michael Sheen, closed two weeks having made a loss of more than £1m, battered by a tough review from the New York Times. In the end, the production got two Tony nominations - for Suchet's dour Salieri and for best revival of a play - and hasn't a prayer of taking either prize.

Amadeus has not been the only British show on Broadway haunted by its own pedigree. In April the Donmar's revival of The Real Thing travelled to New York, receiving ecstatic reviews for the London ensemble. So far, however, attendance has struggled to rise above 70%, in contrast to its original Broadway run in 1984, directed by Mike Nichols. That won five Tonys and sold out for months.

It may be that leads Stephen Dillane and Jennifer Ehle can't match the box office clout of the 1984 players Jeremy Irons and Glenn Close, who at the time were both on the verge of major film careers. (Interestingly, Miramax has a 25% stake in the Broadway revival.) Or perhaps director David Leveaux's forensic approach to Tom Stoppard is too muted for American theatregoers, who want the play socked across the footlights - much as its leading character, a Stoppardesque dramatist named Henry, describes taking a cricket bat to words.

Whatever the reason for the public restraint, The Real Thing needs all the Tonys it can get to give a lift to its limited run. In a category that failed to nominate either Derek Jacobi's Uncle Vanya or Patrick Stewart's headline-making turn in The Ride Down Mt Morgan, Dillane's main competition looks to be Gabriel Byrne, returning to the stage in Eugene O'Neill's A Moon for the Misbegotten. (This production is neck-and-neck with The Real Thing for best revival of a play, while Roy Dotrice, also in Moon, has the supporting actor prize sewn up.)

Ehle faces competition from her own mother, Rosemary Harris - the first time the Tonys have seen a mother and daughter up for the same award. (Several years ago Natasha Richardson was nominated in the same category as her aunt, Lynn Redgrave; both lost.) Harris stole Coward's endearingly creaky play Waiting in the Wings from co-star Lauren Bacall.

The Real Thing apart, the only British title likely to figure at Sunday night's ceremonies is Michael Frayn's Copenhagen, a play long deemed too serious for Broadway, where its chief rival is Dirty Blonde, Claudia Shear's homage to Mae West. That Copenhagen has done at all well in New York is generally ascribed to its American cast, who have been praised for bringing warmth to the rather cerebral London evening. If Copenhagen loses, it will be in good company. Two other British plays, Arcadia and Racing Demon, lost Tonys to middle-brow American fare - Love! Valour! Compas sion! and Master Class, both by Terrence McNally.

Copenhagen's director, Michael Blakemore, may come away with two Tonys - the other for the 12-times-nominated revival of Cole Porter's Kiss Me, Kate. That production, in turn, is up against a second American classic musical, Meredith Willson's The Music Man, which has been just as lovingly restored to Broadway. The pair join Susan Stroman's delicious Lincoln Centre dance-play Contact and the anodyne but popular Swing! in an array of shows placing choreography front and centre, after a spate of British behemoths where (Cats excepted) dance was more or less incidental.

In fact, there's no more apt symbol of the shift in British fortunes on Broadway than the revival of Jesus Christ Superstar, whose lone Tony nomination - best revival of a musical - has been dismissed as a sop to Andrew Lloyd Webber. (Tim Rice may emerge with more honour from the vacuous new Disney show, Aida.) Perhaps Broadway, in rediscovering dance, has once again found its own feet. Or maybe dance is simply a metaphor for survival, as Tony nominee Eartha Kitt puts it in her showstopper in The Wild Party, the season's best and most audacious new musical: "So you think the party's gonna last for ever/And you'll always fly this high, but that depends/You better know how to kick-kick-kick your way out/When it ends."

fields.headline: Train driver 'had no maps'
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Hodder, the newly trained driver who died in the Paddington rail crash, had to rely on sketch maps because his employers did not provide proper route plans, the disaster inquiry heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Michael Hodder, the newly trained driver who died in the Paddington rail crash, had to rely on sketch maps because his employers did not provide proper route plans, the disaster inquiry heard yesterday.

His instructor, Raymond Adams, revealed a catalogue of failings in the Thames Trains driver training programme. He agreed no proper route maps had been available "since British Rail days".

He nodded when asked by Neil Garnham, representing the inquiry: "So Thames Trains drivers plan routes by using handwritten sketch plans they pass among themselves and draw themselves?"

Mr Adams said he had not trained anyone for two to three years before teaching Mr Hodder in May 1999, five months before the crash on October 5, in which 31 died.

He said that he had received no guidance on how to fill in training forms for pupils.

Relatives of the victims gasped when Heinz Winters, signalling manager at Slough, said Railtrack signallers were trained to wait and see if a train stopped of its own accord after passing a signal at red.

He clashed with Robert Owen QC over the action taken by signallers immediately after signal 109 was passed at red. There was a 25-second gap before the collision after one of the signallers realised an accident would occur.

Mr Owen said regulation 47 required signallers to "immediately arrange" for all trains to be stopped in the area "by the most appropriate means". Mr Winters said 99% of trains stopped of their own accord.

The inquiry continues.
