webTitle: Mrs Gore steps out of shadows to boost husband's flagging campaign

fields.headline: Mrs Gore steps out of shadows to boost husband's flagging campaign
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Al Gore turned to his wife, Tipper, to bolster his ailing US presidential campaign yesterday as an opinion poll showed the vice-president trailing Republican rival George W Bush by 10 points.
fields.body:
Al Gore turned to his wife, Tipper, to bolster his ailing US presidential campaign yesterday as an opinion poll showed the vice-president trailing Republican rival George W Bush by 10 points.

Nobody in the Gore camp is prepared to talk of a campaign relaunch, but the appearance yesterday of the upbeat and voter-friendly Mrs Gore to head up the unveiling of her husband's "new family agenda" on mental health came close to being just that.

Like Laura Bush, her rival in the race to become first lady, Mrs Gore had played a relatively low-key role in the presidential contest. But yesterday she stepped out of the shadows, in effect upstaging her husband with a hard-hitting campaign speech on her favourite political issue, mental health reform.

She committed her husband to a detailed programme of action on mental health issues, including forcing US insurance companies to offer mental health coverage in the medical policies on which most families rely.

"I'm so excited about today. I've looked forward to it - probably all my life," Mrs Gore told an audience in Chevy Chase, Maryland.

Mrs Gore regularly joins her husband on the campaign trail but her influence, and that of the couple's eldest daughter Karenna, who is also a key political confidante, has until now been exercised out of the public spotlight.

Yesterday's rally underlines a recognition by campaign strategists for Mr Gore that traditionally unglamorous issues such as mental health and higher education finance can be turned to his advantage because they loom so large in the everyday concerns of American families.

One in four American families has direct experience of mental health care needs, and 51m people in the US receive treatment for a mental disorder in any given year, Mrs Gore said yesterday.

She was treated for clinical depression 10 years ago after her then six-year-old son was severely injured in a road accident.

After a brief period in March when he drew level with Mr Bush in the polls, Mr Gore has slipped behind once again, trailing the Texas governor in 22 out of the 23 published na tional surveys in April and May. In the latest, taken at the end of last week for Fox News, Mr Bush led Mr Gore by 49% to 39%.

The Democrats' decision to showcase Mrs Gore is part of a major rethink in which Mr Gore intends to use the coming weeks before the Independence Day holiday to run a more positive, more autobiographical and more policy-oriented campaign.

Since he beat Bill Bradley to the Democratic nomination in March, Mr Gore has spent most of his energy attacking Mr Bush rather than promot ing himself and his own agenda, a strategy that seems to have failed.

Over the last month, the US pundits have increasingly warned - or crowed - that Mr Gore is losing the 2000 campaign, reporting ever more explicitly the anxieties of Democratic party elders and candidates in November's Congressional elections.

Gore aides privately admit that they have allowed Mr Bush to present himself as the optimistic candidate, and that Mr Gore badly needs to recapture that quality in his own campaign.

The first sign of the new-look Gore came a week ago when the vice-president made a speech promoting access to after-school care. Yesterday's mental health policy launch continued the new theme, and Mr Gore intends to keep the warm and compassionate mood going with a speech on fatherhood tomorrow. He will follow these with further speeches on parenthood and family life.

And later this month he will make what is being billed as a keynote speech cementing his more positive agenda as the run-up to the August Democratic convention begins.

webTitle: Defiant Putin lifts curbs on Russian nuclear exports

fields.headline: Defiant Putin lifts curbs on Russian nuclear exports
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia has relaxed its curbs on exporting sensitive nuclear equipment in a unilateral break with the international consensus that arms control experts say is a blow to non-proliferation efforts.
fields.body:
Russia has relaxed its curbs on exporting sensitive nuclear equipment in a unilateral break with the international consensus that arms control experts say is a blow to non-proliferation efforts.

Breaking with the international practice of banning exports of nuclear materials to countries whose nuclear power programmes are not subject to the full scrutiny of the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), President Vladimir Putin has decreed that it is up to Russia to decide who may buy its nuclear power products.

"This is a step against the mainstream of the non-proliferation treaty," said an international official dealing with nuclear energy. "Putin's decree makes exports possible without guarantees of fullscope safeguards."

Mr Putin's decision, the latest evidence of his resolve to pursue a more robust foreign and economic policy regardless of western reservations, ditches commitments by his predecessor, Boris Yeltsin, pulling Russia into line with the west in its nuclear exports policy.

In theory, Mr Putin's decree will leave Russia free to supply maverick states such as India, Pakistan, North Korea, Israel, Iran, Iraq, Cuba and Yugoslavia with nuclear materials, whereas Mr Yeltsin made this impossible in 1992.

Under a Yeltsin decree eight years ago, Russia signed up for the directives of the nuclear suppliers' group which proscribe nuclear exports to countries which either had declined to sign the nuclear non-proliferation treaty or refused full IAEA access to their civilian nuclear projects.

India, Pakistan, Israel, and Cuba have not signed the treaty while North Korea, a signatory, is generally considered to be in breach of the agreement.

Analysts saw the go-it-alone move as a mockery of the recent pledge from the big nuclear powers, including Russia, to work towards the full elimination of nuclear weapons and of the talk of progress at the recent non-proliferation review conference in New York.

"This is a softening of Rus sia's non-proliferation policy," said Annette Schaper, an international arms control expert at the Peace Research Foundation in Frankfurt, Germany. "It's a big problem that Russia has unilaterally decided to break with the prevailing consensus."

Igor Farofontov, of Greenpeace in Moscow, said: "This is a completely stupid move. We could end up with economic sanctions against us."

The decision, however, which is in line with Mr Putin's determination to assert Russia's clout on the international stage, reflects the influence on him of the powerful nuclear energy lobby, and also shows his eagerness to cash in on what little of Russia's economic assets remains.

In March, Mr Putin made a highly publicised visit to the formerly top secret nuclear research city of Snezhinsk and pledged to reinvigorate the nuclear industry. He has also just abolished the main state agency responsible for environmental protection, a habitual critic of the nuclear lobby.

The Putin decree, the international official said, was "political, a re-interpretation of Russia's commitments under the non-proliferation treaty."

The Yeltsin decree of 1992 stated that Russia could only export nuclear equipment and materials to countries "which do not possess nuclear weapons and whose entire nuclear activities are under the guarantees of the IAEA."

The Putin decree revises this. The Russian government "in exceptional circumstances" can decide to export nuclear materials to a country which has no nuclear weapons but which has not placed all its nuclear activity under IAEA safeguards.

The client government has to give assurances that the equipment will not be diverted for nuclear weapons purposes.

"This is a revolutionary change in Russia's position on non-proliferation," commented the Moscow newspaper, Novye Izvestiya.

Nikolai Ryzhov, the deputy minister for atomic energy, said the nuclear exports would proceed if they "do not contradict Russia's international agreements and if the governments of the countries concerned promise that they will not be used to build nuclear weapons."

webTitle: Town hall funds could go to schools

fields.headline: Town hall funds could go to schools
fields.standfirst: Blunkett to make councils shift resources from bureaucracy into classes Teachers warned against sanitising beastly past Trainees plan boycott
fields.trailText: The government is planning to force councils to shift cash from town hall bureaucracy to classroom education by changing the law to ringfence funds destined for frontline teaching.
fields.body:
The government is planning to force councils to shift cash from town hall bureaucracy to classroom education by changing the law to ringfence funds destined for frontline teaching.

Though no decision has yet been taken, David Blunkett will reveal today that he is to consult local authorities about the shift as part of the government's drive to "provide higher standards and greater opportunities for all our children."

The most efficient local education authorities spend barely 10% of their budgets on administration, while the others spend up to 25% - money that cannot be used on books, equipment and classroom salaries. Ministers are determined to change that.

In his speech to the National Association of Head Teachers in Jersey, Mr Blunkett will say: "There can be no let-up in our drive for higher standards and greater opportunities for all our children. As part of this we need greater clarity about the role of local government in education funding and must ensure that as much money as possible gets to the frontline where it belongs."

Downing Street last night signalled Tony Blair's support for the education secretary's plan to use the forthcoming green paper on local authority finance to test levels of support for protecting school budgets. Councils are certain to resist it, but heads and some teacher unions may favour the switch - unless the money is swallowed up by consultancy fees.

That happened when control of further education was taken away from local authorities under John Major.

The Conservatives have already indicated that they will get rid of LEAs and deal directly with schools, as they did with grant maintained schools before Labour brought them back under LEA control.

Labour would leave special education - for children with disabilities - school transport and buildings under LEA control. But Mr Blair's impatience with progress in improving standards of key public services is evident in the move.

Mr Blunkett's announcement will be welcomed by head teachers, who are increasingly vocal in their criticism of local education authorities.

Delegates at the NAHT conference in Jersey yesterday supported a motion calling for at least 80% of LEA money for schools to be passed on directly to head teachers, although they drew back from a demand for 100%.

David Hart, the NAHT general secretary, said that heads broadly supported Mr Blunkett's view that if LEAs did not exist something like them would have to be invented.

But he expected after the next election that LEAs would be reduced to supplying a few functions, such as transport and support for children with special educational needs, and not much else.

Mr Blunkett will today act on complaints from the NAHT by simplifying the procedure for heads bidding for cash from the Standards Fund, a £1.7bn kitty for delivering government-backed initiatives such as the literacy and numeracy strategies.

Grants will be delivered under six broad headings, rather than the current 44, and few will require competing bids between schools.

He will also promise a new war on red tape, by cutting the number of documents sent to heads by his department by a third and the number of pages by half.

By 2002, paper-based communication between the Department for Education and Employment and the head teachers will have ended, with schools linked to the DfEE via the internet. However, schools would still be able to get printed versions if they wanted them.

webTitle: Fayed backs farmers in GM seeds blunder

fields.headline: Fayed backs farmers in GM seeds blunder
fields.trailText: Scottish farmers fighting for compensation over the genetically modified seeds blunder have found an unlikely champion in the laird of Balnagown, or Mohamed Al Fayed as he is more widely known.
fields.body:
Scottish farmers fighting for compensation over the genetically modified seeds blunder have found an unlikely champion in the laird of Balnagown, or Mohamed Al Fayed as he is more widely known.

The Harrods owner has offered his support to farmers' leaders and politicians north of the border after it emerged that 55 acres of contaminated oilseed rape had been planted on his Highland estate near Inverness.

A spokesman for Mr Fayed said he was outraged and had contacted the National Farmers Union of Scotland and members of the Scottish parliament in the hope that they could present a united front. "He feels that he and other farmers who have been affected are certainly entitled to compensation and that they should protest against this," the spokesman said.

Staff at the 62,000-acre Balnagown estate, which Mr Fayed bought in 1974, had unintentionally planted the genetically modified seed supplied by the Canadian firm Advanta in April. Harrods media director Laurie Mayer said the crop would probably be ploughed up. "If the stuff is ploughed into the ground, this year's crop will be lost. The fields could also have to lie fallow for the next year."

It is thought that in the past two years, up to 600 farmers in Britain may have planted more than 30,000 acres of oilseed rape contaminated with a GM rape seed variety not approved for commercial growing in Europe.

Some estimates suggest that 60% of the seed was planted in Scotland, and Scottish farming representatives have accused the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, of dithering and incompetence over the issue.

Mr Fayed has said Balnagown is the favourite of his many homes. He is reputed to have spent more than £20m on the restoration of its pink-walled castle, the ancestral home of the clan Ross.

A spokesman for the Scottish NFU said last night that it would be happy to see him join their campaign. "We would welcome anyone," a spokesman added.

fields.headline: Doris Hare
fields.standfirst: She spent more than 80 years on the stage - but never escaped the role of Reg's mum
fields.trailText: Whatever it is that turns actresses into troupers - versatility, character, gusto, experience - Doris Hare, who has died aged 95, had what it takes.
fields.body:
Whatever it is that turns actresses into troupers - versatility, character, gusto, experience - Doris Hare, who has died aged 95, had what it takes.

When she started, aged three, theatre was the only form of drama. No films, no wireless, no television, no voice-overs. Above all, no microphones. When she finished - she made her last stage appearance aged 87 - all branches of the medium were thriving. Mainly she stuck to the stage, although it was a stint in television as Reg Varney's mum in On the Buses which brought her unexpected fame.

After her stage debut in her birthplace, Bargoed in Monmouthshire, as a tiny tot in her mother's roaming repertory company, Hare never looked back. "I'll do anything, dear, as long as they pay me," she said.

She seemed as happy in Shakespeare, Marlowe, Shaw, Pinero and Max Frisch as in Pinter, Shaffer, Alan Bennett or No Sex, Please, We're British. And one of her best performances in the theatre was as the permissive, toothless Granny Tooke, aged 120, in Sandy Wilson's 1957 version of Ronald Firbank's novel Valmouth, about a bunch of outrageous Edwardians at a seaside spa. She was there, too, in the same part in Chichester Theatre's revival in 1981.

While the Americans once compared her comic talent on Broadway to Beatrice Lillie's, the Merchant Navy took her to its heart in the second world war after a wartime series of BBC broadcasts called Shipmates Ashore. The programme, with Hare as compere, was held to have done much to raise morale. For that she won an MBE.

On Broadway she had acted opposite Emlyn Williams in the premiere of his thriller Night Must Fall (1936), and in London was hailed by James Agate as the "best comedian" in a Charles Cochran revue, Lights Up! (1940), for Evelyn Laye.

As a young girl, she toured in revues at home and abroad. She worked the halls with Max Miller - and had just played the Holborn Empire when it was bombed in 1940. In the West End she sang and danced for Noël Coward and André Charlot, or pranced about as Toinette in Molière's Le Malade Imaginaire, or did pantomime in the suburbs or played duchesses by the sea. And when the new post-war intellectual drama was heralded, Hare was there in The Fire Raisers at the Royal Court in 1961, going on to join the Royal Shakespeare Company as one of its long-term contract artists in Peter Hall's heyday, and thence to the National Theatre under Olivier, and Chichester under John Clements.

The pre-war years of song-and-dance and having to establish character instantaneously equipped her for the more serious-minded stuff of the 1960s - as Shakespeare's Mistress Quickly in The Merry Wives of Windsor, Mrs Peachum in The Beggar's Opera, Katherine in Marlowe's The Jew of Malta or Mary Hearn in The Farmer's Wife.

When, in wartime, she and Evelyn Laye performed, for example, a somewhat scaled-down Cochran revue in a hangar at Scapa Flow for the Merchant Navy, clinging to the rafters with ships' officers holding down the actresses billowing skirts, stage technique in such untheatrical circumstances was crucial.

What she also learned from having been in so many kinds of show, especially revue, was to project her personality with immediate impact and sympathy. Characters who might in other hands have been rated obscure or wearisome - the sluttish half-wit Meg for example in Pinter's The Birthday Party in 1964 - became in Hare's distinctive and funny.

Of the literal obscurity at the premiere of Shaffer's Black Comedy in 1965, in which the cast had to move around brightly lit but supposedly in total darkness, Hare recalled how "awful" rehearsals were until, on the director's order, they were all blindfolded. As Miss Furnival, gingerly feeling her prissy, genteel way about the Chichester stage, Hare would think she knew where she was - "until you suddenly found yourself in the street..."

Like other highly experienced actresses, she was prone to shameful fits of the giggles. In Heartbreak House as Nurse Guinness, she played opposite John Clements, "a great giggler on the stage like myself. I thought as soon as we are both on stage I'll collapse. He began it, and I just had to dig my fingernails in my hands and struggle."

Hare soldiered on in tours of light comedies (Fiddlers Three, Birds of Paradise) and took over for a year as Eleanor Hunter in No Sex, Please, We're British in 1974, before returning to Shakespeare as the Nurse in a tour of Romeo and Juliet and a West End run as Mrs Ashworth in Waters of the Moon in 1978.

In her seventies she still loved to tour, something her generation was ever fond of - even overseas. She went merrily round, first South America and then Israel as Mrs Swabb in Alan Bennett's Habeas Corpus; and so back to Sussex and the still eyebrow-raising Valmouth.

Although she loved to relate how she was half-way up a mountain in Montenegro when challenged by a native as to whether she was Reg Varney's mother, and how other foreigners pursued her for autographs with "Momma! Momma!", it was the theatre that mattered most.

Doris Hare was married, in 1941, to John Fraser-Roberts, a surgeon. They divorced in 1973. She is survived by her two daughters.

webTitle: Hizbullah heroes face the test of peace

fields.headline: Hizbullah heroes face the test of peace
fields.standfirst:
The force that ousted Israel has a highly visible political presence in Lebanon. What will happen at the polls?

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Abdullah Qasir, a Hizbullah member of the Lebanese parliament, quotes a Koranic verse: "If you are rude, people will not like you."
fields.body:
Abdullah Qasir, a Hizbullah member of the Lebanese parliament, quotes a Koranic verse: "If you are rude, people will not like you."

Rude? The party that became notorious in the 1980s for bombing embassies and kidnapping foreigners is now preaching against rudeness.

Calling itself "The party of God" and incorporating a gun in its emblem may not be the best way to win friends, but these days Hizbullah wants to be loved, by Christians and Sunni Muslims as well as by its fellow Shi'ites.

The Israeli retreat from southern Lebanon has certainly brought Hizbullah respect and admiration, if not love. Almost everyone in Lebanon believes that its long guerrilla war, in which 1,375 "martyrs" died, has brought them liberation.

In the Arab world generally, it is difficult to underestimate the psychological power of its achievement.

Since the establishment of Israel in 1948, through two full-scale wars (in 1967 and 1973), the Arabs have known nothing but defeat. Not only has this coloured political discourse for two generations, it has become deeply embedded in the culture: a constant theme of films, books and poetry. Last week, all that changed.

"This is the first Arab victory," the Hizbullah spokesman Hussein Naboulsi says. "It's the first time the Israelis have left an Arab land in defeat."

The conclusion he would like the world to draw is that Hizbullah's methods work and should be copied elsewhere. Already, taunting comments can be heard in the streets: why have the Syrians and Palestinians failed where the Lebanese have succeeded?

There is, however, still unfinished business with Israel: issues regarding hostages, prisoners and, above all, the return of the Shebaa farms, a border area which is claimed by Lebanon but Israel says belong to Syria.

"If the Israelis do not leave that part of Lebanon the resistance will continue," Mr Naboulsi says.

But he adds: "We're not in a hurry. We'll wait and see." After years of conflict, the Lebanese people clearly want peace, and Hizbullah has a lot to lose by resuming the armed struggle.

On the ground

No party could have hoped for a more auspicious start to an election campaign. Lebanon is due to go to the polls in August and Hizbullah, which has seven MPs, hopes its popularity will make it a significant contender. But for that to happen it must appeal beyond its core Shi'ite constituency.

What began in 1982 as an underground movement during the civil war, and quickly earned a reputation as the most daring of Lebanon's armed groups, is today very much above ground: it has a television station, a radio station, a newspaper and a website (www.hizbollah.org).

Its big stockmarket investments make it an important stakeholder in Lebanon's economy, which some regard as limiting its revolutionary ambitions.

One key to its success is that it combines guns with Good Works. When effective government was lacking in much of Lebanon it set up its own social security network, providing jobs, health care and education.

A European aid worker in south Lebanon says: "During the Israeli occupation, if someone's house was hit by a rocket Hizbullah would be round within two or three days to rebuild it."

This has undoubtedly helped it win favour, though critics accuse it of cynically ingratiating itself with certain groups. It has also created expectations which may be difficult to fulfil, particularly as central government reasserts itself in the south and tries to take over some of Hizbullah's functions.

Its welfare, cultural and sporting organisations are its main recruiting grounds. Anyone can join. "They don't have to be committed to all the rules but they must support Hizbullah politically," Mr Qasir says.

Once they are in these peripheral organisations, volunteers are assessed for loyalty, ideological orientation and discipline and if they pass the test may be invited to join the party. A particular personality type is said to be favoured: those with good listening skills who will implement party decisions without questioning them.

The selection process accounts for the party's extraordinary discipline. Mr Qasir says: "You might find a very poor Hizbullah member, but he never thinks of stealing."

The party is said to maintain personal security files on each of member. It claims "tens of thousands" of members: independent estimates put it at 20,000-25,000. The fighting force probably numbers about 5,000, of which about half can be regarded as trained professionals. Key decisions are made by a close-knit group of no more than 10 people, headed by Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, who took over in 1992 after the Israeli army killed Sheikh Abbas Mussawi.

At the outset Hizbullah was funded mainly by Iran, to the tune of $500m a year in the mid-80s, plus unspecified amounts, probably running to hundreds of millions, for weaponry. That has fallen dramatically over the years and today the Iranian government support is thought to be no more than $20m annually.

Realising that the good times might not last, Hizbullah invested heavily wherever the opportunity arose: in import and export businesses, in banks, agriculture, property, department stores and petrol stations. This provides a steady income, and the party's finances are said to be relatively clean and free from embezzlement.

It does not seek to impose its own code of behaviour on other Lebanese, though this was not always the case: it used to run "morality patrols" on the beach but met with so much opposition that it abandoned them.

Today Lebanon is probably the only Arab country where women walk in the street not only with their heads uncovered, but some with their shoulders and legs uncovered, too.

In local elections in Harat Haraik, an area of Beirut where it dominates, the party amazed its opponents by insisting that a Christian should become mayor. Mr Naboulsi says: "We don't impose our views on others, we let people make their own choice. If you have kids and force them to do things they will hate you. If you are a friend to them they will love you. Islam is not a force, it's discussion and dialogue."

He smiles constantly, the way born-again Christians smile in the United States. Some are suspicious, but Nizar Hamzeh, an expert on Hizbullah at the American University of Beirut, believes it is sincere, up to a point.

It accepts freedom and democracy, not for their own sakes but because of local conditions, he says. "Hizbullah is pragmatic and has decided to perform a contract with the wicked, but the achievement of the Islamic state will always be there as a goal."

Electorally, its problem is that Lebanon's political system has a built-in "sectarian ceiling", designed to prevent any religious group from achieving dominance. This means, in Mr Hamzeh's view, that no matter how popular Hizbullah becomes it may be unable to win more than 10 of the 128 parliamentary seats directly, though it will probably make alliances with other parties.

"The challenge for Hizbullah is how to recruit non-Shi'ites. It has succeeded with some Christians and other sects, but those remain few," he says.

It is not just a matter of persuading them to support the party but, ultimately, converting them to an ideology which is rooted in the political theories of the late Ayatollah Khomeini. To Hizbullah activists, those theories are so obviously correct that dialogue, tolerance and avoiding rudeness will surely be enough to win others over. fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Genevieve | Snake Eyes | Fallen Angels | Heaven's Burning
fields.body:
Genevieve
(Henry Cornelius, 1953)
5.15pm, Carlton Cinema

Vintage charmer with the title's 1904 jalopy driven by racing enthusiast John Gregson and his wife Dinah Sheridan. They're neck-and-neck in the London-to-Brighton race with cheerful Kenneth More and trumpet-blowing Kay Kendall.

Snake Eyes
(Brian De Palma, 1998)
8pm, Sky Premier

The bravura opening, an apparent single 12-minute take in which we follow Nicolas Cage's hustler-cum-cop Santoro going about his dodgy business in an Atlantic City sports stadium before a big fight is a homage to De Palma's beloved Hitchcock, and sets the scene for a gripping thriller. The champ takes a dive and, despite the attentions of Santoro's security chief chum Dunne (Gary Sinise), a political bigwig is shot. Are the two events linked? Santoro starts sifting evidence in an entertaining, just about credible yarn, though the visual trickery distracts.

Fallen Angels
(Wong Kar-Wei, 1995)
8pm, FilmFour

A Hong Kong hitman wants to quit - he's fed up with digging bullets out of his body ("it's so exhausting"). His boss (Michele Reis) harbours a secret longing for him; meanwhile mute ex-con Kaneshiro, prone to forcing hair-washes and ice-cream on people, meets a wacky woman looking for her lover. Their paths interweave in an abstracted, dreamlike, visually compelling account of big-city alienation.

Heaven's Burning
(Craig Lahiff, 1997)
12midnight, Sky Premier

Action, comedy, romance - this Australian road movie has something for everyone, as long as you don't mind a bit of jokey racial stereotyping - Afghans are bloodthirsty sheep-slaughterers, Japanese besuited salarymen, Aborigines stoners. Russell Crowe is the getaway driver in a heist which goes wrong. He finds himself on the run with Midori (Youki Kudoh), a young Japanese woman taken hostage in the raid. Crowe is effective as an average bloke trying to do the decent thing.

fields.headline: Something wild
fields.trailText: The Secret Life of Crocodiles | Star Trek
fields.body:
The salt-water crocodile seized Karla round the hips and she heard her pelvis snap. As she said, "It took the wind out of me at the time." You can quite see it might. Her father jumped on the croc and wrestled her out of its jaws. He did not appear in The Secret Life of Crocodiles (BBC 1) and - with a family in that line of business - you hesitate to ask why.

Though Karla survived the attack, she nearly died from the subsequent water-borne infection. Crocodiles themselves are immune to such infection, which led Dr Adam Britton to theorise that they might produce a natural, powerful antibiotic. All you need is a cooperative crocodile.

I myself have been suffering from a form of down-under deficiency since Les, also known as Bush Tucker Man, disappeared from Discovery's schedules. Bush Tucker Man used to live off the land and, indeed, anything that ran fractionally slower than he did. Rolf Harris is an unsatisfactory stopgap in this respect. How often have you seen him tuck into an iguana? Exactly.

To get a sample of blood from a wild salt-water crocodile, Dr Britton secured the services of Bluey Pugh, his mate, Dog, and his 11-year-old daughter, Frog. Frog, who could hardly see over the dashboard, drove the van ("She's a rough rider, that kid"). Bluey offered to take the doc up Timber Creek in a tin boat borrowed from a bloke down the pub. The idea was to harpoon a salt-water crocodile, pull it to the side of the boat and stick a hypodermic in it. Now crocodiles feel, like Tony Hancock, that a test tube is nearly a tailful, and a crocodile is not one to hide his feelings. This one opened up the tin boat like a can of baked beans. "There's a big hole in the side of the boat!" called Jill Fullerton Smith, the producer, whom I strongly suspect of enjoying herself throughout. "Yeah, we can see it," said Bluey laconically as Timber Creek rose round their ankles.

Time after time, a blood sample was flown to America for analysis at the BBC's expense and, for one reason or another, proved unsuitable. (I would have enjoyed hearing the corporation's comments, just as I would have liked knowing what the bloke down the pub said when he got his boat back with a tooth in it). Time after time the doc set out in search of another croc. You felt he would have been happy with quite a bijou crocodile, but his hunters were always eager to land a whopper.

The final expedition down Shady Creek, home to more salt-water crocodiles than anywhere else on earth, included Karla's Uncle Rob, aka The Barefoot Bushman, and Mick, formerly a ladies hairdresser but now famous in crocodile circles for trapping Cassius, the largest crocodile in captivity. Named, I reckon, for his hungry look.

Catching a crocodile is the easy bit. Then, since they are protected, you have to let them go. Halfway through this tricky bit, someone knocked over the light. A flashlight showed the creature roaring, teeth entangled in a cat's cradle of rope. This is when Rob came gloriously into his own. He closed the crocodile's eyes by touching them with a stick, then cut the snarled rope away with his knife. There's courage and there's God Almighty. This was God Almighty.

It turned out that the salt-water crocodile's blood does contain a protein which kills bacteria resistant to all other antibiotics. It has been called crocodillin.

I once saw a man sitting on a bar stool, wearing a black cloud like a hat. Sometimes he fell off. Sympathisers helped him back. "That", I was told, "is the Man Who Turned Down Volare." You may not remember Volare but, as songs go, it once went round the world.

Jeffrey Hunter was a man like that. He played Captain Pike in the pilot episode of Star Trek but he turned down the series. Gene Roddenberry once said to me: "Nobody had faith in Star Trek. Nobody." Of all the doubters, Jeff Hunter takes the ship's biscuit.

The first series of Star Trek is being rerun on BBC2, starting with this pilot. Here are inchoate signs of life, but not as we know it, Jim. Captain Pike is a man twanging with tension. Mr Spock's ears are distractingly perky and he is apt to panic or, worse, to smile. The Holmes-Watson relationship between an unemotional alien and a warm, cheerful, humorous human would evolve.

Al Read once told Muir and Norden: "Get the character right and you hardly need jokes." Roddenberry was getting the characters right.

webTitle: Virtual footballers to be sued by the real thing

fields.headline: Virtual footballers to be sued by the real thing
fields.trailText: Some of Britain's largest computer software firms are to be sued for millions of pounds by a group of European football players and clubs who are angry that their names have been used in top-selling games without their permission, Belgian lawyers representing the footballers warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Some of Britain's largest computer software firms are to be sued for millions of pounds by a group of European football players and clubs who are angry that their names have been used in top-selling games without their permission, Belgian lawyers representing the footballers warned yesterday.

Legal action will begin in September in Liège, Belgium and similar cases are expected to be launched in Spain, Italy, France and Germany.

The footballers and clubs claim that their names and identities have been used in popular computer games such as Fifa 2000, Uefa Euro 2000 and This is Football without their consent. They are furious that they were not consulted and are seeking compensation worth at least £1.6m in Belgium alone.

Five software firms are being sued; London-based Sony Computer Entertainment Europe; Electronic Arts; Liverpool-based Rage Games; Info grammes; and Eidos, the maker of the cult game Tomb Raider.

The matter has been taken up by Jean-Louis Dupont, the lawyer who won the landmark Bosman case which changed the face of European football and brought about changes in the law covering football transfers and foreign players.

Clubs such as Rangers, of Glasgow, Feyenoord FC, Slavia Prague, Vicenza and several German and Swiss clubs are involved and more are expected to sign up.

A core of international players, many of them Romanian, such as Gheorghe Hagi, are also pressing for damages. "The aim of the case is to stop people profiting from other people's names without having asked their permission first. It's simply not on and perhaps these companies should have been more careful," Daniel Dessard, one of the prosecuting lawyers in Liège, told the Guardian yesterday.

Lawyers will be working out how many of the offending computer games have been sold in total and calculating the damages accordingly. The figure of £1.6m being claimed in Belgium is simply an opening gambit, according to Mr Dessard, and the final sum "might be more or less".

The main allegation is that British software makers are using players' identities, including their skin and hair colour, team position and the way they play without authorisation. It is also alleged that they have illegally appropriated football teams' colours and strips.

The case is not being brought until September to avoid clashing with Euro 2000. "We didn't want to bring a knife to their throat so close to the competition," Mr Dessard says.

The Belgian law firm handling the case is confident that the software firms will cave in to its demands.

"If they are bright they will try to find a solution to this or else they are going to have a lot of trouble on the continent."

It also believes that publicity about the case will open the floodgates for other European football clubs and players to press for damages.

Sony, which owns the This is Football franchise, said yesterday "it would vigorously defend [its] legitimacy" but declined to enter into specifics of the case.

"We have got advance notice of a writ that will be served but we have not received it yet," a spokeswoman said.

Industry insiders said Sony did however have a so-called Fifpro licence which was supposed to cover players' interests.

Surrey-based Electronic Arts, which designed Uefa Euro 2000 and Fifa 2000, said it was aware of the case but refused to comment.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: Quotes of the week
fields.body:
"There is something depressing about the idea that stridently negative critiques of masculinity are at the same time compatible with the goal of trying to be more like men. I wouldn't want to join the army because I wouldn't want anyone to see 'making a man of me' as their appointed task. I wouldn't want anyone to set about 'making a man' of my son either, let alone my daughter"
Deborah Orr on the Ministry of Defence considering whether the ban on women in combat roles should be lifted, Independent

"I don't believe in dieting. If I want to get thinner and wear a swimming costume, I'll have to cut out whisky and potatoes, but you have only one life, so why not enjoy it?"
Mo Mowlam, Red

"I've just started going to the gym and I was told by everybody that goes: 'Oh, once you start, you'll love it.' Three months later, I hate it as much as the first day I went"
Louise, FHM

"Just Gay Enough in heterosexuals, then, is a state of mind that transcends biological leanings. It's an insider's shorthand for saying that a man understands the nuances of modern urban life - and has excellent taste. In other words, a man can be culturally homosexual but genetically straight ... Just Gay Enough is knowing that Jo Malone is a supplier of superior skin products, not a boxer. Too Gay is wearing her aftershave. Just Gay Enough is being able to whizz through a River Cafe or Jamie Oliver cookbook. Too Gay is serving up black pasta. Not Gay Enough is choosing McDonald's over organic. Not Gay Enough is abhorring a vacuum cleaner. Scented candles are Just Too Gay"
Lisa Armstrong on why the ideal straight man is culturally gay, Times

fields.headline: The end of the affair
fields.standfirst: Rod's gone for serial dating, Rachel's gone celibate.  Ekow Eshun  asks if there's ever a right way to handle the break-up of a relationship
fields.trailText: Rod's gone for serial dating, Rachel's gone celibate.  Ekow Eshun  asks if there's ever a right way to handle the break-up of a relationship
fields.body:
Interviewed this week on American DJ Howard Stern's radio show, Rachel Hunter offered some advice to her ex-husband Rod Stewart. Stay off the blondes, Hunter counselled the singer, who was said to be devastated when she walked out of their Beverly Hills mansion 16 months ago. Since then, Stewart has been seen with, among others, model-cum-TV presenter Caprice, Hugh Hefner's ex-wife Kimberly and Essex photography student Penny Lancaster. But if he is to get over the failure of their marriage, Hunter advises, he should follow in her own abstemious footsteps. "I think it is really important to be single for a while before you get back into it. I love relationships but you need time. I have been celibate for seven months. I am waiting for the right man, a man who clicks with me."

It's a familiar story. Couple splits up, he denies his feelings and dives into a string of meaningless relationships, she seeks to work through the pain, all the while holding on to the possibility that true love will re-enter her life. It's tempting, then, as the tabloid press did yesterday, to cast Hunter as a tragic heroine and Stewart as an eternal lad, unable to change his wayward habits, as though they are playing out a real-life chapter from Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus.

Yet who's to say that Stewart is dealing with their break-up any worse than Hunter? It is sometimes easy to forget an essential fact about relationships. They don't make sense. They're fragmented, chaotic, exhilarating and perplexing. Just as what happens between two people never follows a set of rules, neither is there a guide by which to measure the collapse of a relationship. Long schooled in blokeish badinage, men tend to talk about separation as though it were a challenge to their masculinity. Like hunters, we advise each other to "get back in the saddle". Like fishermen, we say: "There are plenty more fish in the sea."

But although it's seductive to suggest that, like cavemen, we are singularly lacking in emotional depth, that's to miss what is really being said when we console each other. Or rather what's not being said, because men feel, all too keenly, the loss and pain that comes with separation. It's just that it is expressed in the sighs and spaces and sudden lapses in conversation that punctuate all the empty words of the newly single. As a coping strategy, it has its flaws. Like troops back from the Somme, recently separated men have the sunken eyes and gaunt cheeks of those wrestling with a private horror. But it does mean that men refuse to make the break-up of a relationship central to their lives. Even while they hurt, they continue to work and meet their friends and talk about sport. Even if all that's holding them up is pride. And that approach has its advantages.

"Women privilege relationships above everything else," complains Adele, who has been single for two years and provided a shoulder to cry on for many of her girlfriends when their relationships have ended. For her, the supportive group of females huddling close to offer hugs and support in times of sorrow, as celebrated in fiction, films and TV shows like Friends, is a pernicious development. "It's quite boring really if the main focus of your peer group is relationships. It means there are so many other aspects of life that are being overlooked and so many other relationships, apart from those with boyfriends, that you could share but don't. Its permissible to talk about partners, for instance, but not dads. There's a huge cost to it all in how we come to look at ourselves and respect ourselves."

Following Adele's theory, it's possible to argue that Rachel Hunter, celibate for seven months and "waiting for the right man", is living as much of a fantasy as Rod Stewart. While he is pursuing pleasure as a way to salve pain, she is putting part of her life on hold in favour of an idealised notion of love that belongs in Mills & Boon.

Unlike Stewart and Hunter, though, most couples don't deal with the end of their affair in such absolute terms. In many modern relationships, there is no clear-cut end at all. Instead, couples make up and break up time and time again. They sleep together and drift apart, and maintain an erratic orbit around each other for months, even years, before finally breaking up or possibly becoming friends. And they do so out of choice, not compulsion because, despite the determinism of books like Men Are From Mars, they know that relationships don't follow a gender-defined script. And it is precisely their unpredictability, their promise of magic or chaos, that draws couples together, however much it hurts when they split apart.

webTitle: French media fury at privacy laws

fields.headline: French media fury at privacy laws
fields.trailText: The French media, already bound by some of the world's strictest privacy rules, reacted angrily yesterday to a new law that places even tougher restrictions on the pictures newpapers and television stations may use.
fields.body:
The French media, already bound by some of the world's strictest privacy rules, reacted angrily yesterday to a new law that places even tougher restrictions on the pictures newpapers and television stations may use.

The legislation, part of an overhaul of the criminal justice system aimed at preserving the presumption of innocence and protecting victims' rights, was passed unanimously by the French senate despite claims that it amounts to censorship.

The new rules outlaw pictures of untried defendants wearing handcuffs and - more controversially - ban the media from showing the victims of crimes or violence if the image is likely to "jeopardise the dignity of the person portrayed".

They were partly a response to public outcry at the alleged behaviour of paparazzi in the wake of the car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, and at the graphic pictures in the French press of the victims of a 1990s Paris bombing campaign by Algerian terrorists.

But the authoritative daily Le Monde said that newspapers would now "hesitate to publish pictures of France as it is".

The editor of Paris Match, one of the picture-led publications most likely to suffer under the new regime, described the rules as retrograde, unworkable and unjust.

"We are being asked to divert our lenses while CNN and every other European newspaper will show the full reality," Alain Genestar told a conference on press freedom yesterday. "We will not be content with showing a shattered window to illustrate a terrorist bombing."

Mr Genestar, who also devoted his editorial in this week's issue of the magazine to the legislation, said Paris Match would be willing to "break the law in the name of freedom of information. And if we are convicted, we will go to the European court".

France already has draconian privacy laws which make it an offence to publish a picture of any private individual without their permission. This has led to bizarre images of, for example, protest marches where the majority of the participants' faces are blanked out.

Laurent Abadjian, picture editor at the left-leaning daily Libération, said the new laws - which carry a penalty of up to £10,000 for transgressions - were a further blow to an already embattled profession. "Inevitably, photographs of a great many important events for our readers will lose all their impact," he said.

Defending her legislation, the justice minister, Elisabeth Guigou, said the state had a "duty to isolated individuals, whom no one defends, by giving them the right to go to court to protect their image." She denied that the measures constituted censorship.

fields.headline: Another country, another world
fields.standfirst:
Weight of differences in languages and cultures causes strain in the system meant to help refugees

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Weight of differences in languages and cultures causes strain in the system meant to help refugees
fields.body:
Liz Westmoreland had just sorted a plan for "language clusters" of asylum seekers in Yorkshire yesterday when a letter arrived from the Home Office.

Instead of the manageable prospect of 10-12 teams of interpreters and networks of community support, she now faces organising 31.

"To give you the idea, we've an Eritrean refugee on the list which would normally mean finding an Amharic speaker," she said at the busy regional office charged with refugee dispersal. "Except that this Eritrean uses a particular dialect and regular Amharic won't do."

It may not be a problem in the cosmopolitan heart of London, but it is a challenge in the regions as the audit commission's report on dispersing asylum-seekers from the capital repeatedly underlined.

The title - Another Country - rings true with an Iraqi woman doctor in a refugee hostel in Leeds, struggling to find an advanced English course to help her studies meet the demands of the General Medical Council before she can practice here. "I'm allowed to deliver the post or be a waitress," she said, putting aside what she can from her £46 income support to meet Royal College of Obstetrics and Gynaecology exam fees.

"I hear on the radio about the queues for hospital treatment, but I can't work as a doctor until I pass the exams.

"People in London can go on sophisticated language courses and pass first time, but there isn't so much choice here."

More basic problems face her Somali friend - one of 21 women in the hostel who are refugees from the world's bloodiest disasters - who has to survive on vouchers instead of cash.

"The trouble is, the supermarket chain with the [voucher] contract in Leeds doesn't do halal meat which she has to eat as a Muslim," said the doctor, who like all the women will not give her name through fear of reprisals against her family back home. "There are plenty of Pakistani shops round here which do the halal, but she doesn't have the money to go there."

The women sort things out sensibly between themselves - a system copied at a more complex level by Ms Westmoreland and Martin Schweiger, Leeds' director of public health, who has worked a careful system with local GPs of not overloading any one practice as asylum seekers arrive.

"Clearly, an asylum seeker is likely to take more time in the surgery, if only because of language problems, just as a foreign tourist would," he said. But the delicate system is now straining, with two groups of GPs in Leeds signalling that they cannot take any more refugees.

The problem, as the audit commission was told during three days of fact finding in the city, is the unpredictable flow of arrivals via the private sector - social housing firms which have contracts with the Home Office and fail to give the regional office either num bers or areas or countries of origin of the asylum seekers.

Leeds has 460 asylum seekers and 300 more are expected through the official system, but estimates for privately-housed ones are "at least as many again".

"They keep popping up in weird and wonderful places," said Lucy Bryson at the Refugee Council's new office in Leeds. "The regional consortium [the official title for the local council-led partnerships in charge of dispersal across England] is so sorted here. And then the private providers come along without a system of fitting in and the whole thing is undermined."

The private providers are essential, however, because of the sheer scale of the operation involved in dispersing large numbers of refugees.

The Iraqi doctor unconsciously echoes the great criticism made in Leeds in the 1930s when slumdwellers were relocated to "garden village" estates before shops, clinics or community centres had been provided. "I wish the Home Office had brought the facilities here before it brought me," she said."As it is, London has all the support."

Everyone involved is conscious that the numbers will swell; a tower block is being prepared in central Leeds and two big housing associations, united in a refugee arm called Yorkshire Safe Haven, are gearing up to expand their operation from Sheffield to Leeds. Exiles and their carers alike are watching local public opinion.

And then there's Parvinder Kaur, 18, and a sixth former at Primrose high school, who rallied fellow pupils to sign a petition against the proposed repatriation of 30 Kosovans at the school who do not yet have homes to return to in Kosova, let alone a school.

Her message was the same as the audit commission's: the regions can make this work, but they need time, a system and the money.

fields.headline: Orsay tackles its marathon queues
fields.trailText: The Musée d'Orsay, home to France's finest collection of Impressionist paintings, is hoping to lose its reputation as the only museum in Paris where visitors spend more time queueing to buy a ticket than admiring masterpieces.
fields.body:
The Musée d'Orsay, home to France's finest collection of Impressionist paintings, is hoping to lose its reputation as the only museum in Paris where visitors spend more time queueing to buy a ticket than admiring masterpieces.

The museum's director, Henri Loyrette, said a fundamental revamp of the museum's entrance should mean the end of the marathon waits of between four and five-hour common for the most popular exhibitions.

The museum is investing £2.5m in the project, which is scheduled for completion in November 2001.

"From our opening in 1986, we've had 50% more visitors than we anticipated," he said. "We've been a victim of our own success. We don't want to increase the number of our visitors - just to improve their comfort."

fields.headline: Steaming
fields.standfirst: Women-only saunas? Pole dancing clubs? A gaygirl scene? Let's hear it for hedonism!  Stephanie Theobald reports on a revolution in lesbian nightlife
fields.trailText: Women-only saunas? Pole dancing clubs? A gaygirl scene? Let's hear it for hedonism!  Stephanie Theobald reports on a revolution in lesbian nightlife
fields.body:
In the steam room, a tanned 22-year-old is relating the story of a pick-up she had recently. "She suddenly pulled out these needles and handed them to me!" "What sort of needles?" echoes a voice from the other end of the room. "You know, for piercing. She wanted me to put them through her nipples!" General gasps and murmurings roll from the mists, followed by a chorus of "Go on" and "What happened next?"

What happened next was that she "put the needle through one and it was like, whoosh, amazing, then I put the needle through the other and it was like, whoosh!" And then, unfortunately, the steam gets overbearing. Dehydration levels go through the roof, the warm lager and red wine in plastic beakers strewn around the floor prove inadequate thirst slakers and one has to exit rapidly, tantalised as to whether the "whoosh" referred to the spurting blood or ensuing orgasm.

The good thing about the ongoing lesbian revolution is that everything new that happens can be deemed culturally and politically significant. The fact is that lesbian liberation has reached the point at which women in London can now live like sleazy gayboys on Mondays here at Flirt and dirty old men on Tuesdays at Loose, a female-only pole dancing night. For the rest of the week, they can act like 70s bimbos by rehearsing for the two lesbian beauty contests taking place in the next few weeks. (Not just one lesbian beauty contest, but two!)

Naturally, the concept of mindless hedonism for lesbians - a kind of gayboy scene for gaygirls - is still in its salad days and female reactions are bound to be different from male ones. Everyone has a gay male friend who will moan, in a bored voice, about how awful gayboy saunas are (the groping hands , sordid goings-on) - so awful, they have to keep going back. But if there is an element of Sodom and Gomorrah to the lesbian sauna, it is more Sodom and Gomorrah meets the netball team. There is some lechery here tonight but mostly there is that all girls together messing around at the back of the class sort of spirit.

Still, how life has changed for lesbians since the 70s when the backdrop to lesbian politics was flickering candles, bobbly jumpers, Joan Baez soundtracks and sex in the back seat. Such codes of practice were inevitable as lesbian feminism was just starting up and you have to make the rules before you can break them - but the rules seemed to stay in place for an inordinately long time. Even three years ago, lesbians with longish hair or lipstick or skirts would be stopped on the door of gay clubs like London's Heaven and asked by bouncers to "prove" that they were lesbian by, say, naming three lesbian clubs (except there weren't three lesbian clubs).

No such starter-for-10 questions at Loose in Soho on Tuesday nights, hosted by Chrystal, a Polish/Swedish bisexual dancer who struts around the stage in Gucci spikes and diamanté. She has a cute thing going with her index finger and lips, a sexy little kiss she gives audience members who are adventurous with the dollar bills they place in various straps, belts and folds. Dollars are on sale for £1 each, as are tequila shots - and Chrystal admits a female audience tends to have that Tupperware party vibe until well watered. Then, she says, they tip more generously than the men who fill the place the rest of the week.

Kai, who runs women-only sex shop Shh!, says this is where she sends her "curious" customers, "the ones who respond to all those lesbiany fashion ads". For them, she says, it's the perfect place to go. "You don't have to be the sad person sitting at the bar. You don't have to do anything. You can interact with other women just by putting dollars in their crotch."

Female audiences are more appreciative than male ones, but tougher. "You shake your butt a bit for men and you wear some underwear and they're happy as Larry. Women want better dance routines, better costumes. There's none of that mystique thing to pull the wool over their eyes."

The woman behind this transformation of lesbian nightlife is Kim Lucas, who started out with the Candy Bar three years ago and went on to open Loose and Flirt. But the new scene is not just in London: Lucas will open a Candy Bar in Brighton in July and Manchester has women-only bar Vanilla. Lucas recently joined forces with the management there to organise the Lesbian Holiday - a two-week, all-in package to Lesbos.

Yet while there is much to be grateful for, not all in the lesbian garden is rosy. Outside London or Manchester, a lesbian is hard-pressed to find much on the entertainment front. Check one of the messages currently posted on the dyke board of RainbowNetwork.com: "Is there anyone in the Notts area that wants meaningless sex, if so let me know, I'm gagging for it."

Like male homosexuals in the 30s, many lesbians are still trying to suss out the secret handshake that gives them access to the wonderful lesbian nirvana they've been reading about in Vogue. Steph Kay from Vanilla says the trouble with lesbians is that they tend to stop going out once they have found a partner, whereas many gay men in couples have long abandoned the heterosexual model of life-long fidelity. This is good news for the clubs. Non-monogamous coupledom has its dangers but it also keeps gay men together for longer than many lesbian couples who often remain for a long time in bad relationships simply because they fear not meeting anyone else. The lesbian pool is so much smaller, they reason, and therefore there are less places to go out. The vicious circle, in short.

Still, over at Flirt, the alcohol and dehydration seem to be doing the trick on the loosening-up front. The Israeli Daryl Hannah lookalike who hasn't had sex in a year has got off with the Chinese American in the jacuzzi's volleyball game. Then the tanned 22-year-old comes and sits on my lap, saying, like a brazen gayboy: "Can I kiss you, then?"

I mumble something about having a girlfriend and she says: "Just a quick one?" with a fetching little moue. By now, you figure, there would have been an orgiastic pile-up in a gayboy sauna and you start thinking again about cultural and political change, about the dyke dollar and such, and you end up making a snap lesbian decision - a cross between teenage dementia, Catholic guilt trip and run-of-the-mill heterosexual response. "Well, OK then, but only for a count of ten."

"Ten?"

"Ten." And so the pioneering work begins. "One, two, three, four, five."

Naturally, the concept of mindless hedonism for lesbians - a kind of gayboy scene for gaygirls - is still in its salad days and female reactions are bound to be different from male ones. Everyone has a gay male friend who will moan, in a bored voice, about how awful gayboy saunas are (the groping hands , sordid goings-on) - so awful, they have to keep going back. But if there is an element of Sodom and Gomorrah to the lesbian sauna, it is more Sodom and Gomorrah meets the netball team. There is some lechery here tonight but mostly there is that all girls together messing around at the back of the class sort of spirit. Still, how life has changed for lesbians since the 70s when the backdrop to lesbian politics was flickering candles, bobbly jumpers, Joan Baez soundtracks and sex in the back seat. Such codes of practice were inevitable as lesbian feminism was just starting up and you have to make the rules before you can break them - but the rules seemed to stay in place for an inordinately long time. Even three years ago, lesbians with longish hair or lipstick or skirts would be stopped on the door of gay clubs like London's Heaven and asked by bouncers to "prove" that they were lesbian by, say, naming three lesbian clubs (except there weren't three lesbian clubs). No such starter-for-10 questions at Loose in Soho on Tuesday nights, hosted by Chrystal, a Polish/Swedish bisexual dancer who struts around the stage in Gucci spikes and diamanté. She has a cute thing going with her index finger and lips, a sexy little kiss she gives audience members who are adventurous with the dollar bills they place in various straps, belts and folds. Dollars are on sale for £1 each, as are tequila shots - and Chrystal admits a female audience tends to have that Tupperware party vibe until well watered. Then, she says, they tip more generously than the men who fill the place the rest of the week. Kai, who runs women-only sex shop Shh!, says this is where she sends her "curious" customers, "the ones who respond to all those lesbiany fashion ads". For them, she says, it's the perfect place to go. "You don't have to be the sad person sitting at the bar. You don't have to do anything. You can interact with other women just by putting dollars in their crotch." Female audiences are more appreciative than male ones, but tougher. "You shake your butt a bit for men and you wear some underwear and they're happy as Larry. Women want better dance routines, better costumes. There's none of that mystique thing to pull the wool over their eyes." The woman behind this transformation of lesbian nightlife is Kim Lucas, who started out with the Candy Bar three years ago and went on to open Loose and Flirt. But the new scene is not just in London: Lucas will open a Candy Bar in Brighton in July and Manchester has women-only bar Vanilla. Lucas recently joined forces with the management there to organise the Lesbian Holiday - a two-week, all-in package to Lesbos. Yet while there is much to be grateful for, not all in the lesbian garden is rosy. Outside London or Manchester, a lesbian is hard-pressed to find much on the entertainment front. Check one of the messages currently posted on the dyke board of RainbowNetwork.com: "Is there anyone in the Notts area that wants meaningless sex, if so let me know, I'm gagging for it." Like male homosexuals in the 30s, many lesbians are still trying to suss out the secret handshake that gives them access to the wonderful lesbian nirvana they've been reading about in Vogue. Steph Kay from Vanilla says the trouble with lesbians is that they tend to stop going out once they have found a partner, whereas many gay men in couples have long abandoned the heterosexual model of life-long fidelity. This is good news for the clubs. Non-monogamous coupledom has its dangers but it also keeps gay men together for longer than many lesbian couples who often remain for a long time in bad relationships simply because they fear not meeting anyone else. The lesbian pool is so much smaller, they reason, and therefore there are less places to go out. The vicious circle, in short. Still, over at Flirt, the alcohol and dehydration seem to be doing the trick on the loosening-up front. The Israeli Daryl Hannah lookalike who hasn't had sex in a year has got off with the Chinese American in the jacuzzi's volleyball game. Then the tanned 22-year-old comes and sits on my lap, saying, like a brazen gayboy: "Can I kiss you, then?" I mumble something about having a girlfriend and she says: "Just a quick one?" with a fetching little moue. By now, you figure, there would have been an orgiastic pile-up in a gayboy sauna and you start thinking again about cultural and political change, about the dyke dollar and such, and you end up making a snap lesbian decision - a cross between teenage dementia, Catholic guilt trip and run-of-the-mill heterosexual response. "Well, OK then, but only for a count of ten." "Ten?" "Ten." And so the pioneering work begins. "One, two, three, four, five."

webTitle: Mugabe to name farms for seizure

fields.headline: Mugabe to name farms for seizure
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe's government will bring its land campaign to a climax tomorrow by decreeing the seizure without compensation of hundreds of white-owned farms.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe's government will bring its land campaign to a climax tomorrow by decreeing the seizure without compensation of hundreds of white-owned farms.

By rushing to confiscate the land before Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections on June 24 and 25 he is slamming the door on international aid for land redistribution. He has stated his determination to seize the farms, no matter what the reaction of the international community.

"We are going to publish in the government gazette a list of the farms that we intend to take for resettlement on Friday and we will publish another list on Monday," said Vincent Kwenda, director of the government's land acquisition committee. The government expected the first black farmers to be on the land by the end of the month.

Mr Kwenda said he was going to each of Zimbabwe's 10 provinces to tell rural people of the government's plans. Poor blacks would be resettled on the properties without waiting for roads, water supplies, schools and other basic infrastructure to be installed.

Last week Mr Mugabe used his presidential powers to enact a law allowing him to take white-owned farmland by decree without compensation.

He personally wrote the new law, which says that Britain, as the former colonial power, must pay for the land stolen from black Africans during the colonial period when the country was called Southern Rhodesia. If it does not, the law says, the government can seize the farms.

The British government has put aside £36m for land resettlement, but says it cannot give financial backing to the seizure of white farms if it is not backed by a careful plan to alleviate rural poverty, and will not do so until the current illegal occupations and political violence end.

Mr Mugabe intends to move more than 100,000 of his black supporters on to seized land by the end of this month. Agricultural experts say a rushed job without adequate financial support will force the blacks to continue as subsistence farmers and cost Zimbabwe dear in lost commercial crops.

Squatters on three white-owned cattle ranches in central Kenya opened fire on police officers trying to evict them, a Kenyan newspaper reported yesterday. The police returned fire but were beaten back, the Daily Nation reported. A six-year old boy was reported missing and five cows were shot dead.

The head of the civil service, Richard Leakey, said last week that the government would not tolerate Zimbabwe-style occupation of white-owned farms, and criticised MPs who had advocated it.

webTitle: Top Russian official killed by Chechens

fields.headline: Top Russian official killed by Chechens
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Chechen guerrillas have assassinated one of the top Russian officials in Grozny, and injured the Russian-appointed mayor of the destroyed Chechen capital in the latest demonstration of the rebels' ability to strike unexpectedly at the Russian forces all over Chechnya.
fields.body:
Chechen guerrillas have assassinated one of the top Russian officials in Grozny, and injured the Russian-appointed mayor of the destroyed Chechen capital in the latest demonstration of the rebels' ability to strike unexpectedly at the Russian forces all over Chechnya.

And far beyond the conflict zone of the north Caucasus, in Volgograd, a Russian serviceman was killed yesterday in a separate bomb blast ascribed to Chechen "terrorists".

Russian officials confirmed yesterday that Sergei Zverev, the deputy head of the Russian administration in Chechnya and the second most senior Russian civilian official in the republic, died when his car hit a radio-controlled bomb laid on the southern outskirts of Grozny on Tuesday evening.

Another government official, Nusreda Khabuseyeva, the deputy mayor of Grozny, also died in the attack and the Russian-appointed mayor, Supyan Mokhchayev, was injured. Russian spokesmen said the attack was apparently aimed at the mayor.

Rebel gunmen followed up the bomb blast by opening fire on the Russian car. Guerrilla leaders all over the breakaway republic are putting pressure on Chechens not to "collaborate" with what they perceive as Russian occupying forces and the attack on the mayor, an ethnic Chechen, appeared to be the most spectacular attempt yet to punish such co-operation.

Nikolai Koshman, the government official in charge of Chechnya, blamed forces loyal to the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, for the attack. "This terrorist act was aimed at the people rebuilding Grozny and restoring peaceful life," he said.

But three months after the Russians levelled Grozny in order to capture it, the scale of the resumed fighting in the city is escalating, with gunfights and rebel ambushes occurring on a daily basis. And there is mounting evidence that the Kremlin is unable to recruit the "loyal" Chechens it needs to run the republic.

In a stark admission of failure, Mr Koshman sacked Bislan Gantemirov as his deputy on Tuesday. Mr Gantemirov is a convicted embezzler and former mayor of Grozny recruited by the Russians months ago as head of a pro-Russian Chechen militia. His forces played a key role in capturing Grozny in February.

But Russian servicemen in the city say that the Gantemirov militiamen regularly fight alongside the Russians during the day only to join the rebels after dark. Hostility between the Russian forces and the Gantemirov men has been soaring for the past month.

Mr Koshman admitted that the militiamen were "uncontrollable" and said almost 300 of them had been sacked for "absenteeism". In all likelihood, they are already fighting on the rebel side.

Meanwhile, human rights monitors from Amnesty International were briefly detained by Russian officials at Moscow airport and had a report on human rights abuses in Chechnya seized, the organisation said yesterday.

The officials told Mariana Katzarova, an Amnesty monitor who was en route to a government-organised conference on Chechnya, that the documents were "anti-Russian government propaganda" and confiscated them.

"Amnesty International is concerned that this type of event sets a dangerous precedent which brings to mind old Soviet practices," the organisation said in a statement.

fields.headline: Universities on the cheap
fields.standfirst: If the government is serious about "opportunity for all" it is surely ironic that it should have become so preoccupied by the issue of Oxbridge admissions systems.
fields.trailText: If the government is serious about "opportunity for all" it is surely ironic that it should have become so preoccupied by the issue of Oxbridge admissions systems (Closing the privilege gap, May 31). Since these institutions will never be able to accommodate more than a small proportion of those who need and deserve to enter higher education, the effect is to collude with the mistaken assumption that excellence is only attainable in exclusive institutions.
fields.body:
If the government is serious about "opportunity for all" it is surely ironic that it should have become so preoccupied by the issue of Oxbridge admissions systems (Closing the privilege gap, May 31). Since these institutions will never be able to accommodate more than a small proportion of those who need and deserve to enter higher education, the effect is to collude with the mistaken assumption that excellence is only attainable in exclusive institutions.

The way to tackle the elitism of our "top" universities is to acknowledge that Britain's newer universities are more than capable of matching the standards of their more privileged counterparts and to provide the investment necessary to ensure they can develop on equal terms.
Prof Hartley Dean
University of Luton hartley.dean@luton.ac.uk

The recent debate about higher education has missed a more glaring inequality: the large numbers of disad vantaged students who have little option but to attend a new university. The fact that these institutions - Oxbridge, redbrick, old and new, are all called universities - is a misnomer. I have taught in both old and new universities and I have found little parity. By missing out on research-based funding, the new universities must generate income from increasing the numbers of students who are, increasingly, barely able to support themselves, far less study at university.

As an admissions tutor and lecturer in a new university, I am exhorted to increase student numbers by further widening access to non-standard entry students and, at the same time, maintain high quality courses and academic standards, and reduce student attrition rates by providing time-consuming, intensive tutorial and remedial support - oh and, of course, sustain a research profile.

Meanwhile, our students struggle to study against a backcloth of poverty, mount ing debt, inadequate child care support and exhaustion from combining education with a part-time job. This is the real inequality within higher education.
Dr Joan Forbes
Coventry University j.forbes@coventry.ac.uk

I am head of Caribbean studies at the University of North London. 80 per cent of my students are single mothers, pursuing black history and culture while gaining vocational training.

Since 1998, however, with the removal of the grant element in student funding, we have experienced a 50% fall in intake. If New Labour really wants a more egalitarian, stable society, it is imperative that poor people, including the much-maligned single mothers who wish to set an example to their children, be assisted to go to the non-elite universities.

Many of my students are cynical about the current fuss over admission to Oxbridge: they see in it another Mandelsonian spin.
Clem Seecharan
University of North London hxezseechac@unl.ac.uk

If New Labour is serious about ending elitism in higher education it must also seek ways of removing a whole tier of vice chancellor's and senior toadies (many of whom are Oxbridge educated) who have operated our once venerated public institutions as little more than unaccountable private fiefdoms over the past two decades.

It is time to reverse a situation in which ever more lavish remuneration packages are being provided for the few at the expense of good terms and conditions for the many.
Robert Page
Nottingham

fields.headline: No: 1647 Harley Street
fields.trailText: Famous for expensive operations by fashionable doctors
fields.body:
Where is it? London W1.

Be more precise: It runs south from Regent's Park to Cavendish Square.

Famous for: Expensive operations by fashionable doctors.

Named after a famous quack? No. Its name comes from Edward Harley, the 2nd Earl of Oxford; he owned the land in the 18th century.

How do I get there? Tell your GP you're tired of waiting to have your hernia done on the NHS and that you'll pay to go private.

Don't be cynical. Anyway, it's not a hernia, it's lip enlargements I want; my local hospital doesn't do them. If you can afford that sort of cosmetic surgery, you can easily pay for a taxi to take you there.

All right. But it's confusing; there's Harley St and Upper Harley St, isn't there? There is, but that could soon change.

Why? The Crown Estate wants the upper part of the street, which it owns, to revert to its original name, Brunswick Place.

Why did it change in the first place? So many private quacks were piling into Harley St in the 20s, that some had to take consulting rooms in the section north of Marylebone Road.

So what? With Upper Harley St rather than Brunswick Place on their bills, they could charge more.

Did Harley St always cater for rich patients? Yes, even in the 19th century, the Hospital for Sick Gentlewomen was there.

Not the sort of place Florence Nightingale would be seen dead in? On the contrary, the Lady with the Lamp worked there for a year.

Other famous (healthy) residents: Wilkie Collins wrote much of The Woman in White at number 12.

Famous patients? Take your pick over the decades - from Virginia Woolf to Patsy Kensit and Pinochet.

Speaking of golden oldies, wasn't Heseltine in the Harley St clinic with a dickey heart? Yes, but, strangely, the clinic's on Weymouth St.

Not to be confused with: Harley-Davidson, Steve Harley, Street of Shame.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Brothers, the film which provided the image of the naked man on the cover of the Friday Review, May 26, is not, contrary to any impression that the context of the accompanying article may have given, funded from the lottery. Paradise Films, the production and distribution company, say the film has been funded entirely by private investors, under the Enterprise Investment Scheme, which has not used lottery money. The film itself is not released until June 23 and at the time the article was published no one at the Guardian had seen it.
fields.body:
Brothers, the film which provided the image of the naked man on the cover of the Friday Review, May 26, is not, contrary to any impression that the context of the accompanying article may have given, funded from the lottery. Paradise Films, the production and distribution company, say the film has been funded entirely by private investors, under the Enterprise Investment Scheme, which has not used lottery money. The film itself is not released until June 23 and at the time the article was published no one at the Guardian had seen it.

Nevertheless the following line was written into the article to account for the use of the cover picture: "Brothers, the movie depicted on our cover, is still an unknown quantity, but the portents aren't good." Prejudgments of unseen films are not good either and it was wrong to suggest one in this case. Apologies.
