fields.headline: GM claims
fields.trailText: Monsanto assert that soya beans have been "widely consumed in Europe in foods and animal foods and foodstuffs without adverse effects". How would they know?
fields.body:
Monsanto assert that soya beans have been "widely consumed in Europe in foods and animal foods and foodstuffs without adverse effects" (Soya gene find, May 31). How would they know? There are no long-term animal feeding experiments and no human health monitoring. Subtle effects such as new allergies or impacts on immune systems need very different investigation to the "substantial equivalence" tests applied today.
Joan Ruddock
MP

The risk of gene transfer within the gastrointestinal tract was identified as far back as 1996 by government advisers. There is no excuse for allowing any GMOs into our food chain until such research has been completed.
Joanna Clarke
Glasgow

fields.headline: Enigma of a blockbuster
fields.trailText: Hugh Sebag-Montefiore, in his account of the capture of an Enigma cypher machine from the crippled German submarine U-110 in 1941, records the role of Sub-Lt DE Balme, but makes no mention of my father who, with Balme, was decorated for his role in boarding the U-boat.
fields.body:
Hugh Sebag-Montefiore, in his account of the capture of an Enigma cypher machine from the crippled German submarine U-110 in 1941 (Enigma variations, G2, May 25), records the role of Sub-Lt DE Balme, but makes no mention of my father who, with Balme, was decorated for his role in boarding the U-boat.

My late father, Cdr GE Dodds, was serving at the time on HMS Bulldog as Capt Baker-Cresswell's chief engineer officer. In his book, The Secret Capture, SW Roskill recorded how my father not only helped with the recovery of materials from the U-boat, but also led a small party into the machine room of the U-110 to see if they could increase the submarine's buoyancy - Baker-Cresswell hoped to tow the stricken vessel to port in Iceland. A tow wire from Bulldog was eventually secured to the submarine.

Baker-Cresswell then recalled his men from U-110 and began the hazardous tow of the damaged vessel towards Iceland with HMS Broadway as escort. The submarine sank before they reached port, but Bulldog already had on board an infinitely greater prize. It is indeed a shame that the extraordinary account of the capture of Enigma and the heroism of the crew of HMS Bulldog should be mauled by Hollwood film makers into an American blockbuster.

fields.headline: ... and on short time
fields.trailText: Perhaps the government's concern should also be directed at the number of weeks universities remain open. In many cases, this amounts to less than half a year; most universities will close in the next week or so and not reopen until the first week of October; and that's for just one of their three annual holidays.
fields.body:
Perhaps the government's concern should also be directed at the number of weeks universities remain open. In many cases, this amounts to less than half a year; most universities will close in the next week or so and not reopen until the first week of October; and that's for just one of their three annual holidays. Our brains are at their most fertile in our late teens and early twenties, so why do universities so curtail the time they give to teaching their students? Is it for the benefit of lecturers and professors - or for economic reasons?

Gordon Brown could commission a study to see if the benefits of, say, a 44-45 week year would materially affect the economics of further education and allow an increase in pay and student allowances. The capital costs of running universities would not be increased and even though the overheads would, they could be amortised over a longer period, providing enormous savings. Just think what would happen to the economy if our factories and offices followed the opening times of these places of further learning.

I already know the myriad arguments that will be put forward to defend the present arrangements, because I have been on the council of a university and the governor of a public school for many years. But if our government really does believe, as I do, in education, education, education, then here is something radical to consider. The result could be much more education for much less money, with universities really focusing on preparing their graduates for life in the outside world. It would also create space for the Lauras of the future.
Terence Conran
London

webTitle: Radio 1 is losing touch with its roots

fields.headline: Radio 1 is losing touch with its roots
fields.trailText: Francis Wheen  rightly decries the BBC's decision to remove Andy Kershaw from its schedules. Culture is a weapon of the utmost power in the battle against racism.
fields.body:
Francis Wheen (G2, May 31) rightly decries the BBC's decision to remove Andy Kershaw from its schedules. Culture is a weapon of the utmost power in the battle against racism. John Peel started the fight 30 years ago when he exposed a rock audience to his weird and wonderful "archive things" - ethnographic material from all over the world, played to a late-night audience on his Radio 1 show. The fight was taken up by the World of Music, Arts and Dance (Womad) launched in 1982 in Bath. Mainstream acts, such as the Beat and Echo and the Bunnymen, shared the stage with the drummers of Burundi and performers from 25 countries demonstrated the rich diversity of the world's music. All the talk was of the financial unviability of the project but, nearly 20 years on, Womad festivals continue. Andy Kershaw is part of that courageous tradition, valuing diversity and challenging racism by showcasting the best of what the world has to offer.
Derek Gadd
London

The music which Andy has become a respected broadcaster for presenting - world music, roots and folk - has been sorely under-represented on our airwaves. In the record megastores, you will find a large amount of floor space given over to these genres. These companies would have those racks out overnight if they were not profitable. In 1999, when the press was full of stories of rock and dance festivals failing, all the big world music and folk festivals - Womad, Sidmouth, Cambridge - were sold out.

How ill-timed to remove the only decent radio show covering all this. Andy Kershaw is the kind of broadcaster the BBC should be cultivating; he manages to enthuse and inform, educate and entertain from a strong position of knowledge, experience and good judgement.
Ian Anderson
Editor, f-Roots Magazine froots@froots.demon.co.uk

We have lost a vital forum for innovative music composition. Ironically, this music is then adopted into the loops and samples used by the current dance music hybrids so loved by the Radio 1 schedulers.
Enin Johnson
Ingrave, Essex

fields.headline: Dream on
fields.trailText: You devote virtually an entire page to Labour candidate selections. You cite the usual unidentified "senior Labour figure", who allegedly claims that the party's parliamentary selection process is "a complete mess, a total nightmare".
fields.body:
You devote virtually an entire page to Labour candidate selections (Labour in turmoil over candidate selection, May 30). You cite the usual unidentified "senior Labour figure", who allegedly claims that the party's parliamentary selection process is "a complete mess, a total nightmare".

You then point to four selections. In the first, you report that all complaints made were found to be groundless. In a second, you conclude that conspiracy theorists will find no Millbank plot. In a third, you note that no complaints have been made. In the fourth, you report that a court challenge was thrown out. The reality is that Labour's parliamentary candidate selection process is progressing smoothly. Contests are keenly fought - that is because members recognise it is an honour to stand as a parliamentary candidate.
Phil Murphy
Assistant general secretary, Labour party

fields.headline: Slings and arrows
fields.trailText: Charlotte Raven  is too pessimistic. When William Hague campaigned in Middle England Romsey, he ranted on about asylum seekers, scroungers and crime, Blair and Straw ran for cover, but Charles Kennedy told him in public he had dragged politics down to the gutter.
fields.body:
Charlotte Raven (G2, May 30) is too pessimistic. When William Hague campaigned in Middle England Romsey, he ranted on about asylum seekers, scroungers and crime, Blair and Straw ran for cover, but Charles Kennedy told him in public he had dragged politics down to the gutter. The good folk of Romsey indicated their agreement on May 4. Fortune favours the brave.
Dennis Outwin
Great Yarmouth, Norfolk enout@waitrose.com

No wonder David Willetts has launched his own "Help the Aged" campaign (Tories woo elderly, May 29). Go round any Tory club and you'll see those are the only supporters his party has got left.
Barry Jackett
Lymington, Hants

Re Nicholas Lezard's review of Jonathan Green's dictionary of slang (Saturday Review, May 27) and the etymology of Caledonia, "a black term for socially ambitious black woman". Try Caledonia by Louis Jordan: "Caledonia, Caledonia, what makes your big head so hot?"
Sue Bywater
Malton, N Yorks

Jim Burfield (Letters, May 31) and the Women's Institute miss the most obvious interpretation of verse two of Jerusalem: it is all about sex. The football crowds should like it, though.
John Horsley
Cottingham, Humberside jh@jillywoods.karoo.co.uk

Re Gay pride takes a knock from mayor of Rome (May 31): "...gays dressed as priests and nuns, frolicking in St Peter's Square". No change there then.
Richard Bliss
Newcastle upon Tyne

As Woody Allen pointed out: Harvard is not that good anyway (Letters, May 30) - they let Kissinger teach there.
Terry Hyde
Edinburgh delooy@waitrose.com

webTitle: Maths test does not add up, say students

fields.headline: Maths test does not add up, say students
fields.trailText: Trainee teachers are threatening to boycott a new compulsory mathematics test which is being taken for the first time today, claiming they were not told about it when they signed up for their courses.
fields.body:
Trainee teachers are threatening to boycott a new compulsory mathematics test which is being taken for the first time today, claiming they were not told about it when they signed up for their courses.

The test, comprising 12 mental arithmetic and 16 written questions, is the first of three national skills tests being introduced by the teacher training agency to ensure teachers are numerate, literate and competent in information and communications technology.

From next year, trainees must pass all three tests before being allowed to practise as teachers. The numeracy test, which has been pitched midway between GCSE and A-level maths, is being introduced a year early.

But student unions, which have balloted on the issue, have warned that members will refuse to sit the first tests today because the government has "moved the goalposts".

The National Union of Students is pursuing a legal challenge to see whether the government can be forced to withdraw the test.

About 25,500 trainees taking the post-graduate certificate in education or in the final year of a bachelor of education course, should take the numeracy test today.

Pav Akhtar, education officer of the Homerton Union of Students at Cambridge, said 95% of students backed a boycott of the numeracy test. He admitted that many students were likely to take the test at the second opportunity at the end of July.

Frankie Sulke, of the teacher training agency, said: "Full details of all the tests were included in the green paper in November 1998 and all teacher training providers were informed the following June."

webTitle: Big shake-up proposed in Scottish education

fields.headline: Big shake-up proposed in Scottish education
fields.trailText: An independent inquiry has recommended the biggest shake-up in Scottish education for a generation, with sweeping changes to the way teachers work and big salary increases.
fields.body:
An independent inquiry has recommended the biggest shake-up in Scottish education for a generation, with sweeping changes to the way teachers work and big salary increases.

The McCrone inquiry, set up by the Scottish executive last year after teachers threatened to strike over pay, calls for across-the-board pay rises of up to 15%; a twin-track career structure with "chartered" teachers earning the highest amounts; a longer working year; and new dismissal procedures for incapable teachers. The package could cost more than £200m a year to implement.

Teachers' unions yesterday welcomed the financial aspects of the plan, but said there were concerns that they will have less control over their working day.

Sam Galbraith, the education minister who ordered the inquiry, said the executive would study the results before deciding on a course of action.

Gavin McCrone, who headed the inquiry, said the recommendations should be regarded as a package and not cherry picked.

Under his proposals, top classroom performers would become "chartered" teachers, earning up to £35,000 a year; and a new starting salary would be set at £17,000.

Teachers would be expected to give up five days of their holidays for training.

There will now be a consultation process on the findings.

webTitle: More Matthew, less Melvyn for ITV as public service role is questioned

fields.headline: More Matthew, less Melvyn for ITV as public service role is questioned
fields.standfirst: Regulators ready to review channel's obligations as number of rivals grows
fields.trailText: The prospect of Melvyn Bragg appearing on Celebrity Stars in their Eyes is an enticing one, and if television regulators get their way, the doyen of ITV's arts programmes may be forced to consider alternative career moves. As the television landscape evolves, the Reithian definition of public service broadcasting - inform, educate, entertain - is being updated.
fields.body:
The prospect of Melvyn Bragg appearing on Celebrity Stars in their Eyes is an enticing one, and if television regulators get their way, the doyen of ITV's arts programmes may be forced to consider alternative career moves. As the television landscape evolves, the Reithian definition of public service broadcasting - inform, educate, entertain - is being updated.

In a consultation paper published yesterday, the independent television commission (ITC) suggests the network should not be forced to provide expensive and often unpopular "public service" programmes if it is to compete effectively with the specialist channels invading the traditional channels' public service heartlands.

The proposals came only a week after the commission had issued a scathing attack on ITV's arts policy, when it called for a complete rethink. But as the digital television age advances, the ITC says its requirements to show factual, arts, drama and other specialised programmes may become overburdening and should be scaled back, or even abolished. Channel 5's similar - although less onerous - obligations may also have to go. But Channel 4 and the BBC should continue to have a strong public service remit, it says.

The ITC's chairman, Sir Robin Biggam, said: "The broadcasting environment is now changing rapidly so we need to reassess and redefine public service broadcasting in the multi-channel digital world. It is clear that public service broadcasting provided by the free-to-air broadcasters will be a cornerstone of future regulation, so it is important to define its role in the developing multi-channel environment."

In its paper, the commission said that, in the short term, ITV should not be stripped of its principal public service obligations, because of the pressure it would exert on the BBC. As a deregulated ITV chased higher peak-time ratings and advertising revenue, the BBC would be tempted to do the same.

But after the analogue signal is switched off, when most homes in Britain have converted to digital television, the position will have changed significantly, the commission suggests.

"ITV's ability to deliver public service broadcasting in the longer term, well beyond digital switchover, can not be guaranteed. If its market position erodes significantly, ITV's commitment to fund the less popular programmes in the public service broadcasting mix may diminish and some support from other sources may be necessary," it says in the consultation paper.

Already, channels such as Discovery, the History Channel and National Geographic are providing specialised services; impartial news is provided by several broadcasters on dedicated channels; while the Cartoon Network and Nickelodeon provide children's programmes. Artsworld, a new arts channel, is about to be launched with investment from the Guardian Media Group and others.

ITV's obligation to provide distinctive regional programmes will be the subject of a separate consultation paper, to be published next week.

The commission stresses that Channel 4 should remain in the public sector: privatisation, favoured by the Treasury, would place severe pressure on the broadcaster's "ethos, breadth and individuality".

In the medium term, while most viewers continue to tune in to the five main channels, regulation should be simplified but not swept away altogether, the commission stresses. But it adds: "Looking further ahead, more significant changes are likely to be appropriate, involving the reduction and perhaps ultimately the abolition of public service broadcasting regulation as we see it today."

The commission is inviting views before it formulates a final position. The government is preparing a communications white paper, to be published this year, to form the basis of wide-ranging legislation.

Ruling the air waves, or waiving the air rules?

BBC

According to its charter, the BBC must provide a "properly balanced service consisting of a wide range of subject matter" and "serve the tastes and needs of different audiences". Standards must be high, "in particular in respect of their content, quality and editorial integrity". Television and radio services must be provided "as a public service for disseminating information, education and entertainment". There are specific requirements relating to cultural programmes, news and current affairs, sport, education, programmes for children and young people, regional programmes and coverage of parliament.

ITV

Diversity

Licensees must provide a service covering nine programme strands: drama, entertainment, sport, news, factual, education, religion, arts and children's programmes.

Minimum requirements

Licensees must provide one hour 30 minutes a week of current affairs, 10 hours of children's programmes, two hours of religious output. Quotas for regional programming vary from 2 hours 30 minutes to 14 hours 30 minutes, depending on the region.

News

Regional licensees must take national and international news from a nominated news provider (currently ITN) and broadcast it live and simultaneously across the network. They must broadcast bulletins in peak time.

Origin and quality of programmes

65% of programmes must be originally produced or commissioned, and a majority of transmissions, except news, sports events, games, advertising and teletext, must be of European origin. At least 25% must be from independent production companies. There is a general requirement for high-quality programmes.

Channel 4

The 1990 Broadcasting Act requires the channel to be a "public service for disseminating information, education and entertainment". Programmes must be of a high standard and wide-ranging, and the channel must be distinctive. Programmes must contain "a suitable proportion of matter calculated to appeal to tastes and interests not generally catered for by Channel 3", and must be innovative and experimental. There is a requirement to provide educational programmes and high-quality news and current affairs.

S4C

The 1990 act provides for S4C as a public service channel in Wales. A "substantial proportion" of the output must be in Welsh, and programmes broadcast between 6.30pm and 10pm must consist mainly of programmes in Welsh. These must be wide-ranging and of a high standard.

Channel 5

Most obligations are similar to those for ITV, but Channel 5 does not have to provide regional programmes or take its news from ITN. There are quotas (lower than those for ITV) for current affairs, religious and children's programmes. It does not have to provide programmes in other categories.

These must be wide-ranging and of a high standard. Channel 5 Most obligations are similar to those for ITV, but Channel 5 does not have to provide regional programmes or take its news from ITN. There are quotas (lower than those for ITV) for current affairs, religious and children's programmes. It does not have to provide programmes in other categories.

webTitle: Ethiopia says war with Eritrea is over

fields.headline: Ethiopia says war with Eritrea is over
fields.standfirst: Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Ethiopia yesterday declared that it considers its two-year-old border war with Eritrea to be over after retaking all the land it had claimed in a punishing 19-day offensive.
fields.body:
Ethiopia yesterday declared that it considers its two-year-old border war with Eritrea to be over after retaking all the land it had claimed in a punishing 19-day offensive.

Eritrea has protested that the war can end only when Ethiopia returns all undisputed Eritrean soil seized in the offensive. But with Ethiopia having pledged to do that, an end to the war between two of the world's poorest countries is in sight.

"Ethiopia has liberated all its territory, and considers the war over," said Selome Taddesse, the government spokeswoman.

The announcement came on the second day of peace talks in Algiers - based on a deal that both countries agreed to but have not reached accord on implementing. A key sticking point was the timing of withdrawals from occupied land. With Ethiopia satisfied that it has retrieved all its territory, that point was overtaken.

But the Eritrean presidential spokesman, Yemane Gebremeskel said: "They can't say the war is over when they still occupy Eritrean territory. Ethiopia has to withdraw to all pre-May 6 1998 [the date the war began] positions." AP

webTitle: Demands grow as Fiji coup leader gains in confidence

fields.headline: Demands grow as Fiji coup leader gains in confidence
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: The Fijian rebel leader, George Speight, issued a fresh set of demands yesterday after snubbing the military regime's compromise candidate for the premiership.
fields.body:
The Fijian rebel leader, George Speight, issued a fresh set of demands yesterday after snubbing the military regime's compromise candidate for the premiership.

Mr Speight, who led a coup on May 19 aimed at toppling the government of the ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, appeared to be growing in confidence after all his earlier demands were met. Ominously, he said that he would keep the hostages - thought to number about 30 - held in parliament for "as long as is necessary".

Instead of releasing the captives as the military hoped, Mr Speight demanded further concessions - primarily more places for his followers in the new government. He will press his case in talks with the military, set to resume today.

Police and soldiers did little yesterday to stop armed supporters of Mr Speight as they stoned cars and beat their drivers outside parliament in the capital, Suva. The violence was focused on members of the ethnic Indian population.

Mr Speight's media adviser, Jo Nata, said the rebels wanted a role in the new interim government "in order to steer Fiji in the direction of indigenous Fijian supremacy".

The army commander, Commodore Frank Bainimarama, who declared martial law on Monday, has offered concessions aimed at trying to secure the release of the hostages, who include Mr Chaudhry.

On Tuesday, the commodore put forward a former army commander, Ratu Epeli Nailatikau, an ethnic Fijian, as interim prime minister. But Mr Speight unexpectedly blocked the appointment.

Commodore Bainimarama appealed for the release of the hostages, saying there was no longer any need to hold members of the old government.

"They are no longer the government. We are the government," he said. "We want to ensure that those people are given their freedom to go back to their homes to see their families."

The commodore promised not to use force to end the crisis, and said dialogue was continuing with the rebels, but "it seems that Speight is avoiding the issue of hostages".

He said the rebels would get an amnesty provided the hostages were freed and all guns returned. The only exception would be the person who killed a police officer.

Western diplomats hope the commodore will hand back power to the legitimate government if he secures the hostages' release. But his comments yesterday - that it was prudent to hold power until a new constitution had been put in place and an election held - raised questions about the military's long-term intentions.

A military spokesman, Lieutenant-Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini, said that even when the hostage crisis is over, military leaders might have to consider what to do about forming a government.

"We may run a much more efficient administration with the military," he said.

After a meeting with the military yesterday, Mr Speight expressed unhappiness at the prospect of prolonged military rule: "It is unacceptable. We are going down a path not in the best interests of what we want to fulfil."

Sources in Suva said Mr Speight had accepted four nominees in the new government, but was pressing for inclusion of about six of his own choices.

webTitle: Gay pair plan a third baby

fields.headline: Gay pair plan a third baby
fields.trailText: Britain's first gay couple to father surrogate children are planning to have another child, they announced last night.
fields.body:
Britain's first gay couple to father surrogate children are planning to have another child, they announced last night.

Millionaires Tony Barlow, 35, and Barrie Drewitt, 31, met an American woman last week who has agreed to carry their next baby.

The couple flew the unnamed Californian woman, her husband and her children, on a secret week-long holiday in Tunisia, to meet her and discuss the surrogacy.

Last night, Mr Drewitt, who, with his partner, caused controversy last year by paying £200,000 to an American surrogate mother, said: "It was wonderful. We had interviewed several candidates but this woman stood out. We got on like a house on fire."

Mr Drewitt, now one of the two proud fathers of five-month-old twins, Aspen and Saffron, continued: "We are determined to go for a family of three children."

The couple will use some of the 24 embryos they had frozen before their twins' birth, which were formed with eggs donated by a married Los Angeles secretary and sperm from the two men.

"The new baby will be a biological brother or sister to Aspen and Saffron," said Mr Drewitt.

The couple, originally from Manchester, but now living near Chelmsford, Essex, hope to transfer the cells to the new surrogate mother in November after she has completed a course of drugs.

The couple, who in the first instance turned to a Californian surrogate mother, Rosalind Bellamy, 33, after being turned down by British adoption agencies, faced not being able to bring up their children, born in Los Angeles, in Britain.

The Home Office initially refused the babies entry, but in January, Jack Straw, home secretary, allowed them to remain indefinitely in the UK.

webTitle: Clinton agrees to share new star wars technology

fields.headline: Clinton agrees to share new star wars technology
fields.standfirst: US will offer Russia secrets of missile defence system
fields.trailText: The United States is willing to share technology for missile defence with other "civilised nations", Bill Clinton promised worried Europeans yesterday.
fields.body:
The United States is willing to share technology for missile defence with other "civilised nations", Bill Clinton promised worried Europeans yesterday.

Speaking during the US-European Union summit in Portugal, Mr Clinton confirmed that he would offer American know-how to Russia in order to defuse its opposition to the controversial missile defence system, nicknamed "son of star wars".

Mr Clinton goes to Moscow on Saturday for his first face-to-face meeting with President Vladimir Putin, who is concerned about US plans to amend a key cold war arms control treaty to permit the construction of the system.

European leaders oppose the multi-billion dollar project on the grounds that it could divide Nato as well as spark a new arms race which would prompt Russia and China to bolster their nuclear arsenals. However, European objections have so far been muted.

Mr Clinton is to decide before the November elections whether to deploy the missile shield, intended to protect the US against "rogue" states like Iraq and North Korea, after tests due in July.

"I don't think we could advance the notion that we had this technology designed to protect us against a new threat, a threat which was also a threat to other civilised nations who might or might not be nuclear powers and not make it available to them," President Clinton said.

Portugal's prime minister, Antonio Guterres, who is currently chairman of the EU's rotating presidency, said that any move to strengthen the security of Europe "must be as comprehensive as possible".

Romano Prodi, president of the European commission, said: "We decided that megaphone diplomacy would be replaced by telephone diplomacy. That is more constructive, even if less sexy."

President Clinton said he was satisfied with progress made in Europe since he was elected president in 1992, shortly after the breakup of the Soviet empire.

"Many were predicting Europe's new democracies would falter, that Russia would turn inward," he said. "Europe's new democracies are joining the transatlantic mainstream ... we have persevered and strengthened Nato."

Little progress was reported at the one-day summit outside Lisbon on trade disputes over US tax breaks for exporters, European banana imports, and a European ban on imports of hormone-treated US beef. But the two trading blocs, the world's largest, agreed to establish a scientific panel to review biotechnology issues, including genetically modified food, which are already under discussion in the wider forum of the G8 group of industrialised countries.

The EU's foreign policy supremo, Javier Solana, said he did not expect these issues to weaken other aspects of the US-EU relationship.

On Monday Washington threatened to retaliate against EU exports after Brussels rejected US revisions to the so-called foreign sales corporation programme, aimed at bringing the US into line with World Trade Organisation rules.

The row centres on a 15% tax break for US exporters that is worth $3.5bn a year and benefits giants including Boeing, General Motors and Microsoft.

The US and the EU are already at odds over European government aid for the Airbus consortium and a new EU aircraft noise law which discriminates against US manufacturers, Washington claims.

fields.headline: Message in a bottle
fields.standfirst: At 19 he was a star, touted for the poetry chair at Oxford. At 20 he was burned out and unable to find a publisher. Last month Barry MacSweeney finally succumbed to the alcoholism that dominated his life and work. His schoolmate Gordon Burn traces his rapid rise and long fall
fields.trailText: At 19 he was a star, touted for the poetry chair at Oxford. At 20 he was burned out and unable to find a publisher. Last month Barry MacSweeney finally succumbed to the alcoholism that dominated his life and work. His schoolmate Gordon Burn traces his rapid rise and long fall.
fields.body:
He was a mod. That much I can say for sure. Four-button Madras jackets, buttoned high; Ben Sherman shirts, Sta-Prest parallel trousers that in Newcastle at that time were known as "parallels" or "strides". There was a vogue for wearing desert boots that started around 1963 or 1964, and a way of walking that involved spinning an invisible stone away with the outside of the left foot, and then the right. The left foot and then the right. A hunched-shouldered, duck-toed walk that seemed to come naturally to the footballers at the school. Was MacSweeney a footballer? I don't remember. He was an athlete, though; a runner. Long-legged. Clean limbed. Not poet material at all. (Not even a poet of the cool school, supposing we had known what that was.)

He had the walk: head down, toes in, haversack slung by a single strap over one shoulder, school tie tied at the skinny end to make a hard, nut-sized knot. He was a face. He had that hair. The boy/girl hair, parted in the middle, fading into bum-fluff at the ears and whisked up into a small bit of baloney at the back - back-combed into a high tuft or boll at the crown. He was sweet-faced. A true androgyne. And very sweet-natured. Cherubic, you would have to say, even allowing for the protuberant jug ears. Sweeno. He was a shy boy, as I remember him; neat and clean, with deep dimples when he smiled and a strawberry flush that constantly threatened to turn into a scalding, full-blown blush. Maybe that's why he started drinking. In his autobiographical Vietnam novel, The Things They Carried, Tim O'Brien claims that it wasn't being caught in crossfire or napalmed or blown apart that the "grunts" on the ground were most afraid of; what they were most afraid of was turning red in front of the other men in their company; they were scared of blushing.

The blurb for Barry MacSweeney's last collection, The Book of Demons, an account of how the demon drink chased and harried and finally (of course) caught him, says MacSweeney was an alcoholic from the age of 16. Many people doubt it. I doubt it. I knew him when he was 16. Not well (not at all, it now seems). I knew him when he was 17 and 18. But his first wife believes he was an alcoholic when she married him in 1968, when he was still only 20. Three years earlier, in a poem collected in his first book, The Boy From the Green Cabaret Tells of His Mother, he had written about "looking for these dark bottles/over the pelmet under the stairs/these green bottles in roomcorners/in the loft these peculiar places". A precocious premonition that his destiny was to be a plonkie.

MacSweeney wrote the cover copy for his last book himself: "Barry MacSweeney wrote his first poem at the age of seven and has been an alcoholic since he was 16 . . . His solitary hard drinking almost killed him, and after a series of life-threatening fits and convulsions, which ended with him on a life-support machine, he underwent rehabilitation through detoxification in several hospitals and an addiction clinic. He has now recovered." He wrote this in what was most likely a state of semi-stupor, the state in which he spent most of the last years of his life, still married to the sense of romantic mystery which allied him with the roster of flame-outs and fuck-ups and holy losers he had been fixated on from his youth.

"His notion of the artist was formed around a myth of exemplary failure and belated recognition," one of MacSweeney's obituarists, Andrew Crozier, wrote two weeks ago in the Guardian. "Rimbaud was an early model for this, others included Chatterton, Shelley, Van Gogh, Jim Morrison and Robert Johnson." A poet and literary academic, Crozier had known MacSweeney for 35 years. He first met him in a pub after a poetry reading in 1964 and remembers him as a moddy boy - a super-mod - carrying a biography of Van Gogh. "All that's missing is the parka," Crozier told MacSweeney, who was only trying to get a bit of bohemianism into his life. He reacted badly. Maybe that's why he started drinking.

He became a little bit beardy. Bushy sideboards and that sort of thing. Kind of wild hair. Big mutton-chop whiskers. But still a long way from what they used to call a beardy-weirdy. There used to be an expression used in the north-east: a face that looked like somebody had chopped sticks on it. Not Barry's face. Not Barry's face then, and - according to those who knew him, and in spite of taking up residence on "Cirrhosis Street, Wrecked Head Road", "living daily rim to mouth" - not Barry's face when he died. It's a long trip from "angel boyhood", as MacSweeney himself acknowledged, "to scarred bottledom". Yet, on the evidence of his friends, he remained - outwardly - remarkably unravaged, almost right up to the end.

His dapperness, it seems, never left him; his keen fastidiousness and his sense of style. Just before he published The Book of Demons in 1997, he tracked down a whisker on the map called Demon's Beck in Northumberland. He was living alone and in considerable squalor by this time, in a mess of bottles and takeaway cartons, usually nursing whatever injury had been caused by his latest fall. He had nasty falls. Toward the end he broke a lot of bones. Knee, ankle, shoulder, ribs - the final year he was seen by eight different hospitals for drink-related accidents. But one of the last pictures shows him in a long, dark overcoat over a black silk mohair suit, wearing a pair of shined-up black Florsheim shoes by the Beck, which turns out to be a rubble-clogged semi-sewer. "Lurking inside the shy Barry was another Barry," Jackie Litherland, his partner through the final years, says. "This was Barry the dandy. He had at least two people in his personality. He would retreat for weeks to what he called his "ravaged corner". His lair. It was like a den. A drinking den, really. But he was also a great dandy. Shoes immaculate, tie perfect, suit draped. He had a lot of style."

MacSweeney and I both had interviews with Thomson Newspapers in Newcastle when we were 16. I went back to school to do A-levels; he left to become a cub reporter on the Evening Chronicle. It was a move which, as luck would have it, brought him into everyday contact with a grizzled greybeard who had counted Ford Madox Ford, WB Yeats and Ezra Pound among his friends. By the early 60s, Basil Bunting had been working in obscurity as a subeditor on the Newcastle Chronicle for several years. His responsibilities included the daily tide table and the City column. Bunting was as old as the century, and his serious writing life seemed to be behind him in 1964. In fact, his reputation as England's major modernist poet was about to be revived by an 18-year-old self-confessed "work conchy" (conscientious objector) and "dole walla" called Tom Pickard, who had just rented a tower on the old city walls from Newcastle Corporation for 10 shillings a week and, with his wife Connie, was about to transform the cultural life of a region.

It is impossible to overstate the impact the Mordern Tower had on me as a booksniff sixth-former, and presumably on MacSweeney, who I regularly saw there as an aspiring poet. The beats came and things occasionally got riotous and dope was smoked. Instead of the usual adolescent maunderings and set texts, at Mordern Tower we were exposed to mad riffers and homosexuals and junkies; to Ed Dorn, Robert Creeley and Alex Trochhi; to Ferlinghetti, Gregory Corso, Ginsberg and other speakers of scary stuff we'd never heard before. Stuff that didn't scan or rhyme or do any of the things that our teachers at the grammar school told us it was meant to do. "Free verse", its visionary exaggerations jiving with a darkly "beat" personal style. It was for: the expression of immediate feeling and "visible truth"; the internal logic of sounds rather than imposed sense (letting it all hang out). It was against: careful, complex, ironic and well-finished work; the anecdotal and the small scale. I bought the donkey jacket; I wore the beard. But in MacSweeney's case, it changed his life. The isolation, the rejection, the gut-spilling, the torment and despair. He went the whole way.

The next time I saw him was in Hudson's student bookshop in Gosta Green in Birmingham. He was staring out at me from the vaguely psychedelic front cover of The Boy From The Green Cabaret Tells of His Mother, his first book. It was 1968 and he was 19 and a celebrity by virtue of having been put up for Oxford University's chair of poetry by his publisher. It was a scam, of course. A publicity stunt. But it was a less celebrity-fixated culture then, and MacSweeney wasn't wise to the ways of the world, and didn't see the train until it hit him. He got burned.

"He felt ridiculed," Jackie Litherland says. "They trashed him. He was just a kid. He found it very difficult to get published after that. He was seen as a 60s fashion victim. The talent didn't diminish, but his manuscripts were rejected."

"As an economic activity, poetry is marginal," Andrew Crozier says, "just as is, for example, hill farming. No one wishes to admit this." MacSweeney was a burn-out at 20. Surplus to requirements; edged out, marginalised; exiled from the mainstream. As it happened, this turned out to be not such a lonely place to be. At Mordern Tower it had been MacSweeney's good fortune to make the acquaintance of the Cambridge don and poet JH (Jeremy) Prynne. It was Prynne's belief that, freed from a unitary, closed-system, "great-tradition" view of culture, the margin could legitimately be seen as the centre. He was the eminence grise of the so-called Cambridge school of writers, which included Andrew Crozier and Peter Riley and, more indirectly, Peter Ackroyd and Iain Sinclair. Prynne is famous for the bloody intractability of his work; for what has been called its "almost mythic quality of luminous opacity". And he became MacSweeney's mentor.

Encouraged by Prynne in the early 70s, MacSweeney published a small-press appreciation of Thomas Chatterton that retrospectively, and probably inevitably, seems shot through with prescience. "Thomas Chatterton, the English romantic poet, was born in Bristol on November 20 1752, and swallowed arsenic 18 years later in London - starved and unrecognised," is Elegy For January's opening sentence. Later, apropos of apparently nothing, MacSweeney writes: "I think of the motorcyclist who does not attempt to avoid the head-on crash, but accelerates into his death."

For the remaining 30 plus years of his life, MacSweeney disappeared into the alternative universe of the little magazines; of fugitive publications and samizdat editions. He started a small imprint of his own, Blacksuede Boot Press, named for the Cuban-heeled boots Bob Dylan wore in the 60s. As a last resort, he would Roneo his poems and send them out to the hardcore of 20 people. "As long as they're out there. You always get the work out," he'd tell Jackie Litherland when she was having difficulty getting her own work published. More recently, he would hit the fax machine in the middle of the night, when he was on a bender and getting shitfaced and writing. His friend, Rick Caddel, co-director of the Basil Bunting poetry centre at the University of Durham, would arrive to find miles of fax paper being unravelled in the mornings by the secretaries. More of Barry's yes-I-am-drinking rants.

But did MacSweeney opt out of poetry's mainstream for ideological reasons, or was he shut out against his will, I wanted to know from Caddel when I went to see him. "There is a whole level of texts that define themselves by their unavailability," he said. "Editions of two or three-hundred or less. I think a lot of people prefer to be published this way. Certainly for Prynne for a long time it was an important point to control publication. Not to be seen to be in the same commodity market, as it were. Whether or not Barry deliberately chose to be published by the small presses, or whether he believed if he sent his work to Faber it would be rejected, I don't know. It is very dangerous to be part of that commoditised counter-culture, the way Tony Harrison is, say. I do know Barry agonised over sending The Book of Demons to Bloodaxe when the time came."

Ranter, MacSweeney's 1985 collection, had been turned down by Bloodaxe in Newcastle. He was devastated when The Tempers of Hazard, his selected poems, were pulped in the year of publication, after Rupert Murdoch acquired Paladin in 1993. He became reclusive and embittered. He disappeared into the bottle and lost his job as deputy editor of the Shields Gazette, where he had worked for eight years. It was around this time that his and Jackie Litherland's paths crossed again. They had originally met at National Union of Journalist conferences many years earlier when they were both attached to the NUJ. The person she encountered was not the Barry MacSweeney she remembered, but a shrinking, violently eczema'd figure, hiding under a baseball cap.

But he courted her, she says, "with a high style". When he was sober, they took trips to the country; he cooked, brewed exotic teas. When he was drinking, he disappeared to his lair in Newcastle and stayed there until he wanted to go sober again. It broke down into a pattern of roughly two months in each place. A dry period followed by the wet season. "I am the addict," as he wrote in one of his late poems, "strapping on his monumental thirst."

"The craving would return," Litherland says. "He'd become very violent. He had problems with anger. You can see it in the poems, which range from the most innocent things in his nature, right across to the most dark. But almost malicious. He'd reach a crescendo of craving. And then he'd just . . . do it."

MacSweeney had been in and out of hospitals and detox clinics for more than a year when, visiting him at his semi in Newcastle in June 1995, Litherland was witness to a catastrophic event. MacSweeney suffered a fit or convulsion in the course of which his head swelled terrifyingly and he vomited black foam and gouts of black blood. It is a full-on rant through the language and, according to one witness, he was "completely transformed" when he performed these accounts of bodily trauma and pathetic abjection and breaking his head.

Instead of being equal parts sober and blotto, the drinking binges started to extend until they entirely consumed MacSweeney's life. He started hallucinating wildly. He broke an ankle; a shoulder. fields.bodyText: He was a mod. That much I can say for sure. Four-button Madras jackets, buttoned high; Ben Sherman shirts, Sta-Prest parallel trousers that in Newcastle at that time were known as "parallels" or "strides". There was a vogue for wearing desert boots that started around 1963 or 1964, and a way of walking that involved spinning an invisible stone away with the outside of the left foot, and then the right. The left foot and then the right. A hunched-shouldered, duck-toed walk that seemed to come naturally to the footballers at the school. Was MacSweeney a footballer? I don't remember. He was an athlete, though; a runner. Long-legged. Clean limbed. Not poet material at all. (Not even a poet of the cool school, supposing we had known what that was.) He had the walk: head down, toes in, haversack slung by a single strap over one shoulder, school tie tied at the skinny end to make a hard, nut-sized knot. He was a face. He had that hair. The boy/girl hair, parted in the middle, fading into bum-fluff at the ears and whisked up into a small bit of baloney at the back - back-combed into a high tuft or boll at the crown. He was sweet-faced. A true androgyne. And very sweet-natured. Cherubic, you would have to say, even allowing for the protuberant jug ears. Sweeno. He was a shy boy, as I remember him; neat and clean, with deep dimples when he smiled and a strawberry flush that constantly threatened to turn into a scalding, full-blown blush. Maybe that's why he started drinking. In his autobiographical Vietnam novel, The Things They Carried, Tim O'Brien claims that it wasn't being caught in crossfire or napalmed or blown apart that the "grunts" on the ground were most afraid of; what they were most afraid of was turning red in front of the other men in their company; they were scared of blushing. The blurb for Barry MacSweeney's last collection, The Book of Demons, an account of how the demon drink chased and harried and finally (of course) caught him, says MacSweeney was an alcoholic from the age of 16. Many people doubt it. I doubt it. I knew him when he was 16. Not well (not at all, it now seems). I knew him when he was 17 and 18. But his first wife believes he was an alcoholic when she married him in 1968, when he was still only 20. Three years earlier, in a poem collected in his first book, The Boy From the Green Cabaret Tells of His Mother, he had written about "looking for these dark bottles/over the pelmet under the stairs/these green bottles in roomcorners/in the loft these peculiar places". A precocious premonition that his destiny was to be a plonkie. MacSweeney wrote the cover copy for his last book himself: "Barry MacSweeney wrote his first poem at the age of seven and has been an alcoholic since he was 16 . . . His solitary hard drinking almost killed him, and after a series of life-threatening fits and convulsions, which ended with him on a life-support machine, he underwent rehabilitation through detoxification in several hospitals and an addiction clinic. He has now recovered." He wrote this in what was most likely a state of semi-stupor, the state in which he spent most of the last years of his life, still married to the sense of romantic mystery which allied him with the roster of flame-outs and fuck-ups and holy losers he had been fixated on from his youth. "His notion of the artist was formed around a myth of exemplary failure and belated recognition," one of MacSweeney's obituarists, Andrew Crozier, wrote two weeks ago in the Guardian. "Rimbaud was an early model for this, others included Chatterton, Shelley, Van Gogh, Jim Morrison and Robert Johnson." A poet and literary academic, Crozier had known MacSweeney for 35 years. He first met him in a pub after a poetry reading in 1964 and remembers him as a moddy boy - a super-mod - carrying a biography of Van Gogh. "All that's missing is the parka," Crozier told MacSweeney, who was only trying to get a bit of bohemianism into his life. He reacted badly. Maybe that's why he started drinking. He became a little bit beardy. Bushy sideboards and that sort of thing. Kind of wild hair. Big mutton-chop whiskers. But still a long way from what they used to call a beardy-weirdy. There used to be an expression used in the north-east: a face that looked like somebody had chopped sticks on it. Not Barry's face. Not Barry's face then, and - according to those who knew him, and in spite of taking up residence on "Cirrhosis Street, Wrecked Head Road", "living daily rim to mouth" - not Barry's face when he died. It's a long trip from "angel boyhood", as MacSweeney himself acknowledged, "to scarred bottledom". Yet, on the evidence of his friends, he remained - outwardly - remarkably unravaged, almost right up to the end. His dapperness, it seems, never left him; his keen fastidiousness and his sense of style. Just before he published The Book of Demons in 1997, he tracked down a whisker on the map called Demon's Beck in Northumberland. He was living alone and in considerable squalor by this time, in a mess of bottles and takeaway cartons, usually nursing whatever injury had been caused by his latest fall. He had nasty falls. Toward the end he broke a lot of bones. Knee, ankle, shoulder, ribs - the final year he was seen by eight different hospitals for drink-related accidents. But one of the last pictures shows him in a long, dark overcoat over a black silk mohair suit, wearing a pair of shined-up black Florsheim shoes by the Beck, which turns out to be a rubble-clogged semi-sewer. "Lurking inside the shy Barry was another Barry," Jackie Litherland, his partner through the final years, says. "This was Barry the dandy. He had at least two people in his personality. He would retreat for weeks to what he called his "ravaged corner". His lair. It was like a den. A drinking den, really. But he was also a great dandy. Shoes immaculate, tie perfect, suit draped. He had a lot of style." MacSweeney and I both had interviews with Thomson Newspapers in Newcastle when we were 16. I went back to school to do A-levels; he left to become a cub reporter on the Evening Chronicle. It was a move which, as luck would have it, brought him into everyday contact with a grizzled greybeard who had counted Ford Madox Ford, WB Yeats and Ezra Pound among his friends. By the early 60s, Basil Bunting had been working in obscurity as a subeditor on the Newcastle Chronicle for several years. His responsibilities included the daily tide table and the City column. Bunting was as old as the century, and his serious writing life seemed to be behind him in 1964. In fact, his reputation as England's major modernist poet was about to be revived by an 18-year-old self-confessed "work conchy" (conscientious objector) and "dole walla" called Tom Pickard, who had just rented a tower on the old city walls from Newcastle Corporation for 10 shillings a week and, with his wife Connie, was about to transform the cultural life of a region. It is impossible to overstate the impact the Mordern Tower had on me as a booksniff sixth-former, and presumably on MacSweeney, who I regularly saw there as an aspiring poet. The beats came and things occasionally got riotous and dope was smoked. Instead of the usual adolescent maunderings and set texts, at Mordern Tower we were exposed to mad riffers and homosexuals and junkies; to Ed Dorn, Robert Creeley and Alex Trochhi; to Ferlinghetti, Gregory Corso, Ginsberg and other speakers of scary stuff we'd never heard before. Stuff that didn't scan or rhyme or do any of the things that our teachers at the grammar school told us it was meant to do. "Free verse", its visionary exaggerations jiving with a darkly "beat" personal style. It was for: the expression of immediate feeling and "visible truth"; the internal logic of sounds rather than imposed sense (letting it all hang out). It was against: careful, complex, ironic and well-finished work; the anecdotal and the small scale. I bought the donkey jacket; I wore the beard. But in MacSweeney's case, it changed his life. The isolation, the rejection, the gut-spilling, the torment and despair. He went the whole way. The next time I saw him was in Hudson's student bookshop in Gosta Green in Birmingham. He was staring out at me from the vaguely psychedelic front cover of The Boy From The Green Cabaret Tells of His Mother, his first book. It was 1968 and he was 19 and a celebrity by virtue of having been put up for Oxford University's chair of poetry by his publisher. It was a scam, of course. A publicity stunt. But it was a less celebrity-fixated culture then, and MacSweeney wasn't wise to the ways of the world, and didn't see the train until it hit him. He got burned. "He felt ridiculed," Jackie Litherland says. "They trashed him. He was just a kid. He found it very difficult to get published after that. He was seen as a 60s fashion victim. No one wishes to admit this." MacSweeney was a burn-out at 20. Surplus to requirements; edged out, marginalised; exiled from the mainstream. As it happened, this turned out to be not such a lonely place to be. At Mordern Tower it had been MacSweeney's good fortune to make the acquaintance of the Cambridge don and poet JH (Jeremy) Prynne. It was Prynne's belief that, freed from a unitary, closed-system, "great-tradition" view of culture, the margin could legitimately be seen as the centre. He was the eminence grise of the so-called Cambridge school of writers, which included Andrew Crozier and Peter Riley and, more indirectly, Peter Ackroyd and Iain Sinclair. Prynne is famous for the bloody intractability of his work; for what has been called its "almost mythic quality of luminous opacity". And he became MacSweeney's mentor. Encouraged by Prynne in the early 70s, MacSweeney published a small-press appreciation of Thomas Chatterton that retrospectively, and probably inevitably, seems shot through with prescience. "Thomas Chatterton, the English romantic poet, was born in Bristol on November 20 1752, and swallowed arsenic 18 years later in London - starved and unrecognised," is Elegy For January's opening sentence. Later, apropos of apparently nothing, MacSweeney writes: "I think of the motorcyclist who does not attempt to avoid the head-on crash, but accelerates into his death." For the remaining 30 plus years of his life, MacSweeney disappeared into the alternative universe of the little magazines; of fugitive publications and samizdat editions. He started a small imprint of his own, Blacksuede Boot Press, named for the Cuban-heeled boots Bob Dylan wore in the 60s. As a last resort, he would Roneo his poems and send them out to the hardcore of 20 people. "As long as they're out there. You always get the work out," he'd tell Jackie Litherland when she was having difficulty getting her own work published. More recently, he would hit the fax machine in the middle of the night, when he was on a bender and getting shitfaced and writing. His friend, Rick Caddel, co-director of the Basil Bunting poetry centre at the University of Durham, would arrive to find miles of fax paper being unravelled in the mornings by the secretaries. More of Barry's yes-I-am-drinking rants. But did MacSweeney opt out of poetry's mainstream for ideological reasons, or was he shut out against his will, I wanted to know from Caddel when I went to see him. "There is a whole level of texts that define themselves by their unavailability," he said. "Editions of two or three-hundred or less. I think a lot of people prefer to be published this way. Certainly for Prynne for a long time it was an important point to control publication. Not to be seen to be in the same commodity market, as it were. Whether or not Barry deliberately chose to be published by the small presses, or whether he believed if he sent his work to Faber it would be rejected, I don't know. It is very dangerous to be part of that commoditised counter-culture, the way Tony Harrison is, say. I do know Barry agonised over sending The Book of Demons to Bloodaxe when the time came." Ranter, MacSweeney's 1985 collection, had been turned down by Bloodaxe in Newcastle. He was devastated when The Tempers of Hazard, his selected poems, were pulped in the year of publication, after Rupert Murdoch acquired Paladin in 1993. He became reclusive and embittered. He disappeared into the bottle and lost his job as deputy editor of the Shields Gazette, where he had worked for eight years. They had originally met at National Union of Journalist conferences many years earlier when they were both attached to the NUJ. The person she encountered was not the Barry MacSweeney she remembered, but a shrinking, violently eczema'd figure, hiding under a baseball cap. But he courted her, she says, "with a high style". webTitle: Ill health makes Plaid leader quit

fields.headline: Ill health makes Plaid leader quit
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Colleagues and political opponents yesterday paid tribute to the Plaid Cymru leader Dafydd Wigley after he decided to stand down as president of the party he steered to stunning success in last year's national assembly elections in Wales.
fields.body:
Colleagues and political opponents yesterday paid tribute to the Plaid Cymru leader Dafydd Wigley after he decided to stand down as president of the party he steered to stunning success in last year's national assembly elections in Wales.

The long serving Caernarfon MP, who received treatment for a heart condition last Christmas, is giving up the post on medical advice.

He has also decided to step down as leader of the 17-strong group in the assembly where Plaid Cymru forms the main opposition to the minority Labour administration. He will remain in the post until the new party president has been elected in July.

Party members, who had hoped to persuade Mr Wigley to consider alternative ways of easing the burden on his health, accepted his decision reluctantly following an emotional meeting in Llandudno yesterday.

Mr Wigley, 57, was elected MP for Caernarfon in February 1974 and has been president of the party since 1991.

During his presidency the party's support at the polls has soared from 8% to 30% last May when Plaid Cymru snatched several traditional Labour heartland constituencies in the assembly elections.

Plaid Cymru chairman Marc Phillips said the party's debt to Mr Wigley was incalculable. He said there could scarcely be another party that had benefited as much from the vision and energy of one man.

Describing the Plaid Cymru leader as a politician for whom he had the utmost respect the first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, said Mr Wigley had made a major contribution to Welsh politics.

"I am sure he will continue to play a constructive part in the devolution story."

The former Welsh secretary, Ron Davies, who worked closely with Mr Wigley during the referendum campaign that led to devolution, said the Plaid Cymru leader had done much to bring status and credibility to the assembly.

"He brought a degree of authority to his group and led his party to a historic high water mark.

His contribution has been very significant. He is highly regarded in Wales and very well respected across the party politcal divide."

Nominations to replace Mr Wigley as president have to be submitted by June 30 and voting will take place on the basis of one member one vote at branch meetings between July 20 and 30.

Among the front runners to replace him will be Ieuan Wyn Jones the Ynys Mon MP who led Plaid Cymru in the assembly while Mr Wigley was convalescing after Christmas.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 There is more news from Edinburgh of my friend Andrew Neil, so busy lately overseeing the annihilation of that once fine newspaper, the Scotsman. Many have credited Andrew's success to a mixture of his looks and a privileged upbringing, but although there is something indelibly Brideshead about Andrew (the seventh generation of Neil to go Magdalen, Oxford), I tend to credit it to his old world courtesy and sweet nature. Last Friday, in a statement on the departure of editor Tim Luckhurst, who'd been ill with high blood pressure and stress, Andrew said: "Tim has seen the paper through some turbulent times and he leaves with my gratitude." How generous, especially as the previous day, meanwhile, the two were overheard chatting in a restaurant, La Bonne Auberge. "I've seen the consultants, and they're happy for me come back to work," Tim said. "No way," replied Andrew, still impersonating Gordon Gekko to this day, "I'm sorry, you're out." One waiter described the row that ensued as "a disgusting public spectacle". Well done, Andrew, you're doing wonderfully. Don't let it slip now.

 While nominations for Stupidest MP 2000 are considered, a contender steps forward for the lesser title of Dimmest Minister. He is Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary not known as the quickest Tornado in the hangar. Shortly before the election, Geoff produced some briefings for Mr Tony Blair, and eventually one reached Mr T with a long cover note explaining that because Geoff - who is very into computers - was staying with an elderly relative, he didn't not have access to his usual machine, and therefore this briefing was written in a different and inferior font. He was most sorry for the inconvenience. Durrrgh!

 Confusion enshrouds the ancestry of Sun football reporter Steven Howard, recently unveiled here as the son of the late Trevor Howard. We now suspect that this is cobblers, and that Steven is the nephew of the equally late and equally noble-seeming Leslie Howard (come to think of it, I'm convinced he's Andrew Neil's role model), whom Vivien Leigh unrequitedly loves in Gone With The Wind.

 What a relief, after such a long period in the Amis desert, to hear a reader's recollections about Kingsley near his death. While he was in a London hospital after injuring his back in a fall in 1995, patients in nearby rooms were touched by his plaintive wails of "Help, help, I'm being held here against my will!" One visitor passing his room was asked: "Hello, hello, do you speak English?" Yes, she said, I do. "Well," wheezed the novelist indicating his TV set, "can you tell me how to turn this on?" Patients who enjoyed seeing him wandering around in his pyjamas were sad to see him leave the hospital and die soon after of a stroke.

 The Sunday Times's A Life in the Day slot features the splendid Professor Stanley Unwin, inventor of the nonsense language Unwinese. After many years as John Prescott's chief speech writer, he wishes to earn some dosh. "Some well paid work would help with my fuel bills," says Stanley, 88, who says he has been in demand. It is a national scandal that such an enchanting comic talent should be ignored in this way, and we look forward to reporting that Countdown - a show the professor says he never misses - has signed him up for a stint in Dictionary Dell.

 Reports of Pokémon fever focus on a British child who had an arm broken in a playground fight, but emotions run high even in first world countries. "As the mother of a nine-year-old Pokémon fanatic and an 11-month-old baby, I enjoyed the brief item about the eight-year-old who wanted to trade his baby sister for a rare card," writes Linda Pasteuning of Rotterdam to Time magazine. "I read the article to my son, and his response was 'Which card?'"

After many years as John Prescott's chief speech writer, he wishes to earn some dosh. "Some well paid work would help with my fuel bills," says Stanley, 88, who says he has been in demand. It is a national scandal that such an enchanting comic talent should be ignored in this way, and we look forward to reporting that Countdown - a show the professor says he never misses - has signed him up for a stint in Dictionary Dell.  Reports of Pokémon fever focus on a British child who had an arm broken in a playground fight, but emotions run high even in first world countries. "As the mother of a nine-year-old Pokémon fanatic and an 11-month-old baby, I enjoyed the brief item about the eight-year-old who wanted to trade his baby sister for a rare card," writes Linda Pasteuning of Rotterdam to Time magazine. "I read the article to my son, and his response was 'Which card?'"

webTitle: Korean veteran's massacre claim proves false

fields.headline: Korean veteran's massacre claim proves false
fields.trailText: An American veteran of the Korean war, whose claim to have taken part in a massacre of civilians was central to a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigation, was exposed yesterday as a fantasist.
fields.body:
An American veteran of the Korean war, whose claim to have taken part in a massacre of civilians was central to a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigation, was exposed yesterday as a fantasist.

Edward Daily, who said he was a member of the historic 7th Cavalry, was actually a clerk and mechanic in another unit and nowhere near the scene when soldiers opened fire at No Gun Ri nearly 50 years ago.

"I have to agree with your records," said the 69-year-old when he was shown military papers indicating that he was miles away with the 27th Ordnance Maintenance Unit at the time. "I can't dispute them. I still feel as though I was at No Gun Ri. I did not intend to be deceptive."

Mr Daily's "eye-witness" account was one of the main sources for a Pulitzer Prize-winning Associated Press news agency report which was the first to show that Americans had taken part in the killings.

Recent reports have cast doubt on his credibility.

But the executive director of AP, Jonathan Wolman, said: "While we remain confident of the central findings of our coverage, AP is dismayed that Ed Daily cannot authenticate his account of the events at No Gun Ri."

Many other witnesses, including South Koreans, have confirmed that the massacre happened on July 26 1950, with estimates of the dead running from fewer than 50 to more than 300.

Mr Daily denies fabricating records but yesterday's New York Times reported that sources close to the United States army's investigation of the killings had obtained fake documents that undermined his claims - among them, that he had been awarded the Silver Cross for bravery.

The former steel worker had joined an association for winners of the Distinguished Service Cross which he never received and had shown friends a regimental group photograph in which his head appeared to have been superimposed on that of another man.

"I have the feeling now that Daily was a conman although I don't know why he was," William Hoffmann, a former 7th Cavalry platoon leader said. "How else could a nice guy who has been so strong in promoting the 7th Cavalry and organising reunions and coming to them and giving speeches do this? I'm still puzzled."

Some Korean war veterans say that they believed Mr Daily was at No Gun Ri because he had insinuated his way into their defective memories in telephone calls, at reunions and in bar room talk.

Richard Burns, a consultant for the book Stolen Valour: How the Vietnam Generation Was Robbed of Its Heroes and Its History, said more former soldiers were falsely claiming responsible for dishonourable behaviour.

"They do that because there is a movement in this country, the victim-hero thing. 'People will feel sorry for me that I killed children and women and they will understand me'," he said.

Jonas Rappeport, a retired forensic psychiatrist, said: "It is not uncommon when a serious murder occurs for a couple of folks to drop by and say 'I did it'. The purpose of this seems to be self-importance."

Mr Daily did not mention a massacre during more than 10 years of group therapy and his ex-wife said he never talked about the war. But then their marriage broke up, his work suffered and the conflict became the core of his life.

He is said to have told a 1986 reunion of veterans: "If you guys will get me stories, I'll put them together and we'll put them in a book."

Mr Daily, who appears to have been a conduit for stories about No Gun Ri rather than a witness, said: "I still remember it vividly. But they are saying I was with a different company. I've seen their documents. How do you deny that? I feel like I'm in a dream world."

webTitle: Fight to block Sinn Fein mayor of Belfast

fields.headline: Fight to block Sinn Fein mayor of Belfast
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A bitter wrangle is expected in Belfast tonight as Sinn Fein presses on with its audacious attempt to secure the post of lord mayor for the first time.
fields.body:
A bitter wrangle is expected in Belfast tonight as Sinn Fein presses on with its audacious attempt to secure the post of lord mayor for the first time.

It would be the only occasion Sinn Fein has held the top post in an Irish city since Terence MacSweeney, hero of the independence war, was elected first citizen in Cork in 1920. He was to die later that year in the city's jail after 74 days on hunger strike.

In Belfast last night, parties were working out tactics to stop republicans winning the race for the symbolic post. An insider said all bets were off.

It had been predicted Sinn Fein would slip home with the backing of the Alliance party. But an Alliance councillor quit over the party's planned support for republicans, and calculations are further muddied because of the illness of at least one nationalist councillor.

Parties in Belfast have previously operated an informal understanding, and, had that held, Sinn Fein could have expected to take the position this year. The incumbent is the Ulster Unionist Bob Stoker.

Tom Constantine, the former US drug enforcement chief, arrived in Belfast yesterday to take up his post as policing oversight commissioner, taking charge of implementing proposals for reforming the RUC for an initial three-year period.

The Democratic Unionist party yesterday unveiled its plan to frustrate the work of the reformed power-sharing executive. It aims to bring down the Good Friday agreement.

The DUP's Peter Robinson and Nigel Dodds return as minister for regional development and social development minister, but will refuse to sit in the government and will resign when the DUP fails in an attempt to have Sinn Fein thrown out of the executive.

But instead of allowing the posts to be filled by the pro-agreement Ulster Unionists and Alliance party, the DUP will rotate them through its assembly members.

webTitle: Jews set to elect woman leader

fields.headline: Jews set to elect woman leader
fields.standfirst:
Deputies could choose first female president in 240 years

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: For the first time in its 240 year history the Board of Deputies of British Jews - the Jewish lay representative body in Britain - is poised to elect a woman president next month.
fields.body:
For the first time in its 240 year history the Board of Deputies of British Jews - the Jewish lay representative body in Britain - is poised to elect a woman president next month.

Jo Wagerman, former head of the Jews' Free School, in north London, has emerged as the only candidate in what senior members of the Jewish community see as a long overdue move to modernise the board and help restore its credibility.

"If anyone can give the board greater respect and recognition, she can. She is a forceful personality, well known and recognisably not from the St John's Wood salon set. She could rescue the board from being a Marx Brothers outfit," said one source.

The board remains influential in representing the community to the government and defending its interests, but some Jews increasingly question its purpose and relevance.

Although women have been eligible to stand for election to the board since 1919 and a third of the 300 deputies, elected by synagogues and community organisations, are currently women, no female candidate has previously come close to heading the organisation.

Some sections of Orthodox Jewry still do not recognise women as capable of election to synagogue councils or of playing any significant role in the organisation.

Mrs Wagerman, 63, said: "The election of women has been effective in broadening the agenda of synagogues and making sure all the issues are addressed. We are losing young people.

"Young women see the Jewish community as being made up of old men defending their territory. You have young women working in finance houses in the City handling more money than the annual budgets of their synagogues but when they ask to help they are told they can make the tea."

As president, Mrs Wagerman - a teacher for 40 years, married to a dentist and living in Hendon, north-west London - will have to try to reconcile mutually suspicious and hostile strands of modern Jewry, increasingly divided over observance and policy.

Splits opened four years ago following chief rabbi Jonathan Sacks's failure to attend the funeral of the reform rabbi and Holocaust survivor Hugo Gryn and his description of the much-revered figure in a letter to Orthodox Jews as being "among those who destroy the faith". Liberal and reform synagogues have refused to recognise Dr Sacks's authority ever since.

"I think the Gryn affair was an explosion ready to happen. Every section of the community must demonstrate its respect for the beliefs of others. We may never be united but we have to learn to listen with courtesy to each other," she said.

Mrs Wagerman comes from a long established British Jewish family - her ancestors were named second in a 1656 petition to Oliver Cromwell to be allowed to settle in the country - but she had what she describes as an atypical Jewish upbringing, with a mother deeply hostile to the faith.

She was beaten up for being Jewish while an evacuee in East Anglia during the second world war and was later forced by her parents to leave school.

Mrs Wagerman said: "I hope people will say I have helped the community to work together and to be less concerned with its divisions."
