fields.headline: Review
fields.trailText: Agfa ePhoto CL18 camera
fields.body:
Small but snappy
Agfa ePhoto CL18 camera £99 plus VAT

Agfa's ePhoto CL18 - a palm-sized digital camera for snaps and videoconferencing - isn't exactly disposable. But at £99 plus VAT, it could reach a new market of people for whom existing models are both too expensive and too hard to use.

This is unashamedly a snapshot camera, and it has the minimum number of controls. The main decision you have to take is whether to push the button to set the so-called High Quality mode - 640 by 480 pixels, the same as a VGA screen, in 24-bit colour - or use Standard Quality.

HQ lets you take 16 pictures before the memory is full, while SQ lets you take 32 before you have to download the results to a PC.

Sorry, no removable storage so you can keep shooting. Sorry, no colour screen on the back so you can see what you have taken. Sorry, no zoom lens. The CL18 does have a small monochrome LCD screen for numeric read-outs, but just about the only extras are the 10 second self-timer and the built-in multi-mode flash.

But, the CL18 does have more potential than this suggests. It comes with a video cable so you can display your pictures on a TV screen, either PAL or NTSC. It also comes with a fast USB cable and a tiny tripod, so that you can use it for video conferencing, for capturing video images, and as a webcam. All these features rely on connecting the CL18 to a PC running Microsoft Windows 98.

While there are cheaper webcams for video-conferencing with Microsoft NetMeeting, the CL18's advantage is that it works as a snapshot camera as well. And while its 0.3 megapixel resolution may look weedy compared to the 3.3 megapixel beasts now taking over the camera market, it's certainly good enough for most web page uses.

The CL18 also comes with a selection of software on CD-rom, including Corel Photo House 5 image-editing software and Corel Print Office 2000.

Bare facts: The Agfa ePhoto CL18 measures 95 x 65 x 35mm and weighs 120g (4.2oz) without its two AA batteries. It has 2MB of non-removable Flash memory that can hold from 16 to 32 colour pictures, depending on resolution.

The fixed focus f/2 lens is the equivalent of a 45mm lens and provides sharp pictures from 50cm (20in) to infinity.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Provocateur
I take my hat off to David East (Feedback May 25). Having often wondered which controversial phrase would guarantee the most responses to a Guardian letters page, I had pondered over "Man U are actually quite a good team", "Wasn't life better under Mrs Thatcher", and "thin people are obviously more intelligent than fat people". However, "Microsoft products always work first time" is simply the best.

I will now stand aside so you can fill the rest of the page with the endless responses from disgruntled PC users and smug Mac-heads.
Derek Chelley
derek.chelly@prudential.co.uk

No win
David East has obviously had better experiences with Windows than I have. Last year, as a 40-something computer novice, I decided to get a PC and learn how to use it. It wasn't long before I was feeling an increasingly strong urge to throw my computer through the nearest window every time it froze up.

At this point I bought a book on Linux which came with a free copy of Red Hat 6.0. Installation involved some mental effort (I had to read part of the book) but wasn't beyond my limited abilities.

I haven't used Windows since. In six months my system hasn't frozen or crashed once, and I've been able to configure it in exactly the way I wanted (not possible with Windows 95). Linux is cheap, reliable, versatile and leaves my glazing intact.
John Rigg
:john@soundman.demon.co.uk

David East should play the National Lottery. With luck like his, he should win the jackpot every week!

Meanwhile, the rest of us suffer regular software crashes caused by the myriads of bugs and subtle incompatibilities within Windows. Eventually, we see the infamous "blue screen of death" of Windows NT one time too many, and our patience snaps.

Then we replace Windows with Linux, and enjoy a stable, reliable and stress-free computing environment, just like the fortunate Mr East.
Dr David Harper
adh@sanger.ac.uk

What's this obsession with Linux? Well, Mr East, having read your letter you are obviously the luckiest man on the planet - please buy my next lottery ticket for me.

My computer crashes constantly, usually in MS Word or Explorer - the wonderful blue screen saying: "Your system is busy, please wait. If you hit Ctrl, Alt, Delete again to restart - because I certainly will be 'busy' for the rest of the day - then you will lose all unsaved information".

Then there is the amount of disk space consumed by Mr Gates' products - 410 Mb, after a fresh reinstall (which took an entire day to do - internet connections, applications, network etc to sort out) due to my machine slowing down to the speed of a snail on dope. Computers are a tool, but they certainly should not be a chore.

The reason Mr Gates is so wealthy is that up until now he has stifled the "innovation" he goes on about by buying up every competitor he can. I was told the other day that only creative people use Macintoshes. I think I shall get a Mac next time, as then I will obviously become one of a rare breed.
Charles Henderson
ce.henderson@virgin.net

Why Linux? My estimated average reboot statistics:
Windows 3.1 - 4 per day
Windows 95 - 3 per day
Windows 98 - 6 per day
Windows NT4 - 2 per week
Linux 2.2.12 - 1 per 3 months (due to power failure).
Lionel Barnett
lionelb@cogs.susx.ac.uk

Take the blame
Tony Fogarty's contribution (Online, May25) to what appears to be the growing issue of the misapplied miracle of IT adds to one's sense of despair.

All this obvious intelligence both human and machine yet so often, so little common-sense. What on earth is wrong with we humans that we regularly promote to power those who are quite unable to implement potentially beneficial systems? The example he quotes is one of a number of high profile messes that were "sold" in every sense of the word. What are rarely seen are the numberless occasions this example is replicated in smaller, more private situations.

The UK needs a structure whereby those who stand to benefit directly from IT change, be they personal or corporate, must be prepared to bear some significant financial responsibility for a bad outcome. God knows they certainly bear the profits.

The last two words of Dr Fogarty's letter were "critical analysis" and they should be carved on the arses of all who sit on the decision committees for such schemes.
David Price
dp003@watford.net

Not wanted
I find myself in a similar position to John Thorpe and his struggle to find work during this supposed IT skills crisis. Having graduated three years ago with a computer science degree I now find my skills dismissed by the industry that demanded them not so long ago, and without an IT job in six months. I have cancelled my subscriptions to industry publications after continually reading about the difficulties of finding enough skilled workers in today's IT marketplace, the effect of IR35 legislation on the skills shortage and how the government plans to relax work permit regulations. Perhaps employers should be looking for longer-term solutions to their staffing needs rather than the "six months here then I'm off" candidates encouraged by recruitment consultants.
Steve May
steve_d_may@hotmail.com

Sit properly
Your article on IT for oldies (May 25) shows a venerable user sitting at a computer looking slightly upwards at the screen in an attitude which can quickly induce pains in the neck and back.

I am typing this while sitting in an easy chair with the keyboard on my lap, and the mouse mat on the arm of the chair. This is no more fatiguing than watching the telly.

The secret is to get a keyboard extension cable and then,with suitably placed equipment, you can even compute with your feet up!
Peter Barker
peterbarker@bcs.org.uk

webTitle: No asylum hearing for Elian, court says

fields.headline: No asylum hearing for Elian, court says
fields.trailText: An Atlanta court today ruled that the shipwrecked Cuban boy Elian Gonzalez was not entitled to an asylum hearing. The decision is a victory for the boy's father and means that he is likely to return to Cuba.
fields.body:
An Atlanta court today ruled that the shipwrecked Cuban boy Elian Gonzalez was not entitled to an asylum hearing. The decision is a victory for the boy's father and means that he is likely to return to Cuba.

A three-judge panel of the US court of appeal said the immigration and naturalisation service's decision that only a parent can act for his six-year-old child in immigration matters "comes within the range of reasonable choices". It said that held true even if the parent was in another country and the child was in the United States.

His Miami relatives may appeal the decision and try to take the issue to the supreme court. An Atlanta court injunction is still in force which bars Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, from taking the child home to Cuba. However, it was unclear whether that would prevent him from taking Elian home following today's ruling.

A crowd had gathered to wait for the verdict in Little Havana, Florida, where Elian's US relatives had looked after him for five months before his seizure by armed federal agents in April. Police spokesman Lieutenant Bill Schwartz said he did not expect the demonstration to become violent.

The judges were asked to decide whether a child as young as Elian could seek an asylum hearing from the immigration and naturalization service. Elian's Miami relatives sought the hearing in a bid to keep him in the country, but his father wanted to return to Cuba with Elian.

The six-year-old has been living with his father in Maryland and Washington DC, and was barred by the appeals court from leaving the country until the decision. Elian was rescued by two fishermen off the Florida coast in November. He was found clinging to an inner tube after his mother and ten others drowned when their boat sank on the way to the United States from Cuba.

The Clinton administration has sided with the child's father and the Cuban government on the issue, despite protests from the Cuban-American community in the US. Cuban leader Fidel Castro held dozens of rallies demanding Elian's return.

webTitle: Olonga fears mystery ankle injury has ended tour

fields.headline: Olonga fears mystery ankle injury has ended tour
fields.trailText: Henry Olonga, the star of Zimbabwe's World Cup campaign last summer, could miss the triangular one-day series against England and West Indies because of a worrying and persistent ankle injury.
fields.body:
Henry Olonga, the star of Zimbabwe's World Cup campaign last summer, could miss the triangular one-day series against England and West Indies because of a worrying and persistent ankle injury.

As Zimbabwe prepared to go into the second Test starting here today without their most hostile fast bowler, the likelihood was growing that Olonga might return home without playing a single international.

That would be a bad blow to a side who are desperate to save face after the comprehensive defeat in the Lord's Test, and who regard the Vodafone Challenge Series as their big chance.

Olonga's ankle injury was initially regarded as so trivial that Zimbabwe were disappointed when he ruled himself out of the first test.

But the bowler himself remains unsettled by the inability to diagnose the source of the pain, which he believes might owe something to a modification in his action that was introduced by Zimbabwe's currently absent bowling coach, Carl Rackemann.

Meanwhile Sky is extending its interactive service from Premiership football into cricket in today's digital coverage from Trent Bridge. Viewers can opt for a variety of camera angles, highlights replays on demand and a scoreboard updated ball by ball.

fields.headline: Hussain hungry for rare hat-trick
fields.standfirst: But England's captain expects a sterner test, writes  Mike Selvey
fields.trailText: But England's captain expects a sterner test, writes Mike Selvey.
fields.body:
Sometimes victory dampens expectation rather than boosts it. Any hopes the England and Wales Cricket Board may have harboured that England's annihilation of Zimbabwe at Lord's would enourage the citizens of Nottingham to pack out Trent Bridge, this smallest of English test grounds, for today's second test have been rudely dashed by the news that only 16,000 tickets have been sold.

The sluggish advance sales may be a reflection on the weather forecast - vile for the first two days and not too shabby thereafter - but are more likely a comment on the abject surrender of the visitors in the first Test.

To the majority this match merely completes the hors d'oeuvre before the main course, which swaggered into London from the Caribbean yesterday on the back of a fantastic win in Antigua.

West Indies cricket has been resurrected this past few months and under Jimmy Adams they will provide a substantially sterner test than Zimbabwe. The England captain Nasser Hussain recognises the dangers in getting too blasé about the Lord's demolition and its relationship to England's prospects of finally nailing West Indies.

"Don't make too much of it," he warned. "They are here just off a win, are fully behind their captain, have four good quick bowlers, some batters coming into form, including some good young players, and one oldish left-hander coming in as well. It will be a tough battle for us."

Indeed it will and the preparation, which began at Lord's, continues in this match where England will be looking to win their third successive test. The notion was presented to Hussain that, for purposes of pre-Windies practice, he would hope the opposition to be more competitive this time round.

"I don't hope," he retorted sharply, "I expect it of them. They will be hurt after Lord's but they are a good side with some top players and they will come back at us. They feel they let themselves down at Lord's but this is their last Test for a while and they want to round things off in good spirits. We expect it but it's how we react to it which is important.

"There are no easy games in Test cricket, especially for us. So we have to get as much confidence and team spirit as we can from this game, with batsmen spending time in the middle and with each other so that we have something special to carry forward to the rest of the summer."

As at Lord's, Hussain will wait until this morning before finalising his side. On that occasion he opted for Chris Schofield's wrist spin rather than the pace of Steve Harmison. Schofield, of course, did not turn his arm over as Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Ed Giddins cleaned up.

Hussain likes balance but at Lord's his indecision with the toss (he apparently did not make up his mind until the coin was in the air) indicates that he may have misread the pitch, underestimating the dampness of the sub-surface.

This pitch, he reckons, is not dissimilar in terms of grass cover (even) and moisture (dry on top but sodden underneath, if the spongy outfield is anything to go by). So, with rain about, it could be expected to play similarly, even to the extent of swinging, an influence of the new stand at the Radcliffe Road end.

Knowing Hussain's inclinations the chances are that England will name that rare species, an unchanged side. However, if the seamers are going to dominate once more, the presence of Schofield would be irrelevant.

West Indies in their heyday never worried about the lack of a spinner and, while shying away from the notion of experiment - Hussain recognises that his side do not have the clout to try that sort of thing - it would be better to give Harmison a debut and the chance to experience test cricket before West Indies, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Australia front up to England.

Zimbabwe's injury worries were eased partially yesterday, with Pommie Mbangwa and Bryan Strang declared fit, although Henry Olonga was still hobbling.

They have made changes to the top of their order, however. Guy Whittall is set to open with Grant Flower and Trevor Gripper has been dropped for Stuart Carlisle. Alistair Campbell, who has played 28 innings in the last two years with a top score of 36 and an average of 13.2, retains his place.

fields.headline: Fleming phlegm halts slide
fields.standfirst: Kent 171-8 v Durham
fields.trailText: Kent 171-8 v Durham
fields.body:
It seems almost sacrilege to suggest that this is not quite Nevill Gate at its regal best. The rhododendrons, by their own clichéd standards, are in rather reluctant bloom, as if sulking at the excessive whims of the season. Some are hiding behind the more prosaic hospitality tents. Where is that pastoral mauve perennial backcloth which symbolises, like few other sights in the domestic game, the timeless serenity of county cricket?

Yet maybe we were lucky to have a match at all. The ground was under water on Sunday and the car park remained out of use yesterday, so that the surrounding streets of this leafy suburban haven were apt to look more like an interminable car sales room.

As for the cricket, it hardly evoked the rich texture of festival time at Tunbridge Wells - on this undeniably lovely, secluded ground where Siegfried Sassoon once, in his Bluemantles CC days, came as a boy to play badly, watch avidly and later to turn his lasting images into poetic lines.

Yesterday the batting was uniformly slow, as predictable as the old hand-wound pavilion clock which tick-tocked all day within the lofty press box. But there were some excuses: the pitch was sluggish, occasionally difficult and did not encourage stroke-making. Unrelieved graft was needed and was dispensed, without a semblance of flurry or risk, in true captain's mode by Matthew Fleming.

He had won the toss and chose to bat. There were various theories about why he did; perhaps he felt conditions would deteriorate as the match progressed. More likely he desperately wanted his unemployed batsmen - they went into the fixture with no batting points and very few overs of match practice - to get sight of the ball again.

This was not what he hoped for. David Fulton went first to a miscalculated pull straight to square-leg. Then Robert Key was bowled by John Wood, before Ed Smith and Alan Wells both fell with the score at 41.

Smith, brought back in place of Rahul Dravid who was away on Asia Cup duty, could not disguise his anguish as he was out lbw without playing a stroke. The experienced Wells chose unwisely to cut, giving a catch at the wicket.

Wood, looking increasingly like a lock forward as he pounded down the hill, took a third wicket to end Matthew Walker's residence. Mark Ealham had at least reached 83 in his only previous championship innings; now Kent's current frustrations were compounded as Paul Nixon's straight drive was diverted on to the stumps with Ealham out of his ground.

Kent finished on 171 for eight, Min Patel edging a catch off the final ball of the day. Fleming was still there, however, doggedly defiant on 37 after 3 hours. Without his four main strike bowlers, all injured, his cussed concentration could be of even more significance as the game goes on.

The large crowd remained loyally supportive. They saw few signs of exciting cricket, certainly not in the style of the feisty suffragettes who years ago went as far as burning down the old pavilion. On a day of caution Durham's bowlers deserved some praise for their persistent challenge on an unrewarding strip.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Too much too soon is often seen as bad thing. The 23-year-old Gloucestershire batsman Chris Taylor is not convinced. On Monday he was a member of the side that reached the Benson & Hedges Cup final. Yesterday he became the first man to hit a century at Lord's on his championship debut, 104 against Middlesex .
fields.body:
Too much too soon is often seen as bad thing. The 23-year-old Gloucestershire batsman Chris Taylor is not convinced. On Monday he was a member of the side that reached the Benson & Hedges Cup final. Yesterday he became the first man to hit a century at Lord's on his championship debut, 104 against Middlesex .

"I was looking for it once I got into the 60s," he said afterwards. "I got nervous in the 70s but I wasn't too bad in the 90s. I didn't realise how intense championship cricket is. Bowlers like Angus Fraser are always at you but it was very enjoyable."

Taylor's century not only secured him a remarkable position in the record books but helped Gloucestershire recover from 29 for four when he arrived at the crease to an eventual 259. The next task for the man who went to the same school as Chris Broad, and who was a prolific runscorer at schoolboy level, is to convince the selectors to pick him for the one-day final against Glamorgan on Saturday week.

"I imagine I will be watching," he said pessimistically. "Ian Harvey will be fit and Rob Cunliffe has returned from a shoulder operation. Lord's is not a bad place to watch, though."

In the match between the top two First Division sides, Leicestershire's Darren Maddy made 63 from 98 balls to give the leaders a good start against Yorkshire at Headingley. They subsequently fell away until Phil DeFreitas hit his third half-century of the season to ensure parity.

"296 is a reasonable score," said the Leicestershire manager Jack Birkenshaw. "We played a few ordinary shots but there's a bit in it for the bowlers and the odd one is keeping low. Hopefully the pitch will get worse."

Peter Martin's five for 44 lifted Lancashire's spirits after their Benson & Hedges Cup disappointment as Derbyshire crashed for 170 at Old Trafford. He was helped by some charitable batting; Mathew Dowman and Michael Di Venuto were dismissed without playing a shot as the ball swung in.

The Essex paceman Ricky Anderson produced career-best figures of six for 34 in the Second Division match at Ilford as Northamptonshire, 85 for two before lunch, lost their last eight wickets for 29 and were all out for 114.

"It wasn't anything special," Anderson said later. "It just swung a lot today and they nicked it." Before yesterday 73 overs in the championship had brought him only three wickets. Darren Cousins took three in reply but Essex, on 147 for three, are heading for a significant lead.

The bottom side Sussex had an encouraging day against Glamorgan at Hove. Only Adrian Dale, 75, and Mike Powell, 46, prospered as Jason Lewry took four for 40.

 Lancashire have confirmed that Muthiah Muralitharan will be their first choice as overseas player next season. "We have a contract with Murali for next season and we're confident that he will be with us unless Sri Lanka's programme changes drastically," the club secretary Dave Edmundson said yesterday.

fields.headline: Adams steals the Macca show
fields.standfirst:
England 2 - 0 Ukraine
Fowler 44, Adams 67
Minute-by-minute match report
Richard Williams' analysis
Real McManaman fails to show
David Lacey on the final 22
fields.trailText: Corners from David Beckham, opportunist goals from Robbie Fowler and Tony Adams and a series of excellent saves from Nigel Martyn gave England some encouragement against Ukraine last night as they sought a win in their last serious test before Euro 2000, and the performance to go with it.
fields.body:
Corners from David Beckham, opportunist goals from Robbie Fowler and Tony Adams and a series of excellent saves from Nigel Martyn gave England some encouragement against Ukraine last night as they sought a win in their last serious test before Euro 2000, and the performance to go with it.

Fowler gave England the lead shortly before half-time after Alan Shearer had seen a header blocked, and Adams increased it midway through the second half after the Ukraine goalkeeper had punched another corner from Beckham on to Shearer's chest, the ball falling nicely for the Arsenal captain to drive it into the net.

Not for a long time has an England game focused so much on an individual player. This one was as much about Steve McManaman as a friendly against Czechoslovakia shortly before the 1990 World Cup had been about Paul Gascoigne. On that occasion the midfielder passed muster with distinction.

Here Kevin Keegan fielded a side designed to give McManaman maximum opportunity to thrive in a floating role behind the strikers. As expected, the England coach switched to a back three with four in midfield.

Steve Gerrard, winning his first cap, provided the main tackling strength and England looked to Paul Scholes to give their movements the precision needed to bring out the best in the roaming McManaman.

In fact it was Scholes who more immediately caught the eye. Twice in the opening eight minutes passes from Fowler on the right found the Manchester United player catching the Ukrainian defence with typical late runs.

The speed of Viacheslav Kernozenko off his line denied Scholes a shot the first time but when the second chance came the goalkeeper was beaten by a well-struck low drive which rebounded from the left-hand post. From an attacking point of view, then, England began encouragingly but defensively they looked suspect against the pace of Sergei Kandaurov.

As Andrei Shevchenko and Sergei Rebrov took Gareth Southgate and Sol Campbell wide, Kandaurov darted in to challenge for anything going in the goalmouth.

With Ukraine setting both the pace and the pattern, Keegan's players found it difficult to impose themselves on the game. Certainly McManaman saw a lot of the ball and ran willingly at the opposition, but his options were reduced by the lack of movement around him and the paucity of service from the wings. This was hardly surprising given that Beckham was being forced back into his own half while Neville, when he did break clear, almost inevitably had to drag the ball on to his right foot.

In the 37th minute Beckham, reacting quickly as the ball came of Yurin Dmitrulin's chest on the right, gathered possession and raced to the byline before centring waist-high. Fowler was well placed to score but was unable to make proper contact and the chance was gone.

When the next opportunity came, however, Fowler accepted it. Two minutes before half-time Shearer's persistence forced a corner on the right, taken by Beckham. Shearer met it with a firm downward header which Kernozenko blocked but could not hold. Fowler drove the rebound into the net and must have felt he had assured himself of a place in Euro 2000.

In the second half it was the turn of Emile Heskey, whose selection for the final 22 was less in doubt but who needed more time to hone up the partnership with Shearer.

Before Heskey had time to settle down, however, Shevchenko had drawn the first save of the evening from Martyn, a sharp shot on the turn which England's goalkeeper cut out at the near post.

Six minutes later Shevchenko met Oleg Luzhny's cross the right with a downward header which Martyn kept out, this time diving to tip it away with his left hand. When Shevchenko tried again, with a deflected free kick, the goalkeeper deflected the ball over the bar.

Going forward England lacked nothing in enthusiasm and after Scholes and Beckham had set him up, Gerrard strode into the area to test Kernozenko with a low shot. Shortly after this Heskey fell on Popov from a great height, suggesting that if all else fails in Euro 2000 Keegan can try the sack-of-spuds approach.

England (3-5-2): Martyn; Adams, Southgate, Campbell; Beckham, Gerrard (Dyer ,82min), Scholes (Barmby, 74), P Neville (Barry, 74); McManaman; Shearer, Fowler (Heskey, h-t).

Ukraine (4-4-2): Kernozenko (Levytsky, 85); Luzhny, Holovko, Vaschuk, Dmitrulin; Popov (Vorebey, 71), Tymoschuk, Husin; Kandaurov; Shevchenko, Rebrov.

Referee: L Michel (Slovakia).

webTitle: England achieve balance - problems both sides

fields.headline: England achieve balance - problems both sides
fields.standfirst:
The spirit of the Bernabeu left Keegan's busy side confused at times, writes Richard Williams
Minute-by-minute match report
Adams steals the Macca show
Real McManaman fails to show
David Lacey on the final 22
fields.trailText: The spirit of the Bernabeu left Keegan's busy side confused at times, writes Richard Williams.
fields.body:
England tried hard to do the right thing by Steve McManaman last night. In other words, they did their best to play the kind of fluid, modern football that McManaman has mastered over a triumphant season at Real Madrid.

It was asking a lot and there were times when the Ukrainians became the latest opponents to prove that possession is not the natural game of the English. In the first half, as the men in yellow shirts and blue shorts passed the ball at will, it really was just like watching Brazil, who had inflicted the same kind of torture four days earlier.

In England's terms, nevertheless, the contrast with last Saturday could hardly have been more profound. Kevin Keegan's five midfielders constantly switched positions, trying to confuse the Ukrainians into leaving gaps.

England took a while to get into some sort of order, perhaps because their tuition had not been entirely clear. McManaman was dead right on Tuesday when he disputed Kevin Keegan's use of the term "free role" to describe his function. McManaman's play with Real Madrid in recent weeks has been marked not by free-spiritedness but by an impressive sense of discipline.

The former Liverpool man certainly tried to imbue England's play with the essence of the Bernabeu. He combined with David Beckham on the right and Phil Neville on the left, and two or three times broke into the penalty area ahead of the strikers, a dimension so lacking in England's play against Brazil.

Typical was McManaman's willingness to track back almost to the corner flag to dispossess Andrei Shevchenko after the Ukrainian striker had robbed Gareth Southgate. That made a full house of England defenders Shevchenko had embarrassed. In the third minute he left Tony Adams for dead outside the England penalty area and fed his old pal Sergei Rebrov. A minute later he diddled Sol Campbell. But it was to the defence's credit that neither Shevchenko nor Rebrov could make the final penetration.

Well as McManaman played, it was Steven Gerrard who took the eye in midfield. The 20-year-old was outstanding, from his designated role in front of the back three to his overlapping incursion down the right in the first half, when he met Southgate's long ball and cleverly fed it back to Beckham. Eventually Gerrard even worked out how to cover for Beckham when the No7 wandered into central areas. Keegan may be tempted to think of Paul Ince, last Saturday's success story, as Gerrard's understudy, rather than vice versa.

England's goals came from Beckham's corner-kicks, compounded by goalkeeping errors, although by the end they had made plenty of chances from open play. In defence, however, questions remain to be answered. Early on, as Shevchenko and Rebrov sliced England's rearguard open, it was tempting to conclude that playing with three at the back and five in midfield makes England look a much better balanced side - in the sense that it gives them a brand-new problem on the right to go with the well known problem on the left.

A win is a win, particularly against a side of genuine class, but it would be rash to assume that, when it really matters, Keegan will prefer the system that beat Ukraine to the one that drew with Brazil.

 The Portugal goalkeeper Vitor Baia, still not recovered from a long-term knee injury, did not train ahead of tomorrow's friendly against Wales and is doubtful for their opening Euro 2000 match with England on June 12.

In the first half, as the men in yellow shirts and blue shorts passed the ball at will, it really was just like watching Brazil, who had inflicted the same kind of torture four days earlier. In England's terms, nevertheless, the contrast with last Saturday could hardly have been more profound. Kevin Keegan's five midfielders constantly switched positions, trying to confuse the Ukrainians into leaving gaps. England took a while to get into some sort of order, perhaps because their tuition had not been entirely clear. McManaman was dead right on Tuesday when he disputed Kevin Keegan's use of the term "free role" to describe his function. McManaman's play with Real Madrid in recent weeks has been marked not by free-spiritedness but by an impressive sense of discipline. The former Liverpool man certainly tried to imbue England's play with the essence of the Bernabeu. He combined with David Beckham on the right and Phil Neville on the left, and two or three times broke into the penalty area ahead of the strikers, a dimension so lacking in England's play against Brazil. Typical was McManaman's willingness to track back almost to the corner flag to dispossess Andrei Shevchenko after the Ukrainian striker had robbed Gareth Southgate. That made a full house of England defenders Shevchenko had embarrassed. In the third minute he left Tony Adams for dead outside the England penalty area and fed his old pal Sergei Rebrov. A minute later he diddled Sol Campbell. But it was to the defence's credit that neither Shevchenko nor Rebrov could make the final penetration. Well as McManaman played, it was Steven Gerrard who took the eye in midfield. The 20-year-old was outstanding, from his designated role in front of the back three to his overlapping incursion down the right in the first half, when he met Southgate's long ball and cleverly fed it back to Beckham. Eventually Gerrard even worked out how to cover for Beckham when the No7 wandered into central areas. Keegan may be tempted to think of Paul Ince, last Saturday's success story, as Gerrard's understudy, rather than vice versa. England's goals came from Beckham's corner-kicks, compounded by goalkeeping errors, although by the end they had made plenty of chances from open play. In defence, however, questions remain to be answered. Early on, as Shevchenko and Rebrov sliced England's rearguard open, it was tempting to conclude that playing with three at the back and five in midfield makes England look a much better balanced side - in the sense that it gives them a brand-new problem on the right to go with the well known problem on the left. A win is a win, particularly against a side of genuine class, but it would be rash to assume that, when it really matters, Keegan will prefer the system that beat Ukraine to the one that drew with Brazil.  The Portugal goalkeeper Vitor Baia, still not recovered from a long-term knee injury, did not train ahead of tomorrow's friendly against Wales and is doubtful for their opening Euro 2000 match with England on June 12.

fields.trailText: David Lacey takes a hard look at Kevin Keegan's final 22 after Kieron Dyer, Rio Ferdinand, David James and Andy Cole miss out.
fields.body:
Andy Cole will miss the European Championship but not for the anticipated reason. Cole missed the cut when Kevin Keegan announced his squad of 22 for Euro 2000 last night but the England coach insisted that the Manchester United player, and his old striker at Newcastle, would have gone had he been fit.

Only on Monday Cole appeared to have recovered fully from the foot injury which had prevented him from training for 3 weeks and kept him out of match action for six, although he has trained with England. If he was not going to go it was assumed that it would be because Keegan did not want him.

Last night, however, the England coach repeatedly stressed that Cole's lack of fitness had been the only consideration. "It would have been too much of a risk taking him to Euro 2000," Keegan said. "Had he been fit I would have taken him.

"Andy wanted to go but I know I've made the right decision and so does he. He was very honest and accepted that it was the right decision. He's not fit for Euro 2000. It's come too soon for him."

The main beneficiary of Cole's absence is Kevin Phillips, who would almost certainly have been left behind had the Manchester United man been fit. Keegan made a point of keeping the door ajar for Cole for the 2002 World Cup qualifiers, given Alan Shearer's retirement from international football after the European Championship. But at 28 Cole's time to make a mark at international level is fast running out.

There are no real surprises in Keegan's squad. David James, Rio Ferdinand and Kieron Dyer were always likely to be left behind, along with the injured Jamie Redknapp and Ray Parlour, although Gareth Barry and Nick Barmby could hardly have envisaged themselves being in it a month ago. Certainly Barmby provided a timely reminder of his England pedigree last night when he came off the bench against Ukraine and immediately began to find openings.

Keegan is confident that he has chosen a well balanced squad with a fine blend of youth and experience. "I want to win Euro 2000," he said, "but what we want and what we'll end up getting may be two different things."

If England are to be successful Keegan's team will need to acquire the technique of Gypsy Rose Lee, a lady who mastered the art of displaying her assets while preserving her modesty. As the squad has confirmed, the old country's football team will go to Euro 2000 with a bold front but lacking certain bare essentials.

At least the England coach has more attacking options than most of his rivals while the middle of his defence will wear a battle-hardened, weatherbeaten look. In midfield, where England's problems in major competitions so often lie, there is a healthy mix of youth and knowledge, and on the right wing David Beckham will have few peers.

The spine of the team will, initially at least, be much as it was under Glenn Hoddle in the 1998 World Cup. With David Seaman in goal, Tony Adams at centre-back, Paul Ince mounting guard in midfield and Alan Shearer bustling and barging up front England will not want for tournament experience. And last night Nigel Martyn and Steven Gerrard proved themslves admirable alternatives while Robbie Fowler's goal against Ukraine confirmed the match sharpness Keegan had been seeking from the Liverpool striker.

The form of the 20-year-old Michael Owen is crucial and much in the European Championship will depend on the quality of service that he and Shearer receive. Keegan knows he can depend on a regular delivery of high-class centres, free-kicks and corners from Beckham on the right.

Yet there is no specialist left-winger in the squad and the England coach will be heavily reliant on Paul Scholes, who played well against Ukraine, providing a strong attacking presence through the middle. He also has reason to be worried about the poverty of the passing from the back.

The main weaknesses of this squad compared to 1998 are that there is no Graeme Le Saux to give England natural width on the left, no Teddy Sheringham to link up the play and no Darren Anderton to add penetration on the right while posing an equal threat through the middle. Additionally, England's weakness in the full-back positions will never be completely overcome simply by shifting players around.

Never has the need to pass the ball accurately and imaginatively been more apparent. The pass master in this squad is Chelsea's Dennis Wise. Could he be the keystone that holds England's performances in Euro 2000 together?

Certainly, if England start giving the ball away, they can find themselves running around with the blind panic of the Keystone Cops, and Graham Taylor gave us enough slapstick in the 1992 European Championship to last a lifetime.
